Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Marketing-Jul-28-2020-01-17-22-69-PM.png?width=1500&name=Email%20Marketing-Jul-28-2020-01-17-22-69-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn69@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118307835_b6663272e08eafde.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png?width=600&name=Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn81@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118305667_72a3e6884fca95ab.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png?width=200&name=Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn65@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118305471_86996beffb75654f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-3.png?width=200&name=Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn1@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118306545_9a12cd83f83c4d2e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png?width=600&name=Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn33@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118305992_0cad5afda6728104.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-4.png?width=300&name=Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118307128_4f583357b1759f83.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-Jul-06-2020-12-35-58-52-AM.png?width=300&name=Why%20Consumers%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20from%20Email%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-Jul-06-2020-12-35-58-52-AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn93@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118306487_153c75469f88c5a7.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhy-consumers-subscribe-to-email&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn21@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118308246_85aaada189f98aee.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"The Plain-English Guide to Brand Equity","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-equity","description":"<p>Before I buy <em>anything </em>that goes on my face, like skincare or makeup, I pour over the reviews. The only exception is when I'm shopping from a brand I trust. In some cases, I don't even question a new launch from those businesses — I purchase the new items <em>knowing</em> I'll be satisfied.</p>  \n<p>It's not that hard to trust a company that has never disappointed you. But today, I was skeptical.</p> \n<p>A makeup company I like is releasing a skincare extension. I was on the fence, so I wanted to see what my favorite YouTubers were saying. Most of them had the same reaction: \"I don't care about the price. When it comes to this brand, I know it's gonna be great.\"</p> \n<p>They will purchase from the new line, regardless of reviews.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>This is known as brand equity. Consumers influence the public perception of businesses, building positive or negative brand equity. But let’s take a closer look.</p> \n<p>If you've ever decided against buying from a specific company based on a review from your friends, you've seen negative brand equity at work. Negative brand equity might result from poor customer service, lack of transparency, or inaccurate pricing.</p> \n<p>Think of that one product you don't mind shelling out a few extra dollars to have because you <em>know </em>you'll be satisfied. In your opinion, that business has positive brand equity. Brand equity determines value because positive brand equity can justify higher prices.</p> \n<p>Now that you know what brand equity is, you're probably thinking about how to find out your company's. To save you that time, let's talk about measuring brand equity.</p> \n<h2>How to Measure Brand Equity</h2> \n<p>Measuring brand equity involves customer knowledge, public perception, and finances. Customers are a no-brainer; Their opinion is the number one source of brand equity, but it shouldn't be the sole indicator. Let's look at a few others.</p> \n<h3>1. Focus on brand awareness.</h3> \n<p>We've gone over how important customers are to brand equity. It starts with awareness. If your audience doesn't know about your company, they won't be able to develop an opinion of it.</p> \n<p>So if you haven't already, take note of how you're handling brand awareness. How are you communicating your company's story? More importantly, how are they responding?</p> \n<p>Leverage consumer response to your brand as an action to create more brand awareness. Content offers, web traffic, and social media performance will give you the data you need to assess brand awareness.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you've found that you generate the most leads by making informative ebooks, create one about a topic that's your company's bread and butter. For a social media agency, that might be creating compelling Instagram stories.</p> \n<p>That way, when a lead sees the ad on Facebook, they'll have an idea of what your company does. The offer is an incentive for them to learn more, and the subject matter will keep them engaged.</p> \n<h3>2. Analyze your company's overall finances.</h3> \n<p>Are you currently analyzing purchase metrics? These metrics will tell you what products are popular among customers and identify shopping patterns that could influence future campaigns.</p> \n<p>Look at how your business interacts with audiences — this influences purchasing behavior. If a customer comments under an Instagram post about poor customer service, it can contribute to negative brand equity. To avoid this, make sure customer service protocol involves answering the consumer comments and concerns.</p> \n<p>If you notice sales are dipping after a few negative comments, revisit customer service protocol. It might be contributing to a lower brand equity and decrease in sales. But by studying how your business interacts with its audiences, you'll quickly identify ways to improve that messaging.</p> \n<p>Make sure you’re telling your audience why your price is worth it. Alternatively, give your audience a chance to see for themselves. In your next ad, announce a sale, boost an offer, or create a free trial.</p> \n<p>That way, your audience can give your company a test run before they commit, and you can begin to measure how this inbound marketing tactic performs among customers. If it increases brand equity, you might have a new winning strategy.</p> \n<h3>3. Identify the public perception of your brand.</h3> \n<p>So far, we've talked about why brand awareness is important to brand equity. But <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/corporate-image?_ga=2.167200702.1860695292.1595883551-940436819.1565181751\">corporate image</a> is also crucial.</p> \n<p>Ask customers to leave reviews. Product reviews are extremely powerful in cementing brand equity. A sushi restaurant with 4.5 stars on Yelp will most likely get more business than the one down the street with 3.9, even if the food is more affordable.</p> \n<p>Analyze what customers are already saying and if they'd recommend your company to a friend.</p> \n<p>At this point, you know how to measure public perception. But it's likely you've run into a problem … You have no idea <em>how</em> to build equity. Let's get the ball rolling with a few ideas.</p> \n<h3>1. Research public perception of your brand.</h3> \n<p>Customers aren't the only group that contributes to brand equity. Audiences are just as important.</p> \n<p>Approaching public perception is going to look slightly different than reaching your customers. The audience you're targeting doesn't know as much about your company as the ones purchasing from your company regularly, so NPS surveys probably won't do the trick.</p> \n<p>However, your market contributes to brand equity from an outward perspective. So, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-buyers-journey-guide\">researching</a> their opinion is going to be helpful in figuring out a few things.</p> \n<p>First, by understanding what your audience thinks of your business, you can learn why or why not people are buying your offerings. Second, you'll understand the challenges your audience is looking for companies like yours to solve. This will inform better business and marketing decisions.</p> \n<p>Public perception is essential to brand equity, but let's face it: We probably don't have the time to spend hours Googling our company to gain insight. So, what can you do to research public perception in a way that saves you time?</p> \n<p>The short answer is software. For instance, <a href=\"https://www.talkwalker.com/quick-search\">Smart Watch </a> looks at follower activity on social media channels. Then, you'll get a customized report that breaks down comments, replies, and likes to tell you a response consensus.</p> \n<p>Additionally, <a href=\"http://brandwatch.com\">Brandwatch</a> can point out where your branded images are appearing. For instance, if you upload a marketing photo into the tool, it'll crawl the web for that image and pull out results. This can help you identify the spaces where your company is the most prevalent — and what people are saying.</p> \n<p>If you're looking for a couple more resources, say, 10 more, this<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/sentiment-analysis-tools?_ga=2.142559154.1860695292.1595883551-940436819.1565181751\"> sentiment analysis tool round-up</a> is your answer.</p> \n<h3>2. Communicate your brand beliefs in marketing.</h3> \n<p>One of the biggest ways to begin building brand equity is to emphasize branding when you execute marketing campaigns. Every visual asset you make should speak to your brand in some way.</p> \n<p>Use <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-creation?_ga=2.142559154.1860695292.1595883551-940436819.1565181751\">colors, images, and copy</a> to your benefit, and introduce a tone that makes sense to your company and audience. If you can look across all customer-facing content and recognize patterns in those three areas, you're likely communicating a strong brand message.</p> \n<p>Customers and audiences will begin to pick up on the details that define your company. For instance, when you look at this Instagram feed, you can notice similar details, imagery, and tone:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Plain-English%20Guide%20to%20Brand%20Equity.png\" alt=\"An example of Instagram branding.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/hubspot/\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>In the image above, you can point to colors, industries, and audiences that relate to HubSpot's brand. Valuable content, like helpful statistics, make this account one to look for in terms of industry insights. As a result, a marketing professional is likely to associate this account with meaningful marketing-based content.</p> \n<p>To build a positive brand equity, speak to what's important to your company and audience.</p> \n<h3>3. Turn what customers say into action.</h3> \n<p>If you've been collecting customer stories and data, see how you can use that information to boost equity. For example, if customer reviews have been mentioning a new addition to your software, teasing its release could be a great way to earn positive reception. Customers that see they're being listened to contribute to excellent equity.</p> \n<p>It could also be a good idea to step up <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/interaction-with-customers?_ga=2.138849331.1860695292.1595883551-940436819.1565181751\">customer interaction</a>. If your company doesn't interact with customers on social channels or email, or reach out for feedback, you probably don't know what they are expecting. Revamp how you get in touch with customers because they hold the most value when it comes to equity.</p> \n<p>Maybe there's a feature upgrade you know customers are really interested in, but you don't have the bandwidth to build. In that case, focus on improving a customer favorite, or a much-anticipated restock of a bestselling product.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Plain-English%20Guide%20to%20Brand%20Equity-1.png\" alt=\"Example of providing what the customers want to see in marketing messages.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>This is a marketing email I got a while ago. Instead of restocking the eyeshadow collection with these shades, <a href=\"http://colourpop.com\">ColourPop</a> decided to split up the collections according to customer suggestions. This move was made to show customers that the company values their opinion — it also builds brand equity.</p> \n<h3>4. Emphasize how you're different from competitors.</h3> \n<p>Do you remember the \"Get a Mac\" campaign? If not, how about the commercials with two actors introducing themselves as either a Mac or a PC? These clips sparked the infamous 2006 debate about which computer choice was better:</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/jz1arPaSSqo\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>Apple released the commercials to emphasize why iMacs were the cool, modern, powerful choice for young adults. Commercials would show a hip, relatable actor talking about the different capabilities of the computer. Then, an older, out-of-touch actor would talk about why they love their limited PC.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/heres-why-apples-steve-jobs-didnt-want-those-mac-vs-pc-ads-to-be-too-funny-2019-05-26\">The commercials were wildly successful</a> and profitable for Apple. They also established brand equity against competitors. Apple's team took the time to name computer specs in a way their audience would understand. They spoke directly to the customer about why Macs were the favorable option.</p> \n<p>To gain that market edge, use campaigns to explicitly state why your product is the best suited for your customer. Maybe it's because you offer a more streamlined way of doing things, like in the Apple commercial.</p> \n<p>Remember not to attack your competition. The goal here is to build your brand without tearing another down. Tell your customers about the features others don't offer, and use that feature to define part of your brand.</p> \n<h3>5. Keep up a helpful presence on social media.</h3> \n<p>This sounds like a no-brainer, but it's so important to actively devote yourself to excellent customer service. I can't count how many times I follow a company on Instagram because of a product, then ultimately decide against buying it because of poor communication from the brand.</p> \n<p>I've seen comments about not receiving orders, trouble cancelling memberships, and misleading products. That's a red flag, but if a company handles these comments in a negative way, that's a deal-breaker. Not only that, but it reflects poorly on my opinion on the brand, as well as other audiences'.</p> \n<p>Whether you're talking to customers in person or online, make sure you're handling concerns with urgency and care. Others take note of how you treat customers and make their own opinions based on what they see.</p> \n<p>If you want a full-guide about how to ace social media customer service, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/social-media-customer-service?_ga=2.202147729.1860695292.1595883551-940436819.1565181751\">check out this post</a>.</p> \n<p>As a consumer, I'm still unsure about the skincare launch I mentioned earlier, but that doesn't mean I won't buy the new lip gloss that launched today. I know and trust this company with cosmetics.</p> \n<p>This company's brand equity doesn't hurt, either. If I need any more convincing, I can just look at the glowing reviews of other lip glosses on the website, on YouTube, and on Instagram. I'll also take note of how others rave about the quick shipment and product quality.</p> \n<p>Brand equity can be the make or break for your company, but after reading this post, you're ready to make it a positive one for your entire audience. Good luck, and happy branding.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbrand-equity&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Plain-English%20Guide%20to%20Brand%20Equity.png","linkMd5":"24817a71f0f9c1d924a85c18a81760cf","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn89@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118301898_d69a030ac4706721.webp","author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Plain-English%20Guide%20to%20Brand%20Equity.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn89@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118301898_d69a030ac4706721.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Plain-English%20Guide%20to%20Brand%20Equity-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn57@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118309386_cbd7dfb4eb296663.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbrand-equity&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn61@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118304931_c886cdf450ea4aab.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"8 Startup Marketing Ideas That Actually Work [+ Examples]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/startup-marketing","description":"<p>Are you new to the startup game, and even newer to the content marketing game?</p> \n<p>With all the work that goes into starting a business, there's little time to think about marketing strategies that prove successful <em>and</em> are feasible for a startup's teams to execute.</p> \n<p>If you find yourself in this boat, don't panic. You probably know the tools that are helpful for startup marketers to use when strategizing — a CMS, social media accounts, and graphic design software, for instance.</p> \n<p>Now, what you need to know is how to <em>use</em> these tools, and similar methods, to create campaigns that align with your business goals. You may have seen other startups' glowing marketing techniques and found yourself wondering how to create a winning strategy.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>For that, we've got you covered. To get a sense of how a marketing strategy can produce success for your startup, we're going to lay out some ideas. These ideas are from startups, and will help you visualize how a successful strategy can be helpful for your own marketing goals.</p> \n<p>Here, let's explore startup marketing ideas and strategies you can use to increase brand awareness, leads, and customers for your startup business.</p> \n<h2>Startup Marketing Ideas</h2> \n<p>Other than starting an email list, using online software, and taking high-quality images, what else can you do to market your startup? Below are some examples.</p> \n<p>If you're struggling to come up with new marketing ideas, maybe you can put a new spin on one that works for your campaign goals. Like some of the companies mentioned, you can use tools you already have at your disposal to execute a winning campaign.</p> \n<h3>1. Use paid ads to build a community.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"http://starburstdata.com\">Starburst Data</a> is a B2B that helps companies understand their website analytics. They use a search query engine that organizes data, so customers can interpret large amounts of data quickly. This startup uses ads on LinkedIn to connect with its audience, like this one promoting their software:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Startup%20marketing.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Starburst Data paid ads example\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/company/starburstdata/ads/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></span></p> \n<p>A content marketer for a company like Starburst has a good chance of finding its target audience on LinkedIn, since it's a platform for professional networking. Part of this marketing campaign involves using <a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/cx/17/06/advertise-on-linkedin?src=go-pa&amp;trk=sem_lms_gaw&amp;veh=Google_Search_NAMER_USCA_Brand-Head-Terms_Alpha_DR_AllLanguages_Restructure_378919961167__linkedin%20ads_c__kwd-12132901520_6458957165&amp;mcid=6612464045041733652&amp;cname=Google_Search_NAMER_USCA_Brand-Head-Terms_Alpha_DR_AllLanguages_Restructure&amp;camid=6458957165&amp;asid=77594803136&amp;targetid=kwd-12132901520&amp;crid=378919961167&amp;placement=&amp;dev=c&amp;ends=1&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMIxqq9tZDU6AIVApSzCh3MkAn3EAAYASAAEgJVWvD_BwE&amp;gclsrc=aw.ds\">LinkedIn Ads</a> to build community and provide helpful information.</p> \n<p>A similar B2B startup strategy could involve making use of a social media platform's paid ads offerings to cater to your audience. Alternatively, you can upload offers for free and use hashtags to get them seen by more prospective customers, like #B2BMarketing, or #MarTech.</p> \n<h3>2. Try social media to connect with customers.</h3> \n<p>Social media marketing doesn't have to include spending money — it can be used to grow your audience and connect with existing members. Take <a href=\"http://paperlessparts.com\">Paperless Parts</a>, for example, a manufacturing company with a stellar Facebook page:</p> \n<iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FpaperlessPARTS%2Fvideos%2F2012071495763706%2F&amp;width=500&amp;show_text=true&amp;height=390&amp;appId\" width=\"500\" height=\"390\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> \n<p>It's free to create a <a href=\"https://business.facebook.com/\">Facebook Business</a> page and optimize it so leads and customers can find it. The Paperless Parts feed begins with recommendations and reviews from happy customers, showing that the business has a dedicated customer userbase. After that, the business posts videos that go behind-the-scenes of the manufacturing process, and also post reminders for webinars and other website content.</p> \n<p>A social media page for a startup that showcases customers provides helpful content and encourages audience participation is a free strategy to expand reach, bring clicks to your website, and show credibility in the industry.</p> \n<h3>3. Crowdfunding marketing, which can generate press.</h3> \n<p>Are you thinking about starting a crowdfunding campaign? If you do, you could earn great press from publications, expanding your campaign's reach. Take <a href=\"http://neighborschools.com\">NeighborSchools</a>, for example, which is a child care startup. NeighborSchools offers unique daycares from licensed and experienced professionals.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Startup%20marketing-2.png\" alt=\"NeighborSchool's website page. \" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"http://neighborschools.com\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<p>When the minds behind NeighborSchools began to seek funding to scale up their service, they turned to crowdfunding to seek out people who believed in the service and were able to invest. This tactic earned the company <a href=\"https://resources.neighborschools.com/blog/seed-round-funding-announcement\">$3.5 million</a> in seed funding, and the success caught the eye of <a href=\"https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20191105005200/en/NeighborSchools-Raises-3.5-Million-Bring-Quality-Affordable\">major publications</a>.</p> \n<p>Even if you have just a few customers, you can use your crowdfunding campaign as a marketing tactic to get more people interested in your business.</p> \n<h3>4. Host a virtual meetup instead of a conference.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"http://mabl.com\">Mabl</a> is a Boston-based SaaS provider for machine learning test automation. It makes the lives of developers who have to test their solutions way easier. To build a larger community, Mabl hosted a virtual meetup with industry experts.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Startup%20marketing-1.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Mabl's interactive webinar invite. \">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://www.meetup.com/ministry-of-testing-boston/events/269353803/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></span></p> \n<p>The meetup's speakers educated its attendees about software testing. This idea is a cool, low-cost way to expand your professional network and provide valuable content for customers without hosting a conference.</p> \n<h3>5. Use user-generated content to tell your story.</h3> \n<p>Startups don't usually have the revenue to produce big-budget social media campaigns. For travel agency <a href=\"http://hopjump.com\">Hopjump</a>, their marketing team found that the best way to tell their story is on Instagram. The business page is filled with clients enjoying their destination vacations, booked using the service:</p> \n<div style=\"text-align: left;\">\n <iframe class=\"instagram-media instagram-media-rendered\" style=\"background: white; max-width: 540px; border-radius: 3px; border: 1px solid #dbdbdb; box-shadow: none; display: block; margin: 0px auto 12px; min-width: 326px; padding: 0px;\" src=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/B-cbVS6Km4l/embed/captioned/?cr=1&amp;v=12&amp;wp=971&amp;rd=https%3A%2F%2Fpreview.hs-sites.com&amp;rp=%2F%3FportalId%3D53%26_preview%3Dtrue%26cacheBust%3D1594144953868%26preview_key%3DPSeBKKEl%26inpageEditorUI%3Dtrue%26benderPackage%3DInpageEditorUI%26staticVersion%3Dstatic-1.22295%26scriptPath%3Dbundles%252Fapp.js%26cssPath%3Dbundles%252Fapp#%7B%22ci%22%3A1%2C%22os%22%3A15049.190000005183%2C%22ls%22%3A4600.720000002184%2C%22le%22%3A4602.624999999534%7D\" width=\"560\" height=\"1019\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>  \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Customers who post their amazing travel pictures on Instagram can tag Hopjump for a chance to be featured on the page, and this also increases exposure for the startup. Satisfied customers can share their experiences with more of Hopjump's target audience.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">A marketing campaign that includes user-generated content is an easy, free way to work in testimonials. You can use your social media channels to execute the campaign and include hashtags for the chance to appear in more feeds.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">When thinking about campaign ideas, you might not have to look that far. You might be able to turn some of the tools you already have at your disposal to boost your campaign messages. Is there a webinar you can host about a topic, or a content offer you think will resonate particularly well with your LinkedIn audience?</p> \n <h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">6. Create SEO-optimized content to attract high-intent visitors.</h3> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">SEO is another free, cost-effective strategy startup marketers can use to spread word about their business.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">But here's the caveat: of all the strategies mentioned, this one takes the longest.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">That's not to say it's incredibly time-consuming — it's not, but it <em>is</em> a continuous job. The more you optimize your website, the better it'll perform, which, in turn, will generate more leads for your company.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">We have to let you know that at this point, SEO won't net you leads or opportunities immediately, but it will lay the foundation for consistent success in the months and years to come.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">The idea behind <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-strategy\">SEO</a> is that you optimize your web pages (and content) for keyword terms you know prospects use to find products or services like yours.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Better yet, you identify <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/28912/the-ultimate-guide-for-mastering-long-tail-search.aspx\">long-tail keyword</a> terms with low to medium competition and high search volume that are relevant to your product or service, and use those instead.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">You main service pages will, of course, be competing with other businesses in your space on many similar terms, but you can use the content you create to link to these pages, bolstering their SEO value over time and increasing their ranking on SERP results pages.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Updating and optimizing your website will ensure it continues to grow and attract interested prospects for the long-term, so it's an opportunity you don't want to miss.</p> \n <h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">7. Implement a referral program.</h3> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Referral-based marketing has become the hype over the last few years as people increasingly look at product/service reviews, testimonials, and case studies to validate their purchase decisions.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">The aim behind this particular startup marketing idea is to leverage those who have already bought your product/service and ask them to advocate on your behalf — whether that's through a review, testimonial, or case study.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">This kind of content is invaluable because it shows and tells your potential customers that you have solved for others like them in the past. To increase the chances of your customers doing this for you, offer them discounts or free product trials.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Additionally, you might consider giving away free keys, trials, or versions of your product to specific people. For example, a good way to gain press coverage and build brand awareness is to let tech journalists try your offering for free. They can then write a review and distribute it to the relevant online publications and link back to your website.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Lastly, make sure that you feature these reviews prominently on your website. They help build trust and authenticity, both of which are key to making sales in today's digital-first world.</p> \n <h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">8. Offer a free or trial version of your product.</h3> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">One of the best ways to get your startup out there is to offer some kind of version of your product/service for free — and it's worked for a lot of businesses already.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Canva, Dropbox, Zapier, HubSpot — all of these high-profile tech companies offer some kind of free/trial version of their product or service to let people try before they buy (or upgrade). As people use them and realize just how great these products are, they feel compelled to buy the full, \"unlimited\" version for all the bells and whistles. Great, right?</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-07%20at%203.57.11%20PM.png?width=1506&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-07%20at%203.57.11%20PM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2020-07-07 at 3.57.11 PM\" width=\"1506\" style=\"width: 1506px;\"></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">But along with getting people to use your product — and inherently talking about how good it is as a result — it's all about lowering the customer's costs of acquisition. What a lot of businesses do with a freemium model is offer current trial users a discount on the full price of the software. This is significantly more appealing than paying the full price and can potentially convert more leads into paying customers very, very quickly.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Also, for those who <em>don't</em> convert to paying customers with this offer, it enables you to understand what features or parts of your service are lacking. You can ask for feedback, make the necessary changes, and then roll them out to see who bites on the full product offering.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">For maximum effect, cross-reference what you offer against the main issues your buyer personas have in relation to technology like yours. Consider adding features to your product/service to address these problems (where possible). Maybe produce a roadmap and show people what they'll be getting. Transparency is a great way to increase users!</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Lastly, bear in mind that this approach does come with the risk that people might not want to upgrade to the full version. That said, be as clear as you can with what users can get from the full version and highlight how valuable it can be for them. Keep your coolest features under wraps!</p> \n <h2 style=\"text-align: left;\">Startup Marketing Strategy</h2> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Next, let's explore various strategies (and some tips and tricks) that enable startup owners and their teams to successfully market their products and services without breaking the bank.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">These strategies are designed to lay the foundation for future success, ensuring ongoing interest even after paid campaigns finish.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Take a look at these five steps you might consider implementing to create a successful, well-rounded startup marketing strategy.</p> \n <h3 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>1. Use SMART goals to focus on business-critical goals upfront.</strong></h3> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">At <a href=\"https://www.hubledigital.com/\">Huble Digital</a>, we use SMART goals. These are goals that are <strong>S</strong>pecific, <strong>M</strong>easurable, <strong>A</strong>ttainable, <strong>R</strong>elevant, and <strong>T</strong>imely. For example, a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-a-smart-goal-template?_ga=2.7647930.945150594.1594052559-779953426.1586203908\">SMART goal</a> could be:</p> \n <ul style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n  <li>Increase organic traffic to our website by 50% by 2021</li> \n  <li>Create 10 new sales focused blogs by September 2020</li> \n </ul> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">The purpose of SMART goals is to set businesses up for success. They provide a sense of direction and help to organize efforts.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">And, while SMART goals are invaluable for any organization, they're particularly beneficial for start-ups.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">In most start-ups, employees have to wear several hats (often due to budget constraints or lack of resources). The founder, for instance, might be responsible for strategy, product development, and even PR, while the chief technology officer (CTO) might be involved in the design of the website, marketing, <i>and</i> social media. There's just so much to do!</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Of course, for all start-ups, the principal focus is product development (and always will be until the \"release\" stage) ... but what about all the other elements that help sustain the business' growth?</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">It's here where SMART goals can really help. Instead of trying to do everything at once, focus on the most business-critical goals, put everything you have behind them, and tackle things in a strategic way. For instance, rather than spreading your time across several initiatives (some of which may not be important right now), focus on three or four that will lay a foundation for your activities or support your current efforts.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">If you're launching with a new product, for instance, focus on the development but also set goals like:</p> \n <ul style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n  <li>Create 10 new blogs to build awareness of the product by X date</li> \n  <li>Publish 2 new web pages to promote the new product by X date</li> \n  <li>Secure 5 placements in online media using digital PR by X date</li> \n </ul> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">These are just some examples, but they can undoubtedly help raise the profile of your business without costing much — the only real expenditure is time. Instead of spreading your capabilities across several initiatives, try focusing on those that will support what you're doing right now.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">The key to sustained growth is consistency and focus, and SMART goals enable you to do just that.</p> \n <h3 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>2. Create detailed documents to distinguish who your target buyers are.</strong></h3> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">SMART goals give your marketing efforts direction and focus, sure, but who are you marketing to?</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">For your start-up's marketing efforts to bring in tangible results, those efforts need to be tailored to your ideal target audience.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Now you'll probably have a good understanding of who it is you want to do business with, but have you articulated that to the rest of your team or — at the very least — put together a document detailing who your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research?_ga=2.7647930.945150594.1594052559-779953426.1586203908\">buyer personas </a>are?</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">It's here where buyer personas come in handy. Buyer personas are semi-fictional representations of your ideal customers. They're based on market research, current data, existing customers, and a few educated assumptions. Buyer personas help you to understand the drivers, business challenges, and needs of those to whom you want to market.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">It's also important to note that buyer personas are not real people, but archetypes of them.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Now that we've briefly covered what buyer personas are, you might be wondering — Okay, but what makes them so valuable to my start-up? Simply put, buyer personas allow you to refine your marketing and segment your audience(s).</p> \n <blockquote> \n  <p style=\"text-align: center;\">You want and need quick wins during the product development and release stages, so why waste time (and money) casting the widest net possible when you can hone in on those most likely to buy from you?</p> \n </blockquote> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Your buyer personas will provide you with a good idea of who these people are. Use that information to build marketing and PR campaigns that focus on the right people, at the right time and place of their buyer's journey.</p> \n <h3 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>3. Have clear, compelling messaging.</strong></h3> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">If you've ever seen a <a href=\"https://www.ronseal.com/the-ronseal-phrase/\">Ronseal advertisement</a>, you're likely already familiar with the following phrase: \"It does what it says on the tin.\"</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">In an age of slick, big-budget marketing campaigns and buzzwords, it falls to you to keep your messages clear and concise.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">People don't want platitudes or jargon. They want to understand what it is your product does, and how it can help them solve their business challenges. In fact – and this may sound harsh – it's not even <i>about</i> your business, it's about how you can help your potential customers.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">With this in mind, any <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-creation?_ga=2.217798558.945150594.1594052559-779953426.1586203908\">content that your start-up creates</a> (and this applies to all businesses of any size) needs to be created with the end user in mind. It needs to be simple, informative, and compelling.</p> \n <h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">4. Create a content marketing strategy to generate leads.</h3> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Content marketing is all about producing high-quality content that answers questions your prospects and customers have, and nurturing them to a point of purchase.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">For instance, blogs are great for increasing your website's organic traffic and awareness of your brand. Each blog should be optimized for a long-tail keyword term, as this will help to drive targeted traffic (i.e. people definitely interested in what you have to say) to your website. It's a really easy way to increase your startup's digital footprint and start building its name.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">The content you create also helps to generate leads and demonstrate your expertise. You could, for instance, produce informative ebooks and gate them behind landing pages on your website. Visitors can then download your ebooks in exchange for their details.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">With this approach, you know that those that <em>do</em> download your ebooks are interested in hearing from you. The ebooks you create will be particularly useful for targeting \"early adopters\", i.e. those that want to be on the cutting-edge when it comes to new technology/software.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Over time, as more and more content is created, your website becomes a repository for information. Providing it's all optimized for the right terms, the right people will find it time and time again.</p> \n <h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">5. Implement a digital PR strategy to increase buzz around your brand.</h3> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Now if you want to get the most out of everything you do — particularly from a content creation perspective — why not amplify it with digital PR?</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Digital PR effectively takes everything good about traditional PR: press coverage, events, outreach, thought leadership content — and does the same for the online space. Suddenly, the assets you've created for your marketing activity can be retrofitted to suit PR purposes.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">In fact, digital PR goes one step further: the agency you work with will do their utmost to earn backlinks (editors and publications are notoriously difficult when it comes to keeping links in content) back to your website. Subsequently, those reading your content via online publications can actually <em>find</em> your business, and the content itself is already optimized for search because you've done it already.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">All-in-all, digital PR will help to increase your startup's visibility both online and offline, helping you to get featured in key trade media relating to what you do and cause a positive stir in your industry.</p> \n <h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">The Best Strategies Use a Combination of Ideas and Tactics</h3> \n <p>If you want to get the best possible results when it comes to marketing, you need to focus on what works.</p> \n <p>While there are loads of different ways to achieve your goals, you should always focus on the most high-impact and cost-effective, and as a startup owner — I'm willing to bet you already know how important that is.</p> \n <p>The best strategies use a combination of what we've mentioned above and then analyze the performance of them to determine which ones require more or less investment. No matter what you do, remember that your marketing activities are only as good as your goals and targeting. Good luck!</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\"></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\"></p> \n</div>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fstartup-marketing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 20 Jul 2020 19:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Startup%20marketing.png","linkMd5":"41c7bba50400b8168dc7706ac158cbf9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn81@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118301652_ef80f20acd9febb0.webp","author":"Bob Dearsley","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Startup%20marketing.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn81@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118301652_ef80f20acd9febb0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Startup%20marketing-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn1@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118313412_82542f09fa0d8e2d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Startup%20marketing-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn77@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118313284_6228f034a5aa26a9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-07%20at%203.57.11%20PM.png?width=1506&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-07%20at%203.57.11%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn89@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118305306_8f6722802431358c.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fstartup-marketing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn89@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118306297_fc0897055b70891c.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"Everything You Need to Know About Starting a Podcast in 2020","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/everything-you-need-to-know-before-starting-a-podcast","description":"<p>I’ve become a morning walking companion to people I may never meet.</p>  \n<p>How is this possible? They take me along in their earbuds as they stream my podcast, <em><a href=\"https://agencymanagementinstitute.com/agency-owner-podcast/\">Build a Better Agency</a></em></p> \n<p>It’s a wonderful sign of things to come for marketers willing to venture into the podcasting universe.</p> \n<p>Once a fringe platform, podcasts are now surprisingly mainstream. According to Nielsen, <a href=\"https://www.podcastinsights.com/podcast-statistics/\">six out of 10 people</a> understand what they are, and 112 million Americans -- 40 percent of the nation’s population -- have listened to at least one. Though podcast listeners lean male, it isn’t by much: 56 percent are men, while 44 percent are women.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Podcast.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Podcast.jpg\" alt=\"how to start a podcast\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 18px;\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=More%20on%20@HubSpot’s%20blog%20post%20here:%20https://bit.ly/strtpodcast%20pic.twitter.com/8g9b5EDr34\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><em>Share this image on Twitter!</em></span></a></p> \n<p>Marketing professionals must not only be aware of these statistics, but they must also leverage them in their own campaigns. When 67 million men and women are monthly podcast consumers, it’s a niche that deserves serious contemplation. Add to that fact the amazing statistic that <a href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/3035954/the-surprisingly-profitable-rise-of-podcast-networks\">63 percent</a> of podcast listeners made a purchase based on something the host recommended, and you have yourself a veritable gold mine.</p> \n<p>Of course, you have to crawl, then walk, then break into a steady trot to glean the benefits.</p> \n<h2><strong>A no-nonsense primer from a podcast experimenter.</strong></h2> \n<p>In my case, I’d written blog posts, conducted webinars, and published articles in places like <em>Forbes</em> and <em>Fast Company</em> for some time. These content producers worked, but I felt a different portal would help connect with more agencies and leaders in an accessible, easy to find, on-demand format.</p> \n<p>As a longtime podcast listener myself, I recognized that the podcasting platform was the next logical step for me -- especially if I wanted to reach a narrow audience of mid-sized agency owners and leaders as an authority in my field for more than 23 years. And as a long-time professional, I hired Predictive ROI, an Agency Management Institute agency, to produce the podcast so I wouldn’t make as many rookie technical mistakes.</p> \n<p>Still, opening yourself up to podcasting is a little like breaking the lid on Pandora’s box. Until you do it, you have no idea what to expect. Still, that doesn’t mean you can’t head off issues before you go live.</p> \n<p>Expect a certain amount of learning as you go, but be ready to explore the technology before fully launching your podcast. You wouldn’t open a bakery with your very first pie, so don’t hit “publish” until you get the lay of the land and make a plan. (Being a podcast guest prior to launching your own is a smart idea, too.)</p> \n<h2><strong>Podcasting in the beginner’s circle.</strong></h2> \n<p>Even if you’ve never been in front of a mic before, you can map out the first phase of a solid podcast schedule. From there, you’ll be able to branch out.</p> \n<h3><strong>1. Create a checklist to keep yourself on task.</strong></h3> \n<p>I asked myself tons of questions repeatedly before committing to podcasting. They included everything from the niche audience I wanted to reach to whether being the host of a podcast was a short-term fad or a long-term interest. I also considered what podcast style I preferred to offer the public, including a show prep and publishing schedule.</p> \n<p>Obviously, your checklist will be individualized, but be sure it includes a section on technical elements. Setting up audio, iTunes, accounts, and interviews can be tricky if you haven’t done your homework.</p> \n<h3><strong>2. Set up your basic show format.</strong></h3> \n<p>Every interviewer prefers to run his or her podcast in a particular way. Many podcasters ask guests the same questions, but as a listener, I find that gets stale in a hurry. Sure, it’s less prep work, but it makes the host look lazy. I preferred interviewing subject matter experts but wanted to occasionally keep the door open to produce a solocast. My compromise was a 4–1 ratio of interviews to solocasts.</p> \n<p>I was reasonably confident that I could have a few questions on hand and then launch into a conversation on the fly from there. A big risk? Maybe. But I believed I could pull off a 45-minute to 60-minute conversation without a safety net.</p> \n<h3><strong>3. Leverage the heck out of your network.</strong></h3> \n<p>The first 10 episodes set the tone for any podcast launch, so make sure you line up high-profile, interesting, engaging guests who won’t be turned off if you have very few -- or no -- listeners. My friends came through in a big way for me, offering me rock stars from day one. Not only did they help publicize the podcast, but they also generously allowed me to ride on their social media coattails.</p> \n<h3><strong>4. Track your downloads.</strong></h3> \n<p>Rob Walch was one of my recent podcast guests who offered an important consideration for any podcasters: You have to stay on top of your downloads. Rob’s suggestion is to hit at least 500 downloads an episode to feel sure you’ve broken the cycle of only having people in your inner circle tune in.</p> \n<p>What’s a reasonable download number for your, quote, “success”? Only you can determine this, but it helps to keep a steady eye on the numbers. Starting to see a downward trend in listenership? Go back to square one and ask those tough questions again so you can pivot before your podcast loses traction.</p> \n<h3><strong>5. Produce great content consistently.</strong></h3> \n<p>Does everyone have a bad episode once in a while? Sure. And if you’ve planned in advance and have great content in the bag, you can simply not release it in lieu of a better one. Before you release your podcasts publicly, try to have several on hand. That way, you get the relief of a buffer zone.</p> \n<p>Don’t try to start too quickly. You can always ramp up your delivery later. With my travel schedule that sees me on no fewer than 200 planes a year, I decided to get 10 episodes in before I proved to myself I could sustain the effort. August and September 2015 were a flurry of set-up and recordings, and we opened our podcast doors -- virtually -- in October 2015. Since then, we’ve published a new episode weekly without fail.</p> \n<h3><strong>6. Prepare to become a podcast promoter.</strong></h3> \n<p>Your target personas won’t find your podcast without a little help, so promote it like your life depends on it. I utilized our company’s email list, my personal social channels, and myriad other platforms. In addition, I requested that each guest promote his or her episode.</p> \n<p>We were fortunate to get on iTunes New and Noteworthy, landing us in the top five of several of its subject-specific lists during our first month.</p> \n<h3><strong>7. Learn how to monetize your podcast.</strong></h3> \n<p>Finally, it’s important to figure out how to earn an income based on your podcasting. One way is to promote your book, workshop, or online course, creating thought leadership at the same time.</p> \n<p>If you have a narrow audience lacking depth or width and you just can’t sell advertisements or sponsorships, you can still make numbers work in your favor.</p> \n<p>Sound like hard work? It is, but it’s totally worth it if you strategize. Two years after unveiling my first episode, we have 110 five-star reviews, and episodes are downloaded in more than 125 countries. I’m pleased to say we’ve also earned a presenting sponsorship from HubSpot. Podcasting hasn’t just been a feeder for the business, but a phenomenal marketing opportunity as well.</p> \n<p>Have you thought about taking the podcasting plunge? The water’s a bit choppy at first, but there’s plenty of room for another swimmer!</p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Feverything-you-need-to-know-before-starting-a-podcast&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Jul 2020 10:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/podcast-2018.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"8a6c8545d9e3e5d575a7ab15d0e218e5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn45@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118303762_0471a5202365b035.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/podcast-2018.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"topdog@agencyroundtable.com (Drew McLellan)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Podcast.jpg?width=1500&name=Podcast.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn53@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118313003_77bf14d504d3eb7f.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Feverything-you-need-to-know-before-starting-a-podcast&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn37@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118311855_c8b2faa06b67f4e8.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"How to Go Live on Instagram in Five Easy Steps","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-go-instagram-live","description":"<p>Earlier this morning, I joined a free workout class from my bedroom.</p> \n<p>I placed weights and a yoga mat beside my bed, and took the class in real-time with 6,000 of my closest friends.</p> \n<p>You might be thinking I took the class on Peloton's website, or through another boutique fitness studio.</p> \n<p>In reality, I actually took the class on Instagram — and, more specifically, <a href=\"https://help.instagram.com/292478487812558\">Instagram Live</a>.</p> \n<p>There are plenty of benefits for businesses to post Live videos on Instagram. For one, people <em>love </em>watching live videos. The content can feel more authentic and natural than it would if it had been pre-recorded — just consider how addicting <em><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live\">Saturday Night Live</a></em> can be, particularly if the actors <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7ZMWodZWNPo\">make mistakes or break character</a>.</p> \n<p>Additionally, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/live-video-stats\">82% of people prefer live video</a> from a brand over standard social media posts.</p> \n<p>You might consider using Instagram's Live feature to host live Q&amp;A's with industry leaders, stream entire virtual events, or host live product tutorials from social media influencers.</p> \n<p>If you've never posted a live video on Instagram, you're in luck. Here, we'll dive into how you can go live on Instagram in five easy steps. (By the way, I'm no Instagram influencer, so please excuse the sad plant as my only willing Live video subject.)</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>How to Go Live on Instagram</strong></h2> \n<p><em>It's important to note — these instructions will only work if you're opening the Instagram app on mobile. However, if you'd prefer to create a live Instagram video from desktop, you'll need to use a third-party tool like <a href=\"https://app.loola.tv/\">Loola TV.</a></em></p> \n<p><strong>1. First, open your <a href=\"https://apps.apple.com/us/app/instagram/id389801252\">Instagram app</a> on your smartphone, and click the camera icon in the top left corner. </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/step-one-instagram-live.jpg?width=462&amp;name=step-one-instagram-live.jpg\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 462px;\" width=\"462\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>2. On the bottom navigation, scroll all the way to the left until you see \"Live\". Then, click the big white circle to begin recording. (Note: You'll know you're Live when you see the pink \"Live\" button at the top of your screen, as well as the text \"We're telling your followers that you've started a live video\" at the bottom.)</strong></p> \n<p><strong><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/step-two-instagram-live-2.jpg?width=462&amp;name=step-two-instagram-live-2.jpg\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\" width=\"462\" style=\"width: 462px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/step-three-live-instagram-2.jpg?width=462&amp;name=step-three-live-instagram-2.jpg\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\" width=\"462\" style=\"width: 462px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>3. When you see accounts begin appearing at the bottom of your screen, you'll know people have begun joining your live video. Feel free to send them a Wave! </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/step-four-instagram-live-1.jpg?width=462&amp;name=step-four-instagram-live-1.jpg\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\" width=\"462\" style=\"width: 462px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>4. When you want to end the video, click \"End\" at the top right of your screen. When Instagram asks you, \"Are you sure you want to end your live video?\", click the red \"End Now\" button.</strong>&nbsp;</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/step-five-instagram-live-3.jpg?width=462&amp;name=step-five-instagram-live-3.jpg\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\" width=\"462\" style=\"width: 462px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>5. Finally, feel free to share your live video to your IGTV, so followers can still watch the video on your Instagram account after-the-fact. Alternatively, you can download the video to share it on your website or other social media pages, or delete the video. </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/share-instagram-live.jpg?width=462&amp;name=share-instagram-live.jpg\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\" width=\"462\" style=\"width: 462px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>If you choose to share your live video to your IGTV, your followers can continue watching and re-watching whenever they're available. If you're creating an exclusive membership-only live event, you might want to skip this step, but otherwise, it's a good idea to keep the content you've created to continue boosting awareness for followers who weren't able to join live.</p> \n<p>For instance, I regularly partake in fitness trainer <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/kayleigh_guinee/\">Kayleigh Guinee's Instagram Live workout classes</a>, but there are times I'm unavailable for the live version. Fortunately, I know she saves her videos to IGTV, so I'm able to pull up the videos whenever I'm ready to watch:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/goliveinstagram.jpg?width=462&amp;name=goliveinstagram.jpg\" alt=\"goliveinstagram\" width=\"462\" style=\"width: 462px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Best of all, I can pause, fast-forward, or replay the live version whenever I need to. You'll know you're watching a previously live Instagram video if you see the small \"was live\" text in the top left of the screen:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/waslivekayleigh.jpg?width=462&amp;name=waslivekayleigh.jpg\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\" width=\"462\" style=\"width: 462px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>I spoke with Kayleigh to understand why influencers choose live video over other forms of content.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Kayleigh told me, \"Online workouts are amazing, but&nbsp;<em>live&nbsp;</em>workouts on Instagram allow my followers to connect with me — and one another — while continuing to build a community, which is more similar to in-person fitness classes.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Kayleigh added, \"We're all able to see who joins, chat with each other, and workout in real-time. There is also something about having a time set aside to join a workout that helps us all stay more accountable.\"</p> \n<p>Ultimately, if you're unsure whether Instagram live will work for your brand, you can always give it a try. It's easy, and free, so there's little to lose when experimenting — and potentially a lot to gain.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Finally, there are some great features included in Instagram's Live tool. Let's explore what those are, next.</p> \n<h2><strong>Instagram Live Features</strong></h2> \n<p>Once you're rolling with an Instagram Live, you'll see four icons at the bottom of your screen — including a question mark icon, a paper airplane, two smiley-faces, and a filter icon.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/icons-instagram-live.jpeg\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>1. The Question Mark Icon</strong> lets you share questions from your viewers. (It's important to note, you'll only be able to share questions if someone has submitted a question during your Live video.)</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_7265.png?width=462&amp;name=IMG_7265.png\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\" width=\"462\" style=\"width: 462px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>2. The Paper Airplane Icon</strong> lets you send a direct message to someone about your Instagram Live video, which you might want to do if you're hoping to invite someone who hasn't yet joined your Live video to watch.</p> \n<p><strong>3. The Two Faces Icon</strong> lets you invite someone to co-host your Instagram Live. This will help spread your Live video to a bigger audience (including the co-host's followers). You might do this if you're hosting a Q&amp;A with various experts, or partnering with influencers to promote a product.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/co-host-instagram-live.jpg?width=462&amp;name=co-host-instagram-live.jpg\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\" width=\"462\" style=\"width: 462px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p><strong>4. The Filter Icon</strong> lets you add filters to your Instagram Live video to make them appear more polished or interesting — like this filter I added to my plant.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/instagram-live-filter-1.jpg?width=462&amp;name=instagram-live-filter-1.jpg\" alt=\"go-live-on-instagram\" width=\"462\" style=\"width: 462px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Additionally, if you want to turn off commenting, tap the three dots in the \"Comment\" box, and click \"Turn Off Commenting\". Alternatively, you can click the three dots if you'd also like to \"Turn Off Requests to Go Live\" if you don't want other participants asking to co-host.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/turn-off-commenting.png?width=376&amp;name=turn-off-commenting.png\" alt=\"turn-off-commenting\" width=\"376\" style=\"width: 376px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>We'd also recommend hiding offensive comments to ensure followers don't post inappropriate comments during a live video. To do this, go to your Instagram<strong> Settings &gt; Privacy &gt; Comments</strong>. Then, toggle on \"Hide Offensive Comments\".</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can manually filter to hide certain inappropriate words or phrases you don't want to appear during your live video. Just toggle \"Manual Filter\" and then type in the phrases you'd like hidden.</p> \n<p>And that's it! Hopefully, you'll have your own Instagram Live videos up-and-running in no time. Remember, there's no pressure to make your Live videos perfect. In fact, followers often appreciate when they can see real, authentic, behind-the-scenes footage of your brand.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>To learn more about creating top-notch live videos and get inspiration, take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/live-video-formats\">Which Types of Live Video Are People Actually Watching? [New Data]</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-go-instagram-live&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
