\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 29 Jul 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/go-instagram-live.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"2b300d81acc7d3f3a2cb13f587f95108","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn21@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118303646_32211dea2b4abe0f.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/go-instagram-live.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/step-one-instagram-live.jpg?width=462&name=step-one-instagram-live.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn26@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118310112_1c3c3596d30c01c9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/step-two-instagram-live-2.jpg?width=462&name=step-two-instagram-live-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn74@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118310570_8e4924e0d5fc8082.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/step-three-live-instagram-2.jpg?width=462&name=step-three-live-instagram-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn33@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118307110_5a067c4515d9a5ec.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/step-four-instagram-live-1.jpg?width=462&name=step-four-instagram-live-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn57@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118309201_f8f34617d712f888.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/step-five-instagram-live-3.jpg?width=462&name=step-five-instagram-live-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn66@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118310498_66fe5639aa35f293.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/share-instagram-live.jpg?width=462&name=share-instagram-live.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn89@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118311391_8c52de7c50205b58.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/goliveinstagram.jpg?width=462&name=goliveinstagram.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn85@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118305014_7b05d4f6c3717b70.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/waslivekayleigh.jpg?width=462&name=waslivekayleigh.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn69@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118308702_80f029e76039a3e2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/icons-instagram-live.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn97@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118311826_b8fc893c730de8fa.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_7265.png?width=462&name=IMG_7265.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn45@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118307196_e77717a13d934956.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/co-host-instagram-live.jpg?width=462&name=co-host-instagram-live.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn81@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118313281_72c4c816538c0a7c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/instagram-live-filter-1.jpg?width=462&name=instagram-live-filter-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn37@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118308902_a1e9b210839632e4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/turn-off-commenting.png?width=376&name=turn-off-commenting.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn5@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118305043_bb617b9868404ba2.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-go-instagram-live&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn81@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118312195_6e5d02aa66a606ee.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"Why the HubSpot Social Team Developed a Private Facebook Group and How It Impacted Our Audience","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hubspot-social-private-facebook-group-marketer-to-marketer","description":"<p>In 2019, the HubSpot Social Media Team set out to evaluate new opportunities for the brand to create and engage with the specific user communities on Facebook.</p>  \n<p>We know that today’s Facebook user behavior is shifting. While people still value video, image, and text content, they are finding authentic connections in shared interest groups instead of in their existing personal networks.</p> \n<p>These community groups on Facebook are a major opportunity for HubSpot to provide value to our target personas around the world. This would not only help us foster connections and growth for our current, future, and potential growing audience, but it would also provide us with a unique insight into the various communities of people and their experiences today.</p> \n<p>Since then, we have launched our first Facebook Group, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/groups/marketertomarketer/\">Marketer to Marketer</a> … because nobody knows marketing like marketers do.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>Why a Facebook Group, and why now?</h2> \n<p>Facebook Groups allow our audience to connect with each other and have valuable discussions. Businesses who center a Group around their brand or industry can build a community around it — making our brand and products even <em>more</em> valuable to potential customers.</p> \n<p>Groups also give us the chance to showcase our industry expertise and dedication to our members, especially since questions asked by members (and answers provided by us) are visible to others.</p> \n<p><em>And what’s better than gathering a group of people who love you and the industry in which you’re the thought leader? </em></p> \n<p>Organic reach for Facebook posts has been steadily declining. Facebook Group posts are a different story. At Facebook’s F8 conference in 2019, <a href=\"https://about.fb.com/news/2019/04/f8-2019-day-1/\">Mark Zuckerberg announced</a> their plan to really focus on supporting and promoting Groups going forward. They’ve been explicit in their desire to prioritize meaningful content in people’s feeds.</p> \n<p>That being said, we wanted to take this opportunity to create a Group as they are the perfect way to spark meaningful discussions with an audience.</p> \n<h2>How We Created the HubSpot <em>Marketer to Marketer</em> Facebook Group</h2> \n<p>When building out our Facebook Group strategy, we followed a number of steps to get our team aligned and working.</p> \n<h3>1. Research</h3> \n<p>To start, we researched the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/facebook-marketing\">value of Facebook Groups</a> and why businesses should create them. We did this to determine if this would be an opportunity for social growth and a benefit to our social audience.</p> \n<p>Determining the value of this Group — not just for our audience, but also for HubSpot — was key in helping us identify the purpose of the Group.</p> \n<p>One way we conducted this research was by gathering feedback from our audience across all social channels to see what topic they considered to be the biggest “missing link”. This was helpful because it showed us that marketing was the biggest topic in which they had an interest.</p> \n<p>We also connected with other teams internally to see how they leveraged their Facebook Groups (like <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/thehubspotacademy/\">HubSpot Academy</a>) and piece together their research. Lastly, we listed out all the potential risks of our Facebook Group. This helped us be prepared for any red flags if they were to come up.</p> \n<h3>2. Planning</h3> \n<p>Once in the planning phase, we outlined what resources were needed to create and maintain a Group. This included any header or profile images and what a daily workflow would look like for managing <em>Marketer to Marketer</em>. We also reviewed what steps we needed to take to create the Group, such as the smaller details for building it.</p> \n<p>We put together a brief that compiled all the research and best practices we learned in order to map out the launch of this Facebook Group. This included a proposed timeline, necessary resourcing, and an overview of what the Group would look like.</p> \n<p>We also crafted two months’ worth of content ideas for the Group. This content wasn’t set in stone but has helped create conversations when Group activity has lulled.</p> \n<h3>3. Reporting</h3> \n<p>In order to understand how we’d track and grow <em>Marketer to Marketer</em>, we defined how we would report on the data provided by the Group. This also helped us understand how it creates value for our audience and for HubSpot.</p> \n<p>Lastly, we used that data gathered to inform future content areas in which to expand as well as other audiences to support through Groups.</p> \n<h2>The Impact of the <em>Marketer to Marketer</em> Facebook Group</h2> \n<p>We examined the impact of <em>Marketer to Marketer</em> in a few different ways.</p> \n<p>In terms of the Facebook platform, our <em>Marketer to Marketer</em> Group hasn’t really had a significant impact on the broader HubSpot Facebook Page — the Group is probably too small to make a difference there.</p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/hubspot/\">HubSpot Facebook Page</a> has almost two million followers and <em>Marketer to Marketer </em>has just over 2,000. In this case, the pool of people in our Group is simply too small to impact such a large audience.</p> \n<p>Instead, the Group gives us a more direct way to interact with a more engaged audience. The Group content gets preferential placement in followers’ news feeds, whereas our normal Page content is a different content angle — we share brand awareness content related to different areas of Marketing, Sales, <em>and</em> Customer Service. (View examples <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/hubspot/videos/194420115130650/\">here</a> and <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/hubspot/videos/687338512092357/\">here</a>.)</p> \n<p>In short, we consider our Group followers as our VIPs.</p> \n<p>The Facebook Group also gives our members an outlet for more niched conversations, providing security and privacy to open up about any struggles, techniques, opportunities, or new information they’ve discovered about their industry.</p> \n<h2>Learnings, Discoveries, and Next Steps</h2> \n<p>Since launching the Group in March 2020, it’s been successful. Due to the depth of the conversations we’re seeing there as well as the fact that the group has become a self-sustaining community, it’s continued to grow with a higher than expected average of posts per week — while only doing organic promotion.</p> \n<p>During this tumultuous time for marketers, we’ve seen that people can use the Group as a resource to gather ideas or help from other marketers to work through their business needs. The first 90 days were specifically challenging due to national and global events, but even with the odds stacked against it, the <em>Marketer to Marketer</em> Facebook Group is still thriving with members participating in conversations and helping marketers along the way.</p> \n<p>Our learnings on Facebook Group growth have shown that it’s important to do ongoing promotion to reach an audience that could benefit from the conversations — now more than ever. From there, establish a consistent admin posting cadence with questions of the week or thought starters for marketers.</p> \n<p>We’ve established a dedicated day of the week to be “question day,” which has allowed the Group to function on its own while making our presence known and drumming up engagement. Since the Group started, it’s grown 2,000 members, and we plan to push it larger and larger for more marketers to take advantage of this outlet of community.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhubspot-social-private-facebook-group-marketer-to-marketer&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 23 Jul 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/imageedit_38_4549915027.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"3ca4af28de59e10ecba2cfc269ddbcaf","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn49@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118303763_a41003c74545fb2d.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/imageedit_38_4549915027.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Krystal Wu","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhubspot-social-private-facebook-group-marketer-to-marketer&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn25@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118309179_168529202685843c.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"9 Ways to Deal With Imposter Syndrome Before It Hinders Your Success","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/impostor-syndrome-tips","description":"<p>\"I got lucky.\"</p> \n<p>\"I don't belong here.\"</p> \n<p>\"I'm a fraud, and it's just a matter of time before everyone finds out.\"</p> \n<p>Sound familiar?</p> \n<p>Most of us have experienced feelings of doubt and unworthiness at some point in our lives. But when your accomplishments are a result of your own knowledge, hard work, and preparation and you <em>still</em> feel inadequate ... you're probably suffering from impostor syndrome.</p> \n<h3></h3> \n<p class=\"p1\" style=\"font-size: 18px; text-align: center;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline; font-style: italic;\"><span class=\"s1\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Imposter%20Syndrome-2.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Imposter%20Syndrome-2.jpg\" alt=\"Imposter Syndrome \" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; margin: 0px auto;\"></span></span><span style=\"text-decoration: underline; font-style: italic;\"><span class=\"s1\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=More%20on%20@HubSpot’s%20blog%20post%20here:%20https://bit.ly/copeimposter%20pic.twitter.com/yRr80Kwa2B\"></a></span></span></p> \n<p class=\"p1\" style=\"font-size: 18px; text-align: center;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline; font-style: italic;\"><span class=\"s1\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=More%20on%20@HubSpot’s%20blog%20post%20here:%20https://bit.ly/copeimposter%20pic.twitter.com/yRr80Kwa2B\">Share this image on Twitter!</a></span></span></p> \n<p>People who suffer from this syndrome often feel like frauds -- despite being smart, skilled, capable professionals who actually deserve whatever commendations and praise they're given. Rather than celebrating their accomplishments, they worry that they've somehow tricked people into thinking they're good enough. As a result, they live in fear of being \"found out\" or \"exposed.\"</p> \n<p>Impostor syndrome is actually fairly common: Researchers believe that <a href=\"http://www.forbes.com/sites/margiewarrell/2014/04/03/impostor-syndrome/#15042fb0eb9d\">up to 70% of people</a> have suffered from it at one point or another. But that doesn't make it any less damaging to a person's confidence and career growth.</p> \n<p>So if you feel like you're suffering from impostor syndrome or something like it, know that there <em>are</em> ways to curb these feelings in a healthy, proactive way. Here are 11 tips to help you get started.</p> \n<h2>9 Tips for Coping With Impostor Syndrome</h2> \n<h3>1. Know the signs.</h3> \n<p>We often overlook the signs of impostor syndrome that come up in our day-to-day lives. However, recognizing these signs is the first step toward overcoming them.</p> \n<p>You might suffer from impostor syndrome if:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>You feel like you \"got lucky\" when you actually prepared well and worked hard.</li> \n <li>You find it hard to accept praise.</li> \n <li>You apologize for yourself when you didn't actually do something wrong.</li> \n <li>You hold yourself to incredibly -- sometimes impossibly -- high standards.</li> \n <li>You find the fear of failure paralyzing.</li> \n <li>You avoid expressing confidence because you think people will see it as overcompensating or obnoxious.</li> \n <li>You're convinced you're not enough.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Pay attention to your language choices, both when you're talking to other people and when you're talking to yourself -- especially when it comes to talking about work. If you find your own success or the praise others give you uncomfortable, do some reflective thinking on where those types of thoughts came from and what it means in your professional life.</p> \n<h3>2. Know you're not alone.</h3> \n<p>When you have impostor syndrome, some of the most important encouragement comes from realizing how many hugely successful people, both male and female, have built amazing careers even while regularly coping with it.</p> \n<p>Which highly accomplished people have spoken about their impostor syndrome? Here are some quotes from <em><a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/26/your-money/learning-to-deal-with-the-impostor-syndrome.html?_r=0\">The New York Times</a> </em>and<em><a href=\"http://www.forbes.com/sites/margiewarrell/2014/04/03/impostor-syndrome/#3458b1fbeb9d\"> Forbes</a>:</em></p> \n<p>\"I have written eleven books, but each time I think, 'uh oh, they’re going to find out now. I’ve run a game on everybody, and they’re going to find me out.'\" - Author, Poet &amp; Civil Rights Activist Maya Angelou:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>All I can see is everything I’m doing wrong that is a sham and a fraud.”</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>\"All I can see is everything I’m doing wrong that is a sham and a fraud.” Actor Don Cheadle</p> \n<p>\"The beauty of the impostor syndrome is you vacillate between extreme egomania and a complete feeling of: ‘I’m a fraud! Oh God, they’re on to me! I’m a fraud!’ So you just try to ride the egomania when it comes and enjoy it, and then slide through the idea of fraud.” - Actress, Writer &amp; Producer Tina Fey, from her book <em>Bossypants</em></p> \n<h3>3. Distinguish humility and fear.</h3> \n<p>There's taking humility in your hard work and accomplishments, and then there's feeling overcome with fear because of them. Sometimes, simply being good at something can cause is to discount its value. But as <a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/26/your-money/learning-to-deal-with-the-impostor-syndrome.html?_r=0\">Carl Richards wrote in a <em>New York Times </em>article</a>, \"After spending a lot of time fine-tuning our ability, isn’t it sort of the point for our skill to look and feel natural?\"</p> \n<p>It all boils down to feeling unworthy. I like how Seth Godin put it <a href=\"http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2015/10/entitlement-vs-worthiness.html\">in a blog post</a>: \"When you feel unworthy, any kind response, positive feedback or reward feels like a trick, a scam, the luck of the draw.\"</p> \n<p>But it <em>is </em>possible to feel worthy without feeling entitled, and overcoming impostor syndrome is all about finding a healthy balance between the two. Godin goes on to write, \"Humility and worthiness have nothing at all to do with defending our territory. We don't have to feel like a fraud to also be gracious, open or humble.\"</p> \n<h3>4. Let go of your inner perfectionist.</h3> \n<p>I <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/productivity-hacks-counterintuitive\">recently wrote about</a> how perfectionism, while helpful in certain contexts, can be a major roadblock for productivity. Turns out it can be a major roadblock for overcoming impostor syndrome, too.</p> \n<p>Many people who suffer from impostor syndrome are high achievers; people who set extremely high standards for themselves and are committed to doing their best and being the best.</p> \n<p>But perfectionism only feeds into your impostor syndrome. When you feel like a fraud, it's usually because you're comparing yourself to some *perfect* outcome that's either impossible or unrealistic.</p> \n<p>Not only can no one do everything perfectly, but holding yourself to that standard <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/productivity-hacks-counterintuitive\">can actually be super counterproductive</a>. At some point, you need to take a step back and ask yourself: When is good enough <em>good enough? </em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/good-enough-content-creation-design\">Read this blog post</a> to see what a formula for \"good enough\" might look like. And if you need further encouragement, <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/news/oliver-burkeman-s-blog/2014/may/21/everyone-is-totally-just-winging-it\">read this article from </a><em><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/news/oliver-burkeman-s-blog/2014/may/21/everyone-is-totally-just-winging-it\">The Guardian</a>.</em></p> \n<p>Bottom line? While striving for perfection is certainly noble, it's usually not realistic -- and often, it's counterproductive and will only make you feel more like a fraud.</p> \n<h3>5. Be kind to yourself.</h3> \n<p><span>\"Take the pressure off yourself and stop trying to be the expert on day one.\" advises HubSpot marketing manager Jennifer Stafancik. </span></p> \n<p>Impostor syndrome often manifests itself as a voice in our heads, berating us with negative messages like \"you're not smart enough\" or \"you're a fraud.\"</p> \n<p>Negative self-talk is a bad habit, and it can heavily influence our stress and anxiety levels.</p> \n<p>\"Being kind to yourself\" simply means changing the way you talk to yourself in your head by practicing <em>positive </em>self-talk. Not only can it help you become less stress and anxious, but it can also help you build the courage to do things that'll bring you greater rewards.</p> \n<p>Maria Klawe, the president of Harvey Mudd College, <a href=\"http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/future_tense/2014/03/imposter_syndrome_how_the_president_of_harvey_mudd_college_copes.html\">suffered from what she called \"impostoritis\"</a> for most of her career. While she found it hard to silence the negative thoughts completely, she practiced hard to add positive thoughts to her inner voice. \"Now I wake up most days with a voice on the left side of my head telling me what an incredible failure I am,\" she wrote. \"But the voice on the right side tells me that I can change the world -- and I try to pay more attention to it.\"</p> \n<p>First, try to catch yourself whenever you have a negative thought. Then, turn around and challenge your own claim. For example, if you find yourself thinking, \"I just got lucky,\" challenge that by thinking, \"What steps did I take and what work did I put in to get to this point?\"</p> \n<p>Then, you can answer your own question using affirmations, which are short, focused, positive statements about a goal you have. In this case, one might be as simple as, \"I worked hard – and I always work hard.\"</p> \n<p><span>\"For me, I put a lot of pressure on myself when joining HubSpot since it was a lateral move, which ended up sparking imposter syndrome -- something I honestly thought I was immune to.\" Stefancik explains. \"Once I realized there was no reason to rush and to give myself more realistic milestones the imposter syndrome symptoms started to melt away.</span></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/wired-success/201305/do-self-affirmations-work-revisit\">Psychologists have found</a> that repeating affirmations like this can improve stress and anxiety levels, perhaps because these positive statements build a bridge into your subconscious mind.</p> \n<h3>6. Track and measure your successes.</h3> \n<p>When you feel like an impostor, one of the hardest things to grasp is how much of a role you have in your own successes. You might default them to luck or others' hard work, when in fact, your own work, knowledge, and preparation had a lot to do with it.</p> \n<p>To help show yourself that you're actually doing well, keep track of your wins in a private document.</p> \n<p>There are a lot of different ways to track these successes, and the metrics you use will depend entirely on your job. If you're a blogger, you might keep track of your posts' monthly average page views and watch them go up, or compare them to the team average. You might also keep a separate tab to paste kind words people have written to you via email, Twitter, blog comments, and so on.</p> \n<p>In the same vein as keeping track of your success metrics, keep a file on your computer of wins and positive reinforcement both at work and in your personal life. One of the best things I've done is created a folder on my personal Gmail account called \"Happy,\" where I've stored everything from my college acceptance email to praise from my colleagues and bosses. Whenever I need a lift, I open that Gmail folder and scroll through them.</p> \n<p>You can create an email folder for these emails like I did, or create something like a \"swipe file\" (i.e. a digital file) on your computer or phone to store screenshots of emails, tweets, dashboard metrics ... whatever makes you feel good about your hard work and preparation.</p> \n<h3>7. Talk about it with a mentor and your manager.</h3> \n<p>No one should suffer in silence. Sharing your thoughts and experiences with someone else will make you better equipped to deal with your impostor syndrome. We recommend sharing them with both a mentor and your direct manager.</p> \n<p>Your mentor will be able to help you talk candidly about your struggles with impostor syndrome, while giving you a more objective point of view -- especially if they work on a different team or at a different company. When you share your experience with them, you might ask if they've ever felt that way, or if they know someone who has.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/mentor-tips-positive-impact\">The best mentors are forthcoming</a> about the struggles they've gone through and the mistakes they've made in their careers, and you may find that they have some helpful stories or advice for how to deal with what you're feeling.</p> \n<p>We'd also suggest that you talk with your direct manager about your experiences, too. Why? Because they're more likely to have the knowledge and tools to help you overcome your impostor syndrome in the context of your current job.</p> \n<p>For example, you might ask them to help you find a system for tracking your successes, or figure out which metrics you should measure. Knowing what they know about both you and your role, they may also help you seek out more opportunities to shine and gain visibility on your team or at your company in general.</p> \n<p>Finding a mentor or manager to talk to is a strategy that Krystal Wu, HubSpot's Social Media Community Manager highly recommends.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><span>\"I've learned the best way to deal with imposter syndrome was to find a mentor to help guide me through my career choices,\" Wu says. </span></p> \n<p><span>As an example, Wu reflects, \"I was new to my social community role and to marketing and I wanted to do my best work but I didn't know what that meant all the time.\"</span></p> \n<p><span>\"When I put myself out there to find people in roles similar to mine, attended events to learn more about my industry and learned from my mentor it helped me gain confidence in my career,\" Wu explains. \"The more confidence and education I had the more the imposter syndrome started to fade.\" </span></p> \n<p><span>\"I won't say it's completely gone -- because let's be real, I'm always learning,\" Wu admits. \"But it's not something hanging over my head all the time. It comes and goes and I know that surrounding myself with people that are more knowledgeable in my field has helped me grown.\"</span></p> \n<p>Speaking of opportunities ...</p> \n<h3>8. Say \"yes\" to new opportunities.</h3> \n<p>It's impossible to say \"yes\" to everything, especially when you're feeling stressed or spread thin. But it's all too common for people who have impostor syndrome to turn down career-making opportunities because they don't feel like they'd do a good job.</p> \n<p>When you're presented with a new opportunity, it's important to distinguish between the voice in your head saying you can't do it because you're not worthy and the one saying you can't do it because you have too much on your plate. The former is your impostor syndrome speaking.</p> \n<p>But remember: Taking on challenging new work and doing well at it can open a <em>lot </em>of doors for you. Don't let your inner impostor turn down these game-changing opportunities. They can do wonders to help you learn, grow, and advance your career.</p> \n<p>Keep Richard Branson's <a href=\"http://www.huffingtonpost.com/susie-moore/success-and-motivation_b_5198200.html\">famous quote</a> in mind: \"If someone offers you an amazing opportunity and you are not sure you can do it, say yes. Then learn how to do it later.\"</p> \n<p>While it might be intimidating to take on a role you're not sure you can succeed in, know that you were asked to do it for a reason, and there's nothing wrong with learning new things and asking questions along the way.</p> \n<h3>9. Embrace the feeling, and use it.</h3> \n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\">It's really hard to get rid of impostor syndrome completely -- especially if you've had it for years and years. The fact that hugely successful people like Maya Angelou and Don Cheadle feel that way after all they've accomplished is evidence that it can sometimes be a lifelong condition.</p> \n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\">That's why the best angle from which to tackle your impostor syndrome isn't getting rid of it completely; it's stopping it from hindering your success.</p> \n<h2 class=\"story-body-text story-content\">Taking on Imposter Syndrome</h2> \n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\">I like the way <a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/26/your-money/learning-to-deal-with-the-impostor-syndrome.html?_r=0:\">Richards put it</a><i>:</i> \"We know what the feeling is called. We know others suffer from it. We know a little bit about why we feel this way. And we now know how to handle it: Invite it in and remind ourselves why it’s here and what it means.\"</p> \n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\">Richards says he's been invited to speak about his work and career all over the world, and yet he <em>still</em> hasn't been able to get rid of his impostor syndrome. What he has learned to do is think of it \"as a friend.\"</p> \n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\">Whenever he hears that negative voice in his head, he pauses for a minute, takes a deep breath, and says to himself, \"Welcome back, old friend. I'm glad you're here. Now, let's get to work.\"</p> \n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\"><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published in January 2016, but was updated in March 2020 for comprehensiveness and freshness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fimpostor-syndrome-tips&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Jul 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/how-to-deal-with-imposter-syndrome.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"c29d0f7ed0d543016303890b05f177df","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn93@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118303655_4af92bb033d2491d.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/how-to-deal-with-imposter-syndrome.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"lkolowich@hubspot.com (Lindsay Kolowich)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Imposter%20Syndrome-2.jpg?width=1500&name=Imposter%20Syndrome-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn1@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118305373_ce17976e3359e9b2.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fimpostor-syndrome-tips&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn85@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118308822_d4fd0d91c8050535.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"What is a 301 Redirect, and When Should You Use One?","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/7430/what-is-a-301-redirect-and-why-should-you-care.aspx","description":"<p>I moved five times in the last year. And every single time I moved, I forgot to sign up to have my mail forwarded to my new address.</p> \n<p>Mail forwarding is an important step in any moving process, as it ensures you don't lose any valuable information that's sent to you.</p> \n<p>And the same can be said for your website: If you're moving a website from one URL to another, you need to take the necessary steps to ensure your visitors get sent to the right place. In the world of tech, this is called a 301 redirect.</p> \n<p>Here, we're going to discuss what a 301 redirect is and when you need to use one, as well as how to redirect a URL in HubSpot or WordPress. Additionally, we'll explore the differences between a 301 and 302 redirect.</p> \n<p>Let's dive in.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>What is a 301 redirect?</strong></h2> \n<p>301 is a status code which a server sends to your browser. It is one of many possible status codes, some of which you've probably heard about (including 404 - Not Found, 403 - Forbidden and, 500 - Server Error). When you visit a webpage and the server sends the page normally, the status code it attaches to that page is 200 - OK.</p> \n<p>You can think of a 301 redirect like a mail forwarder. Once you've moved a piece of content away from a specific URL, anyone who tries to visit it will receive a 404 - page not found message.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>To improve their user journey, you can ask the server to forward visits from the old URL to a new location — the new home of your piece of content — using a 301 redirect.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Now, when you attempt to visit the old URL, the server will send back the 301 - Permanently Moved status code, and then move you on to the new location.</p> \n<p>This happens so quickly that you're usually not aware of it, and will simply find yourself on the piece of content for which you'd searched. You might notice that the URL is different from the one you clicked on, or typed in. Or you might have a browser extension such as <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/redirect-path/aomidfkchockcldhbkggjokdkkebmdll?hl=en\">Ayima Redirect Path</a> which lets you know when you've been redirected.</p> \n<p>The other key role that a 301 redirect fulfills is with search engines. Having useful status codes that correctly signal where content has moved to allows search engines such as Google and Bing to keep their index up-to-date.</p> \n<p>Essentially, a 301 redirect will let search engines know:<em>\"Hey, you know that piece of content that users enjoyed clicking on from the SERPs? Well, it now lives over here, so take all that visibility you associated with this page, and transfer it over to this new URL.\"</em></p> \n<p>This is why 301 redirects are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-strategy\">important for SEO</a>.</p> \n<p>Now that we've covered that, let's dive into how you can do a 301 redirect for yourself.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2><strong>How to Do a 301 Redirect</strong></h2> \n<p>The actual process of implementing a 301 redirect varies from CMS to CMS and platform to platform. While we aren't able to discuss the specifics of every CMS platform, we can take a close look at HubSpot and WordPress. Hopefully, these instructions should help you get started regardless of the CMS you use.</p> \n<h3><strong>How to Redirect a URL in HubSpot</strong></h3> \n<p>1. To set up a redirect in <a href=\"https://www.noisylittlemonkey.com/hubspot/partner-agency\">HubSpot</a>, navigate to <strong>Settings</strong> (using the cog in the top right) &gt; <strong>Domains and URLs</strong> &gt; <strong>URL Redirects</strong>.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect-1.png\" title=\"\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>2. From here, choose \"Add a URL redirect\". The interface looks like this:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect-2.png?width=499&amp;name=How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect-2.png\" title=\"\" width=\"499\" style=\"width: 499px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>We'll go over some use cases later, but for now let's look at the options here.</p> \n<h4>Standard</h4> \n<p>In most cases, you will want to implement a single page-to-page redirect. In this case, choose \"standard.\" Next, you'll want to add the Original URL and the Redirect To URL — for your old and new URLs, respectively.</p> \n<p>You can hit \"Add URL Redirect\" and the redirect will be added to HubSpot.</p> \n<p>At this stage, we would always recommend testing your redirect. First, expect to wait a few minutes for the change to apply to the server. Next, try visiting the Original URL in an incognito browser window and check that it works as you expected.</p> \n<h4>Flexible</h4> \n<p>In some cases, creating single page-to-page redirects is very inefficient. For example, if you have just moved an entire folder of content, you may have 15 pages within a subfolder that you now need to redirect. In such cases, it's a better idea to use a <em>flexible</em> redirect.</p> \n<p>You can think of a flexible redirect as a formula, or a rule. It will allow you to redirect everything within a certain folder to a different folder, while keeping the rest of the URL the same.</p> \n<p>When you select Flexible redirect, HubSpot will automatically provide you the link to the <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/cos-general/how-do-i-set-up-a-flexible-pattern-url-mapping\">flexible URL pattern redirect help page</a>, which will give you specific guidance on how to use the syntax for this feature.</p> \n<h4>More Options</h4> \n<p>Under More Options, HubSpot offers various advanced variations on these redirect types. It will allow you to deliver a 302 Temporary Redirect instead, choose the order which HubSpot moves through the redirect rules when resolving a URL (which may change which valid rule is triggered), disable a redirect if content is present at the URL, preserve query strings, force HTTPS, and force trailing slashes on the end of all URLs.</p> \n<h3><strong>How to Redirect a URL in WordPress</strong></h3> \n<p>If you aren't a HubSpot customer, then you will need to apply 301 redirects differently. WordPress is the <a href=\"https://websitesetup.org/popular-cms/\">most popular CMS in the world</a>, so it makes sense for us to touch upon how one might go about looking at redirects in a WordPress context next.</p> \n<p>However, it's important to note that WordPress itself is very flexible. Installations of WordPress can vary wildly, and so there is no one-size-fits-all guide we can provide as was the case with the HubSpot CMS.</p> \n<p>If in doubt, you should consult your web developer when it comes to adding URL redirects.</p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><strong>1. Apply a redirect via the server itself.</strong></h4> \n<p>The best way to apply redirects from a speed and technical point of view is actually via the server itself, rather than relying on WordPress to do it. WordPress does not offer a facility to implement 301 redirects out-the-box, although there are plenty of plugins available that will give you access to this functionality.</p> \n<p>When applying 301 redirects via the server itself, this is going to vary wildly depending on the software stack your server is using. You might be using Apache, nginx, IIS or some other platform, each of which will need to be tackled differently. This may also vary depending on your hosting provider.</p> \n<p>If you do not know how to apply a redirect via the server itself, it's not something we'd recommend fiddling with as it may lead to an interruption of service for your website — instead, we'd suggest consulting with your IT team or web development partner.</p> \n<h4>2. Redirect a URL using a free WordPress plugin.</h4> \n<p>Sometimes in marketing, you must compromise that optimal solution for the solution you can actually achieve. This may be one of those cases. If for some reason you are not able to implement a redirect via your server, you can consider using a WordPress plugin.</p> \n<p>This is not the optimal method — plugins will be slower, and you are forced to rely on third-party code, so proceed at your own risk.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect-3.png\" title=\"\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><a href=\"https://wordpress.org/plugins/search/301+redirect/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Each interface will be different, so you will have to consult any third-party plugin's help documentation for specific guidance.</p> \n<h2><strong>When to Use a 301 Redirect vs. a 302 Redirect</strong></h2> \n<p>In general, you should expect to use 301 redirects.</p> \n<p>However, there are a few cases when you might want to use a 302, instead, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>You might be using a phased website launch plan.</li> \n <li>You might be redirecting users as part of functionality where SEO does not apply, such as login gateways or e-commerce checkouts.</li> \n <li>You might be using a temporary holding page, and do not want to confuse search engines or damage your search engine rankings by signaling that you're permanently redirecting your detailed, rich content to an empty holding page.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2><strong>301 Redirect Use Cases</strong></h2> \n<p>Here are some specific cases where you will want to reach for the 301 redirect as a tool.</p> \n<h3>1. Changing a URL.</h3> \n<p>Maybe your original URL was poorly optimized, or you are re-organizing the folder structure of your website URLs.</p> \n<p>Moving a piece of content in HubSpot CMS is very simple — just change the URL on the settings tab of the content's edit page, and HubSpot will automatically add a URL redirect for you. Be sure to check that this is working before you move on.</p> \n<h3>2. Recreating a piece of content.</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, you might want to completely rebuild your old piece of content on an entirely new page — for instance, if you decide you want to use a different webpage template.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>In this case, you'll want to make sure that you have implemented a simple 301 redirect from the old URL to your new one. Once this is in place, be sure to un-publish and archive the old page.</p> \n<p>If doing a lot of these, we suggest using a flexible rule or, if a flexible rule is not appropriate, using a tool such as <a href=\"https://www.screamingfrog.co.uk/seo-spider/\">Screaming Frog SEO Spider</a> in conjunction with Google Sheets or Microsoft Excel to map your redirects in bulk, and then import them into HubSpot.</p> \n<p>You can do this on the URL Redirects page using the Import button:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect.png?height=292&amp;name=How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect.png\" title=\"\" height=\"292\"></p> \n<p>HubSpot will provide you with a sample file to structure your redirects, and a <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/cos-general/how-to-bulk-upload-url-mappings-to-hubspot\">link to the bulk upload redirects help page</a>.</p> \n<h3>3. Consolidating several pieces of content.</h3> \n<p>If you have decided that you have multiple pieces of content that overlap, compete for the same keywords, or all cover the same topic, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remove-outdated-content\">you might want to consolidate them</a>. However, you will not want to throw away the search engine visibility that these old pages might have achieved.</p> \n<p>Once you have created your new, consolidated resource, you should set up a simple 301 redirect from each of the old pages, to the single new page.</p> \n<h3>4. Migrating content from one domain to another.</h3> \n<p>If you're moving your website from one domain to another, it is vitally important that you implement page-to-page 301 redirects from your old content to your new content.</p> \n<p>This is easy if the site is moving a domain, but remaining the same in terms of structure and layout. If the content is changing or being restructured, it is still important that you make sensible redirection choices that honor your users original intent, in order to pass the visibility of each of your old pages to their new counterparts.</p> \n<p>When implementing page-to-page 301 redirects from one domain to another, you have a specific challenge to keep in-mind: your redirects must be served from the Original URL.</p> \n<p>It is useless if, for instance, you've connected HubSpot to your new domain, but not your old domain, for you to then host the 301 redirects for your old domain onto HubSpot. You will need to work with your IT partner, web development partner, and/or HubSpot partner to ensure that serving redirects from your old domain has been accounted for. We recommend that these remain in place indefinitely.</p> \n<h3>Migrating a Website During a Phased Web Launch</h3> \n<p>You may be moving your website from one domain to another as outlined above, but due to project constraints, you are using a phased launch approach. This means that you're launching the core website pages in phase one, then a second wave of pages in phase two, and so on.</p> \n<p>In this case, we recommend creating a phased redirect map. All URLs from your old domain should be accounted for, and a redirect outlined for each phase.</p> \n<p>For phase one, you will expect to implement 301 redirects for all the pages that will be accounted for on the new site. You will also add 302 redirects for all other pages, usually to the new website's homepage. This will prevent users trying to visit your old domain from receiving a 404 error, without confusing search engines by having your pages suddenly redirect to seemingly irrelevant content.</p> \n<p>As you launch each phase, you should update your redirects, replacing your 302s with 301s as the counterpart content becomes available.</p> \n<p>Once again, these redirects must be implemented such that they are served from your old domain.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><strong>301 Redirect Mistakes to Avoid</strong></h2> \n<p>Now that you understand the importance of the 301 redirect, we'll review common&nbsp;steps in the process to review to make sure you don't make a mistake that could adversely impact your site's <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/seo-training\">SEO</a>.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><strong>1. Setting up a 302 redirect between versions of your domains.</strong></h3> \n<p>301 redirects point the power of inbound links from one URL to another, and although it might not look like it, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com\">http://blog.hubspot.com</a>&nbsp;and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com\">blog.hubspot.com</a>&nbsp;are two different URLs. Make sure you set up a 301 redirect from all of the different iterations of your brand's domain to boost your search engine results.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><strong>2. Setting up a 301 redirect after creating a new page.</strong></h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/biggest-seo-blunders#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">Back in 2010</a>, Toys 'R Us purchased the toys.com domain without setting up a 301 redirect first, and their new site's SEO results plummeted because it was re-crawled by Google as a brand-new domain without inbound links from the original Toys 'R Us domain pointing to it. Be sure to set up the 301 redirect before migrating your website content so your site doesn't lose traffic in the process.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><strong>3. Using a 302 redirect during content migration.</strong></h3> \n<p>Unless you're temporarily migrating your website's content while updating or repairing your website, use a 301 redirect to maintain the inbound links and your search rankings while making changes to your domain.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><strong>4. Having redirects link to outdated content.</strong></h3> \n<p>If you don't set up redirects from the older internal links on your website (such as a link to your company blog on your homepage), you'll create a <a href=\"https://blog.metrixa.com/5-big-seo-redirect-mistakes-and-how-to-avoid-them\">bad user experience</a> for site visitors who click on these older, not-directed links. The old internal link will eventually kick over to the new domain, but it might take several seconds or show a white screen in the meantime.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><strong>5. Redirect a page with a different intent than the destination page.</strong></h3> \n<p>This will be a breeze with proper organization and record keeping, but make sure that you're redirecting to the correct pages. To illustrate, you wouldn't want to redirect a user looking for your homepage to your blog page.</p> \n<p>Keeping this transition smooth will contribute to SEO being accurate, and will lead to more happy visitors to your site.</p> \n<p>Whether you're thinking about overhauling all content in a site migration, or you're just refurbishing some outdated webpages, 301 redirects help. If you're planning out this new stage, think about incorporating them in your project; your SEO won't take a dive and website visitors will continue to find the helpful content they're looking for.</p> \n<h2><strong>Other Types of Redirects</strong></h2> \n<p>There are other types of redirect too, including:</p> \n<h3>1. 302 - Temporarily Moved</h3> \n<p>This functions almost identically to a 301 redirect. However in this instance, we are acknowledging that the move is temporary. For a user, this makes no practical difference, but for a search engine the message is clear — don't worry about ranking this new page, as it won't be around for long. Stick to using the old one, it will be back.</p> \n<h3><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">2. Meta Refresh, or Javascript Redirects</span></h3> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">This is different from the previous two approaches. The page will load normally with a 200 - OK status code. Then, a script runs on the page that moves the user onto another page. </span></p> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">There may be certain edge cases when this is the only practical option, but in general you should avoid this approach. It is not associated with SEO best practices and often can provide a confusing user experience.</span></p> \n<h3>Addressing Internal 404 Errors</h3> \n<p>Your SEO or web team might have identified some broken links on your website. In this case, it's best practice to create a 301 redirect to forward users from the broken URL through to an appropriate resource — one that is fundamentally congruent with the piece of content they were expecting to find.</p> \n<p>However, you should also look to update the offending hyperlinks to point to the new URL, as well. Having a website that relies on 301 redirects for internal navigation is not best practice.</p> \n<h3>Addressing 404 Errors Reported in Google Search Console</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, you will see Google Search Console reporting 404 pages that you don't even link to internally. So where do these come from?</p> \n<p>Google Search Console populates its \"Coverage\" section from all kinds of sources. Sometimes the URLs are simply ones that it has seen before on a previous incarnation of your website, or it might have seen an external link on some other website.</p> \n<p>Your mindset should be that if Google has seen this URL before, a user might have as well. They might have it saved as a bookmark, or have it written down in an email, or on a third party website, and they may still click on it. That being the case, you want to make sure that those users receive the optimum user experience, so you should try to create 301 redirects to push these users to an appropriate piece of content that is fundamentally congruent with the piece of content they were expecting to find.</p> \n<p>301 redirects are vitally important for maintaining a healthy website. They serve a core function in signaling to both users and search engines when your website content moves and changes, and ensure that as your web presence evolves, your user journey remains clear and logical, and your visibility in search engines is preserved from iteration to iteration.</p> \n<p>Be sure to familiarize yourself with the method of implementing redirects within your current website environment, so that you can manage this effectively.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in December 2010 and has been updated for accuracy and comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F7430%2Fwhat-is-a-301-redirect-and-why-should-you-care.aspx&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
