\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 23 Jul 2020 13:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect-1.png","linkMd5":"2c03338adf1b94a11b50c7fd0abf1bfa","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn77@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118301715_6afcd9cb52116fd8.webp","author":"Jon Payne","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn77@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118301715_6afcd9cb52116fd8.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect-2.png?width=499&name=How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn77@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118306995_b344e67b89e1b43d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn33@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118313443_f2d13473f1ee346e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect.png?height=292&name=How%20to%20do%20a%20301%20redirect.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn29@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118311689_68286940d0191b1a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F7430%2Fwhat-is-a-301-redirect-and-why-should-you-care.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn1@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118308899_450fdd16a457b62f.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"Remote Smarketing 101: How to Align Distributed Marketing and Sales Teams","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-smarketing","description":"<p>To create the optimal customer experience, it's undeniably critical that your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tried-and-true-sales-marketing-alignment\">sales and marketing teams are well-aligned</a>.</p>  \n<p>If you don't, your prospects will suffer.</p> \n<p>For instance, imagine this: your prospect has been researching a new video conferencing tool for weeks. She's <em>finally</em> found one company she's extremely interested in — yours.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Before calling a sales rep, your prospect decides to read numerous blog posts on your website. She also downloads an ebook, watches your company's YouTube videos, and even chats in a few of your community forums.</p> \n<p>Once your marketing materials have convinced her your product could be a good fit, she decides to call one of your company's sales rep.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, the sales rep has no background knowledge on the content with which the prospect has already interacted. The sales rep begins a generic introductory sales pitch, not realizing your prospect is <em>almost </em>ready to buy — she just has a few final questions.</p> \n<p>This results in a less-than-ideal user experience for your prospect, who won't feel valued as someone who's been interacting with your brand's content for weeks already.</p> \n<p>This isn't an ideal experience for your company's sales or marketing teams, either. If the sales rep was aware of the content with which the prospect has interacted, they'd have an easier time connecting with the prospect and understanding her needs upfront.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/sales-and-marketing\">well-aligned sales and marketing teams</a> have a <em>major</em> impact on your business' bottom line. In fact, companies with well-aligned sales and marketing teams generate <a href=\"http://www.wheelhouseadvisors.net/how-to-align-sales-marketing-to-boost-revenue-by-208-infographic/#:~:text=By%20aligning%20sales%20and%20marketing,could%20generate%20208%25%20more%20revenue.&amp;text=Organizations%20which%20align%20sales%20and,67%25%20better%20at%20closing%20deals.\">208% more revenue</a> from marketing efforts.</p> \n<p>However, if your marketing and sales teams are primarily remote or operate out of different locations, it can be even more challenging to align the teams than it would be in-person. That's where <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/remote-leadership?utm_source=marketing_blog&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=remote_leadership\">good remote leadership</a> comes into play.</p> \n<p>For this article, I've spoken with Debbie Farese, HubSpot's former Director of Sales Enablement and current Director of Global Web Strategy, and Matt Hambor, HubSpot's Corporate Sales Manager, to gather insights into how you might align your own distributed marketing and sales teams.</p> \n<h2><strong>3 Tips for Aligning Distributed Marketing and Sales Teams</strong></h2> \n<h3>1. Ensure your goals are aligned across distributed marketing and sales teams.</h3> \n<p>Ultimately, to align distributed marketing and sales teams, it's critical you ensure both teams have clearly identified mutually-beneficial goals.</p> \n<p>Debbie Farese told me: \"Goal alignment is the best way to ensure sales and marketing teams are aligned, no matter where they sit. For marketing, this means looking at metrics that factor in the quality of leads generated, not just the quantity. Examples are lead-to-qualified-lead rates, close rates, revenue per lead, and more.\"</p> \n<p>Farese added, \"For sales, this means committing to working the leads that marketing generates and tracking this along with success in closing deals. Examples are work rates, productivity per rep, and more.\"</p> \n<p>Ultimately, it's not enough to <em>say </em>you've aligned goals across teams. Instead, you need to prove it, with some of the metrics Farese mentions above. And, whether your team is remote or in-office, you'll want to continue to foster meetings that allow both teams to pivot if your current strategy isn't enabling the teams to work hand-in-hand effectively.</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say your sales team has identified \"inform customers of new product features\" as a major goal for the year. However, this goal hasn't been properly communicated with the marketing team.</p> \n<p>Undoubtedly, this causes friction for the prospect. A prospect might receive tons of high-quality marketing materials before speaking with a sales rep — including ebooks, blog posts, webinars, newsletters, and YouTube videos — but they'll feel caught-off guard if most marketing materials don't mention the product's new features.</p> \n<p>It makes it easier for both your sales and marketing teams to effectively perform their roles if both teams are well-aligned in a few critical goals.</p> \n<p>And, most importantly, it makes it easier on your prospects and customers if your teams are aligned. You don't want your prospects to feel like your company is disorganized, or that they're receiving disparate information from different teams within your larger organization.</p> \n<h3>2. Have your marketing team listen to sales calls or join Slack conversations.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/online-sales?utm_source=marketing_blog&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=online_selling\">If your sales team is largely remote</a>, that likely means your sales reps function primarily via video or conference calls to close deals, rather than in-person customer meetings. This could make it easier to integrate marketing into the sales process, or enable marketing leaders to listen, on occasion, to prospect conversations to ensure the marketing team is delivering relevant content.</p> \n<p>For instance, Farese told me, \"Through remote work, it's easier than ever for marketing to listen in on customer and prospect calls to understand their persona even better, develop empathy for sales reps, and get an understanding for what content and messaging really resonates.\"</p> \n<p>Additionally, Matt Hambor mentioned as a leader of a remote team, it's critical you \"encourage everyone to contribute to communication via Slack, email, or text. If you hear a good idea or success story from a member of your team, encourage them to share it with the larger group.\"</p> \n<p>This concept can also help align your marketing and sales teams — for instance, you might invite members of your marketing team to your sales team's Slack channel, so they can take note of customer concerns and successes and consider using those stories as Case Studies or by highlighting the customer in a company newsletter.</p> \n<h3>3. Create both formal and informal opportunities for sales and marketing to collaborate.</h3> \n<p>Matt Hambor, who's been managing a majority remote sales team for over two years, told me a few tactics he's used to facilitate team bonding and cross collaboration. Hambor says, \"Setting clear expectations and being transparent when dealing cross-functionally is critical with any type of collaboration, but even more important when it's remote.\"</p> \n<p>You might try implementing a few cross-department virtual meetings once a month, or once a quarter. Hambor's team, for instance, meets with a HubSpot Marketing Manager once a month for a standup meeting in which both teams are able to ask questions and ensure their priorities are well-aligned.</p> \n<p>By ensuring your sales team is able to glean insight into marketing strategies and priorities, you're ensuring your sales reps have a firm understanding of your prospects' entire start-to-finish buyer's journey, so they can better meet prospects wherever, and whenever, they'd like to be met.</p> \n<p>Additionally, Hambor mentions he often hosts weekly happy hours, contests within the team, and other more casual events to facilitate team bonding. To align your sales and marketing teams, then, you might try creating a quarterly remote happy hour, trivia game, or cross-department bonding activity.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, whether your teams are remote, in-person, or a mixture of both, Hambor says it's vital as a manager that you show you care about your employees' well-being. Hambor says, \"It's important you ask how your employees are doing … and <em>actually</em> care. They could be going through things you don't have exposure to. It's important you have a genuine interest in their well-being and success. The last thing you want is your remote teammates feeling isolated and insecure reaching out and asking for help.\"</p> \n<p>Once you've implemented some strategies mentioned above, consider sending a survey to your sales and marketing teams to gather insights into other potential opportunities for cross-department collaboration and partnership. Your marketing and sales teams will thank you — and so will your prospects and customers.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: The post was originally written in March 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fremote-smarketing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Jul 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/remote-smarketing.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"300c61d80f3b6a0326a8b27cf193b204","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn89@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118303664_209363e56446afca.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/remote-smarketing.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fremote-smarketing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn9@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118305731_9ceaba0dd2e77662.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"10 Pieces of Content Your Audience Really Wants to See [New Data]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-your-audience-actually-wants","description":"<p>Content marketing is constantly evolving, which is what we here on the HubSpot blogging team love about our jobs. It keeps things interesting. And while it’s easy to get caught up in experimenting with innovative content, it’s important that we pay close attention to how our <strong>readers</strong> are changing, too.</p> \n<p>According to <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/reports/the-future-of-content-marketing\">HubSpot Research</a>, 2016 marks the start of a new phase of technological development, where new innovations and consumer preferences will usher in a new way of how marketers will do business.</p> \n<p>Our research team surveyed over 1,000 internet users worldwide to learn about their preferences and behaviors when it comes to their content consumption habits. In this article, we’re diving deeper into two specific trends to discuss how marketers can prepare their content strategies to meet the needs of their readers.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ContentTypes-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=ContentTypes-1.png\" alt=\"Content Types\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 18px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=More%20on%20@HubSpot’s%20blog%20post%20here:%20https://bit.ly/audiencecontent%20pic.twitter.com/ftSRKbE5wd\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><em>Share this image on Twitter!</em></span></a></p> \n<h2>What content types do readers want to see more of in the future?</h2> \n<p>HubSpot Research found that internet users’ behaviors are changing to reflect a growing interest in visual content. They’re also shifting where they’re reading content, choosing social media platforms over of more traditional blog and long-form outlets:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/types_of_content-1.png?width=669&amp;name=types_of_content-1.png\" alt=\"types_of_content-1.png\" width=\"669\" title=\"types_of_content-1.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>It’s important to note that these survey results don’t mean that content creators should abandon mediums such as blogging or podcasting, as these content outlets will continue to provide value over time. Instead, what the above chart suggests is that marketers should develop a more diversified strategy to meet the growing demand for alternative content types such as video and social media content.</p> \n<h2>How are readers consuming content?</h2> \n<p>For content creators, it’s important to know what kind of content readers want, and also how they want to read it. HubSpot found that different types of content are more likely to retain readers’ close attention than others. Generally speaking, longer written content is more likely to be <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/examples-skimmable-content\">skimmed</a>, and content with more visual elements, such as videos and images, are more likely to be thoroughly consumed:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/thorough_vs._skim_read.png?width=730&amp;height=383&amp;name=thorough_vs._skim_read.png\" alt=\"thorough_vs._skim_read.png\" width=\"730\" height=\"383\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>Now that we’ve reviewed the types of content readers want and how they want to consume them, let's take a look at some effective examples of below.</p> \n<h2>10 Pieces of Content Your Audience Actually Wants to See</h2> \n<p>Click on the categories below to check out examples of the types of content your audience is looking for:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong><a href=\"#videos\">Videos</a></strong></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"#socialmedia\">Social Media</a></strong></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"#news\">News Articles</a></strong></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"#research\">Research Content</a></strong></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"#games\">Online Classes/Educational Games</a></strong></li> \n</ol> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Videos</h3> \n<p>Video is and will continue to be a huge part of content marketing: <a href=\"http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/service-provider/ip-ngn-ip-next-generation-network/white_paper_c11-481360.html\">According to Cisco</a>, <a href=\"http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/service-provider/ip-ngn-ip-next-generation-network/white_paper_c11-481360.html\">80%</a> of web traffic will be video by 2019. That's a lot. And this same sentiment is reflected in <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/reports/the-future-of-content-marketing?_ga=1.172014307.1733063552.1465306056\">the latest report from HubSpot Research</a>, where 45% of survey respondents admitted to watching 1+ hours of video on Facebook and YouTube each week.</p> \n<p>To further illustrate this point, let's consider that users watch <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2015/11/04/facebook-video-views/\">8 billion</a> videos on Facebook and <a href=\"http://www.theverge.com/2016/4/28/11526294/snapchat-10-billion-daily-video-views-users-stories\">10 billion</a> videos on Snapchat per day. Today, social media platforms are becoming more about content sharing <i>and</i> discovery, so an integrated video and social media strategy will be necessary for brands seeking to compete. (<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/video-social-media-marketing?utm_campaign=Marketing%20Blog%20-%20Internal%20Links%20%5BSeptember%5D&amp;utm_medium=10%20Pieces%20of%20Content&amp;utm_source=Blog\">Learn more about creating video for social media in our free ebook.</a>)</p> \n<h4>1) <a href=\"https://www.buzzfeed.com/tasty\">Tasty on BuzzFeed</a></h4> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.07%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/mNHq7T9YHHs\" width=\"560\" height=\"314\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>BuzzFeed’s Tasty videos are a great example of the type of video content people want to consume. <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/buzzfeedtasty/\">According to their Facebook Page</a>, they can be best described as “snack-sized videos and recipes you'll want to try.” It’s as simple as that.</p> \n<p>Each video covers one recipe in an engaging, fast-motion format -- making them tailor-made for Facebook scanners.</p> \n<p><strong>Why this works so well:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>They’re short and sweet.</strong> <a href=\"https://www.minimatters.com/youtube-best-video-length/\">Mini Matters </a>reports that YouTube viewers favor short videos, approximately 42 seconds in length.</li> \n <li><strong>They don’t require sound to understand what’s going on.</strong> <a href=\"http://digiday.com/platforms/silent-world-facebook-video/\">According to Digiday</a>, 85% of videos on Facebook are watched without sound.</li> \n <li><strong>They teach how-to skills. </strong><a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/articles/i-want-to-do-micro-moments.html\">Google</a> reports that searches for “how to” video content have increased 70% year-over-year.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><em>Views: 1.1 million</em></p> \n<h4>2) <a href=\"http://www.vox.com/\">Vox Media</a></h4> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.07%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/czWhVBmrNPQ\" width=\"560\" height=\"314\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>Vox’s video content varies between news, explainers, entertainment, and how-to videos (check out their full <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/voxdotcom/videos?flow=grid&amp;sort=p&amp;view=0\">YouTube channel</a> here), and their videos are highly shareable and easy to consume.</p> \n<p><strong>Why this works so well:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>The video are around two minutes in length. </strong><a href=\"https://wistia.com/blog/does-length-matter-it-does-for-video-2k12-edition\">According to research from Wistia</a>, this length is optimal to ensure viewers watch all the way through to the end.</li> \n <li><strong>They feature captions and animations</strong> so viewers can understand the gist of the video without having to turn on the <a href=\"http://digiday.com/platforms/silent-world-facebook-video/\">volume</a>.</li> \n <li><strong>They cover breaking news</strong>, which <a href=\"https://blog.twitter.com/2015/new-research-twitter-users-love-to-watch-discover-and-engage-with-video\">64%</a> of Twitter users surveyed said they want to see more of.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><em>Views: 2.7 million</em></p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Social Media</h3> \n<p>The global social media audience is vast: <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/264810/number-of-monthly-active-facebook-users-worldwide/\">Facebook</a> has 1.7 billion daily active users (DAUs), <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/253577/number-of-monthly-active-instagram-users/\">Instagram</a> has 500 million, <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/282087/number-of-monthly-active-twitter-users/\">Twitter</a> has 313 million, and <a href=\"http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-06-02/snapchat-passes-twitter-in-daily-usage\">Snapchat</a> has 150 million. Users are consuming <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/reports/the-future-of-content-marketing\">more content than ever</a> on social media networks, and content creators will have to shift their publication strategy to meet their audience where they’re gathering information.</p> \n<h4>3) <a href=\"http://www.intel.com/\">Intel</a></h4> \n<p>&nbsp;</p>  \n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\">\n <a href=\"http://www.intel.com/\"></a> \n <p><a href=\"http://www.intel.com/\"></a><a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/TBT?src=hash\">#TBT</a> Ready for lift-off: all systems were a go for an amazing Drone 100 night at Sydney Opera House. <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/IntelAtVivid?src=hash\">#IntelAtVivid</a> <a href=\"https://t.co/z3gLXkZbuC\">pic.twitter.com/z3gLXkZbuC</a></p> — Intel (@intel) \n <a href=\"https://twitter.com/intel/status/773949985347870720\">September 8, 2016</a>\n</blockquote> \n<h4 style=\"text-align: center;\">  </h4>  \n<p>Here’s another example of the power of video marketing in the context of social media posts -- the second most popular content form users are looking for. Intel creates products in the information technology and cloud computing space, but their tweets touch on how technology interacts with the rest of the world.</p> \n<p>For example, this tweet shares a video from Drone 100, an event Intel hosted in Sydney, Australia where users launched Intel drones for a crowdsourced light show. (<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-use-twitter-for-business?utm_campaign=Marketing%20Blog%20-%20Internal%20Links%20%5BSeptember%5D&amp;utm_medium=10%20Pieces%20of%20Content%20Your%20Audience%20Actually%20Wants%20to%20See%20%5BNew%20Data%5D&amp;utm_source=Blog\">Learn more about how to use Twitter for business here.</a>)</p> \n<p><strong>Why this works so well:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>The tweet uses video</strong>, which drives engagement: <a href=\"https://blog.twitter.com/2015/new-research-twitter-users-love-to-watch-discover-and-engage-with-video\">82%</a> of Twitter users watch video content, and Twitter videos drive <a href=\"https://blog.twitter.com/2015/new-research-twitter-users-love-to-watch-discover-and-engage-with-video\">more retweets, likes, and replies</a> than video on third-party players.</li> \n <li><strong>The tweet uses relevant hashtags sparingly</strong>. <a href=\"http://locowise.com/blog/are-hashtags-overrated-and-overused-the-surprising-effect-of-social-media-hashtags\">Locowise</a> found that numerous hashtags don’t contribute to greater Twitter engagement, but that the occasional relevant hashtag, such as #TBT or a branded campaign hashtag, can help new users find your content.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><i>Retweets: 190</i>, <i>Likes: 492</i></p> \n<h4>4) <a href=\"http://www.fedex.com/\">FedEx</a></h4> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/fedex2.png?width=730&amp;height=467&amp;name=fedex2.png\" alt=\"fedex2.png\" width=\"730\" height=\"467\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>FedEx features stunning photos of their trucks, planes, and envelopes around the world, and what’s more, the vast majority of their posts are photos taken by other Instagram users. Rather than posting boring photos from a mail sorting facility, FedEx featured this gorgeous shot of a branded plane with a full moon in the background.</p> \n<p><strong>Why this works so well:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Their Instagram features user-generated content</strong> (UGC), which humanizes brands and promotes greater brand <a href=\"https://www.yotpo.com/blog/consumer-decision-making-process-ugc/\">engagement</a>.</li> \n <li><strong>Their posts feature hashtags</strong>, which help users find new Instagram accounts to follow. <a href=\"http://trackmaven.com/blog/2015/01/everything-marketers-need-know-instagram-sponsored-content/\">According to research from TrackMaven</a>, Instagram posts with four to five hashtags saw an increase in interactions.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><em>Likes: 1,337</em></p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>News Articles</h3> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.journalism.org/2016/07/07/pathways-to-news/\" style=\"font-family: proxima-nova, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 1em; line-height: 1.5em; background-color: transparent;\">Four in ten Americans</a> get their news online, and <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/reports/the-future-of-content-marketing\" style=\"font-family: proxima-nova, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 1em; line-height: 1.5em; background-color: transparent;\">55%</a> of HubSpot Research respondents find new content by searching on publications’ websites directly. That said, online newspapers and magazines should continue regular, if not daily, publication to keep up with reader demand.</p> \n<h4>5) <a href=\"http://www.espn.com/\">ESPN</a></h4> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/17616306/bill-belichick-new-england-patriots-just-keep-winning-rookie-qb-no-tom-brady\"></a><a href=\"http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/17616306/bill-belichick-new-england-patriots-just-keep-winning-rookie-qb-no-tom-brady\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/espngif.gif_final.gif?width=910&amp;name=espngif.gif_final.gif\" alt=\"espngif.gif_final.gif\" width=\"910\" title=\"espngif.gif_final.gif\" style=\"width: 910px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></a></p> \n<p>According to our research, more readers want news articles, but that doesn’t mean they want to read them thoroughly. As <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/reports/the-future-of-content-marketing\">37%</a> of those surveyed indicated they would be more likely to skim-read news articles, this article from ESPN does a great job of balancing the desires of skim-readers and content devourers alike.</p> \n<p><strong>Why this works so well:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>This longer article features an accompanying video</strong> for those who don’t have the time to read the full text.</li> \n <li><strong>It includes bullets </strong><strong>and</strong> <strong>images </strong>to <a href=\"https://www.nngroup.com/articles/concise-scannable-and-objective-how-to-write-for-the-web/\">maintain reader attention</a> and to break up larger paragraphs of text.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><em>Facebook Shares: 1.9K</em></p> \n<h4>6) <a href=\"http://mashable.com/\">Mashable</a></h4> \n<p><a href=\"http://mashable.com/2016/09/23/tesla-solar-roof-launch/#_s0.gZ3NUGq4\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mashabletesla.gif?width=730&amp;height=296&amp;name=mashabletesla.gif\" alt=\"mashabletesla.gif\" width=\"730\" height=\"296\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></a></p> \n<p>Here’s a shorter news <a href=\"http://mashable.com/2016/09/23/tesla-solar-roof-launch/#_s0.gZ3NUGq4\">article</a> from Mashable, the blog-turned-news outlet that covers anything and everything related to the technology in our lives. This article does a great job of balancing the needs of both skim-readers and close-readers with its comprehensive overview without overwhelming readers.</p> \n<p><strong>Why this works so well:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>The article incorporates tweets and external content</strong> from Elon Musk’s <a href=\"https://www.tesla.com/blog/master-plan-part-deux\">master plan</a> to make the article more diverse and visually interesting.</li> \n <li><strong>The article uses visuals</strong>, which are more memorable than text alone according to the <a href=\"http://www.huffingtonpost.com/randy-krum/the-key-to-infographic-ma_b_6510744.html\">picture superiority effect</a>.</li> \n <li><strong>It has a</strong> <strong>clear headline</strong> that tells the story of the article if readers don’t make it to the end, which <a href=\"http://www.copyblogger.com/magnetic-headlines/\">Copyblogger</a> tells us only 20% will.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><i>Social Media Shares: 2.2K</i></p> \n<a></a> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Research Content</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/reports/the-future-of-content-marketing?&amp;_ga=1.71875027.1733063552.1465306056#LINK2\">Based on our survey</a>, readers are looking for original research that can be consumed thoroughly, but also easily understood. Research publications should look to other trends in content marketing, such as the increased interest in visual elements, to guide their research strategy.</p> \n<h4>7) <a href=\"https://chartbeat.com/\">Chartbeat</a></h4> \n<p><a href=\"http://blog.chartbeat.com/2016/08/31/when-should-you-post-on-social-media/\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Chartbeat_research_content.png?width=730&amp;height=1910&amp;name=Chartbeat_research_content.png\" alt=\"Chartbeat_research_content.png\" width=\"730\" height=\"1910\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></a></p> \n<p>Here’s a short and sweet research article from the folks over at Chartbeat. If you’re producing research content at your organization, there are a few strategies you can test to get more readers looking at your work.</p> \n<p><strong>Why this works so well:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>It uses effective data visualization. </strong><a href=\"http://www.brainrules.net/vision\">According to Brain Rules</a>, relevant images accompanied by reading or hearing information helps us remember 65% of the information days later -- when we read text alone, we only remember 10%.</li> \n <li><strong>It uses color, </strong>which is an important factor when it comes to creating visual elements: Color improves content readership, recall, and attention span by roughly <a href=\"http://www.office.xerox.com/latest/COLFS-02UA.PDF\">80%</a>.</li> \n <li><strong>Text is broken up</strong> with quickly digestible images, like the clearly captioned graphs above. This is important because research shows that readers might only read <a href=\"https://www.nngroup.com/articles/how-little-do-users-read/\" style=\"font-weight: 400;\">20%</a> of an article’s text, while scanning the rest.</li> \n <li><strong>The content is actionable.</strong> Readers want to come away knowing <a href=\"http://feldmancreative.com/2016/06/make-written-content-great/\">how to apply</a> the results of findings to their own strategies.</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>8) <a href=\"http://www.nielsen.com/us/en.html\">Nielsen</a></h4> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.nielsen.com/us/en/insights/reports/2016/whats-in-our-food-and-on-our-minds.html\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Nielsen_Research_Content.png?width=730&amp;height=1301&amp;name=Nielsen_Research_Content.png\" alt=\"Nielsen_Research_Content.png\" width=\"730\" height=\"1301\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></a></p> \n<p>Here’s another cool graphical breakdown of research from Nielsen, which researches consumer and media behaviors around the world. They conducted detailed research about global eating habits and how they’ve evolved according to demographic and socioeconomic changes around the world, but the published results aren’t lengthy. It’s easy to scan this research and quickly glean the results without poring over a huge paper.</p> \n<p><strong>Why this works so well:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>The headline inspires curiosity</strong> in the reader and takes advantage of a phenomenon known as <a href=\"https://blog.kissmetrics.com/headline-psychology/\">the curiosity gap</a>, which makes readers <a href=\"https://www.cmu.edu/dietrich/sds/docs/loewenstein/PsychofCuriosity.pdf\">more likely</a> to click and learn new information.</li> \n <li><strong>The research article uses information-carrying images, </strong>such as graphs, infographics, and charts, which readers typically pay <a href=\"https://www.nngroup.com/articles/photos-as-web-content/\">more attention to</a> than the rest of the text on the page.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Online Classes/Educational Games</h3> \n<h4>9) <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn\">CodeAcademy</a></h4> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/codeacademy_.png?width=1024&amp;name=codeacademy_.png\" alt=\"codeacademy_.png\" width=\"1024\" style=\"width: 1024px;\"></p> \n<p>CodeAcademy’s online coding classes are easy, portable, and, most importantly, free. Anyone can sign up for these interactive lessons and see the website, game, or program they’re building as they complete each module so they can see their finished product.</p> \n<p><strong>Why they work so well:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>The classes meet a demand</strong>: CodeAcademy teaches Java, SQL, and Python, which are among the <a href=\"http://blog.edx.org/the-3-most-lucrative-programming-skills-you-can-learn-online-for-free\">most popular coding skills</a> in terms of their demand in the workplace.</li> \n <li><strong>The classes have clear course objectives and are easy to use</strong>, which, according to an Eduventures <a href=\"http://www.eduventures.com/2015/06/why-online-students-succeed/\">survey</a>, were students’ top priorities when pursuing online classes. CodeAcademy’s bare bones platform is split so that students can always see an overview on the left-hand side of what they’re studying and how it will help them long-term.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><em>Users: 24 million</em></p> \n<h4>10) <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/certification\">HubSpot Academy Certifications</a></h4> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot_academy-3.png?width=730&amp;height=349&amp;name=hubspot_academy-3.png\" alt=\"hubspot_academy-3.png\" width=\"730\" height=\"349\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>HubSpot Academy Certifications are free online training courses centered around the development of marketing and sales skills. The Inbound Marketing Certification course, for example, provides folks with an opportunity to invest in their career by staying up-to-date on the latest marketing best practices.</p> \n<p><strong>Why they work so well:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>The classes are self-paced.</strong> <a href=\"http://www.irrodl.org/index.php/irrodl/article/view/603/1178\">This approach represents a growing trend</a> in the e-learning space, as it allows student the flexbility they need to work around their schedules.</li> \n <li><strong>The classes meet a demand.</strong> The HubSpot Academy Certifications cover critical areas such as inbound marketing, sales, and email marketing -- some of the <a href=\"https://www.quicksprout.com/2016/09/09/the-9-digital-marketing-skills-in-high-demand-right-now/\">most in-demand skills</a> in the marketing and advertising industries.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><em>Users: 50K</em></p> \n<h3>Common Themes for Marketers</h3> \n<p>That was a lot of information. Let’s review some common themes and takeaways that you can apply to your content strategy after finishing this article:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Keep video content short and sweet. Ideally, it won’t require sound to be played.</li> \n <li>Video content should answer a question or meet a demand that lots of people are looking for.</li> \n <li>Humor (when appropriate) makes for memorable content.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/visual-content-marketing-strategy#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">Images and videos</a> are key to more engaging social media posts.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-proof-examples#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">Social proof</a> helps beef up claims behind your content.</li> \n <li>Experiment with user-generated content for greater social media engagement.</li> \n <li>Use clear, grabbing <a href=\"https://library.hubspot.com/datadriven-strategies-titles-headlines\">headlines</a> to draw the attention of readers.</li> \n <li>Use images, bullets, and formatting to break up text in longer articles for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/examples-skimmable-content\">skim-reading</a>.</li> \n <li>Make content actionable so readers can come away knowing what to do next.</li> \n <li>Use graphs and <a href=\"https://library.hubspot.com/how-to-create--use-beautiful-infographics-in-your-marketing\">infographics</a> to display numerical data when possible.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Now that you know how to create different types of content that 2016 readers are looking for, check out the rest of our <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/reports/the-future-of-content-marketing\">content marketing research</a>, and learn key tips and tricks for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/difference-between-good-and-great-content#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">writing great content</a> today.</p> \n<p><i>What’s your favorite type of content? Are you more likely to skim-read some types of content more than others? Share with us in the comments below.</i></p>   \n<img (Sophia Bernazzani)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ContentTypes-1.png?width=1500&name=ContentTypes-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn41@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118311994_e6ab97304e42b83b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/types_of_content-1.png?width=669&name=types_of_content-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn17@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118305860_f2e010d98c3d011e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/thorough_vs._skim_read.png?width=730&height=383&name=thorough_vs._skim_read.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn93@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118307921_cdd9049315cf6d42.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/fedex2.png?width=730&height=467&name=fedex2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn17@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118313441_5a26d23bbaa03226.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/espngif.gif_final.gif?width=910&name=espngif.gif_final.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn21@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118305092_3ef285e4301ee995.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mashabletesla.gif?width=730&height=296&name=mashabletesla.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn37@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118305131_b4a10f71d6463d79.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Chartbeat_research_content.png?width=730&height=1910&name=Chartbeat_research_content.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn69@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118307169_9aeeba5644976c8a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Nielsen_Research_Content.png?width=730&height=1301&name=Nielsen_Research_Content.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn29@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118304883_569d2929fd335fd9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/codeacademy_.png?width=1024&name=codeacademy_.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn89@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118308021_543bfab8ce165a48.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot_academy-3.png?width=730&height=349&name=hubspot_academy-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn9@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118307433_d4167e4519020b57.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcontent-your-audience-actually-wants&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn57@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118311331_667f82c6a2e2c3f8.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:41","title":"Tried-and-True Tips for Sales and Marketing Alignment","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tried-and-true-sales-marketing-alignment","description":"<p>My interest in sales and marketing alignment best practices started when our Latin American sales team grew a <em>ton</em> in just a few weeks.</p> \n<p>Suddenly, communication between Sales and Marketing (nicknamed \"smarketing\") was much harder to get right. When we were a smaller team, I could meet one-on-one with each salesperson and talk about how we could help generate more (and better) leads ... but that wasn't scalable as we grew.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>I needed help. To learn what other marketers were doing to work efficiently with their sales teams, I scheduled meetings with several members of our field and channel marketing team.</p> \n<p>It turns out that each marketer I spoke with had great advice and processes to better work with Sales ... but none of them had the <em>same</em> advice and process.</p> \n<p>To help share the information across our team and with anyone else new to Sales and Marketing alignment, I decided to compile everyone's best practices into a blog post.</p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Sales Alignment</h2> \n<p>Before we dive into those best practices, however, let's take a second and discuss Sales alignment. Sales alignment refers to the steps your sales team takes to ensure they're aligned with Marketing. Here are a few Sales alignment strategies.</p> \n<h3>Organize Sales around buyer personas.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research\">Buyer personas</a> aren't just valuable to Marketing; they also educate Sales on who they're selling to, what they care about, and how to help them. Consider your buyer personas as you organize your sales team, create sales enablement materials, set up your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/sales/crm-ready-sales-email-templates\">CRM email templates</a>.</p> \n<h3>Designate staff to receive and qualify leads.</h3> \n<p>One avenue through which Sales and Marketing will always be connected is through lead sharing. As Marketing generates leads through content offers and campaigns, they pass them to Sales to qualify, nurture, and convert.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Who on your Sales team accepts <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/definition-marketing-qualified-lead-mql-under-100-sr\">marketing qualified leads</a>? If you can't answer that question in five seconds flat, you need to review your Sales team structure and designate someone (if not a small team) to receive and assign these leads. If there's one place where Sales and Marketing need to be aligned, this is it.</p> \n<h3>Facilitate training between teams if needed.</h3> \n<p>Have Sales hold product demonstrations for Marketing (perhaps the same ones they give prospective customers). Alternatively, ask Sales if they have had some trouble with specific questions during their calls. Smarketing is just as much about education as it is about alignment.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Sales and Marketing Best Practices</h2> \n<p>Here are some of the best smarketing tips and tricks that my colleagues use.</p> \n<h3>1. Meet regularly.</h3> \n<p>The best way for Sales and Marketing to stay connected is to, well, stay connected. Regular meetings are an effective way to avoid siloing these teams.</p> \n<h4>Have an onboarding smarketing meeting with every new salesperson.</h4> \n<p>In order to support Sales successfully, it is very important to share processes, resources, and best practices from the start. Use this time to get to know each other and share how Marketing will be supporting the sales team. If you have a large number of salespeople starting, hold a monthly meeting to set these expectations and field any questions new folks might have.</p> \n<h4>Attend sales weekly meetings.</h4> \n<p>Attending weekly sales meetings allows marketers to know how Sales is doing with their quota and goals, and offer support when needed. Use this time to share the upcoming campaigns, content, and offers that Marketing will be promoting that week. Also ask for content ideas and recommendations for your future offers and blog posts.</p> \n<h4>Have a monthly meeting with sales managers.</h4> \n<p>Marketing and sales managers should meet on a monthly basis to analyze results and evaluate their SLA. Important metrics to share are lead generation, MQLs, percent of leads worked, and lead-to-customer conversion rate.</p> \n<h4>Attend events together.</h4> \n<p>Whether it's an industry meetup group, happy hour in your office, or an organized conference — spend time together in a casual setting. Attending an event together provides you with a unique opportunity to get to know your Sales department outside of the traditional work environment.</p> \n<h3>2. Create a team email alias.</h3> \n<p>Have an email alias that gets sent to both Sales and Marketing teams. Use this strategically to share important information in both directions. This also allows external teams to share pertinent information with both groups.</p> \n<h3>3. Have a content creation process in place.</h3> \n<p>Your sales reps are talking with prospects all the time and know what is getting them excited about your company. The problem is that a lot of times they don't have time to write down this feedback. How can you help? Make sure to put together a process to gather this input.</p> \n<h4>Hold brainstorm sessions at weekly meetings.</h4> \n<p>Have a five-minute brainstorm session at a sales meeting to ask what content they would like to have to share with prospects or attract more leads.</p> \n<h4>Use a shared Google document to collect ideas and references.</h4> \n<p>Have a shared Google spreadsheet where Sales can add ideas or certain references for content creation.</p> \n<h3>4. Coordinate your content marketing campaigns with Sales.</h3> \n<p>Marketers are constantly promoting new offers and content, so it's important to keep the sales team up-to-date with these promotions so they know what recent offer their leads are receiving.</p> \n<p>Here are the basic steps for coordinating your offers with Sales:</p> \n<h4>Include your promotion on a shared calendar.</h4> \n<p>Build a Google Calendar and add the date and time of your promotion (it might be an email, webinar, or social media campaign) along with the URL, the main talking points, and description of each offer. Make sure to invite your sales team to this calendar so they can see it on their personal accounts.</p> \n<h4>Email the offer to Sales.</h4> \n<p>Once your offer has been promoted and you start getting leads, you should email the sales team with the following information:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Offer talking points. </strong>Include two to three bullets about the offer. Assume the salesperson hasn't read the offer — what main concepts should they know when talking to prospects? Good talking points usually include: stats, business use cases, or \"how to\" advice.</li> \n <li><strong>Lead views. </strong>Make sure to include the list of the leads your offer is generating so Sales can take action. If you have <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/crm?utm_campaign=Marketing-Blog-CTA&amp;utm_source=Marketing-blog&amp;utm_medium=Blog&amp;spc-source=blog\">a CRM,</a> you can easily generate views and share them with your sales team.</li> \n <li><strong>A quote of the week. </strong>Similar to the talking points, including a more general quote that Sales can use on their calls can keep the conversations up-to-date. The best quotes are the ones that are data-driven and relevant, so try to include a recent industry trend or stat.</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Build follow-up email templates for your promotions.</h4> \n<p>Offers are a great way to generate new leads <em>and</em> re-engage old leads. Build <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-email-templates-from-hubspot-reps\">email templates for your sales team</a> to start a conversation. This email should be specific about the offer and how your company might help with the prospect's interest.</p> \n<h3>5. Set shared goals — together.</h3> \n<p>Historically, Sales and Marketing function with different key performance indicators (KPIs) and, therefore, different goals. Most goals are separate — Sales may be focused on monthly revenue while Marketing hones in on website traffic.</p> \n<p>A good smarketing strategy prioritizes shared goals, too. There are a few KPIs — like conversion rate and lead value — that both teams can measure and influence. Identify these KPIs for your sales and marketing teams can work towards.</p> \n<h3>6. Share your reporting and analysis.</h3> \n<p>What do your sales and marketing teams track and measure? What do they learn from their analysis? Just as you keep your communication and ideation channels open between Marketing and Sales, make sure each team shares their learnings, too. You never know what your salespeople and marketers could learn from seemingly unrelated KPIs and analyses.</p> \n<h3>7. Help showcase your salesperson's expertise.</h3> \n<p>Marketing is responsible for promoting all aspects of your company, including your products, brand, and salespeople&nbsp; — the folks your prospective customers will connect with and, hopefully, trust. Leverage your marketing resources to showcase your sales team's expertise.</p> \n<h4>Ghostwrite a blog post under your salesperson's name.</h4> \n<p>Consider <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ghostwriting-tips\">ghostwriting a post</a> under your salesperson's name. Interview them on the topic, transcribe your conversation, and turn that into a blog post. This can help the salesperson establish credibility and familiarity with their leads.</p> \n<h4>Get them to use social media.</h4> \n<p>If your salesperson is active on social media, then encourage them to share your company's content. You can even write some lazy social media messages for them, so all they have to do is copy and paste them on their favorite networks.</p> \n<h3>8. Shadow sales calls.</h3> \n<p>Also, take some time to sit next to your sales team and listen to their calls. This is a great learning experience that will help you step into your sales team's shoes and see how they illustrate the business use of your product or service. You can also get ideas for future content creation and how to build some of the follow-up emails of your offers.</p> \n<h3>9. Organize sales enablement resources in one easy-to-access location.</h3> \n<p>Marketers work hard to create <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/sales-enablement\">sales enablement</a> resources such as brochures, company overviews, and presentations, but all that hard work goes to waste if your sales team can't find (and use) them.</p> \n<p>So try to keep all your sales enablement resources in one shared place where Sales can easily access them. This location is a great place to also host your campaign calendar, links to relevant offers, and specific content for a market or persona.</p> \n<h3>10. Have fun and get to know each other.</h3> \n<p>Finally, some of the most important advice is to try to get to know each other as people. Organize lunches, outings, and celebrations, and just have fun. This helps build trust among team members and ensures that people feel comfortable leaning on each other for support.</p> \n<p>Need help coming up with an outing idea? <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/creative-team-outing-ideas#sm.0001ralmokx9oe96wpl15ahh67v4e\">Check out this list of 17 fun ideas</a> — from improv workshops to karaoke.</p> \n<h2>Sales + Marketing = Smarketing</h2> \n<p>Aligning your sales and marketing team helps both teams reach their goals <em>and</em> boost company revenue. Apply these sales and marketing best practices to improve your smarketing strategy.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in October 2015 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftried-and-true-sales-marketing-alignment&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
