\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 20 Jul 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/GettyImages-1155230435.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"99fb1b7679d3580693357e1fdd9064c4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn45@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118303933_4c9146bebc957924.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/GettyImages-1155230435.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"csamsing@hubspot.com (Carolina Samsing)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftried-and-true-sales-marketing-alignment&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn69@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118313033_fd050b44f590f68d.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:41","title":"5 Things Gen Z Will Spend Money On & Why Marketers Need to Care","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-gen-z-spends-money-on","description":"<p>With a purchasing power of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/retail-courts-gen-z-spending-power-over-140-billion-2020-1\">more than $143 billion</a>, Gen Z is expected to shake up the retail industry.</p>  \n<p>Although many in Gen Z are earning their first paychecks, entering college, or just joining the workforce, <a href=\"https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.cnbc.com/amp/2019/09/17/gen-z-shopping-habits-can-fuel-a-brick-and-mortar-resurgence-report-says.html\">studies already show</a> that the generation shops and spends money much differently than its millennial predecessor.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>For example, while millennials enjoy <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z\">primarily shopping online</a>, Gen Z -- <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z\">an age group which is even more connected to technology</a> -- surprisingly <a href=\"https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.cnbc.com/amp/2019/09/17/gen-z-shopping-habits-can-fuel-a-brick-and-mortar-resurgence-report-says.html\">prefers shopping in stores</a>. Additionally, while millennials and past generations were more loyal to brands, Gen Z is <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-shopping-habits-kill-brands-2019-7\">more interested in buying products that will give them the best value</a> based on their price.</p> \n<h2>Why is Gen Z so budget-conscious?</h2> \n<p>Why is Gen Z so conscientious about their spending habits? Mounting research suggests that the age groups' thoughts on money link directly to the economic era they were raised in.</p> \n<p>While millennials grew up in more stable financial times, most of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z\">Gen Z's earliest memories took place during the U.S. recession</a>. Much of this generation grew up in highly budgeted households or saw how their families were impacted by economic troubles.</p> \n<p>Meanwhile, a large percentage of millennials, as well as those in other age groups. are able to recollect times where their economy was booming. Organizations including the Pew Research Center say these eras have psychologically molded how each generation thinks differently about money. While researchers believe both millennials and Gen Z are money conscious, with goals of avoiding financial instability, millennials are considered to be \"more optimistic\" future finances.</p> \n<p>As Gen Z ages, studies and purchasing behaviors hint that they haven't been able to shake their concerns of financial instability. Much research shows that to get Gen Z to invest in a product or service, the offering needs to be so valuable to them that they can justify purchasing it.</p> \n<p>In recent years, data about Gen Z's purchasing habits have concerned many brands and marketers, especially those that rely on frills and brand loyalty to sell their products. Many have also asked, \"If Gen Z is focused on saving money, what will they actually buy?\"</p> \n<p>Luckily, there's plenty of data that reveals which products are most valuable to Gen Z. This data can help marketers learn more about Gen Z's purchasing motives and execute on campaigns that better acknowledge how their products can be valuable to those in the age group.</p> \n<p>To help brands market to Gen Z when they reach full purchasing power, here’s a list of five items, services, or product categories you can expect them to invest in.</p> \n<h2>5 Things Gen Z Will Spend Money On</h2> \n<h3>1. Gen Z will spend money on education.</h3> \n<p>While millennials are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z\">one of the most highly educated age groups</a>, Gen Z is on track to have the <a href=\"https://www.pewsocialtrends.org/2018/11/15/early-benchmarks-show-post-millennials-on-track-to-be-most-diverse-best-educated-generation-yet/\">best level of education</a>. At this point, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z\">Gen Z's already been shown</a> to start saving for college at a much younger age than millennials.</p> \n<p>As members of the generation enroll in college or begin to spend their own money, news outlets have <a href=\"https://www.retaildive.com/news/back-to-school-spending-expected-to-reach-record-highs/559137/\">predicted and reported</a> bursts in school-related purchases fueled by Gen Z shoppers.</p> \n<p>Aside from purchasing supplies, Gen Z is also likely to invest in courses or educational programs that will advance their future earnings. In fact, while <a href=\"https://learning.linkedin.com/blog/learning-thought-leadership/gen-z-is-shaping-a-new-era-of-learning--heres-what-you-should-kn\">62% of Gen Z</a> will take classes or learn new skills if it makes them better at their job, <a href=\"https://learning.linkedin.com/blog/learning-thought-leadership/gen-z-is-shaping-a-new-era-of-learning--heres-what-you-should-kn\">59% will do the same</a> if it will boost their salary.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&amp;%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care.png?width=600&amp;name=5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&amp;%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care.png\" alt=\"Why gen Z will learn new skills\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://learning.linkedin.com/blog/learning-thought-leadership/gen-z-is-shaping-a-new-era-of-learning--heres-what-you-should-kn\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>In fact, due to the rising costs of college, most of Gen Z has deprioritized non-essential purchases just to <a href=\"https://learn.joinhandshake.com/our-team/gen-z-pragmatism-about-the-coming-job-market-debt/\">save money for academic investments</a>.</p> \n<p>Gen Z's interest in saving money and frugal purchasing behaviors aren't that shocking. <a href=\"https://learn.joinhandshake.com/our-team/gen-z-pragmatism-about-the-coming-job-market-debt/\">One recent study</a> projects that three-quarters of Gen Z will have student loans at graduation. More than <a href=\"https://learn.joinhandshake.com/our-team/gen-z-pragmatism-about-the-coming-job-market-debt/\">60% of the age group</a> is also expected to have college debt beyond $25,000.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, many researchers believe that Gen Z's interest in academia is rooted in <a href=\"https://learn.joinhandshake.com/our-team/gen-z-pragmatism-about-the-coming-job-market-debt/\">their need for financial stability</a>. Many in the age group believe that a <a href=\"https://learning.linkedin.com/blog/learning-thought-leadership/gen-z-is-shaping-a-new-era-of-learning--heres-what-you-should-kn\">good education will lead to a great job with high pay</a>.</p> \n<p>As a marketer, it's important to keep Gen Z's budgeting and educational goals in mind. This generation wants to learn new things, is saving for college, and prioritizes investments that better their future. You'll need to convince them that your product is worth buying -- even when they're putting most of their money into a college fund.</p> \n<p>As you create your product promotions or campaigns, consider how your product could help or benefit the experiences of someone planning for college, college students, or young professionals.</p> \n<p>If your product isn't specifically geared towards education, your campaigns could zone in on how it could improve a college or work-life experience. For example, if you're marketing furniture, you could create a promotion that highlights products that would fit in an apartment or dorm room. Or, if you market a clothing company, you could highlight clothing items that could be worn in a job interview in a blog post on your website.</p> \n<p>Aside from creating content that directly links your product to career interests or academics, you can also lean into Gen Z's need to learn new things by developing educational content that teaches audiences about your industry. After viewing your educational content, audiences might want to learn more about your product and develop a stronger sense of trust for your brand. Later, if they're interested in buying a product related to your brand's industry, they might consider your brand first.</p> \n<p>If you want to leverage educational content, keep the age range of your audience in mind. While younger members of Gen Z might be primarily interested in B2C brand content due to their college or high-school age, Gen Zers entering internships or the workforce might value educational B2B content that can show them how to get ahead in their industry.</p> \n<h3>2. Gen Z will splurge on experiences.</h3> \n<p>Despite being linked to heavy social media use, researchers say most of Gen Z <a href=\"https://www.campaignlive.com/article/report-gen-z-chooses-spend-hours-away-social-media/1585629\">likes to take breaks from social media and screens from time to time</a>.</p> \n<p>In a recent study, <a href=\"https://www.campaignlive.com/article/report-gen-z-chooses-spend-hours-away-social-media/1585629\">95% of Gen Z participants under 24</a> admitted to feeling stressed \"somewhat often\" or \"very often.\" Participants then pointed to online activity, homework, and finances as triggers that have caused physical or emotional signs of stress.</p> \n<p>To ease stress, <a href=\"https://www.campaignlive.com/article/report-gen-z-chooses-spend-hours-away-social-media/1585629\">many participants of the study</a> said they took breaks from screen time, read books, or left their home to find in-person experiences.</p> \n<p>According to <a href=\"https://forbusiness.snapchat.com/blog/the-youth-of-the-nations-global-trends-among-gen-z\">Snap Inc. and GlobalWebIndex</a>, Gen Z is actually more intrigued by experiences than millennials. For example, Gen Z is more likely to <a href=\"https://forbusiness.snapchat.com/blog/the-youth-of-the-nations-global-trends-among-gen-z\">view local art and try out adventure or extreme sports activities</a> than millennials. Below are just a few of Gen Z's top overall interests, according to the study:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&amp;%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care-1.png?width=600&amp;name=5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&amp;%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care-1.png\" alt=\"Gen Z's top five interests\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://forbusiness.snapchat.com/blog/the-youth-of-the-nations-global-trends-among-gen-z\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>While Gen Z values products and services that will benefit their future and help them navigate major pain points, they also still like to budget time and money for experiences <a href=\"https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/d3kd7q/we-asked-gen-z-about-their-spending-habits\">such as dining out, local excursions, or occasional travel</a>.</p> \n<p>Although Gen Z will invest in something that will offer them positive life experience, you should still keep the age group's budget conscientiousness in mind if you're marketing something to them. Because they care about cost and value, Gen Z members <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z\">might heavily research</a> a restaurant, excursion, or travel service before spending money on it.</p> \n<p>If you're a brand that sells excursion or in-person experiences, simply placing a few colorful stock photos on your website might not pull in Gen Z. You might have to take a step further by including detailed information about your offerings, highlighting <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/happy-customers-marketing-opportunity\">positive reviews</a>, and even <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-strategy-guide\">launching a blog</a> that provides more information and demonstrates your credibility.</p> \n<p>If your brand sells physical items rather than excursions, consider creating messaging that highlights how your products can improve or boost an experience.</p> \n<p>For example, if you sell coffee, you could create an ad showing a tired young adult energizing themselves with a sip of coffee before a day of adventuring in the wilderness. Or, if you sell clothing, your ads could highlight how they're perfect for outings like vacations or nice dinners out. Regardless of the product, tell a story about an experience Gen Z is interested in and then explain how your product can help them.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">3. Gen Z prioritizes essential products, services, and utilities.</h3> \n<p>Like millennials, life experiences and education matter to Gen Z. However, as a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/happy-customers-marketing-opportunitygeneration\">frugal </a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/happy-customers-marketing-opportunitygeneration\">generation</a>, the age group still wants to make sure they have enough money for essential products such as food, health products, and home supplies.</p> \n<p>Putting essential budgeting first was a clear theme that <a href=\"https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.vice.com/amp/en_us/article/d3kd7q/we-asked-gen-z-about-their-spending-habits\">Vice</a> discovered when its journalists interviewed a handful of Gen Z members about their lifestyle and purchasing habits. <a href=\"https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.vice.com/amp/en_us/article/d3kd7q/we-asked-gen-z-about-their-spending-habits\">Almost all of the participants</a> explained that they would invest more in essential products rather than buying products related to fun, entertainment, fashion, or fan loyalty.</p> \n<p>If your brand sells essential products, like food, cleaning supplies, or medication, there are two things you'll want to do.</p> \n<p>First, create marketing content that acknowledges and reminds Gen Z audiences of why your products are so essential and worth budgeting for.</p> \n<p>Second, keep in mind that even if your products are essential, Gen Zers might still research them, read the box before making a purchase, or compare them to other items in the same aisle. Because many brands make essential products, you'll want to create messaging that notes why your product is more effective or a better bargain than all the other versions of it out there.</p> \n<p>If your brand doesn't sell an essential product, it's even more important to create marketing materials that establish a need for your product, how it can help customers solve for daily pain points, and why it's worth a Gen Z member's hard-earned money. Remember that Gen Z's first purchasing priority might not be your product, then think of ways you can still grab their attention anyways.</p> \n<p>Not sure how to establish a sense of need when your product isn't essential? Below is an example of content from InfoArmor, an information security service owned by Allstate. In <a href=\"https://twitter.com/InfoArmor/status/1249763745435435009\">the recent tweet</a>, InfoArmor shared a blog post about the dangers of information security when working remotely and how InfoArmor could protect remote employee information.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&amp;%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care-2.png?width=600&amp;name=5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&amp;%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care-2.png\" alt=\"infoarmor tweet designating why people need to. purchase a product\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>When reading the tweet or the blog post attached to it, a person in Gen Z or any age group might identify where they might run into information security risks and might consider purchasing the product to keep their information safe.</p> \n<p>On average, <a href=\"https://forbusiness.snapchat.com/blog/the-youth-of-the-nations-global-trends-among-gen-z\">Gen Z spends more than four hours per day</a> online, which trumps past generations -- <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z\">including millennials</a>. As the most hyper-connected generation that's existed so far, it's not shocking to think that Gen Z will spend money on technology. However, because they're financially conscious, many in the age group will prioritize buying the most essential or useful technologies. For example, nearly <a href=\"https://forbusiness.snapchat.com/blog/the-youth-of-the-nations-global-trends-among-gen-z\">100% of Gen Z own a smartphone, 70% own a computer, and 30% own a tablet</a>.</p> \n<h3>Gen Z will invest in technology.</h3> \n<p>Aside from technological essentials, Gen Z will occasionally splurge on technological experiences that help them have fun, such as video games. In fact, a 2019 study found that <a href=\"https://teamwhistle.com/\">two-thirds of Gen Z men</a> say gaming is a \"core component\" of who they are.</p> \n<p>While you might worry that Gen Z isn't worth marketing to because they won't splurge on your products, this age group certainly can be persuaded to make larger purchases that offer fun experiences or improve their daily lives.</p> \n<p>But, even though they will invest in higher-priced products, Gen Z will still need thorough convincing before pulling out their wallets. As noted above, it's incredibly important for brands targeting Gen Z to create content that demonstrates why the age group needs their product, how the product could solve daily boredom or woes, and why it's better than a competitor's.</p> \n<p>For example, although some consumers might consider <a href=\"https://www.fitbit.com/us/home\">Fitbit fitness trackers</a> frivolous, this brand does a great job of explaining why their product can be a necessary tool to use within a fitness routine.</p> \n<p>On social media, Fitbit gives facts about why walking and cardio -- two activities the bracelet can track -- are important to health. And, <a href=\"https://blog.fitbit.com/fitbit-premium-wellness-report/?utm_source=TWITTER&amp;utm_medium=social&amp;utm_campaign=USA+-+CA_64280_2961885792_20200130171400_Educate_Product+News+%26+Updates&amp;linkId=79296620\">in a November blog post</a>, Fitbit more deeply connected its product to health needs by discussing how its reporting software could help people communicate better with their doctors.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>While Fitbit doesn't claim its product is necessary for health, the brand shows audiences how the product can be used to help them track their fitness needs and progress.</p> \n<p>When a pessimistic or budget-conscious Gen-Z member researches Fitbit, they might find its content informative and helpful. From there, if they're interested in a healthier lifestyle, they might realize that Fitbit is a credible brand that could help them with their fitness needs.</p> \n<h3>Gen Z prefers to buy low-priced clothing.</h3> \n<p>A recent <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-shopping-habits-kill-brands-2019-7\">Business Insider</a> report revealed that Gen Z isn't easily persuaded by a logo when it comes to clothing. In fact, unlike other generations, brand loyalty is <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-shopping-habits-kill-brands-2019-7\">one of the last things they think about</a> when making a purchasing decision. What the generation does focus on is price and value.</p> \n<p>In the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-shopping-habits-kill-brands-2019-7\">Business Insider report</a>, a 20-year-old named Amanda Chermin explained, \"I can't afford nicer brands of clothes -- I like to save and would rather have money in the bank than be broke.\"</p> \n<p>Instead of splurging on the hottest brand from New York Fashion Week, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-shopping-habits-kill-brands-2019-7\">the age group</a>, which also prefers to shop in stores, is more likely to purchase cheaper clothing that's either not from a name brand, on clearance, or re-sold.</p> \n<p>Although they aren't loyal to the same stores and brands <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-shopping-habits-kill-brands-2019-7\">millennials zoned in on</a>, Gen Z still feels pressure to buy and wear clothing that's considered good quality or fashionable. Aside from purchasing affordable clothing, the need to look their best has also led to many in Gen Z to invest <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-shopping-habits-kill-brands-2019-7\">in clothing rental services</a> or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/try-before-you-buy\">try-before-you-buy shopping experiences</a>.</p> \n<p>Although Gen Z is expected to spend <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-shopping-habits-kill-brands-2019-7\">less money on clothing than other generations</a>, researchers believe they still feel pressure to look good in front of their peers. These pressures, which might stem from <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-shopping-habits-kill-brands-2019-7\">social media, school, work, or social environments</a> will still drive the age group to clothing stores or ecommerce sites. While retail marketers should expect shifts in spending behaviors from this generation, Gen Z will still buy clothing that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-shopping-habits-kill-brands-2019-7\">looks good on them, is good quality, and has an affordable price</a>.</p> \n<p>The themes related to clothing purchases are important to keep in mind -- even if you aren't marketing clothing products. As we've established, Gen Zers are always looking for a good bargain and won't use just a brand name to justify a purchase. Regardless of how popular or well-known your brand is, you'll still need to highlight why your products are better than cheaper versions from competitors.</p> \n<p>Although your logo might not persuade Gen Z to buy your product, you can still use authentic brand trust and popularity to your advantage. Although Gen Z is budget-conscious, they also care about what their peers think of them. This means that they might still feel a need to splurge on a product, such as a clothing item, if they know that people in their age group have it.</p> \n<p>If you're marketing to Gen Z, consider asking popular influencers or happy young adult customers to discuss your product on social media. An authentic product review will not only build a sense of brand trust, but it will also show Gen Z audiences that the product is popular and being used by people they follow. From there, a Gen Z member might research or purchase a product simply because it's more popular or has better reviews than a cheaper alternative.</p> \n<h1>How to Market to a Money-Conscious Generation</h1> \n<p>Based on research noted above, Gen Z is less likely to splurge on frivolous products or brand names. As a marketer, hearing about these mounting studies might make you nervous.</p> \n<p>But, in the long run, the consumer trend of putting value first shouldn't scare or shock you. In fact, it should motivate you to ask, “How can I provide better value to my customers?”</p> \n<p>Although Gen Z might seem more budget-conscious, this doesn’t mean they won’t buy anything from you at all. In fact, many of your most frugal prospects will still buy, invest in, or splurge on your brand's offerings if they seem valuable, help them solve pain points, or provide a positive, memorable experience.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, bettering your brand, focusing on the customer experience, and promoting positive company reviews will go a long way with Gen Z and all other audiences.</p> \n<p>Interested in learning more about Gen Z? Check out these stats pieces on their <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/gen-z-stats\">demographics</a> and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/gen-z-workforce-stats\">their workforce aspirations</a>. You can also read more about their <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-gen-z-searches-for-content\">online content consumption habits her</a></p> \n<p>If you’re looking to learn about both Gen Z and millennials, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z\">check out this comparison piece</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhat-gen-z-spends-money-on&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 20 Jul 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/things-gen-z-will-spend-money-on.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"2b4f8416f51ceaf45cc9389bc6b62291","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn81@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118303752_6107e5d51252ed3f.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/things-gen-z-will-spend-money-on.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"pbump@hubspot.com (Pamela Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care.png?width=600&name=5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn46@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118310338_ba90012855a2dedd.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care-1.png?width=600&name=5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn62@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118310923_1a76fcb511fb667b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care-2.png?width=600&name=5%20Things%20Gen%20Z%20Will%20Spend%20Money%20On%20&%20Why%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Care-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn65@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118307119_ffeb53fb7d796d76.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhat-gen-z-spends-money-on&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn61@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118307721_b0ba4393422a33cd.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"Why You Need a Responsive Web Design and How to Do It [+ Examples]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/responsive-design-list","description":"<p><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">The insights from this article came from the </span><a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/website-optimization?utm_source=marketing_blog&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=website_optimization_blog\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">H</a><a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/website-optimization?utm_source=marketing_blog&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=website_optimization_blog\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">ubSpot Academy's Free Website Optimization Course</a><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">. Take the full course to learn more about responsive design and how to optimize your website's performance.</span></p> \n<p>Across the world, <a href=\"https://gs.statcounter.com/platform-market-share/desktop-mobile-tablet\">over 50%</a> of total internet activity is done on mobile devices. Desktops follow behind with a <a href=\"https://gs.statcounter.com/platform-market-share/desktop-mobile-tablet\">little over 45%</a> of total internet activity, and tablets make up the rest.</p> \n<p>Today, with so many people surfing the web from their phones, it's essential to offer a great mobile website experience. Without it, you can't cater to the majority of internet users, and are likely missing out on traffic and leads for your business as a result.</p> \n<p>So how do you create an effective mobile experience? That's where responsive design comes in.</p> \n<blockquote>\n Simply put, responsive web design is the method of designing web pages that appear in their optimized form across all devices.\n</blockquote> \n<p>In other words, a responsive design will automatically reformat your website for all screen sizes. This allows your website visitors to easily view and interact with your site no matter what device they're using.</p> \n<p>Here, let's explore how responsive design works, and take a look at some examples to inspire your own responsive web design in 2020.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>How does responsive design work?</strong></h2> \n<p>A website developed with responsiveness in-mind adjusts to the size of the device and browser to display the content appropriately. Breakpoints are set up to target ranges that define specific displays. For example, you generally see breakpoints for phones, tablets, and desktops.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D-1.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>There are a number of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/responsive-web-design\">responsive web design best practices</a> to follow:</p> \n<ol type=\"1\"> \n <li><strong>Buttons</strong>: A person's finger is much larger than the pointer on a computer screen. Buttons and hyperlinks should be at least 48 pixels wide and 48 pixels tall to ensure all users can click them.</li> \n <li><strong>SVGs</strong>: Scalable Vector Graphic Files define an image's shape in terms of vectors, meaning they can scale infinitely without losing quality image quality.</li> \n <li><strong>Responsive Images</strong>: Not all of your images are going to be SVGs. For these, you'll want to use CSS rules to automatically adjust the dimensions of the image to fit the users' screen size.</li> \n <li><strong>Fonts</strong>: Make sure that your font is legible across all devices. At a minimum, Google recommends using a base font size of 16 CSS pixels.</li> \n <li><strong>Device Features</strong>: While prospects and customers can't call you over their computers, they definitely can on their smartphones. Consider changing your “Chat Now!” CTA to “Call Now!” and include your business phone number in lieu of email.</li> \n <li><strong>Test</strong>: As always, test your responsive website on different devices and browsers. To see how your website is currently performing, check out <a href=\"https://website.grader.com/\">HubSpot's Website Grader tool</a>.</li> \n</ol> \n<h2><strong>Responsive Web Design vs. Isolated Mobile Web Pages</strong></h2> \n<p>There are two major methods for creating mobile websites: responsive design and mobile templates. Responsive design requires you only have one website that is coded to adapt to all screen sizes, no matter the device the website's being displayed on.</p> \n<p>In contrast, a mobile template is a completely separate entity requiring you to have a second, mobile-only website or subdomain. Mobile templates are also built for each specific site, not per screen size.</p> \n<p>Mobile-only websites can be great solutions for larger applications such as Facebook and Twitter, but for most businesses, a responsive website is much more cost-efficient, and easier to develop and maintain.</p> \n<p>Unlike isolated mobile websites, where you create a whole separate version of a website for mobile devices, responsive design adapts the layout to any screen size by using fluid, proportion-based grids. Responsive websites serve the same HTML to all devices and use CSS media queries to change how your website should look on each device.</p> \n<p>As the number of people surfing the web from their phones continues to climb, a responsive design will make your life as a marketer easier and your website more effective. A mobile-friendly website will save you money in the long run, deliver a great user experience, and perform better across all devices.</p> \n<h2><strong>Responsive Web Design Examples</strong></h2> \n<p>If you aren't using responsive web design already, then you're in luck because it's very easy nowadays to get started with it.</p> \n<p>For example, on the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms\">HubSpot CMS Hub</a> alone, there are hundreds of templates available for free or purchase that are all responsive right out of the box. Let's take a look at five remarkable examples of responsive web design in action from <a href=\"https://designers.hubspot.com/inspire/browse\">HubSpot developers</a> for some inspiration.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.gingrapp.com/\">Gingr</a>, a pet-care software company, outshines the competition.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.smartbugmedia.com/\">SmartBug Media</a> designed a new website for a pet-focused SaaS company, Gingr, that reflected the brand's fun voice while providing rich UX and mobile functionality. The design balances organic shapes with realistic imagery, which conveys and reinforces Gingr's unique solution and professional yet modern voice.</p> \n<p>To add texture without creating clutter, the site integrates shapes that play off Gingr's logo, as well as uses organic shapes that resemble animal hair. The website functions well across devices by reorganizing the page elements while keeping the CTA above-the-fold.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D-2.jpeg\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.sunspacetwincities.com\">Sunspace Twin Cities'</a> new website drives 40% increase in revenue.</h3> \n<p>Specializing in sunspace porch windows, Sunspace Twin Cities provides luxury porch windows to homeowners and contractors in Minnesota and Western Wisconsin.</p> \n<p>The website has a functional UX that makes the most out of the space available on desktop, tablets, and mobile devices. Both the header and body copy are clearly legible, and the simple design allows the website's content to speak for itself. Best of all, once the company updated their website's design, they saw a <a href=\"https://designers.hubspot.com/inspire/entry/new-website-drives-increase-in-revenue\">40% increase in revenue</a>.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.hongdaservice.com/\">Hongda Service</a>'s B2B website redesign.</h3> \n<p>It can be difficult to design a website that translates well cross-culturally. Hongda's management team knew that appealing to foreigners was paramount to their success as a China-based company, and they were happy to progress with HubSpot to generate more leads.</p> \n<p>The purpose of their design was to resonate with a Western audience. The blue primary and orange accent colors help this website stand out. Additionally, the site's elements are easy to engage with across devices.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D-1.jpeg\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h3>4. Energy sustainability platform <a href=\"https://www.net4energy.com/\">Net4energy</a> redesigns for both B2C and B2B customers.</h3> \n<p>Net4energy is a multisided platform that connects users who want to learn more about energy sustainability concepts and providers of products and services. Net4energy aims to inspire and educate users with guides, ebooks, and helpful content.</p> \n<p>With their responsive design, Net4energy is able to offer their content to audiences whether they're in the office or on-the-go. This example functions well because the header copy and CTA are resized to take up the right amount of space on each device without decreasing the readability or usability of the site.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D.jpeg\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://www.digitallunchbreak.nsw.gov.au/\">ACYP</a> creates a modular website design.</h3> \n<p>ACYP (the Advocate for Children and Young People) wanted to create a fresh new look for their website and the ability to manage it going forward. This required building page templates and modules using HubSpots's draggable module CMS function.</p> \n<p>The website uses a variety of modules that automatically adjust their width and height depending on the device they're being viewed on. The images resize to take up just the right amount of space so that the header and body copy are immediately visible, even on mobile.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D-3.jpeg\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>To learn more about how to create a high-performing website to grow traffic and leads, check out <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/website-optimization\">HubSpot Academy's free Website Optimization Course</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fresponsive-design-list&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 21 Jul 2020 18:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D-1.png","linkMd5":"a11f5f2790727a5ff75cdedc20eb6c92","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn57@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118301682_8f030a057ef77372.webp","author":"Corey Braccialini","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn57@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118301682_8f030a057ef77372.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D-2.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn57@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118312906_3872f0d03cc6c4c1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn98@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118310835_4f022e4f45829f95.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D-1.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn17@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118307558_45b4663e9e90a0e2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn25@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118307582_41a2e855a8427936.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Why%20You%20Need%20a%20Responsive%20Web%20Design%20and%20How%20to%20Do%20it%20%5Bwith%20examples%5D-3.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn17@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118310717_c95c2fa378a0269b.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fresponsive-design-list&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn21@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118311868_aba40ed095244968.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"How Video Consumption is Changing in 2020 [New Research]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-video-consumption-is-changing","description":"<p>In 2020, video is more important to consumers than ever before.</p>  \n<p>Each day, we stream our favorite shows, watch explainer videos on YouTube to learn something new, or follow events, Q&amp;As, and interviews via live video.</p> \n<p>Unsurprisingly, video content's current popularity is due in part <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.191150952.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">to millennial and Gen Z</a>&nbsp;consumers. These age groups are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.228898654.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">more connected to the internet</a>&nbsp;than older age groups,, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.228898654.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">prefer to be entertained or learn new things from online videos</a>.</p> \n<p>At this point, marketers know that they should be leveraging video in their marketing strategy. According to HubSpot's <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">2020 State of Marketing report</a>, video beat out heavyweight contenders like email, blogging, and infographics as the most used type of marketing content.</p> \n<p>The interest in video isn't surprising or new. Throughout the last century, we've seen video move from black and white televisions to smartphones and tablets. As consumers have seen this content become more available at our fingertips, brands have discovered a number of new ways to implement video in their marketing.</p> \n<p>Now, rather than relying on a commercial during our favorite sitcoms to learn about a product, we're inundated with marketing videos <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-platforms-through-the-decade?_ga=2.228898654.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">all over social media</a>, streaming apps, and search result pages.</p> \n<p>Video isn't going anywhere, but it is always expanding, changing, and evolving to fit new consumer needs and new platforms.</p> \n<p>As this content continues to evolve with each new generation, marketers should&nbsp;continue researching video consumers' interests, hobbies, and behaviors.</p> \n<p>In this blog post, I'll highlight six research-backed ways video consumption habits are changing and how marketers can respond strategically.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>How Video Consumption is Changing in 2020</h2> \n<h3>1. Consumers are beginning to rely on marketing videos from brands.</h3> \n<p>In the past, consumers would visit websites, look at online reviews, watch commercials, and maybe search out a few YouTube videos to learn about a product. Now, with video being accessible on every major social media network, they are learning to rely more heavily on this type of content in their research phase.</p> \n<p>While brands are seeing <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing?_ga=2.228898654.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">higher engagement than ever from video marketing</a>, consumers increasingly expect&nbsp;to see this type of content from brands. Even back in 2018, a whopping <a href=\"https://www.wyzowl.com/video-marketing-statistics-you-cant-ignore/#79%25_of_people_have_been_convinced_to_buy_a_piece_of_software_or_app_after_watching_a_brand%E2%80%99s_video\">87% of consumers</a>&nbsp;said they wanted to see more video from brands in the next year.</p> \n<p>In 2020, it's likely that the expectation of brands to provide marketing videos has gotten even stronger. Each day, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/state-of-video-marketing-new-data?_ga=2.228898654.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">consumers use product demos, video reviews, and unboxings</a>&nbsp;to learn about products before they buy them.</p> \n<p>What do increasing video content expectations mean for you as a marketer? Well, if a prospect is interested in a product or service in your industry, looks for video reviews or tutorials, and can't find any related to your brand's offering, they <a href=\"https://www.wyzowl.com/video-marketing-statistics-you-cant-ignore/#79%25_of_people_have_been_convinced_to_buy_a_piece_of_software_or_app_after_watching_a_brand%E2%80%99s_video\">might buy a product from another brand</a>.</p> \n<p>Why? Videos give consumers the opportunity to see how a product or service works in real life, discover any flaws before purchasing the item, and identify perks that they might not learn about in the text-based description. This content might also appear to be more authentic than a heavily edited product shot, which can boost a consumer's trust in a brand or offering.</p> \n<h3>2. Half of Gen Z and Millennials \"don't know how they'd get through life without video.\"</h3> \n<p>To some, this isn't that much of a shock. Each new generation <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z\">has watched more online video than the last</a>. However, when it comes to those under the age of 34, videos have more of an impact on daily life than ever before. In <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/feature/youtube-video-data-watching-habits/\">YouTube's survey</a>, 50% of people in both generations said they \"couldn't live\" without video in their daily lives.</p> \n<p>Aside from using video for entertainment, both millennials and Gen Z prefer to watch videos for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.128736974.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">information gathering purposes</a>. Even when it comes to learning about a new brand or product, these age groups prefer video explainers, product demos, or other marketing videos to simply reading about a company online.</p> \n<p>With <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.128736974.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">millennials nearing 40 and Gen Z beginning to gain full purchasing power</a>, there's a good chance that these two age groups will take up a major portion of your audience soon if they &nbsp;aren't already.</p> \n<p>At this point, marketers aiming to attract these two generations should consider testing out video strategies on social media or their own websites. While these age groups might regularly use video for entertainment purposes, it's also likely that they'll use it to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.128736974.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">learn more about products or brands worth investing in</a>. If there's a great video recommendation or tutorial out there for a product they're interested in, they might find it, watch it, and use that content to confirm that this purchase is right for them.</p> \n<h3>3. Video consumers want to relax -- or escape -- from daily life.</h3> \n<p>In the past, older generations might have turned on their favorite TV sitcom or gone to the movies to escape from the stresses of daily life. While the platforms have changed as younger consumers take over the video market, the instinctive need for relaxing or entertaining content hasn't.</p> \n<p>When asked to rank the reasons why consumers watch video content, <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/feature/youtube-video-data-watching-habits/\">YouTube survey </a>participants said they primarily watch videos in order to, \"relax and unwind.\" Additionally, the fourth most common reason that people watch videos is that the content makes them laugh. Additionally, people cited, \"Makes me forget about the world around me,\" as the seventh most common reason for watching videos.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"why consumers watch Youtube videos\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D.png?width=600&amp;name=How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D.png\" title=\"\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/feature/youtube-video-data-watching-habits/\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>As a marketer, you shouldn't put all of your time and money into just creating mindless content that will relax your viewers or give them a laugh. But, you can keep in mind that many viewers are still looking to be entertained or intrigued by your content.</p> \n<p>Even when you're creating an informative marketing video, you can consider experimenting with funny anecdotes or adding other entertaining qualities. Interested in adding fun elements to your next marketing video? <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/7-boring-big-brands-that-used-humor-to-amp-up-their-marketing?_ga=2.153195514.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">Get inspired by major brands</a>&nbsp;that effectively used humor in their marketing.</p> \n<h3>4. Consumers want to learn more about their niche and passions.</h3> \n<p>Aside from looking for escapism, <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/feature/youtube-video-data-watching-habits/\">YouTube viewers</a>&nbsp;are motivated to watch content that teaches them new things, especially when related to their passions, interests, hobbies, or social causes. While the second most common reasoning for watching a video was it, \"teaches me something new,\" people also said they prioritize content that allows them to \"dig deeper\" into their interests or \"relates to\" their passions.</p> \n<p>Odds are your product relates to someone's interests, hobbies, passions, or career. This is the type of person you'll want to watch and enjoy your videos.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research?_ga=2.153195514.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">Creating a buyer persona and target audience</a>&nbsp;around this type of person will help you identify video topics that they'll value, benefit from, and remember your brand for publishing.</p> \n<h3>5. Consumers don't care if your video looks like it has a big budget.</h3> \n<p>There's a common misconception that marketing videos need to feature the biggest Hollywood stars and must be shot in a high-priced studio. In 2020, as marketers are increasingly producing video remotely, this myth has definitely been debunked.</p> \n<p>But, if the evolving video marketing workforce hasn't convinced you that low-budget videos can still be effective, here's what YouTube discovered in its survey:</p> \n<p>When asking consumers to rank the top reasons they watched videos, surprisingly <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/feature/youtube-video-data-watching-habits/\">\"high production quality,\" and \"famous actors\"</a>&nbsp;neared the bottom of the list.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"top reasons consumers choose to watch a video\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-1.png?width=500&amp;name=How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-1.png\" title=\"\" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/feature/youtube-video-data-watching-habits/\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Aside from ranking high-budget video features as the least likely reasons for watching videos, millennials and Gen Z differ from older age groups in that they're more accepting of user-generated content over professionally made videos. This might hint that brands can leverage content created by their own customers or fans when creating marketing videos:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Consumers views on user generated content\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-3.png?width=400&amp;name=How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-3.png\" title=\"\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/feature/youtube-video-data-watching-habits/\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>At this point, there are plenty of ways to produce <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-make-a-video-ht?_ga=2.128758350.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">an affordable video with solid quality from any home or workspace</a>. And, while it will still take time and money to launch this content, effective marketing videos made anywhere can boost your level of brand awareness.</p> \n<h3>6. Younger generations are watching longer content.</h3> \n<p>The average Gen Z member has <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.153777914.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">an online attention span of eight seconds</a>. That's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.153777914.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">four seconds less than millennials</a>. But although Gen Z's attention span for general online surfing might be quite short, long-form videos that interest them can grasp their attention -- and keep it.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"video consumption demographics\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-2.png?width=600&amp;name=How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-2.png\" title=\"\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/feature/youtube-video-data-watching-habits/\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>The adoption of long-form content with each new generation isn't new. According to <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/feature/youtube-video-data-watching-habits/\">YouTube's study</a>, millennials also watched longer-form videos more often than their Gen X predecessors.</p> \n<p>As a marketer, you'll need to keep the attention spans of each new generation in mind as you set the pace for your video content.</p> \n<p>Your video has mere seconds to catch a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.153777914.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">millennial or Gen Z member's</a>&nbsp;attention as they're aimlessly scrolling through a social media feed. However, if your video captures viewers immediately and then continues to offer entertaining, valuable, or interesting information throughout, these age groups might watch the whole thing -- even if it is on the longer side.</p> \n<p>Before you put a marketing video online, re-watch it from the point-of-view of a somewhat busy consumer. Then, ask yourself, \"Does this video pull viewers into the action quickly and keep their attention?\" If you're worried that parts of your video seem dull, you might want to shorten it. But, if your team thinks it's entertaining or informative the entire time, you can experiment with publishing your longer-form video and learning from its results.</p> \n<h2>Navigating Video in 2020</h2> \n<p>With each new generation, the video world will continue to evolve.</p> \n<p>However, at this point, the video landscape is changing in favor of marketers. Not only do consumers <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.236223299.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">prefer to learn about brands via video content</a>, but they use it as a necessary tool in the information-gathering phase of their buyer's journey.</p> \n<p>Additionally, the vast majority of video consumers now strive to learn something new about an interest or hobby, rather than just using video to entertain themselves. This means marketers can harness educational videos in their strategy and offer consumers content that relates to their niche, while also marketing a brand or product.</p> \n<p>In 2020, you don't need a high-priced video budget to succeed as a marketer. You just need to create content that engages, educates, and intrigues your audience.</p> \n<p>To learn more about how to create a winning marketing video -- even on a budget -- check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/video-marketing\">this how-to post</a>. For tactical promotional tips, check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/video-marketing?_ga=2.236223299.311160823.1595816611-631527517.1595282187\">The Ultimate Guide to Video Marketing</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Jul 2020 11:00:00
