Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D.png?width=600&name=How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn49@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118303751_0ec4d7f024a9df1a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-1.png?width=500&name=How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn89@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118313132_b795a7fa8be00b3a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-3.png?width=400&name=How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn45@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118311014_c4611053797c833f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-2.png?width=600&name=How%20Video%20Consumption%20Is%20Changing%20in%202020%20%5BNew%20Research%5D-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn82@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118310369_402b491afd8d3edf.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-video-consumption-is-changing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn37@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118309166_316bab44a4c555d9.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"Why You Should SEO-Optimize Your Content, Even if Your Goal Isn't Organic Traffic","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-seo-can-help-nonorganic-goals","description":"<p>Nowadays, you can't conduct a successful content marketing strategy without incorporating SEO methods.</p>  \n<p>Neil Patel explained it well when <a href=\"https://neilpatel.com/blog/seo-is-content-marketing/\">he wrote</a>: \"Good SEO ... means consistent output of content. Consistent output means that you're doing content marketing, and you're doing it right. There isn't any way around it.\"</p> \n<p>I can imagine you might be thinking — \"OK, but my goal for content marketing isn't <em>just</em> SEO. It's also creating thought leadership content, and lead generation, as well.\"</p> \n<p>Of course, every marketer should consider more than organic traffic when analyzing success metrics. After all, SEO isn't the only component of a successful marketing strategy.</p> \n<p>But SEO efforts don't just help you reach organic traffic goals — they can also help you achieve your brand awareness and lead generation goals, as well.</p> \n<p>Here, let's explore how SEO can help you meet all your marketing goals, even if those goals don't require organic traffic.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 15px; text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/SEO-Jul-28-2020-01-29-48-13-PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=SEO-Jul-28-2020-01-29-48-13-PM.png\" alt=\"SEO optimize your content\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 18px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=More%20on%20@HubSpot’s%20blog%20post%20here:%20%20https://bit.ly/seogoals%20pic.twitter.com/g3MNrEUQ9X\"><em><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Share this image on Twitter!</span></em></a></p> \n<h3>How SEO Can Help You Reach the 3 Main Content Marketing Goals</h3> \n<p>Before we dive into how marketers can use SEO strategies to reach their content marketing goals, let's take a short detour and refresh ourselves on three of the primary reasons for doing content marketing:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Lead generation.</strong> If you have salespeople ready to close sales but need to fill their pipeline with more qualified leads, the primary goal for your content marketing is probably lead generation. Lead generation is the process of converting people who've heard of your company into people who want to hear from your company more often. And then when those leads trust you and view you as an expert in your industry, they're more likely to convert into customers.</li> \n <li><strong>Thought leadership/brand awareness. </strong>If you're hoping to position your company as a knowledgeable expert within your industry, your primary content marketing goal is probably thought leadership. Consistently getting thought leadership content published in trusted publications — whether through guest-contributed articles or press mentions — is a fantastic way to build credibility with your audience.</li> \n <li><strong>SEO.</strong> If there's a lot of competition in your space and you're gunning for the top spot in your target audience's mind, your primary goal for content marketing is probably SEO. SEO works to get your website to the top of the list when your audience looks for certain keywords in search engines. The content on your site and the pages that link to your site give your website a better score, boosting your overall credibility with the search engine.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you didn't have a specific content marketing goal in mind before you started reading, pick the one from the list above that's most important to you right now. Keep that goal in mind as you keep reading.</p> \n<h2><strong>SEO Strategies to Reach Any Content Marketing Goal</strong></h2> \n<p>Now that you have a specific goal in mind, let's take a look at a few SEO strategies that can help you improve your content marketing results, as well as how you can apply these SEO strategies to reach your content marketing goals.</p> \n<h3>1. Keyword Research</h3> \n<p>To put it simply, keyword research lets you see what search terms you're currently ranking for, what others in your industry are ranking for, and which keywords could use more of your attention.</p> \n<p>For example, you might discover that your audience is looking for \"guides on creating a content marketing strategy.\" While a certain publication you want to partner with might not be looking for an article that spells this out in a lengthy, detailed how-to guide, you <em>could</em> write a higher-level article for that publication that links to a white-paper on your site that dives deeper into the process of developing an effective content marketing strategy.</p> \n<p>This would allow you to create content that your audience is looking for, while also publishing in an important publication that helps demonstrate your brand as a thought leader in the industry. Of course, researching your keywords will look the same regardless of your content marketing goal — but the way you <em>use</em> that information will differ.</p> \n<p>If your primary goal is <strong>lead generation</strong>, keyword research can enable you to identify pain points or sales objections you might want to cover in your content. This will allow you to tailor your content to what your audience actually wants to know and strategically use keywords related to your audiences' searches so you can reach them in search results. Once you reach them there, you can hopefully lead them to your site to engage with your company further.</p> \n<p>Focusing on <strong>thought leadership</strong>? Keyword research can help you find out what questions your audience has so you can provide answers and position your company as authorities in your industry. You can include short-tail (e.g., \"AI\") and long-tail (e.g., \"what is artificial intelligence\") keywords in your content to rank for those keywords and further solidify your place as a thought leader online. After all, if your audience members don't find you when they search for information related to your expertise, they probably won't consider you a credible expert.</p> \n<p>If <strong>SEO</strong> is your focus, keyword research lets you see how you stack up against the competition when it comes to ranking for important keywords in your industry. It will give you insight into what keywords your content initiatives should focus on so you can improve those rankings and be more competitive on search engine results pages.</p> \n<p>To <a href=\"https://blog.influenceandco.com/5-steps-to-keyword-research-that-will-boost-your-content-marketing\">conduct keyword research</a>, analyze your website's current rankings, identify keywords your competition doesn't rank for but that might be good opportunities, look for question-based keywords you can focus on to answer your audience's queries, and cluster your findings so you can identify trends. Google's autocomplete, similar searches, or <a href=\"https://support.google.com/adwords/answer/2999770?hl=en\">Keyword Planner</a> are accessible ways to explore what your audience is searching for. If you want to go deeper, you can use a keyword tool like <a href=\"https://ahrefs.com/\">Ahrefs</a>, <a href=\"https://www.semrush.com/\">SEMrush</a>, or <a href=\"https://moz.com/\">Moz</a> to get a more well-rounded picture.</p> \n<h3>2. Topic Clusters</h3> \n<p>Search engines' algorithms favor topic-based content, so it can be beneficial to link related content under \"<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/topic-clusters-seo\">topic clusters</a>.\" Basically, building topic clusters allows you to provide deeper coverage across a range of core topics and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-strategy\">create an efficient information architecture</a>.</p> \n<p>You can develop a pillar page for each of your company's main focus areas. Then you'll build out more specific subtopics, or \"cluster content.\" These pieces of cluster content will provide more detail related to a specific long-form keyword that's related to the main topic you covered on the pillar page. The pillar links to each cluster page, and each piece of cluster content links back to the pillar with the same hyperlinked keyword.</p> \n<p>For example, at my company, <a href=\"https://www.influenceandco.com/\">Influence &amp; Co.,</a> we created a pillar page titled \"<a href=\"https://blog.influenceandco.com/what-is-content-marketing\">The Ultimate Guide to Content Marketing</a>.\" This is a longer piece of content that covers six ways readers can take their content marketing to the next level, diving deep into how to achieve the advice in each section. This pillar page links out to multiple cluster pages (and the cluster pages link back), which results in that solid architecture I just mentioned.</p> \n<p>We also produced a couple of guest-contributed articles related to this pillar page to create a comprehensive content plan that provides a wide range of specific, tactical content to help our audience better understand content marketing — and how to do it well.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Content-Map.Landing-Page-01-1.png\" alt=\"Content-Map.Landing-Page-01-1\">\n</div> \n<p>If you're focusing on <strong>lead generation</strong>, this linking ecosystem enables you to keep your audience members engaged with your content longer, which boosts the likelihood that they'll fill out a form or reach out to you. Plus, as your audience members spend more time on your site, they learn more about your company, making them more qualified leads once they do decide to take the leap and give you their information.</p> \n<p>Topic clusters can benefit a <strong>thought leadership</strong> strategy as well, because this approach lets you create overview content <em>and</em> in-depth content, which positions you as a thorough expert on the subject matter that your audience is interested in and cares about.</p> \n<p>Finally, working to achieve <strong>SEO</strong> goals? This model can help you organize your site's structure.</p> \n<p>Building a strong information architecture can lead to better rankings in organic search across a broad subject area. Those hyper-focused pieces of cluster content will allow you to work toward that strong architecture while also maintaining your focus on producing content that your audience cares about. Plus, creating one high-performing cluster page can elevate search rankings to all of the other pages that are linked to the same pillar.</p> \n<p>A great way to plan out your topic clusters is to develop a content map. Before you even begin creating content, decide what your pillar page will focus on. Then nail down topics for a few cluster pages. You can even take it a step further and identify what subjects you'd like to cover in guest-contributed articles related to that overarching topic. We've put together a free <a href=\"https://offers.influenceandco.com/download-your-customizable-content-map?hsCtaTracking=ac2b69fb-106d-46bd-8d54-3e14e3020fac%7Cf7625b73-4211-455a-abd0-01beadbe2505\">content map template</a> that you can use to get started.</p> \n<h3>3. Optimizing Blog Posts</h3> \n<p>Blogging can position your website as a relevant answer to your target audience's burning questions. And optimizing those posts for search can help you actually reach your audience members so you can provide the value they're looking for.</p> \n<p>Blog post optimization can advance both <strong>thought leadership</strong> and <strong>lead generation</strong> goals because if the content you're producing for your site isn't ranking well, it isn't showing up as a relevant answer to your audience's questions. This means you won't be perceived as an expert, and you most definitely won't generate more leads.</p> \n<p>If you're focusing on <strong>SEO</strong> as your primary goal, optimizing blog posts is a given. Your content isn't going to rank well if you're not including relevant short- and long-tail keywords that your audience cares about.</p> \n<p>To <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-search-engine-optimization\">optimize your blog content</a>, focus on one or two long-tail keywords that line up with the intent of your target readership, and include those keywords in your post where they fit in naturally. For example, if your audience has been searching for information on creating a predictive analytics strategy, you'll want to publish a blog post about the strategy and techniques behind predictive analytics.</p> \n<p>When writing that post, you'll need to include long-tail keywords for which people are searching. Those might include \"how to do predictive analytics,\" \"predictive analytics strategies,\" and \"predictive analytics techniques.\" This way, your blog post will show up in search results for people who are looking for more detailed insights on developing a predictive analytics strategy.</p> \n<p>In addition, make sure your blog is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/improve-your-websites-user-experience\">responsive and mobile-friendly</a>. Creating a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/meta-descriptions\">meta description</a> that's keyword-rich, optimizing your images with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/image-alt-text\">alt text</a>, and linking to other pages on your blog whenever possible will also help you rank.</p> \n<p>These are just a few SEO strategies that can help you reach your content marketing goals, whether you're focusing on SEO itself, thought leadership, or lead generation. This certainly isn't an exhaustive list, but it'll get you started on your journey of optimizing your way to better content marketing results.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-seo-can-help-nonorganic-goals&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Jul 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/seo-nonorganic-goals.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"899f9b9af236b584178f3d560b0dac7d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn37@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118303753_63d73dc2034008c9.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/seo-nonorganic-goals.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Kelsey Raymond","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/SEO-Jul-28-2020-01-29-48-13-PM.png?width=1500&name=SEO-Jul-28-2020-01-29-48-13-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn29@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118313562_987c6dcf20aae9f1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Content-Map.Landing-Page-01-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn14@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118310328_16f2e6a38b9952f7.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-seo-can-help-nonorganic-goals&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn85@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118307978_a3cfd063656f3386.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"17 Blogging Mistakes to Avoid in 2020, According to HubSpot Bloggers","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/beginner-blogger-mistakes","description":"<p>Sometimes, when I tell people that I blog for a living, they roll their eyes. \"That's so easy,\" they say. \"You get a paycheck for sitting on the internet all day and writing. A monkey could do your job!\"</p> \n<p>That's when<em> I</em> roll my eyes. See, people are quick to deem blogging as a no-brainer job. But when they actually sit down to write their first couple of posts, it hits them: <em>This is way harder than I thought</em>. Like any person starting a new job, they mess things up.</p> \n<p>That's okay -- it happens to pretty much every new blogger. Luckily, it's pretty easy to avoid these roadblocks if you know they're coming.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>So for all of you beginner bloggers out there who are looking to get up-to-speed quickly, keep on reading. Below are common mistakes most beginners make and some tips on how to avoid them.</p> \n<h2>What Is a Blog?</h2> \n<p>Simply put, a blog is a tool that can help develop an online presence, attract leads, and engage with an audience. It's often a series of editorial content centered around a central topic that demonstrates industry expertise -- for instance, a catering company might write blog posts like \"The 11 Best Appetizers to Serve to a Crowd\" or \"Stress-Free Dinner Parties: Recipes that are Prepared Ahead of Time\".</p> \n<p>Blogs can help drive traffic to your website, convert that traffic into leads, establish authority in your industry, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-a-blog?_ga=2.117054918.1559363486.1561986372-527251855.1560789477\">ultimately grow your business</a>. In fact, organizations are <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics?_ga=2.222693727.558674788.1561985800-983944916.1546275206\">13x more likely to see positive ROI</a> by prioritizing blogging.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Blogging Tips for Beginners</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Create blog posts that serve your larger company goals.</li> \n  <li>Identify what resonates with your audience.</li> \n  <li>Write like you talk.</li> \n  <li>Show your personality; don't tell it.</li> \n  <li>Make your point again and again.</li> \n  <li>Start with a very specific working title.</li> \n  <li>Specific posts should still tie into the bigger picture.</li> \n  <li>Use a specific post type, create an outline, and use headers.</li> \n  <li>Give your audience something to walk away with.</li> \n  <li>Use data and research to back up the claims you make in your posts.</li> \n  <li>Use examples to back up why what you're saying is important.</li> \n  <li>When drawing from others' ideas, cite them.</li> \n  <li>Take 30 minutes to edit your post.</li> \n  <li>At a certain point, just publish it.</li> \n  <li>Blog consistently with the help of an editorial calendar.</li> \n  <li>Focus on the long-term benefits of organic traffic.</li> \n  <li>Add a subscription CTA to your blog and set up an email newsletter.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h2>Blog Post Mistakes to Avoid</h2> \n<p>Most of a blog's traffic is driven organically -- in other words, consumers will search for something on a search engine and click on your blog if it matches their intended topic. However, there are a lot of organizations competing for your audience's attention, so it's important to avoid common blog mistakes to stand out.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Here are the most common blog post mistakes (and their solutions), according to HubSpot bloggers.</p> \n<h3>1. Create blog posts that serve your larger company goals.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You think of ideas that only interest you.</h4> \n<p>As much as you might read and re-read your blog posts after you publish them, you're not the only reader, or the intended reader.</p> \n<p>When you start blogging, ideas will come to you at random times -- in the shower, on a run, while on the phone with your mom. While the ideas may come at random moments, the ideas themselves should never be random. Just because it's a good idea in general -- or something that interests you personally -- doesn't mean it's a good idea for your company.</p> \n<h4>Solution: Align your blog posts with company growth goals.</h4> \n<p>The reason you're blogging is to solve problems for your audience and, ultimately, to grow your business. So, all of your blog post ideas should <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33898/How-to-Set-SMART-Marketing-Goals-for-2013-TEMPLATE.aspx\">help serve those growth goals</a>. They should have natural tie-ins to issues in your industry and address specific questions and concerns your prospects have.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"Your blog is a honeypot, not a megaphone. Make a point to position your content around what your audience wants to discover, not what you want to tell them.\"</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 18px;\">&nbsp;</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 20px;\">— Amanda Sellers, HubSpot's Historical Optimization Writer</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Need help figuring out what those goals are and how to address them? Chat with your manager about the larger company goals, and then <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/sales/schedule-meeting\">schedule a meeting</a> with someone on the sales team to hear what questions they get asked most often. After both meetings, you should know which goals you need to achieve and have some ideas on how to achieve them.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>2. Identify what resonates with your audience.&nbsp;</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You forget about your persona.&nbsp;</h4> \n<p>If you want your blog content to perform well (i.e. generate traffic, leads, and sales), it must resonate with your audience and compel them to take action. One of the biggest mistakes is assuming that your content will perform if you haven't actually considered your audience or the actions you want them to take.</p> \n<h4>Solution: Understand your persona's pains and solve for them.</h4> \n<p>By <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona\">defining your buyer persona</a> and the things that matter to them, you can bridge the gap with your content.&nbsp;</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"Your persona is the basis for everything you create. Writing for yourself won’t always resonate with your intended audience. If you, instead, speak your persona’s pains, challenges, and goals and they feel like you are speaking to them, they are more likely to stay on the page and convert on your offer.\"</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 18px;\">&nbsp;</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 20px;\">— Christina Perricone, Content Marketing Manager at HubSpot</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>If you're not consciously thinking about your persona's pains, you're just creating content for content's sake, which is a waste of resources.</p> \n<h3>3. Write like you talk.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: Your writing is too stiff.</h4> \n<p>Writing a blog post is much different than writing a term paper. But when bloggers first start out, they usually only have experience with the latter. The problem? The style of writing from a term paper is <em>not</em> the style of writing people enjoy reading.</p> \n<p>Let's be honest: Most of the people who see your post aren't going to read the whole thing. If you want to keep them interested, you have to compel them to keep reading by <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hard-to-read-blog-posts\">writing in a style that's effortless to read</a>.</p> \n<h4>Solution: Try to write blogs that feel personable.&nbsp;</h4> \n<p>It's okay to be more conversational in your writing -- in fact, we encourage it. The <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-interesting-content\">more approachable your writing is</a>, the more people will enjoy reading it. People want to feel like they're doing business with real people, not robots.</p> \n<p>So loosen up your writing. Throw in contractions. Get rid of the jargon. Make a pun or two. That's how real people talk -- and that's what real people like to read.</p> \n<h3>4. Show your personality; don't tell it.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You think people care about <em>you</em> as a writer.</h4> \n<p>It sounds harsh, but it's the truth: When people first start out blogging, they think that their audience will be inherently interested in <em>their </em>stories and <em>their</em> interests ... but that's not the case. It's no knock against them as a person -- it's just that when you're new, no one is interested in you and your experiences. People care way more about what you can teach them.</p> \n<h4>Solution: Infuse your personality without eclipsing the topic.</h4> \n<p>Even though people don't really care that it's <em>you</em> that's writing the post, you can infuse parts of your personality in your writing to make them feel more comfortable with you. How you do that is entirely up to you. Some people like to crack jokes, some like to make pop culture references, and others have a way with vivid descriptions.</p> \n<p>HubSpot's Director of Content <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/coreyeridon\">Corey Wainwright</a> is particularly good at this. Here's an example from the introduction <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-crowdsource-blog-post-google-docs\">of one of her posts</a>:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/show-personality-in-blog-post.png?width=600&amp;name=show-personality-in-blog-post.png\" alt=\"show-personality-in-blog-post.png\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>To infuse personality into your own writing, try looking for ways to relate to your readers on the topic you're writing about -- then write in the first person as if you're hanging out with them and chatting about it. Make your tone personal, approachable, and engaging, just like you would in a face-to-face conversation.</p> \n<h3>5. Make your point again and again.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You digress.</h4> \n<p>Although you are encouraged to let your own personality shine through in your writing, don't abuse the privilege. It's one thing to be yourself in the topic you're covering, but it's another thing to bring up too many personal experiences that bury the point you're trying to make.</p> \n<p>Don't digress into these personal anecdotes and analogies too much -- your readers aren't sitting in front of you, which means you can't guarantee that you have their undivided attention. They can (and will) bounce from your article if they lose patience.&nbsp;</p> \n<h4>Solution: Repeatedly assert your argument.&nbsp;</h4> \n<p>To prevent your writing from losing its audience, restate your point in every section of the article. The best blog posts commit to an overarching message and then deliver it gradually, expressing it multiple times in small ways from beginning to end.</p> \n<p>If you're writing about how much water a potted plant needs, for example, don't spend three paragraphs telling a story of how you came home to a dead fern after returning from a two-week vacation. This story offers real evidence of your point, but what&nbsp;<em>is</em> your point? Certain plants can't go without water for more than 14 days. That's one possible point, and it should be stated upfront.</p> \n<h3>6. Start with a very specific working title.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: Your topics are too broad.</h4> \n<p>When people start blogging, they generally want to write on really big topics like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>\"How to Do Social Media Marketing\"</li> \n <li>\"Business Best Practices\"</li> \n <li>\"How to Make Money on the Internet\"</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Topics like these are far too broad. Because there are so many details and nuances in these topics, it's really hard to do a good job answering them. Plus, more specific topics tend to attract smaller, more targeted audiences, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/definition-long-tail-keyword-100-words-sr\">which tend to be higher quality</a> and more likely to convert into leads and customers.</p> \n<p>So, to get the most short-term and long-term benefits of blogging, you'll need to get way more specific.</p> \n<h4>Solution: Begin with a clear, concise idea.</h4> \n<p>Nailing really specific blog topics is crucial to knocking your first few posts out of the park. Let us help you brainstorm with our <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/blog-topic-generator\">Blog Ideas Generator</a>. This tool allows you to enter basic terms you know you want to cover, and then produces five sample blog titles that work for business blogs.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind that a working title isn't final -- it's just a concrete angle you can use to keep your writing on track. Once you nail this stage of the ideation process, it's much easier to write your blog posts.</p> \n<h3>7. Specific posts should still tie into the bigger picture.&nbsp;</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You're don't tie a specific topic into your reader's broader struggle.&nbsp;</h4> \n<p>You already know how important it is to resonate with your buyer persona and understand their pain points. However, there's a reason why they're experiencing pain points and what is driving them to get it solved.&nbsp;</p> \n<h4>Solution: Understand the challenges and consequences they're facing.</h4> \n<p>You should be asking yourself:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>What is at stake?</li> \n <li>What do they gain by taking action?</li> \n <li>What are they afraid of happening if they don't take action?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>All of these things can manifest in the content that you write for your blog post. Doing so will signal to your reader that you understand what they're going through and you want to help.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"If you're uninterested in a particular topic you're writing about, it's probably because you haven't stopped to think big-picture. Understanding how the topic you're writing about will fit into a reader's broader challenges will help you find meaning and value in any post you write, and will enable you to connect with your readers better.\"</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 18px;\">&nbsp;</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 20px;\">— Caroline Forsey, Editor of the HubSpot Marketing Blog</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>For instance, let's say you're tackling a post like \"first vs. third-party APIs.\" While the topic is dry and allows for little creativity, the big-picture value is huge: to help your readers decide whether they need to shell over the big bucks for an in-house API or whether they can save money and time by asking a third-party to develop their API. Essentially, \"first vs. third party APIs\" is a question that hits at computer security, efficiency, and budget constraints, all of which could have big consequences for your reader.</p> \n<h3>8. Use a specific post type, create an outline, and use headers.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: Your writing is a brain dump.</h4> \n<p>Sometimes when I get a great idea I'm excited about, it's really tempting to just sit down and let it flow out of me. But what I get is usually a sub-par blog post.</p> \n<p>Why? The stream-of-consciousness style of writing isn't really a good style for blog posts. Most people are going to scan your blog posts, not read them, so it needs to be organized really well for that to happen.</p> \n<h4>Solution: Structure your blog with a template, outline, and section headers.</h4> \n<p>The first thing you should do is choose what <em>type </em>of blog post you're going to write. Is it a how-to post? A list-based post? A curated collection post? A SlideShare presentation? For help on this, <strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/blog-post-templates\">download our free templates for creating five different types of blog posts</a>. </strong>Once you have a template down, it'll be easier to write your outline.</p> \n<p>Writing an outline makes a big difference. If you put in the time up front to organize your thoughts and create a logical flow in your post, the rest becomes easy -- you're basically just filling in the blanks.</p> \n<p>Using headers is also critical for reader experience.&nbsp;</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"While it's nice to imagine that your readers hang on your every word, the reality is that they're probably mostly skimming your posts. As you write, be sure you're making your piece skim-friendly: including plenty of paragraph breaks, clearly titled sections, relevant images, and formatting that makes it easy to find the piece of information they likely came for.\"</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 18px;\">&nbsp;</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 20px;\">— Karla Cook, Sr. Manager of the HubSpot Blog Team</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>To write a blog post outline, first come up with a list of the top takeaways you want your readers to get from your post. Then, break up those takeaways into larger section headers. When you put in a section header every few paragraphs, your blog post becomes easier and more enjoyable to read. (And plus, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-friendly-blog-post-checklist-ht\">header text with keywords is good for SEO</a>.) When you finally get to writing, all you'll have to do is fill in those sections.</p> \n<h3>9. Give your audience something to walk away with.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You're relying on the conceptual instead of the concrete.</h4> \n<p>One of the first things you’ll do in your blog research is look up how other publications are writing about a topic. However, if you notice, almost all the results on the first page of Google are writing about conceptual, vague ideas. How can your blog stick out? You can include actual, actionable steps to achieve success.</p> \n<h4>Solution: Include actionable steps to achieve success.</h4> \n<p>One of the biggest tenets of content creation is that it should be useful, and that means your audience should walk away with something.&nbsp;</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"People want to learn how to do things in actuality, not just theoretically. When you’re done with a blog, ask yourself, 'Will the reader know how to implement this idea?' or 'Did I provide steps to achieve success?'\"</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 18px;\">&nbsp;</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 20px;\">— Rebecca White, Jr. Staff Writer at HubSpot</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>This might come in the form of a \"how-to\" as you recommend they implement a particular strategy, or it might simply be a suggestion for a tool or tactic to make a process easier.</p> \n<h3>10. Use data and research to back up the claims you make in your posts.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You don't use data as evidence.</h4> \n<p>Let's say I'm writing a blog post about why businesses should consider using Instagram for marketing. When I'm making that argument, which is more convincing?</p> \n<ol> \n <li>\"It seems like more people are using Instagram nowadays.\"</li> \n <li>\"Instagram’s user base is growing far faster than social network usage in general in the U.S. <a href=\"http://www.emarketer.com/Article/Instagram-Continues-Double-Digit-Growth/1013612#sthash.jucUQgyf.dpuf\">Instagram will grow 15.1% this year</a>, compared to just 3.1% growth for the social network sector as a whole.\"</li> \n</ol> \n<p>The second, of course. Arguments and claims are much more compelling when rooted in data and research. As marketers, we don’t just have to convince people to be on our side about an issue -- we need to convince them to <em>take action.</em> Data-driven content catches people's attention in a way that fluffy arguments do not.</p> \n<h4>Solution: Use data to support your arguments.&nbsp;</h4> \n<p>In any good story, you’ll offer a main argument, establish proof, and then end with a takeaway for the audience. You can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-use-data-in-marketing-content\">use data in blog posts</a> to introduce your main argument and show why it's relevant to your readers, or as proof of it throughout the body of the post.</p> \n<p>Some great places to find compelling data include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/\">HubSpot Research</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.pewresearch.org/\">Pew Research Center</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.marketingsherpa.com/freestuff.html\">MarketingSherpa</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.stateofinbound.com/\">HubSpot's <em>State of Inbound</em> report</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>11. Use examples to back up why what you're saying is important.&nbsp;</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You're not adding enough context.&nbsp;</h4> \n<p>Meg Prater, Managing Editor of the HubSpot blogs, shared with us that “When I first joined the HubSpot Blog team, I would consistently get the edit that I wasn’t adding enough examples to support my statements. For example (See what I did there?), I might write ‘SMBs should expand their social media strategies to experiment with newer, cheaper channels.’ Sure, that might be true, but it’s a pretty broad suggestion.</p> \n<h4>Solution: Illustrate ideas with examples, visual aids, and additional content.&nbsp;</h4> \n<p>A stronger way to share this with an audience might be to say, 'SMBs should expand their social media strategies to experiment with newer, cheaper channels. For example, you might test running ads on question-and-answer platform Quora, or simply answer industry questions for which your product or service is an answer.'</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"By adding a specific example to my previously broad statement, I’ve made my point easier to understand and more actionable for my readers.\"</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 18px;\">&nbsp;</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 20px;\">— Meg Prater, Managing Editor of the HubSpot Blogs</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>As bloggers, we become experts in our industry. Because of this, it's easy to forget about specificity when giving advice, explaining examples, or walking through a common process. Even Pamela Bump, HubSpot's Staff Writer for Audience Growth, admits that she has been guilty of not going into enough depth in a first draft.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"When you review your blog post, read it from the point of view of a new grad entering a field or someone who's just learning about a topic for the first time.\"</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 18px;\">&nbsp;</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 20px;\">— Pamela Bump, HubSpot's Staff Writer for Audience Growth</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Ask yourself questions like, \"Will readers know what this big word means?\", \"Will they recognize this acronym?\", or \"Can they easily visualize this example, or do I need to add a visual aid?\" From there, you can determine where you need to explain something more, or hyperlink potentially confusing words other blog posts that relate to them.</p> \n<h3>12. When drawing from others' ideas, cite them.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: Your content borders on plagiarism.</h4> \n<p>Plagiarism didn't work in school, and it certainly doesn't work on your company's blog. But for some reason, many beginner bloggers think they can get away with the old copy-and-paste technique.</p> \n<p>You can't. Editors and readers can usually tell when something's been copied from somewhere else. Your voice suddenly doesn't sound like you, or maybe there are a few words in there that are incorrectly used. It just sounds ... off.</p> \n<p>Plus, if you get caught <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/internet-content-theft\">stealing other people's content</a>, you could get your site penalized by Google -- which could be a big blow to your company blog's organic growth.</p> \n<h4><strong>Solution: Give credit where credit is due.&nbsp;</strong></h4> \n<p>Instead, take a few minutes to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33098/How-Not-to-Steal-People-s-Content-on-the-Web.aspx\">understand how to cite other people's content in your blog posts</a>. It's not super complicated, but it's an essential thing to learn when you're first starting out.</p> \n<h3>13. Take 30 minutes to edit your post.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You think you're done once the writing's done.</h4> \n<p>Most people make the mistake of not editing their writing. It sounded so fluid in their head when they were writing that it <em>must</em> be great to read ... right?</p> \n<p>Nope -- it still needs editing. And maybe a lot of it.</p> \n<h4>Solution: You'll never regret time spent proofreading.&nbsp;</h4> \n<p>Everyone needs to edit their writing -- even the most experienced writers. Most times, our first drafts aren't all that great. So take the time you need to shape up your post. Fix typos, run-on sentences, and accidental its/it's mistakes. Make sure your story flows just as well as it did in your outline.</p> \n<p>To help you remember all the little things to check before publishing, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-editing-checklist\">check out our checklist for editing and proofreading a blog post</a>.</p> \n<h3>14. At a certain point, just publish it.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You try to make every post perfect.</h4> \n<p>I hate to break it to you, but <strong>your blog post is</strong> <strong>never</strong> <strong>going to be perfect. </strong>Ever.</p> \n<p>There will <em>always</em> be more things you can do to make your posts better. More images. Better phrasing. Wittier jokes. The best writers I know, know when to stop obsessing and just hit \"publish.\"</p> \n<h4>Solution: Better to publish and update than postpone for perfection.&nbsp;</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/good-enough-content-creation-design\">There's a point</a> at which there are diminishing returns for getting closer to \"perfect\" -- and you're really never going to reach \"perfect\" anyway. So while you don't want to publish a post filled with factual inaccuracies and grammatical errors, it's not the end of the world if a typo slips through. It most likely won't affect how many views and leads it brings in.</p> \n<p>Plus, if you (or your readers) find the mistake, all of you have to do is update the post. No biggie. So give yourself a break once and a while -- perfect is the enemy of done.</p> \n<h3>15. Blog consistently with the help of an editorial calendar.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You don't blog consistently.</h4> \n<p>By now, you've probably heard that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blogging-frequency-benchmarks?_ga=1.30446463.1733063552.1465306056#sm.0001ralmokx9oe96wpl15ahh67v4e\">the more often you blog</a>, the more traffic you'll get to your website -- and the more subscribers and leads you'll generate from your posts. But as important as volume is, it's actually more important that you're blogging <em>consistently</em> when you're just getting started. If you publish five posts in one week and then only one or two in the next few weeks, it'll be hard to form a consistent habit. And inconsistency could really confuse your subscribers.</p> \n<p>Instead, it's the companies that make a commitment to regularly publishing quality content to their blogs that tend to reap the biggest rewards in terms of website traffic and leads -- and those results continue to pay out over time.</p> \n<p>To help establish consistency, you'll need a more concrete planning strategy.</p> \n<h4>Solution: Schedule and publish blogs consistently.&nbsp;</h4> \n<p>Use it to get into the habit of planning your blog post topics ahead of time, publishing consistently, and even scheduling posts in advance if you're finding yourself having a particularly productive week.</p> \n<p>Here at HubSpot, we typically use good ol' Google Calendar as our blog editorial calendar, which <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/create-robust-editorial-calendar-ht\">you can learn how to set up step-by-step here</a>. Or, you can <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/blog-editorial-calendar\">click here to download our free editorial calendar templates</a> for Excel, Google Sheets, and Google Calendar, along with instructions on how to set them up.</p> \n<h3>16. Focus on the long-term benefits of organic traffic.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You concentrate your analytics on immediate traffic.</h4> \n<p>Both beginner bloggers and advanced bloggers are guilty of this blogging mistake. If you concentrate your analysis on immediate traffic (traffic from email subscribers, RSS feeds, and social shares), then it's going to be hard to prove the enduring value of your blog. After all, the half-life for those sources is very brief -- usually a day or two.</p> \n<p>When marketers who are just starting their business blogs see that their blog posts aren't generating any new traffic after a few days, many of them get frustrated. They think their blog is failing, and they <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-failing-change-perspective\">end up abandoning it prematurely</a>.</p> \n<h4>Solution: The ROI of your blog is the aggregation of organic traffic over time.</h4> \n<p>Instead of focusing on the sudden decay of short-term traffic, focus instead on the cumulative potential of organic traffic. Over time, given <em>enough </em>time, the traffic from day three and beyond of a single blog post will eclipse that big spike on days one and two <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-friendly-blog-post-checklist-ht#sm.0000o5c3iom8gdkipdw2l236rj19q\">thanks to being found on search engine results pages through organic search</a>. You just have to give it a while.</p> \n<p>To help drive this long-term traffic, make sure you're writing blog posts that have durable relevance on a consistent basis. These posts <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/31501/Why-Every-Business-Blog-Needs-Evergreen-Content.aspx\">are called \"evergreen\" blog posts</a>: They're relevant year after year with little or no upkeep, valuable, and high quality.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"Your evergreen content is an ongoing asset and in many cases has more potential to perform than a new, unproven post.\"</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 18px;\">&nbsp;</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 20px;\">— Amanda Sellers, HubSpot's Historical Optimization Writer</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Over time, as you write more evergreen content and build search authority, those posts <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hubspot-blog-compounding-posts\">will end up being responsible for a large percentage of your blog traffic</a>. It all starts with a slight shift in perspective from daily traffic to cumulative traffic so you can reframe the way you view your blog and its ROI entirely.</p> \n<h3>17. Add a subscription CTA to your blog and set up an email newsletter.</h3> \n<h4>Mistake: You aren't growing subscribers.</h4> \n<p>Once you start blogging, it's easy to forget that blogging isn't just about getting <em>new</em> visitors to your blog. One of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/the-benefits-of-business-blogging-ht\">the biggest benefits of blogging</a> is that it helps you steadily grow an email list of subscribers you can share your new content with. Each time you publish a new blog post, your subscribers will give you that initial surge of traffic -- which, in turn, will propel those posts' long-term success.</p> \n<p>The key to getting significant business results (traffic, leads, and eventually customers) <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/grow-blog-subscribers-grow-traffic\">all starts with growing subscribers</a>.</p> \n<span class=\"hs-cta-wrapper\"><span class=\"hs-cta-node hs-cta-7925d2df-4129-4a61-a296-d814fb00ea18\"></span></span> \n<h4>Solution: How to set up a subscription CTA and email newsletter:</h4> \n<p>First, use your email marketing tool to set up a welcome email for new subscribers, as well as a regular email that pulls in your most recent blog posts. (HubSpot customers: You can <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/blog-user-guide-v2/how-to-configure-your-blogs-subscription-options?_ga=1.173330083.1866822358.1456501228\">use HubSpot's email tool to easily set up these regular email sends</a>, as well as <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/cos-blog/how-do-i-send-a-blog-welcome-email\">set up a welcome email for new subscribers</a>.)</p> \n<p>Next, add subscription CTAs to your blog (and elsewhere, like the footer of your website) to make it easy for people to opt in. These CTAs should be simple, one-field <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/forms\">email opt-in forms</a> near the top of your blog, above the fold. As for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/types-ctas-blog\">where to put these CTAs</a>, we typically place our blog CTAs at the bottom of our blog posts or add a slide-in, which you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-add-a-slide-in-call-to-action-to-your-blog-posts?_ga=2.221654492.558674788.1561985800-983944916.1546275206\">learn how to do using a free tool called Leadin here</a>.</p> \n<p>You can also <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/bid/109514/Why-You-Need-A-Blog-Subscription-Landing-Page\">create a dedicated landing page for subscribers</a> that you can direct people to via other channels such as social media, other pages on your website, PPC, or email. (For a list of more simple ways to attract subscribers, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32703/20-Simple-Ways-to-Boost-Blog-Subscribers.aspx\">read this blog post</a>; for more advanced ideas, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/get-subscribers-blog-ideas\">read this one</a>.)</p> \n<p>Don't worry if you read through this list and are now thinking to yourself, <em>Well this is awkward ... I've made literally every single one of these mistakes. </em>Remember: I used the word \"common\" to describe these mistakes for a reason. The more you blog, the better you'll get at it -- and you'll reap the benefits in terms of traffic and leads in the process.</p> \n<p>We hope you'll use this list of mistakes as fuel for the fire to step up your blogging game. After all, the benefits of keeping up a healthy business blog will be well worth the time and effort.</p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbeginner-blogger-mistakes&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 20 Jul 2020 17:08:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/blogging-for-beginners.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"805b18a6bab736126e3ece6e8f74dca2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn93@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118303749_61cff06b9cc1d0cd.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/blogging-for-beginners.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"lkolowich@hubspot.com (Lindsay Kolowich)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/show-personality-in-blog-post.png?width=600&name=show-personality-in-blog-post.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn70@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118310519_77540c3f77ad4dc7.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbeginner-blogger-mistakes&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn1@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118312687_129481d513e266d4.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"It’s the Little Things: How To Write Microcopy","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/writing-great-microcopy","description":"<p>Earlier today, I visited Yelp to order lunch. What I like about the site is how easy it is to navigate. If I were accessing the website for the first time, I wouldn't have any worries about how to use it to my benefit.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Have you ever visited a website and noticed small phrases of text that guide you to your goal? Or, when you make an online purchase, is there text on the web page that lets you know your payment information is secure?</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>That text is called microcopy, and it's a wonderful tool for UX. For instance, let's say I was visiting Yelp for the first time today, without knowing what the website's purpose was. I wouldn't have to worry because the microcopy helps fill in that confusion.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Microcopy on Yelp \" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-4.png?width=624&amp;height=196&amp;name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-4.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"196\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"http://yelp.com\" style=\"font-style: italic; font-weight: normal;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>In the search bar, the microcopy tells me the types of things I could search, and where I can set my location. \"Burgers, barbers, spas, handymen…\" are all examples of what I can find using the site, which is super helpful for a first-time user.</p> \n<p>Additionally, the location settings tell me I could search for businesses near me or elsewhere. So when I move in a couple of weeks, I won't have to wait until I arrive to search for restaurants near my new place.</p> \n<p>It's likely you've interacted with microcopy before and it gave you useful information, like how to search for something and secure payment information. It's meant to add to the user experience of visitors on websites, and in this post, we'll get into how it works.</p> \n<p>Microcopy is a part of almost every website. When you visit a website for the first time and a newsletter pops up, the text you see is an example. When you come across a headline describing the product, or find a sentence that gives a web page more context, you're interacting with microcopy.</p> \n<p>But what exactly is microcopy, and how is it helpful?</p> \n<p>When was the last time you tweeted or made a Facebook status? Do you remember the microcopy that shows up before you start typing? This short phrases asks you to complete an action — like typing out what's happening or what's on your mind:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Microcopy shown on Twitter\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy.png?width=536&amp;height=122&amp;name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy.png\" title=\"\" width=\"536\" height=\"122\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>As someone who's been tweeting for years, I don't even notice the microcopy. But let's say I've just joined Twitter and have no idea how to compose a tweet, or what&nbsp;to tweet. \"What's happening?\" is a useful prompt to help out — I now know I can type what's going on around me and press \"Tweet.\"</p> \n<p>In this case, the microcopy tells the user how to do something and inspires action with a button. Even though it's subtle, the addition of microcopy on Twitter gives instructions and answers questions a new user might have before they can ask them.</p> \n<p>Microcopy gives extra explanation. For instance, if your website offers a niche product, you can use a microcopy headline to give first-time visitors an idea of why your product is valuable. Alternatively, if you're introducing a new product, microcopy can describe it in more detail.</p> \n<p>If you've ever filled in a form, explored a product page, or sourced contact information, you've come across microcopy that supports a brand and its services. For instance, if you forget your login to one of your favorite websites, the microcopy most likely reminded you how to do so.</p> \n<p>Microcopy is part of the user experience. It's a tactic you can use to support the overall story as your brand, as well as describe some of the complexities of your product, right off the bat.</p> \n<p>To produce great microcopy, you need to have a deep understanding of your target audience. Once you know more about them, the questions they might have, and the information they need to know, microcopy can serve as an effective part of your website.</p> \n<p>Let's look at some examples of brands who know how to speak the language of their customers and make use of effective microcopy.</p> \n<h2>Microcopy Examples</h2> \n<p>MIcrocopy can come in a few different forms. It doesn't have to be extremely tiny or fit into a search bar. Sometimes it's bold. It all depends on the copy's intended purpose and the design of the website.</p> \n<p>Let's see how some brands are using microcopy effectively to enhance the user experience.</p> \n<h3>1. HubSpot</h3> \n<p>This microcopy example on HubSpot's homepage explains the product. In two sentences, visitors gain an idea of what HubSpot's tools do, and how it can help them.</p> \n<p>The language is personable and easy to read. In support of the CTA, the microcopy leads into the value of getting started or trying out a demo. It inspires action. <img alt=\"Microcopy on HubSpot\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-Jul-17-2020-02-58-52-96-AM.png?width=624&amp;name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-Jul-17-2020-02-58-52-96-AM.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"http://hubspot.com\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p>Notice how the text isn't necessarily small, either. This is alright if the theme of your website allows for larger text. Microcopy is more about communicating a helpful message to your audience, regardless of text size.</p> \n<h3>2. Wear Your Voice</h3> \n<p>Wear Your Voice is an online publication dedicated to bringing a spotlight to marginalized voices, sparking communication about topical issues, and providing a safe space for audiences to learn.</p> \n<p>This microcopy is what you see on the homepage as part of a newsletter offer. It lets the reader know that they won't receive spam. Not only that, but the microcopy in the space communicates how to receive the newsletters, by entering an email.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Wear Your Voice microcopy\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-2.png?width=624&amp;name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-2.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://wearyourvoicemag.com/\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p>If you want to use microcopy in a subtle way to increase conversions, utilize a strategy that's similar. Include it in a form space or to inform browsers about any concern they may have that would stop them from completing the CTA.</p> \n<h3>3. Honey</h3> \n<p>Honey is an app extension that saves its users money every time they make an online purchase. Because this service is niche, the website provides helpful microcopy about how it works.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Honey app Microcopy\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-Jul-17-2020-02-58-53-09-AM.png?width=434&amp;height=479&amp;name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-Jul-17-2020-02-58-53-09-AM.png\" title=\"\" width=\"434\" height=\"479\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.joinhoney.com/\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p>The headers act as an introduction to the thought, and the microcopy supports the steps. This microcopy is organized, but doesn't take up too much space. Additionally, the phrases are short and easy to comprehend.</p> \n<p>For a service that may seem complicated at first, simplified steps are an excellent measure to ensure leads know how Honey can add value to their lives. If your product or service is niche, consider using microcopy to explain how it works in a comprehensible way, like Honey.</p> \n<h3>4. Shea Makery</h3> \n<p>When it comes to branding and brand voice, microcopy is a great asset. Take this example from Shea Makery, a bakery-themed body care ecommerce store. The text used on the site contributes to the overall tone of the brand and ties in a CTA.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Microcopy from Shea Makery\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-3.png?width=624&amp;height=372&amp;name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-3.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"372\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://sheamakery.com/\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p>\"So much to choose from, all guilt-free with zero calories!\" Introduces the brand with fun, compelling microcopy. The short, rhyming sentence plays up the whimsical, cheerful atmosphere of the website, and the baking attribution speaks to the overall theme of the company.</p> \n<p>Maybe your business is heavily influenced by a theme, like Shea Makery. If that's the case, microcopy with sensory details, like sight, can influence leads to browse your offerings.</p> \n<h3>5. The Canadian African</h3> \n<p>Rather than have a separate \"About Me\" page, this health food blog uses microcopy for the introduction. On the right panel of the website, The Canadian African, you can see a short description of the site and the person in charge.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Microcopy on a food blog \" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-1.png?width=315&amp;height=569&amp;name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-1.png\" title=\"\" width=\"315\" height=\"569\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://thecanadianafrican.com/\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p>The copy is short and simple, but still tells the reader what they'll find on the site. By adding a photo, above the text, the website becomes more personable. So if you're running a solo venture and want to appeal to your target audience, consider using microcopy to introduce yourself on the homepage.</p> \n<p>We've seen microcopy in action — and how it comes in many different forms. If you're pumped to compose some great copy of your own, that's great! Before you do, make sure you check out these best practices.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>To make microcopy effective, keep in mind these microcopy best practices.</p> \n<h3>1. Understand your audience's needs.</h3> \n<p>One of the keys to writing great microcopy is understanding your audience. If you know what they're looking for when they visit your website, what you write can help guide them. For instance, if you know audiences will want to know how to log in to your website, use microcopy in those fields to tell them how.</p> \n<p>To learn more about your audience and what microcopy will be helpful, refer to your buyer personas. They'll outline the challenges of your ideal customer, so you'll have a clue of how to leverage microcopy. Let's say your persona is the busy marketer looking for an all-in-one CRM — your product page microcopy can allude to that challenge, like \"Our tools take the stresses away from what you love doing.\"</p> \n<p>Alternatively, you can run a few <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/heat-map?_ga=2.263827269.830048207.1594954727-940436819.1565181751\">heatmap</a>&nbsp;tests for your website to gain insight about where your audience is clicking the most. Could the areas that aren't getting the most traffic benefit from copy that speaks the customer's language?</p> \n<h3>2. Focus on brief phrasing.</h3> \n<p>As marketers, know that one of the \"don'ts\" of website design is to avoid loads of text. After all, very few of us want to read a novel on a website that sells computer software. So when you're writing microcopy, make it brief.</p> \n<p>The purpose of microcopy is to guide, inform, or support. Typically, it's no longer than one sentence. This is because it's not supposed to be the star of your website, but rather, a helpful addition.</p> \n<p>When you visit a website for the first time and immediately see an offer, notice the microcopy. Does it have a quippy, witty phrase that persuades you to complete the form? That's an example of accurately leveraging microcopy to your advantage.</p> \n<h3>3. Make your copy actionable.</h3> \n<p>A great way to use microcopy is to get customers to complete an action on your website. We've briefly talked about how offer and form microcopy can be useful for conversion.</p> \n<p>In addition to forms and offers, microcopy can be used in ads, captions, and on product pages. It could persuade audiences to take the intended action. If you use microcopy in tandem with a CTA, for example, you could make an ad incredibly effective — tell the audiences what the benefit will be after engaging.</p> \n<p>If there's areas on your website that could benefit from an actionable phrase that's too long for a CTA button, consider making it microcopy instead. That way, it can support the CTA without adding too much text.</p> \n<h3>4. Add in your brand voice.</h3> \n<p>Another great use for microcopy is to give more definition to your brand. Maybe you find your website comes off slightly impersonal, but you don't want to crowd pages with extra body text. Try using microcopy to fill in that gap.</p> \n<p>Because microcopy isn't a headline or body text, there's more freedom to use it to support your company's mission, vision, and beliefs. Communicate with your audience in a personable way in a short phrase, and you'll have a higher chance of building a solid customer relationship.</p> \n<p>This tactic will make your web pages more inviting. It'll spark intrigue with your target audience, and let them know what truly sets your company apart from competitors.</p> \n<h3>5. Be careful with going overboard.</h3> \n<p>As we've talked about, too much text isn't appealing. If leads find there's too much to read on your site, they might become disinterested and click to another. The same is true with microcopy.</p> \n<p>Microcopy works best when it supports other text or inspires action. It should serve a purpose and be used sparingly. An overload of microcopy can be too hard to read — remember, the text is usually small.</p> \n<p>If you're worried you're using too much microcopy, try running an A/B test for your web pages. That way, you can determine the winner based on audience behavior.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwriting-great-microcopy&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
