\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 16 Jul 2020 21:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-4.png?width=624&height=196&name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-4.png","linkMd5":"002c6b656aef2ea240d0db4cb76d6357","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn73@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118301925_dee6e3c5ad8757ef.webp","author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-4.png?width=624&height=196&name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn73@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118301925_dee6e3c5ad8757ef.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy.png?width=536&height=122&name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn57@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118306315_9d82afcb9905db1f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-Jul-17-2020-02-58-52-96-AM.png?width=624&name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-Jul-17-2020-02-58-52-96-AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn69@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118305217_7b77897731241cc6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-2.png?width=624&name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn61@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118311293_834d92c010398990.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-Jul-17-2020-02-58-53-09-AM.png?width=434&height=479&name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-Jul-17-2020-02-58-53-09-AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn78@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118312965_68d5c35831fa4a32.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-3.png?width=624&height=372&name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn41@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118309914_39fee62a47a2e7a8.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-1.png?width=315&height=569&name=It%E2%80%99s%20the%20Little%20Things%20How%20To%20Write%20Microcopy-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn89@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118310463_b12de36469148383.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwriting-great-microcopy&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn77@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118312121_28b20bbff415ec5d.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:41","title":"What Is a Whitepaper? [FAQs]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-a-whitepaper-examples-for-business","description":"<p>The definition of a whitepaper varies heavily from industry to industry, which can be a little confusing for marketers looking to create one for their business.</p> \n<p>The old-school definition comes from politics, where it means a legislative document explaining and supporting a particular political solution.</p> \n<p> In tech, a whitepaper usually describes a theory behind a new piece of technology. Even a business whitepaper can serve a variety of uses and audiences -- some more product-focused than others. And although it is put together like an ebook, the two are written quite differently.</p> \n<h3></h3> \n<p>We're here to arm you with the <em>best</em> definition of a whitepaper in the context of business and what to do (and not do) as you create one. This article covers:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"#what-is-whitepaper\">What is a whitepaper?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"#how-to-write-whitepaper\">How to write a whitepaper</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"#whitepaper-examples\">Whitepaper examples</a></li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h2>What Is a Whitepaper?</h2> \n<p><strong>A whitepaper is a persuasive, authoritative,</strong><strong style=\"font-size: inherit;\"> in-depth report on a specific topic that presents a problem and provides a solution.</strong></p> \n<p>Marketers create whitepapers to educate their audience about a particular issue, or explain and promote a particular methodology. They're advanced problem-solving guides. Typically, whitepapers require at least an email address for download (usually they require information more than that), making them great for capturing leads.</p> \n<h3>What Isn't a Whitepaper?</h3> \n<p>A product pitch.</p> \n<p>Although Investopedia <a href=\"http://www.investopedia.com/terms/w/whitepaper.asp\">defines</a> a whitepaper as \"an informational document issued by a company to promote or highlight the features of a solution, product, or service,\" be warned that overtly shilling your own stuff could turn off your readers.</p> \n<p>The goal of a whitepaper is to inform and persuade based on facts and evidence, not tell the world why people need to buy your product right now.</p> \n<h3>How Are Whitepapers Different From Blog Posts and Ebooks?</h3> \n<p>Speaking of what a whitepaper <em>isn't</em> ... if you're looking for a quick and interactive way to present your value to the industry, a whitepaper is not your only option. There are also ebooks and blog posts -- both of which have various differences from a whitepaper.</p> \n<p>What really set these products apart are the size, appearance, and time commitment of each one. Whereas writing blog posts and ebooks can take anywhere between a few hours and a few weeks, a good whitepaper can take between a few weeks and a few months to write and polish. They're less flashy, much more serious in tone, and more heavily researched than blog posts and ebooks.</p> \n<p>Let me show you a comparison. The set below is one of our own ebook templates (<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/13-free-customisable-ebook-templates\">which you can get for free here</a>). It's a thorough but simple read:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/free%20ebook%20template%20cover.png?width=264&amp;name=free%20ebook%20template%20cover.png\" style=\"width: 264px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Cover of a free ebook template offered by HubSpot\" title=\"Cover of a free ebook template offered by HubSpot\" width=\"264\">&nbsp;&nbsp;<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/free%20ebook%20template%20page.png?width=274&amp;name=free%20ebook%20template%20page.png\" style=\"width: 274px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Page from a free ebook template offered by HubSpot\" title=\"Page from a free ebook template offered by HubSpot\" width=\"274\"></p> \n<p>Now, here is a whitepaper based on our latest research on emerging tech for small to mid-sized businesses (a great report -- <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/emerging-tech-for-smbs\">see the web version here</a>). You can see how much detail whitepapers can go into, both in text and in its images:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/emerging%20tech%20for%20business%20whitepaper%20cover.png?width=278&amp;name=emerging%20tech%20for%20business%20whitepaper%20cover.png\" style=\"width: 278px; margin: 0px auto;\" width=\"278\" alt=\"hubspot research whitepaper cover that reads: &quot;a practical approach to emerging tech for smbs&quot;\">&nbsp;&nbsp; <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/emerging%20tech%20for%20business%20whitepaper%20page.png?width=276&amp;name=emerging%20tech%20for%20business%20whitepaper%20page.png\" style=\"width: 276px; margin: 0px auto;\" width=\"276\" alt=\"hubspot research whitepaper internal page that is about why blockchain matters\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Images via <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/file:///Users/brbecker/Downloads/HubSpot%20Emerging%20Tech%20Report%20(1).pdf\">HubSpot Research [PDF]</a></span></p> \n<p>Ebooks and whitepapers can start on the same template. But ultimately, whitepapers are the academic papers of marketing content. Readers expect a high degree of expertise backed by solid research that is fully documented by references.</p> \n<p>Ebooks, on the other hand, are often extensions of a subject you cover regularly on a blog. They can come out of diligent research, but they appeal to a wider audience when unpacking a business subject.</p> \n<p>You can imagine this makes them kind of boring in comparison -- truthfully, most people don't actually <em>want</em> to read whitepapers, but they do it anyway to build their knowledge of an operation they need more insight on before making their next move.</p> \n<p>For this reason, they tend to be particularly detailed and informative, authoritative, and written by industry experts. And these qualities can make some decision makers feel better about a future purchase.</p> \n<h3>What Makes a Good Whitepaper?</h3> \n<p>Technically, there are no minimum requirements for whitepapers. Anyone can call anything a whitepaper -- this doesn't mean you should, though. Without some boundaries on what is and what isn't a whitepaper, we risk confusing our audience and losing credibility. Here's what an A+ whitepaper looks like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Length: </strong>No fewer than six pages, including illustrations, charts, and references. Can be upwards of 50 if the topic requires that much detail. (Chances are, it won't.)</li> \n <li><strong>Structure:</strong> There is usually a title page, table of contents, short executive summary (optional but helpful), introduction, several pages educating the reader about the problem, several pages hypothesizing a solution, several pages offering an example of a company that used that solution to achieve results, and a conclusion.</li> \n <li><strong>Density: </strong>Denser than an ebook. Whitepapers aren't usually easy to skim -- in fact, readers usually need to read them over more than once to get every morsel of information out of it.</li> \n <li><strong>Format: </strong>PDF in portrait orientation (8.5\" by 11\").</li> \n <li><strong>Style:</strong> Professional, serious, well written, and well edited. I'd recommend hiring a graphic designer to design page layout, images, fonts, and colors as well.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Whitepaper Examples for Lead Generation</h3> \n<p>So, if whitepapers are so boring, why do marketers create them? Well, they're a great resource for your prospects and sales team, and they help you build credibility and trust with your readers. Also, people who choose to download whitepapers often are further into the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/19022/How-to-Leverage-the-5-Stages-of-the-Customer-Buying-Cycle-for-More-Sales.aspx\">customer buying cycle</a>.</p> \n<p>With that in mind, here are two use cases for a whitepaper:</p> \n<h4>A Technical Case Study</h4> \n<p>It's been said that case studies, like ebooks, are very different from whitepapers. However, some case studies are long enough that they're best packaged as whitepapers themselves.</p> \n<p>A case study is essentially the story of a customer's success reaching a goal as a result of their partnership with another party. This success is best conveyed through certain metrics the customer has agreed to be measured on. And depending on how technical or complex the service is that they received, the more research and detail other potential customers will want to see as they continue their buyer's journey.</p> \n<p>Therefore, case study-based whitepapers can be a terrific way of demonstrating thought leadership on a dense concept through a real-world example of how this concept helped someone else succeed.</p> \n<h4>A Reference Guide</h4> \n<p>Imagine you work for a company that sells kitchen cleaning equipment to restaurants and you write a whitepaper about the maintenance and inspection of commercial kitchens.</p> \n<p>That whitepaper is probably chock full of information about legal requirements for exhaust systems, cooking equipment, and cleanliness documentation that could put even the biggest kitchen maintenance enthusiast to sleep if read cover-to-cover.</p> \n<p>But it also serves as an incredibly useful reference for restaurant owners who want to know how to maintain their kitchens to pass inspection. Once they know how clean they need to keep their kitchens, they'll likely buy some expensive cleaning equipment from you because they see you as a helpful, detail-oriented, credible source.</p> \n<p>Many people create whitepapers for this purpose -- a resource that their leads can take with them to become better at their trade. Ideally, the better they become, the more qualified they are to work with the organization that gave them the whitepaper.</p> \n<p>Now that you know the purpose of whitepapers and how they differ from ebooks, it's time to get started in creating your own. With the above best practices in mind, here's the approach you can take to produce an excellent whitepaper for your audience:&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How to Write a Whitepaper</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Identify your audience's pain.</li> \n  <li>Do your research.</li> \n  <li>Create an outline.</li> \n  <li>Put pen to paper and flesh out your outline.</li> \n  <li>Use imagery to support your points.</li> \n  <li>Get feedback.</li> \n  <li>Invest in the formatting and design.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>1. Identify your audience's pain.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>While you're a subject matter expert in a unique position to provide content, you must consider your audience and what is going on in their lives. By creating a whitepaper that addresses (and solves) for their needs, you'll better be able to generate demand for your whitepaper.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>To do this, consider <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona\">creating a buyer persona</a>. This activity will help you put yourself in their shoes. Then, you'll want to consider what kind of information would attract them, how they'd use the information, and how it would solve their pain or problem.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>2. Do your research.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Whitepapers are informational in nature, and you'll want to determine how to provide information your audience can't get elsewhere. You can do that by:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Running an original study/survey</li> \n <li>Putting together unique case studies</li> \n <li>Detailing a unique process or project</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you're unable to do your own research, try drawing statistics from government and/or survey organizations and analyzing them in a unique way (and make sure you cite your sources).&nbsp;&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>3. Create an outline.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Because whitepapers are long-form in nature, an outline can help organize your thoughts. Consider sketching out your topic in the following format:&nbsp;</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Introduction and Synopsis</strong> - Introducing the topic of the whitepaper, explaining why it's important (from the standpoint of the audience), and what the whitepaper sets to do, convey, or solve.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><strong>Overview</strong> - Defining some some of the key terms you intend to use, detailing the variables or parameters involved, and summarizing what you'll discuss.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><strong>Body</strong> - Laying out all the key points and highlights you'll hit.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><strong>Conclusion</strong> - Explaining the key take-aways from the body and any action items the reader should take.</li> \n</ol> \n<h3>4. Put pen to paper and flesh out your outline.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Using an informational and fact-based tone, begin expanding on the ideas you have by using the outline as a guide. In addition, each paragraph should contribute to the overall goal of the piece.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>5. Use imagery to support your points.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Because whitepapers go deep on research and analysis, visuals such as charts, graphs, and tables can help you present information in a visually interesting way and make the paper easier to read.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>6. Get feedback.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>It's critical to present the best write-up you can for your readers. The higher quality it is, the more authority you'll have in your audience's eyes. Get feedback from someone you trust to catch typos or other issues with readability.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>7. Invest in the formatting and design.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>While it's not necessary to get too flashy with it, color, layout, and imagery goes a long way to make your whitepaper appealing.&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Whitepaper Examples</h2> \n<p>To provide even more inspiration, here are modern examples of whitepapers that are emblematic of great whitepaper execution (and why):</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">Not Another State of Marketing Report</a>, HubSpot</h3> \n<p>HubSpot does an amazing job every year compiling data from experts and partners to convey modern trends in the marketing landscape. This is useful for marketers because they can use the statistics to create marketing and sales content as well as learn from the macro shifts that are happening in the industry. The whitepaper presents this information with attractive graphs and short editorial summaries along with links to more in-depth articles on each topic.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot-whitepaper-example.jpg?width=400&amp;name=hubspot-whitepaper-example.jpg\" alt=\"hubspot whitepaper example: &quot;not another state of marketing report&quot; cover for 2020\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"http://pages.custora.com/ebook-ItsNotYouItsMyData-ChurnBook.html\">It's Not You, It's My Data</a>, Custora</h3> \n<p>Custora created this whitepaper about customer churn, why it's important, and how to prevent it. What makes this ebook great is that it promises concrete value to the reader (revenue savings from preventing attrition) backed by a wealth of data and actionable advice. Even better, the whitepaper is modern and attractive, so the reading experience is pleasant. This helps the reader consume the long-form content without friction.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/custora-whitepaper-example.jpg?width=400&amp;name=custora-whitepaper-example.jpg\" alt=\"custora whitepaper example: &quot;it's not you, it's my data&quot; cover that reads &quot;leveraging customer analytics to build a scalable customer churn prevention system&quot;\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"http://pages.custora.com/ebook-ItsNotYouItsMyData-ChurnBook.html\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://services.google.com/fh/files/misc/ai_adoption_framework_whitepaper.pdf\">Google Cloud's AI Adoption Framework</a>, Google</h3> \n<p>This whitepaper leverages Google's authority to persuade the reader into adopting AI. By providing a methodology in the beginning, Google aims to give the reader the tools to think through the power of AI as it can be applied to their business. Then, the whitepaper dives into more technical information for advanced readers.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-whitepaper-example.jpg?width=400&amp;name=google-whitepaper-example.jpg\" alt=\"google whitepaper example: cover that reads &quot;google cloud's AI adoption framework&quot;\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://cloud.google.com/whitepapers\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://cmap.amp.vg/web/c1qxwi3hzxffv\">Employees and Cybersecurity</a>, Excedeo</h3> \n<p>Excedo aims to educate about the security risks that employees may unknowingly pose to businesses when improperly trained. The whitepaper advocates about the types of internal IT policies and training that are essential in today's world.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excedo-whitepaper-example.jpg?width=400&amp;name=excedo-whitepaper-example.jpg\" alt=\"excedo whitepaper example: first page that reads &quot;employees and cyber security&quot; and an introduction to the topic\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://cmap.amp.vg/web/c1qxwi3hzxffv\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Whitepapers have a long history, and their uses have continued to change. Be sure to decide whether or not a whitepaper will actually serve your audience before spending the months-long process to produce it. Sometimes, an ebook will do just fine. On the other hand, long-form educational content has a place in your content strategy.</p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"></span></p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"></span></p> paper-examples-for-business&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn45@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118308526_a348a1e70de05b46.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"33 of the Best Social Media Marketing Blogs of 2020","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/5977/36-awesome-social-media-blogs-everyone-should-read.aspx","description":"<p>The great thing about the internet is that it's full of brilliant marketers sharing great information -- all for free.</p> \n<p>Social media is no exception.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>If you have some extra time in your week to add more blogs to your reading list, we recommend you consider subscribing to some of these 33 blogs specifically about social media marketing.</p> \n<h2></h2> \n<h2>33 of the Best Social Media Blogs</h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing\">HubSpot Marketing Blog</a></h3> \n<p>On the HubSpot Marketing blog, we strive to cover every topic that a modern-day marketer would need to know about. This includes social media. Not only can you find <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-marketing\">general posts about social media marketing</a>, but you can also find content and original research about <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-story-formats\">specific platforms, like Instagram</a>.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.socialmediaexplorer.com/\" title=\"Social Media Explorer\"> Social Media Explorer </a></h3> \n<p>Social Media Explorer, founded by Jason Falls, is constantly pumping out great posts on social media's impact on marketing and public relations.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://thefuturebuzz.com/\" title=\"The Future Buzz\"> The Future Buzz</a></h3> \n<p>Adam Singer's blog, The Future Buzz, takes a clear approach to social media marketing and SEO topics, and isn't afraid to take a stance against ideas and tactics he thinks are bad for marketers.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.ducttapemarketing.com/blog/\" title=\"Duct Tape Marketing\"> Duct Tape Marketing</a></h3> \n<p>If you're a small business owner, Duct Tape Marketing is a must-read for strategic and tactical advice about leveraging online marketing and social media to grow your business.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://www.socialmediatoday.com/\">Social Media Today</a></h3> \n<p>Social Media Today offers a diverse mix of news on social networks' latest developments and cutting-edge tips to perfect your use of each platform. The blog also hosts live Twitter chats from its Twitter hashtag, #SMTLive, on various social media topics twice a month.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://smallbiztrends.com/category/social-media\">Small Business Trends</a></h3> \n<p>The Social Media section of Small Business Trends, a large news property for entrepreneurs, is filled with expert social media advice and multimedia content for the small business.</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://www.webinknow.com/\" title=\"Web Ink Now\"> Web Ink Now</a></h3> \n<p>Author and speaker, David Meerman Scott shares great theories and real-life examples of social media's impact on marketing, as well as easy-to-understand content that is great for non-marketing executives.</p> \n<h3>8. <a href=\"https://rebekahradice.com/blog/\">Rebekah Radice</a></h3> \n<p>Rebekah Radice is an award-winning social media influencer, and her blog is evidence of her expertise in this industry. Her blog packages common social media topics into solution-based content that tells marketers what they need to know. She also hosts a podcast called Brand Authority, further expanding on the challenges she examines on her blog.</p> \n<h3>9. <a href=\"https://www.marismith.com/mari-smith-blog/\">Mari Smith</a></h3> \n<p>Mari Smith has been called the \"Queen of Facebook,\" and her Facebook-specific blog is a testament to this generous title. Smith uses the latest Facebook trends to create up-to-date insights for the modern social media marketer -- with ample video marketing advice to boot.</p> \n<h3>10. <a href=\"https://www.thesocialmediahat.com/\">The Social Media Hat</a></h3> \n<p>From social media to email marketing, this simple-looking property is an all-in-one resource for content marketers. The Social Media Hat also includes a recommended list of marketing tools, giving you opportunities to apply what you learn from the blog to your marketing operations.</p> \n<h3>11. <a href=\"https://www.jonloomer.com/\">Jon Loomer</a></h3> \n<p>Jon Loomer is a blogger and podcaster whose website offers both articles and video tutorials on all things Facebook marketing.</p> \n<h3>12. <a href=\"https://www.toprankblog.com/\" title=\"TopRank Online Marketing Blog\"> TopRank Online Marketing Blog </a></h3> \n<p>The TopRank blog has a long history of delivering a great blend of search engine and social media marketing information in easily digestible lists and posts.</p> \n<h3>13. <a href=\"https://www.socialmedia.biz/\">SocialMedia.biz</a></h3> \n<p>This comprehensive blog breaks down its social media content into News, Business, How-To, and Marketing topics -- providing a reader experience that is sorted according to the unique social media challenges you might face in your career.</p> \n<h3>14. <a href=\"https://www.dreamgrow.com/\">DreamGrow</a></h3> \n<p>DreamGrow is dedicated to social media in the context of content marketing. The blog caters to both content creators and marketing strategists, showing readers how to use social media to grow as businesses and as individuals.</p> \n<h3>15. <a href=\"https://www.marketingprofs.com/marketing/library/articles/\" title=\"Marketing Profs Daily Fix\"> MarketingProfs Daily Fix</a></h3> \n<p>While MarketingProfs reserves some of its content for paid members, its Daily Fix blog offers great daily marketing content for free.</p> \n<h3>16. <a href=\"https://www.zdnet.com/blog/feeds?tag=mantle_skin;content\" title=\"Social Business\" style=\"font-size: 1.5rem;\"> Social Business</a></h3> \n<p>Eileen Brown's blog, a property of ZDNet, is an expansive resource for emerging trends relating to social media's impact on business.</p> \n<h3>17. <a href=\"http://askaaronlee.com/\">Ask Aaron Lee</a></h3> \n<p>Aaron Lee is a social media manager from Malaysia, who uses his experience as an entrepreneur to educate half a million readers worldwide on using social media to grow a business.</p> \n<h3>18. <a href=\"http://altitudebranding.com/\" title=\"Altitude Branding\" style=\"font-size: 1.5rem;\"> Altitude Branding</a></h3> \n<p>For thoughtful and honest commentary and advice on social media and conducting business on the web, check out Amber Naslund's blog.</p> \n<h3>19. <a href=\"https://davefleet.com/\" title=\"Dave Fleet\"> Dave Fleet</a></h3> \n<p>Dave's blog provides valuable information regarding how social media has an impact on brands and traditional communications functions like public relations and advertising.</p> \n<h3>20. <a href=\"https://www.socialmediaexaminer.com/\" title=\"Social Media Examiner\"> Social Media Examiner</a></h3> \n<p>With tons of great guest authors and consistent how-to content, Social Media Examiner offers a ton of free advice for marketers across industries.</p> \n<h3>21. <a href=\"https://www.convinceandconvert.com/category/social-media-marketing/\" title=\"Convince and Convert\"> Convince &amp; Convert</a></h3> \n<p>Jay Baer provides actionable information about the best ways to use social media to improve reach and convert new customers.</p> \n<h3>22. <a href=\"http://web-strategist.com/blog/\" title=\"Web Strategy by Jeremiah Owyang\"> Web Strategy by Jeremiah Owyang</a></h3> \n<p>For an analyst's perspective on high-level social media concepts and emerging trends like social CRM, take a minute to check out Jeremiah's blog.</p> \n<h3>23. <a href=\"https://searchengineland.com/\" title=\"Search Engine Land\"> Search Engine Land</a></h3> \n<p>Long-time search engine marketing resource Search Engine Land provides expert advice on search marketing.</p> \n<h3>24. <a href=\"https://problogger.com/\" title=\"ProBlogger\"> ProBlogger</a></h3> \n<p>For those who are interested in improving and expanding their blog across all their digital channels, ProBlogger discusses the strategies and tactics needed to become a successful blogger.</p> \n<h3>25. <a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/insights/\">Sprout Social</a></h3> \n<p>Sprout Social is a social media management tool whose <em>Insights</em> blog is always tuned to the latest best practices in social media marketing -- from what content to post to using chatbots for better customer service.</p> \n<h3>26. <a href=\"https://badpitch.blogspot.com/\" title=\"Bad Pitch Blog\"> Bad Pitch Blog</a></h3> \n<p>The Bad Pitch Blog points out mistakes other marketers have made so that you won't make them, too. You'll find some important perspective on media relations -- across all digital channels -- in these posts.</p> \n<h3>27. <a href=\"https://moz.com/blog/category/social-media\">The Moz Blog</a></h3> \n<p>Moz is known for offering expert tools and advice on search engine optimization (SEO). What you might not know is that the famous Moz Blog also gives you social media advice from the unique perspective of SEO.</p> \n<h3>28. <a href=\"https://pegfitzpatrick.com/blog/\">Peg Fitzpatrick</a></h3> \n<p>Peg Fitzpatrick is the author of the best-selling book, \"The Art of Social Media,\" and her blog is an equally creative take on social media marketing for today's content producers.</p> \n<h3>29. <a href=\"https://www.razorsocial.com/blog/\">RazorSocial</a><em><br></em></h3> \n<p>RazorSocial's social media blog is one of nine content categories that shows you different ways of thinking about content strategy, as well as how to perfect your use of certain marketing tools.</p> \n<h3>30. <a href=\"https://sociallysorted.com.au/\">Socially Sorted</a></h3> \n<p>This award-winning marketing blog comes from Donna Moritz, an Australian content strategist who writes about using social media to become a better storyteller.</p> \n<h3>31. <a href=\"https://neilpatel.com/blog/\">Neil Patel</a></h3> \n<p>Neil Patel is a marketing expert, entrepreneur, and consultant who's worked with a number of major companies like Amazon, NBC, and GM.</p> \n<p>While Patel's research and insights have been <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/author/neil-patel\">featured on our own blog a handful of times</a>, he also publishes content on <a href=\"https://neilpatel.com/blog/\">his own site</a>. While many of his posts relate to SEO, you can also find content around other digital marketing topics, including social media.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>32. <a href=\"https://later.com/blog/\">Later</a></h3> \n<p>Later is primarily known for its Instagram scheduling platform. However, they also have a pretty comprehensive social media blog that HubSpot's social manager, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/author/kelly-hendrickson\">Kelly Hendrickson</a>, personally loves to read.</p> \n<h3>33. <a href=\"https://buffer.com/\">Buffer</a></h3> \n<p>Similar to other blogs on this list, Buffer posts a handful of social-media related posts per day. Buffer, which is a personal favorite of our social media community manager, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/krystalwu\">Krystal Wu</a>, also use videos, original data, and infographics to tell visual stories about social media tactics.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2>Reading Up on Social Media Trends</h2> \n<p>The list of social media blogs is endless, and could be quite overwhelming to you. You might be asking yourself, \"How do I keep up with all 33 blogs on this list?\"</p> \n<p>The truth is that you don't need to read every single blog on this list every day. You just need to skim the ones that value your team and strategies most.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>To eliminate the need for constant surfing, when you find a blog you love, subscribe to its email list for daily notifications in your inbox.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>To learn more about social media marketing, be sure to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-marketing?_ga=2.33091454.1781837030.1595282187-631527517.1595282187\">check out our ultimate guide</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published in September of 2018 but was updated in July 2020 for freshness and comprehensiveness.&nbsp;</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F5977%2F36-awesome-social-media-blogs-everyone-should-read.aspx&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 27 Jul 2020 00:45:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/best-social-media-blogs.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"a0c7f27a335220d3c13873783e60a2bc","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn17@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118303660_202b6ddf232b8d82.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/best-social-media-blogs.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"kbodnar@hubspot.com (Kipp Bodnar)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F5977%2F36-awesome-social-media-blogs-everyone-should-read.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn69@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118304796_5658e2877dea5e50.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"5 Ways Go-to-Market Strategies Will Change in the Post-Pandemic Economy","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/waking-up-in-a-digitally-transformed-world","description":"<p><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">This article is part of a series on how business is changing as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Other pieces in the series include HubSpot's Chief Customer Officer on&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hubspot-cco-on-growth\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Why We Need to Talk About Growth</a><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">&nbsp;and our VP of Marketing's&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-playbook-for-times-of-crisis%5D\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Content Marketing Playbook for Times of Crisis</a></p> \n<p>The COVID-19 pandemic has produced a plethora of paradoxes.</p>  \n<p>As the rate of employment has gone down, the <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/08/unemployment-is-higher-than-ever-so-why-is-the-market-rallying.html\">stock market has surged</a>. As we find ourselves more socially distant from one another, we’re <a href=\"https://www.nbc26.com/news/local-news/pandemic-brings-families-closer-together\">connecting more than ever</a> with friends and family. And as <a href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/featured-insights/americas/which-small-businesses-are-most-vulnerable-to-covid-19-and-when\">growth has slowed</a> for many companies, their digital transformation has accelerated. Dramatically.</p> \n<p>Companies in nearly every industry have urgently adopted remote tools to allow them to support employees working from home. Millions of marketers have quickly signed up to automation software to help them move their entire marketing strategy online. And brick-and-mortar retailers have hastily acquired website management systems to enable them to spin up ecommerce sites.</p> \n<p>Plans for gradual, carefully managed digital transformation have been torn asunder by the pandemic, and the changes that many leaders thought would take years to implement have taken place in a matter of weeks. Entire industries are now waking up in a digitally transformed world awash with new opportunities ... and unknowns.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Is a remote workforce a threat to productivity or a boon for hiring? Is a fully online marketing strategy going to bring companies and customers closer together, or drive them further apart? Are rapidly adopted tech tools going to stimulate internal alignment or drive a wedge between teams?</p> \n<p>These are the questions that companies are asking themselves as they rewrite their go-to-market strategies and charge headlong into the new economic era. The answers will largely depend on whether they welcome the tides of change or attempt to row against them. Because, with change always comes opportunity, and the businesses that view this period of upheaval as a chance to create efficient new processes, upskill employees, and better serve their customers are the ones most likely to thrive in the coming years.</p> \n<p>To help businesses navigate their digital transformation journey with success, we’ve put together a list of five key ways in which go-to-market strategies are changing, along with advice on how to adapt to each.</p> \n<h3><strong>1. Outside Selling ➜ Inside Selling</strong></h3> \n<p>The pandemic has turned outside sales teams into inside sales teams overnight. And while some companies may view this change as temporary, most will witness first hand the benefits that come with inside selling and commit long-term to the model.</p> \n<p>In the digitally transformed world, prospects and decision-makers are less likely to be located in the same office — or even in the same territory — making it all the more difficult for outside salespeople to arrange meetings. Inside selling, however, gives salespeople the opportunity to connect with prospects at any time, from any location.</p> \n<p>Tools like live chat, 1:1 asynchronous video, and sequences — which allow sellers to schedule personalized follow-up emails to prospects — are now available as standard with many <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/sales\">sales software</a> products. These features enable salespeople to adapt how they sell to the way prospects want to buy and allow them to increase their productivity without losing the personal connection that comes with outside selling. In fact, inside sales teams make <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/inside-vs-outside-sales\">43% more phone calls</a>, leave 10% more voicemails, and send 9% more emails than organizations predominantly made up of outside sales people.</p> \n<p>On top of that, <a href=\"https://transaction.agency/ecommerce-statistics/85-percent-of-consumers-conduct-online-research-before-making-a-purchase-online/\">85% of consumers</a> now conduct online research before making a purchase decision, meaning salespeople’s time is better spent building relationships and providing prospects with helpful information online rather than placing the majority of their focus on running in-person demos.</p> \n<p>To successfully adapt to an inside sales model, companies should seek out sales software that’s user-friendly enough to allow their salespeople to get started quickly, while also powerful enough to provide them with a centralized view of customer data — an essential ingredient to delivering a personalized experience to prospects, even without meeting in-person. Sales leaders should also provide training to their teams on how to run effective demos online and set up webcams in a way that’s professional without being impersonal. According to <a href=\"https://www.gong.io/blog/how-to-turn-a-field-sales-rep-into-an-inside-sales-rep/\">Gong</a>, using a webcam in sales calls increases the likelihood of closing a deal by an eye-catching 41%.</p> \n<h3><strong>2. Offline Marketing ➜ Online Marketing</strong></h3> \n<p>If there is one image that illustrates the fact the marketing world is moving from offline to online during the pandemic, it’s that of empty billboards. From <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/03/business/media/ads-commercials-coronavirus.html\">Tokyo</a> to <a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/jer1961/49820126792\">Toronto</a>, outdoor advertising canvases that were once in high demand have been left blank as marketers pour all of their resources into online channels. And in most industries, it’s likely to remain that way.</p> \n<p>When a marketing strategy is fully online, it enables marketers to manage their budgets and strategies by metrics. Everything from webpage traffic and email open rates to social media engagement and digital ad ROI can be measured accurately, giving marketers a deep insight into which channels are the most effective at engaging customers. It also allows marketers to keep pace with rapid shifts in consumer behavior and adjust messaging and budgets in a matter of hours — something that takes weeks, or even months, to do with offline channels like TV and outdoor advertising.</p> \n<p>Never have these benefits been more visible than in recent months. As many offline channels have gone quiet during the pandemic, online engagement between consumers and companies has reached record heights. According to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/covid-19-benchmark-data-retro1\">HubSpot data</a>, website site traffic increased by 16% from Q1 to Q2, and marketing email open rates were 18% above pre-COVID-19 levels by the beginning of Q3. Companies that were already invested in these channels have not only been able to stay engaged with customers throughout the current crisis, they have been able to quickly adjust the tone of their messaging to reflect the times and communicate important information to their audiences in a timely manner.</p> \n<p>Companies that are embracing fully online marketing strategies for the first time should be cautious, however, to not open up too many new digital channels all at once. Doing so could overwhelm marketing teams as they’re coming to terms with new tools and tactics, and create a disjointed experience for customers. Instead, marketers should prioritize a small number of new tactics, set goals for each, and implement a system to measure progress. For example, instead of setting up accounts on every social media channel at once, which could be difficult to manage, marketers should choose one or two platforms that suit their brand and seek to build an engaged audience there before branching out. Similarly, teams seeking to implement an email marketing strategy for the first time should choose software that includes analytics features like A/B testing in order to closely monitor what’s resonating with audiences.</p> \n<h3><strong>3. Traditional Customer Service ➜ Self-Service</strong></h3> \n<p>During the pandemic, the volume of customer-initiated chat interactions has increased by <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/covid-19-benchmark-data-retro1\">45%</a>, and self-service options like this will go from being a “nice to have” to a “must have” in the eyes of consumers in the digitally transformed world.</p> \n<p>When a business empowers its customers to self-serve, everyone wins. Automated chat, for example, helps customers find solutions to issues more quickly than if they had to email or call a helpline, while also freeing up customer service staff to work on more complex customer issues. Businesses that had a chatbot on their website prior to the pandemic were well-positioned to manage the increased volume of queries that accompanied the crisis, and from here on, customers will expect to be able to have their questions answered in minutes without having to pick up a phone. After all, according to <a href=\"https://d16cvnquvjw7pr.cloudfront.net/images/blog/Infographic/zd_search_customer_self_service_inforgraphic.jpg\">Nuance Enterprise</a>, 67% of customers prefer to use self-service options instead of speaking with a company representative.</p> \n<p>Automated chat is just one of a number of ways businesses can provide self-service options to their customers. Companies should also consider building a knowledge base — a collection of resources that offer guidance on common queries — and creating product training videos for new customers. HubSpot’s version of this, HubSpot Academy, saw <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/covid-19-benchmark-data-edition3\">traffic double</a> between March and May, highlighting the growing desire of customers to engage with high-quality, on-demand video that enables them to become more skilled with the products they use.</p> \n<h3><strong>4. Funnel ➜ Flywheel</strong></h3> \n<p>According to research conducted by HubSpot in the midst of the pandemic, consumers cite “customer care” as the single greatest influence on their sentiment towards a company. As more companies come to see customer experience as the key to growth in the post-pandemic world, many will <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/our-flywheel\">abandon the funnel model in favor of the flywheel</a>.</p> \n<p>While the funnel focuses exclusively on <em>acquiring</em> customers, the flywheel is built to <em>delight</em> them over the course of their entire journey with a company. When companies embrace the flywheel, it enables them to place the customer at the center of everything, from how they attract and engage customers to how they help them achieve long-term success. Thinking of the customer journey in this way helps companies to identify the areas of their business in which they can remove friction and apply force in the name of delivering an experience so delightful, customers can’t help but tell others.</p> \n<p>There are three key steps to take when adopting the flywheel model.</p> \n<p>Firstly, companies should identify their core business metrics so that they can monitor progress and identify areas for improvement. Secondly, they should look for the parts of the flywheel in which they can add more force, in other words, the aspects of their business that have the greatest impact on key metrics. At HubSpot for example, we increased force by introducing a self-purchase option for prospects, expanding our knowledge base, and creating a dedicated customer marketing team to ensure that outgoing communications were consistent.</p> \n<p>As a third step, companies should identify points of friction that counteract force in their flywheel. A good starting point for companies seeking to reduce friction is to analyze the experience a customer has when they move from being the responsibility of the sales team to the customer success or service team. Does their new point of contact at the company have historical information about their purchase experience and pain points? If not, there could be an opportunity to remove friction by introducing a process or system that shares new customer information between different teams.</p> \n<h3><strong>5. Bloated Tech Stack ➜ Lean Tech Stack</strong></h3> \n<p>As companies accelerate their digital transformation, many are rapidly adopting a vast array of new technologies. The ample choice of powerful tools available at companies’ fingertips is unquestionably a positive thing, but there are potential downsides to consider. For example, when a businesses rushes to move its entire operation online — as many are now having to do — they run the risk of taking on a host of disparate tools that don’t work well together, leaving them with a bloated tech stack that creates data silos, increases administrative work, and makes it difficult for teams to stay aligned.</p> \n<p>In the digitally transformed world, we will see an increase in companies seeking to shed their tech debt and construct a lean suite of tools that enables them to move quickly in the post-pandemic era.</p> \n<p>When building a tech stack, companies should select a system that gives all internal teams access to a single source of truth on customer data. Without this, customer-facing staff will be working off different information, making it monumentally difficult to deliver the type of seamless, contextual experience that customers now expect. Additionally, businesses should consider how easy or difficult it is to integrate additional tools with their platform of choice. In order to keep a tech stack lean, companies need the freedom to build it in a way that suits their unique needs.</p> \n<h3><strong>The Great Acceleration</strong></h3> \n<p>The 1930s brought with it the Great Depression. Ten years ago, the Great Recession took hold. As an optimist, I hope this time will be remembered by businesses as “The Great Acceleration” — a time when companies in every industry and region underwent a rapid digital transformation that defined a new economic era.</p> \n<p>The go-to-market playbook for this era will be one made up of inside selling, online marketing, and self-service options for customers, underpinned by a flywheel mindset, and powered by a lean tech stack that enables them to keep pace with customer expectations. Companies that embrace these new strategies are the ones most likely to navigate these times with success and thrive in the post-pandemic world. And it is my hope that in years to come, businesses will look back on The Great Acceleration and remember it not for the economic stagnation that took hold, but rather for the rapid progress that took flight.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwaking-up-in-a-digitally-transformed-world&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 20 Jul 2020 11:45:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/digital-transformed-world.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"1edcfa4f16f34c2f10d9933c6ba5a134","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn21@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118303767_5543045bab522c35.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/digital-transformed-world.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"manderson@hubspot.com (Meghan Keaney Anderson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwaking-up-in-a-digitally-transformed-world&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn29@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118306495_8db86d2fdad043e1.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"8 Modern Tips for Marketing to Millennials","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-to-millennials","description":"<p>You've seen the articles lamenting the death of certain industries and changing consumer attitudes, all paying tribute (negatively or positively) to a certain generation born in the 80s and 90s. It seems that journalists love to write about Millennials and marketers love to analyze them. Why, though?&nbsp;</p>  \n<p>Boomers hold <a href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/this-depressing-chart-shows-the-jaw-dropping-wealth-gap-between-millennials-and-boomers-2019-12-04\">57% of the wealth in the U.S.</a> and are at peak buying power. With that in mind, is there a reason we never seem to stop hearing about Millennials?</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>Why Millennials Are Important to Marketers</h2> \n<p>As Millennials enter their 30s and 40s, often with student loans or young children, they haven't yet reached their full buying power compared to GenXers or Boomers. Nonetheless, there are multiple reasons to pay attention to this generation:&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>1. Millennials are the most lucrative market.</h3> \n<p>Even though as a group, they haven't reached their full buying power yet, their buying power eclipses that of other generations. They make up 25% of the population, and with an estimated annual buying power of <a href=\"http://www.millennialmarketing.com/who-are-millennials/\">over a trillion dollars</a>, they are the most lucrative market. Plain and simple: Nearly every marketer today is making Generation Y a priority – or at least working to understand what drives and delights this instrumental group.</p> \n<h3>2. Millennials switch brands.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Millennial market research performed by Daymon Worldwide suggests that only 29% of Millennials will buy the same brand, which is a much lower brand loyalty score compared to previous generations.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>This indicates that brands must do more to attract and keep Millennial customers, leading to the need for constant innovation on marketers' and service teams' parts.</p> \n<h3>3. Millennials are tech-savvy.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>According to <a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/09/09/us-generations-technology-use/\">Pew Research</a>, \"Almost all Millennials (nearly 100%) now say they use the internet.\" Having grown up with or only slightly before the internet, Millennials are not shy about using technology. This is attractive to brands who sell technology or use technology to sell.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>4. Millennials use devices.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Pew Research also found that 9 out of 10 Millennials have a smart phone. With widespread device ownership and use comes a higher likelihood of consuming web content, which gives rise to different modes of marketing.</p> \n<p>One key element that justifies Millennial domination of the marketplace is the fact this new marketing style – which we’ll delve into in just a minute – isn’t just a fad. Here, we’ll discuss important tactics for marketing to the demographic of the hour and explain why these tactics are lasting ones.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How to Market to Millennials</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Create authentic content.</li> \n  <li>Ditch outbound marketing methods.</li> \n  <li>Be informative with inbound marketing, instead.</li> \n  <li>Put them first and connect organically.</li> \n  <li>Market with intention rather than latching on to gimmicky marketing fads.</li> \n  <li>Be open to collaboration.</li> \n  <li>Push the convenient and practical side.</li> \n  <li>Lean into the fun and the experiential.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>1. Create authentic content.</h3> \n<p>Millennials are spending an average of <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/topics/2576/us-millennials-internet-usage-and-online-shopping/\">242 minutes online or using apps per day</a>, and they’re craving content-driven media. They’re scouring websites, blogs, and social media because they feel empowered by all of the remarkable content they’re discovering. They’re also sharing, liking, pinning, tweeting, snapping, forwarding, and commenting on all of their findings to impart this sense of empowerment to the online community. So, what makes this type of content really resonate with this group? Millennials trust what they feel is authentic.</p> \n<p>Interacting in a user-centric environment is what engages them, as <a href=\"https://www.socialmediatoday.com/news/survey-finds-consumers-crave-authenticity-and-user-generated-content-deli/511360/\">90% of Millennials say authenticity is important to them</a> when deciding which brands they support. Today, young shoppers’ attitudes and behavior are largely inspired by people they know in person or online, or even strangers who share their interests on social networks. Millennials carry these “advisors” with them on their smartphones and everywhere they go. They trust relevant, authentic opinions from real product users they can relate to. In fact, <a href=\"https://stackla.com/resources/blog/42-statistics-about-user-generated-content-you-need-to-know/\">Millennials believe that user-generated content is 35% more memorable than other media</a>.</p> \n<p>For brands that want to successfully reach Gen Y-ers, they simply need to speak their language. People ages 18 to 34 will perk up when hearing or reading words that could have come from the mouths of their peers, as these messages warrant comfort&nbsp;and trust. When you offer your audience content they would proudly share with others, you’re building a real brand-consumer relationship.</p> \n<h3>2. Ditch outbound marketing methods.</h3> \n<p>Millennials want to feel connected and involved when it comes to their purchases, and traditional marketing does not encourage this. Outbound marketing methods<strong>, </strong>like magazine ads, direct mail campaigns, and radio spots, do not impress Millennials. In the mind of a young consumer, these campaigns are impersonal and company-focused, filled with logos and void of any real substance. This generation demands more customer-driven, personalized marketing. Only 1% of Millennials say a compelling advertisement can build trust (<a href=\"https://www.iab.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Crowdtap_TheMarketersGuidetoUGC.pdf\">Crowdtap</a>).</p> \n<p>That’s why these young consumers do a lot of their research via blogs, forums, and YouTube videos. Odds are that an intrusive ad isn’t going to be a deciding factor. While such ads may be relevant to the person’s search history and may put the idea in the their head, seeing it wasn’t their choice. Millennials feel empowered to make their own online choices – which are usually inspired by their peers or other authentic content.</p> \n<h3>3. Be informative with inbound marketing, instead.</h3> \n<p>Millennials support businesses that are dedicated to improving their customers’ lives with informative content. Rather than product and service listings, Millennials want e-books, whitepapers, blog posts, videos, and other how-to information – and that’s inbound marketing. They appreciate thought leadership and expertise, so this is your company’s chance to provide killer content that ranks highly in Google and show young consumers that you’re the industry buff.</p> \n<p>Mac Cosmetics’ YouTube page is a great example of how brands can offer their audience how-to’s from the experts. People want helpful guidance, and when your company takes the time to provide that, they appreciate it and respect what you stand for. Mac is giving young viewers exactly what they want, where they’ll find it. <a href=\"https://www.theshelf.com/the-blog/youtube-habits\">54% of Millennials check YouTube daily</a>,&nbsp;so utilizing YouTube is perfect. A Millennial makeup lover is much more likely to tell her friends to check out Mac’s makeup tutorials than show her friends a print ad of Mac talking about how great they are.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/465783/3.png\" alt=\"3\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>4. Put them first and connect organically.</h3> \n<p>Millennials want to feel like your content was created with their interest (not their wallet) in mind. When this is the case, they are more organically introduced to purchasing your products or services. Without ever being “pushy,” your educational content helps build strong brand-consumer relationships. People appreciate honesty, and brands with transparent campaigns&nbsp;win.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/465783/hqdefault.jpg\" alt=\"hqdefault\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><br>And, what’s more transparent than encapsulating the spontaneous adventures of travelers in hostels – with skinny dipping? <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/hostelworld\">Hostelworld’s Meet the World</a> advertising campaign, which features genuine travelers that are strangers upon meeting and share a once in a lifetime adventure of skinny dipping, celebrates real travelers in real places who crave adventures, not souvenirs. This successfully speaks to Millennials because it screams “Live!” instead of “Buy!” – and that’s something that’ll stick with them. Most young people would rather have an unforgettable experience than seek out luxury, and Hostelworld gets that.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>5. Market with intention rather than latching on to gimmicky marketing fads.</h3> \n<p>If you think content marketing is a passing trend, think again! Here are some key examples of <a href=\"http://todaymade.com/blog/history-of-content-marketing/\">how content marketing has succeeded over the years</a>:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>1895:</strong> John Deere introduces&nbsp;<em>The Furrow</em>,&nbsp;a free publication with tons of farming tips and techniques to help farmers become more profitable. Today, it’s available in more than 40 countries and in 12 different languages.</li> \n <li><strong>1900:</strong> Michelin Tires released a 400-page auto maintenance guide with everyday drivers in mind, and also included travel tips. 35,000 copies were distributed free of charge before the company started selling the manual for a profit.</li> \n <li><strong>1904:</strong> Jell-O circulated free copies of its own cookbook, highlighting creative ways to use the unique product. In 2 years, the company saw sales increase to over $1 million annually.</li> \n <li><strong>1966:</strong> Nike released a 19-page booklet titled&nbsp;Jogging. It was filled with advice on enjoying running as a recreational activity, including posture and striking tips. This brought running, as a sport, to America, and it never once mentioned a Nike shoe.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/465783/5.jpg\" alt=\"5\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><br>We know that Millennial consumers value awesome, authentic content – so it looks like content marketing isn’t going away anytime soon. The inbound methodology, with its emphasis on strong and consistent content creation, is not a fad and will continue to win over your ideal customers.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>6. Be open to collaboration.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Today, Millennials are interested in having a say and becoming product co-creators. In fact, <a href=\"http://millennialbranding.com/2015/millennial-consumer-study/\">42 percent said they are interested in helping companies develop future products and services</a>. In our society, companies usually create products and hope that their target market will consume them. When it comes to Millennials, they want to be more involved with how products get created. So, companies that enable them to be part of the product development process will be more successful. Marketers need to focus on building relationships with consumers by fueling their self-expression and helping them establish their own personal brand.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/465783/6.jpg\" alt=\"6\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><br>Coca-Cola used online co-creation to gather expressions of its brand promise “<a href=\"https://en.eyeka.com/contests/6101-coca-cola-energizing-refreshment/results\">Energizing refreshment</a>.” They prompted their audience to unleash their creativity&nbsp;by interpreting Coca-Cola as an energizing refreshment in whatever style or format they wished. Coca-Cola gathered these videos, animations, illustrations, and photographs to use in its marketing campaigns worldwide. This method was mutually beneficially in that Millennials all over the world got to pour a bit of themselves into a product made <em>for</em> them, while helping Coca-Cola bring fresh authenticity to the market.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>7. Push the convenient and practical side.</h3> \n<p>Millennials <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/blakemorgan/2019/01/02/nownership-no-problem-an-updated-look-at-why-millennials-value-experiences-over-owning-things/#2049f5f3522f\">prefer use over ownership</a>, saying they would rather pay full price to access an item when they need it as opposed to owning it. These shoppers would rather rent, share, and barter than buy.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/465783/7.png\" alt=\"7\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><br>In this new “sharing economy,” mobile services and apps such as Spotify and Airbnb, and fashion sites like Rent the Runway and Relapse Clothing, have taken advantage of this crucial opportunity. This is also a new trend in the automotive industry. According to an analysis recently released by car-buying platform Edmunds, Millennials are acquiring cars – they’re just not buying them. Instead, they’re opting to lease more luxurious, tech-forward cars than they could otherwise afford to buy, such as Ram, GMC, and Lexus models. Capitalizing on this “sharing” mentality is a smart move for modern businesses, especially those targeting Millennials. Offer more creative and feasible options so that, in case consumers can’t yet buy, they can at least try.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>8. Lean into the fun and the experiential.</h3> \n<p>Young consumers increasingly see the act of researching and browsing for a purchase more compelling than the purchase itself. Millennials tend to crave the <em>experience</em> of shopping more than the purchase. In other words, online exploration is becoming more than a means to an end, with many young shoppers viewing e-commerce as a form of entertainment. This phenomenon has been coined as “Fauxsumerism.” Pinterest is a perfect example of how the shopping journey can also become an act of personal expression. This social platform, which helps users catalog prospective purchases by curating collections of items of interest, accurately reflects the facts that <a href=\"http://www.mobilecommercedaily.com/millennials-empowered-by-mobile-social-to-dictate-path-to-purchase-report\">40 percent of Millennials make wish lists of products</a>&nbsp;they want to buy (The Intelligence Group).</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/465783/8.png\" alt=\"8\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><br>Successful companies understand that young consumers want to have an enjoyable online browsing experience, which is why brands like Etsy show off their products on Pinterest, making perusing and pinning fun and social. No matter what platform you use, you should market to Millennials in entertaining ways in order to effectively engage them and inspire activity.</p> \n<p>Marketing to Millennials is a long-term play because this group is wired for authentic, content-driven, honest experiences that cater to who they are and their voices they yearn to share. Empower them with the pieces they’re looking for in this puzzling world and remind them that, because of their generation, the bigger picture is looking brighter. Keep this sentiment in mind as you consider millennials as one of your buyer personas.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August 2015 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-to-millennials&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"500 Apps of Summer: Customers' Top App Marketplace Picks","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/500-apps-of-summer","description":"<p>Last month, the HubSpot app partner ecosystem passed a notable milestone in <a href=\"https://medium.com/@HubSpot/why-hubspots-building-a-centralized-platform-c9017b2a09f9\">our platform journey</a>: we officially welcomed the 500th app to our <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps\">App Marketplace</a>.</p>  \n<p>App #500 was <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/sales/calling/falemais-voip-216592\">FaleMais VoiP</a>, a popular virtual calling platform headquartered in Brazil that now integrates with the HubSpot CRM. It was great to celebrate the 500-app milestone with their launch in the marketplace, as they represent the growing number of international partners in our ecosystem.</p> \n<p>We're thrilled to have apps from over 30 countries worldwide, from giant market-makers such as <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/ecommerce/shopify\">Shopify</a>, <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/sales/sales-enablement/slack\">Slack</a>, and <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/webinar/zoom\">Zoom</a> to entrepreneurial startups that are building apps exclusively for HubSpot, such as <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/ecommerce/depositfix\">DepositFix</a>, <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/sales/sales-enablement/geomaptool-178602\">GeoMapper</a>, and <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/productivity/project-management/psohub-213771\">PSOhub</a>. A wide variety of solutions, from front-office <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/abm\">ABM</a> to back-office <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/productivity/erp\">ERP</a>, are available.</p> \n<p>Now, to be candid, the number of apps in our marketplace isn't our key performance indicator. We value quality over quantity, and we primarily measure success by how many customers find the apps in our ecosystem to be useful for their business. We're much more excited by the fact that customers have installed over 1,000,000 instances of these apps.</p> \n<p>In fact, most HubSpot customers each install 5 or more apps, indicating customers know the value of an integrated stack. We're not the only ones seeing this growth, Blissfully's 2020 <a href=\"https://www.blissfully.com/saas-trends/2020-annual-report/\">Saas Trends</a> report shares mid-market companies (101-1,000 employees) average over 137 apps to grow their business — a 30% increase year over year.</p> \n<p>For our customers, HubSpot is able to serve as their system of record — \"a single source of truth\" — for customer data and engagement activity across their different tools. Acting as the glue to bring greater cohesion to their stack of SaaS business apps.</p> \n<p>As the ecosystem grows, HubSpot has <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/company-news/hubspot-grows-platform-ecosystem-to-500-apps\">launched improvements</a> to the App Marketplace to help ensure customers continue to gain value.</p> \n<p>Leaning into the pursuit of quality apps and improvements to aid customer choice, we added ratings and reviews and a new certification process to our App Marketplace last quarter.</p> \n<p>Ratings and reviews allow customers to share what they like best about these apps, how well they work with HubSpot, and what they want to see improved. Reviews include sub-ratings for ease of use, features &amp; functionality, value, and support &amp; documentation.</p> \n<p>We are happy to see how thoughtful customers are in sharing their feedback and opinions. App certification helps signify quality and trust for the customer. App certification is the process of having the HubSpot product team complete a technical review and approve an app for quality and efficiency.</p> \n<p>To celebrate the ecosystem's growth — in number of apps and in improvements to usability — we want to highlight some of our top apps.</p> \n<h2><strong>Top 30 Apps by Ratings and Reviews</strong></h2> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/500%20Apps%20of%20Summer-2.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>One of the best indicators of our customers preferred integrations is to look to the top rated and review apps in our App Marketplace. Most sales teams today are remote and lack the previous experience of selling remotely.</p> \n<p>Recently published <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/covid-19-benchmark-data-retro1\">HubSpot benchmark data</a> reveals, \"The ratio of call prospecting to email prospecting was almost 1:1 before the pandemic. Now it's closer to 1:2.\" With the increase in email and decrease in calling, response rates are historically low. Sales teams are entering uncharted waters.</p> \n<p>To aid the change we've compiled a list of top remote selling apps from July 2020 to help get the numbers of calls back to equilibrium and <a href=\"https://hubs.ly/H0rYGH40\">resources</a> to help companies sell from anywhere.</p> \n<h3><a signifies trust and quality for our customers. Our app partners apply to be considered for certification after being listed for six months and reaching a minimum number of installs. Certified apps gain HubSpot's stamp of quality after undergoing a technical review by our product team.. Below are the newest certified apps available in the App Marketplace for July 2020.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/sales/crm/dear-lucy-connector\">Dear Lucy</a>-- dashboards for sales and marketing</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/data-management/help-desk-migration\">Help Desk Migration</a> -- service hub import and export</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/sales/calling/cloudtalk\">Cloud Talk</a> -- make and receive calls in HubSpot</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/analytics-data/plecto\">Plecto</a> -- create dashboards for team performance and KPIs</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/analytics-data/octoboard\">Octoboard</a> -- live business performance metrics</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/live-chat/smszap\">SMSZap</a> -- SMS marketing and sales automation</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/wordpress/mailoptin\">MailOptin</a> -- grow and engage your email list</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/sales/calling/callingly\">Callingly</a> -- notify your sales team when you get a new lead</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/sales/calling/dialpad\">Dialpad</a> — connect and automate your business phone system</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/analytics-data/modata\">MoData</a> -- sales forecasting, pipeline, activity tracking</li> \n</ul> \n<p>We're grateful to our app partners who continue to innovate and build as our customers' needs evolve. We look forward to continuing to elevate these new solutions to help our customers' businesses grow better. To learn more about these apps or discover additional ones, visit the <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps\">App Marketplace</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2F500-apps-of-summer&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Jul 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/500%20Apps%20of%20Summer-2.png","linkMd5":"fedcc464e7cd7d9fade61af50e96369b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn49@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118301654_456e485d43f90c06.webp","author":"sbrinker@hubspot.com (Scott Brinker)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/500%20Apps%20of%20Summer-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn49@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118301654_456e485d43f90c06.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/500%20Apps%20of%20Summer-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn25@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118306101_02a0a298c79681f2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/500%20Apps%20of%20Summer.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn42@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118310348_f4911ea21eaec5df.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/500%20Apps%20of%20Summer-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn65@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118304976_40bbebf32d8f5a83.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2F500-apps-of-summer&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn81@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118304826_3b282262b2699216.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:41","title":"Grow Your Marketing Agency With These 7 Tips","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-grow-your-digital-marketing-agency","description":"<p>Creative agencies are at the heart of the campaign process for their clients. Did you know that <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing?hubs_signup-url=www.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing-statistics&amp;hubs_signup-cta=null&amp;_ga=2.258042442.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">over 75% of agency marketers</a> believe that they directly influence revenue? From this stat, it's easy to see that, whether your agency specializes in advertising or branding, you're actively helping clients reach their revenue goals.</p>  \n<p>But maybe your agency hasn't been growing as much as you'd like. If you're finding that you're having trouble gaining qualified leads and sticking out from competitors, you've come to the right place.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Growing your agency happens from the inside.
