In this post, we're going to talk about seven things you can do in-house that will help your agency grow. When things are uncertain, refer to these tips to grow your client base and develop lasting strategies that will support your business.</p> \n<p>Branding is an image that gives definition to your company in public. Sometimes, the first contact prospects have with agencies are their brand, so yours should speak to your agency.</p> \n<p>For those just starting out with branding, think about your company's mission and goals. From there, create a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/branding?_ga=2.86576088.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">branding strategy</a> that keeps those values, and your customer's needs, at the helm.</p> \n<p>Think about colors, symbols, and formats that represent the values of your organization. For more resources, check out some of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/branding?_ga=2.258148938.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">these branding strategies and tips.</a></p> \n<p>If you have a brand strategy set in place, focus on improving its structure. Invest in upping the branded content on your social media and website. Your specific, unique style will draw the eyes of customers, and the messaging will keep them engaged.</p> \n<h3>2. Adjust your pricing model if needed.</h3> \n<p>Do your prices accurately reflect the quality of your service offerings? If not, it might be time to adjust them. Make sure the price matches the effort, especially if you've experienced an increase in clientele.</p> \n<p>A set <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/pricing-strategy?_ga=2.258148938.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">pricing model</a> ensures you have enough resources to allocate within your company. You can charge hourly, by commission, or at a fixed rate. But in any case, if you change the pricing model, make it scalable.</p> \n<p>Scaling alleviates the need to constantly change pricing in the future. Frequently adjusting pricing models may result in a loss of certainty with clients. So, reflect what you offer with pricing, stick to it, and alert customers of the adjustment.</p> \n<h3>3. Find and optimize keywords on your website.</h3> \n<p>Think about some of the keywords most commonly associated with your company. Your industry, target audience, and offerings are most likely keywords essential to your business. A social media marketing agency, for example, might use keywords \"marketing industry,\" \"social media agency,\" \"social post scheduling,\" and \"social network analytics.\"</p> \n<p>When you figure out useful keywords, use them on webpages and in supporting content following <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-search-engine-optimization?_ga=2.258148938.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">SEO rules</a>.</p> \n<p>Optimizing your content with keywords gives those web pages a greater chance of ranking highly on Google. Google reads SEO language used on web pages to suggest the best ones for search queries.</p> \n<p>For instance, assigning <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/negative-keywords?_ga=2.258148938.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">negative keywords</a> makes your content show up on more relevant SERPs. In addition to negative keywords, producing branded content with those keywords gets your brand more reach, especially on Google.</p> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-keyword-research-ht?_ga=2.258148938.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">keyword research strategy</a> exposes the content you produce to a wide range of valuable prospects. The right keywords will help draw in the right people.</p> \n<h3>4. Use tools to create a scalable strategy.</h3> \n<p>The process you have for attracting new clients should be able to grow with your company. Your current strategy may not be scalable. Let's talk about how to create one that's more flexible.</p> \n<p>First, identify where in your strategy variables like time management and workload become a problem. When you know what to focus on, you can come up with a solution that serves your company's goals.</p> \n<p>Your new strategy should have room to expand as your company does. Take <a href=\"https://www.archimedia.co.nz/\">ArchiMedia</a>, for instance. The New Zealand-based company went from offering a few marketing services to being a full-service inbound agency. Using <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/growth-platform?hubs_signup-url=www.hubspot.com%2Fcase-studies-directory&amp;hubs_signup-cta=casestudy-readmore&amp;utm_campaign=Growth%20Stack%20Launch&amp;utm_source=Blog&amp;_ga=1.204202064.1181321780.1479841976\">HubSpot's growth platform</a>, the team expanded their strategy into a scalable one that supported the new services.</p> \n<p>The growth platform is a mix of HubSpot's CRM, marketing, and sales tools, specifically designed to maximize growth. ArchiMedia's team created CTAs, landing pages, forms, and analytics to refine lead capture. In five months, their newly expanded strategy <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/case-studies/archimedia?hubs_signup-url=www.hubspot.com%2Fcase-studies-directory&amp;hubs_signup-cta=casestudy-readmore&amp;_ga=2.258148938.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">doubled leads and increased turnover rate</a> by 30%.</p> \n<p>The new strategy fits the expanded services, and makes the process organized and streamlined. If you're not yet using tools to help you improve your strategy, it might be outdated. See what you can do with automation software — it may be what you need to flexibly grow your process.</p> \n<h3>5. Determine an upselling process.</h3> \n<p>Upselling offers more services to a customer on top of what they've agreed to purchase. It involves explaining to the consumer why they can't be without another product. Think about being asked about dessert after finishing dinner at a restaurant — that tactic is upselling.</p> \n<p>Agencies with an upselling process can use it to strengthen client relationships by providing for them at another stage of the buyer's journey. Instead of <em>just</em> offering the social media package to clients, offer analytics reporting for an added fee so they won't have to worry about it later.</p> \n<p>Think about what you can add to solve the challenges of your target audience beyond your core product. That way, your company earns more business. For more resources about how to upsell, check out these posts:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/upselling?_ga=2.252797513.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">9 Non-Sleazy Strategies for Upselling Your Customers</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/cross-selling?_ga=2.252797513.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">Cross-Selling and Upselling: The Ultimate Guide</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/how-to-upsell?_ga=2.252797513.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">How to Upsell Your Customers</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>6. Leverage client referrals to earn new customers.</h3> \n<p>Agencies often rely on referrals to boost lead generation. Referrals earn qualified leads from already existing clientele. Being proactive about collecting them gives you a larger sphere of influence, even if clients are already referring.</p> \n<p>Referrals help you gain clients with similar challenges to the ones of your buyer personas. They can work towards increasing your market share and drive revenue.</p> \n<p>Ask clients for a referral after they've shown satisfaction with your work. For supporting content, send an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/what-is-nps?_ga=2.252797513.1927936983.1595381564-940436819.1565181751\">NPS survey</a>, create an offer to share, or build an email template. When you ask clients, you'll have measurable content to give.</p> \n<p>When you ask customers, think about giving an incentive so your client will be more inclined to take part. Alternatively, you can start a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-referral-program?hubs_signup-url=blog.hubspot.com%2Fservice%2Fhow-to-get-referrals&amp;hubs_signup-cta=null\">referral program</a>, so you'll always have a set process for referrals. For more ideas about how to use client referrals, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/how-to-get-referrals\">check out this list of 14</a>.</p> \n<h3>7. Have a specialization as a selling point.</h3> \n<p>Whether your agency offers one specific skill set or a multitude of services, focus on a specialization. In other words, choose one offering that your customers love, and use it as a selling point.</p> \n<p>Having a specialization helps you earn leads looking for companies with that expertise. When they find your business, they'll be exposed to the full range of how you can help, giving you an upselling opportunity.</p> \n<p>Specialization also helps with branding, as customers identify one service the company is known for — defining your business to prospects. If your social media agency runs near-foolproof campaigns for clients, market that component, and use client referrals to gain more business in that sector.</p> \n<p>You can also use specializations to point out which offering needs more clients by using referrals to revamp and remarket to target customers.</p> \n<p>Whether you're part of a young agency that's just starting out, or in the process of revamping, there's always room for improvement. Maybe you've had a couple of these ideas on the back burner. It might be the perfect time to really dive into how they can help your business in the long run.</p> \n<p>What are going to choose from this list to grow your marketing agency? I can't wait to see what you come up with.</p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-grow-your-digital-marketing-agency&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/digital-marketing-agency-1.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"0c6adb6b1af58c1fc8dbf1404b81a9b1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn25@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118303645_83e34779c582d77a.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/digital-marketing-agency-1.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-grow-your-digital-marketing-agency&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn5@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118313279_bbf724f7a804ee48.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"13 Online Team Building Games to Try with Colleagues","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/online-team-building-games","description":"<p>\"As the saying goes, the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. This is especially true in the context of distributed teams,\" says <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/mcw22/?src=aff-lilpar&amp;veh=aff_src.aff-lilpar_c.partners_pkw.123201_plc.adgoal%20GmbH_pcrid.449670_learning&amp;trk=aff_src.aff-lilpar_c.partners_pkw.123201_plc.adgoal%20GmbH_pcrid.449670_learning&amp;clickid=yCBWJMzKrxyOTv1wUx0Mo38WUkiWFqVxRyHJTQ0&amp;irgwc=1\">Meaghan Williams</a>, HubSpot's Remote Work and Inclusion Program Manager.</p> \n<p>Team building gives your team a greater sense of togetherness.</p>  \n<p>Most likely, you can envision team building games in your head: exciting team outings, fun outdoor activities, or after-work happy hour chats.</p> \n<p>But what does team building <em>online</em> look like?</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>When members of your team work remotely, it can be a slight hurdle to foster team building without face-to-face contact. Williams notes, \"It can be hard to build that same sense of belonging and commitment to the team when you’re remote. That’s where <em>remote team building</em> comes into play.\"</p> \n<p>Although it can be tough to figure out how to build team morale virtually, the task isn't impossible.</p> \n<p>Remote team building games improve the morale of your team and their sense of belonging, which is essential for your team's overall productivity and employee satisfaction</p> \n<p>We've put together a list of exciting team building exercises and games for your remote team to try out. Let's go over them in the next section.</p> \n<h2>Online Team Building Games</h2> \n<p>When coming up with ways to bond with your team online, Williams suggests assuming that anything is an option. This mindset combats restrictive thinking with games and opens up new realms of possibilities.</p> \n<p>\"This mentality has led to everything from remote yoga to remote holiday parties, and we’ve had so much fun along the way,\" she says.</p> \n<p>So with that in mind, let's go over exciting options for building up your team.</p> \n<h3>1. Remote MTV \"Cribs\"</h3> \n<p>Similar to the workings of the hit MTV show <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV_Cribs\">\"Cribs,\"</a> you and your team could spend some time showing off your remote work spaces. This game, inspired by the team at <a href=\"https://www.helpscout.com/blog/virtual-team-building/\">Help Scout</a>, is a fun way to get a look into the workspaces of your teammates.</p> \n<p>To give it a \"challenging\" aspect, have team members vote on their favorite workspace at the end, and the winner can enjoy the bragging rights of having the most impressive remote work setup.</p> \n<h3>2. Remote Work Bingo</h3> \n<p>Using a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/free-customizable-business-babble-bingo-cards?_ga=2.80748695.1820706288.1588960737-940436819.1565181751\">bingo template</a>, create a bingo card and schedule a quick game as a \"brain break\" for you and your team. You can make it personalized to fit your company and team like the one below:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/17%20Online%20Team%20Building%20Games%20to%20Try%20with%20Colleagues.png?width=1500&amp;name=17%20Online%20Team%20Building%20Games%20to%20Try%20with%20Colleagues.png\" alt=\"Remote Bingo template from HubSpot\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\">\n</div> \n<p>Have your teammates submit ideas for Bingo spaces to make it a collaborative process. You can even offer a prize for the winner, such as an online gift card. Another plus — Bingo is easy enough to build into a routine meeting.</p> \n<p>To make Bingo work remotely, pick one person to be the moderator. They would call out a random phrase and wait a few seconds for players to search their card for that phrase. If the player has that phrase on their card, they'd use a tool, such as paint, to mark that space.</p> \n<p>Once a player has marked enough spaces in a row, they'd announce <em>\"Bingo!\" </em>in the video call and wait for the moderator to check their answers. If the row is vertical, horizontal, or diagonal, and matches the spaces, that colleague wins.</p> \n<h3>3. Mafia</h3> \n<p>Mafia is known by a couple of different names, and is often played by large groups. Essentially, the game is a \"whodunnit\" mystery-solving challenge. One of the players is a silent \"killer,\" and it's up to everyone else to figure out the culprit.</p> \n<p>There's a couple of roles to assign in Mafia to keep organizational structure, like \"Doctor,\" \"Townspeople,\" and \"Detective.\" The best part about the game? It can all be played over a video call. Click <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mafia_(party_game)\">here</a> for a full run-down of how to play Mafia.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, we re-created Mafia to fit in a Zoom call. We used a combination of the chat box, Slack, and turning off cameras to re-imagine the campfire classic in a virtual setting.</p> \n<h3>4. Happy Hour</h3> \n<p>One of the most fun remote team building events I've done with my team has been remote happy hour. It's an opportunity for your colleagues to get together and bond outside of work, remotely.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, we use happy hours to foster a deeper relationship with team members. At one point, we even held a virtual wine tasting, where participants brought a glass of German wine and listened to a colleague explain how to taste for specific qualities, and pointed out things about wine that aren't common knowledge, like how to create air in a wine glass.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Participants can bring any beverage they choose (tea, seltzer, or other non-alcoholic beverages should be encouraged as well), talk about what they've brought, and enjoy a relaxed atmosphere.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>5. Emoji Stories</h3> \n<p>Using less than six emojis, begin to write a story in an instant message thread or the chat section of a video call. Then, one by one, your coworkers will add to that story using five more. You can keep going until every teammate has had a turn, or until you run out of ideas.</p> \n<p>To get the ball rolling, here's a potential story starter: 🏘⛈💡🚫 … what happens next to the neighborhood with no power during a storm?</p> \n<h3>6. DIY Pantry Challenges</h3> \n<p>Are the members of your team obsessed with shows like <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MasterChef_(American_TV_series)\">MasterChef</a> or <a href=\"https://www.foodnetwork.com/shows/chopped\">Chopped</a>? Alternatively, are they big into YouTube cooking shows, like Bon Appetit's <a href=\"https://www.bonappetit.com/video/series/gourmet-makes\">Gourmet Makes</a>? If so, it could be fun to challenge your colleagues to create their own version of a popular cooking show or a tutorial of their favorite comfort food recipes!</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 1500px; max-height: 1500px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 100.00%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Xi28pEbMdTw\" width=\"1500\" height=\"1500\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>This can be done in a variety of ways, but to give it a \"challenging\" aspect, pick one dish that's simple to make, like a patty melt or mac and cheese. Give your team one week to film their own versions of the recipe, upload it to a Google Drive, and choose the winner based on creativity of the dish.</p> \n<p>Cooking is an awesome way to express creativity, and as the saying goes, food often brings people together. Plus, leftovers mean there's no extra thinking to do when it's lunchtime!</p> \n<h3>7. Book Club</h3> \n<p>HubSpotters are no strangers to book clubs. A recent book club we've hosted centered around a theme of diversity, inclusion, and belonging. One of our colleagues chose a <a href=\"http://mindaharts.com/book/\">book to fit this theme, </a>and participants had a discussion to talk about what the book meant to us and how we could transfer the ideas presented in the book to create change in the workplace.<a href=\"http://mindaharts.com/book/\"></a></p> \n<p>This can be a recurring event or a one-time session, but the purpose is to discuss ideas outside of team projects. It can be a nice break from your day to discuss a good book — whether it's every month or a couple of times a year.</p> \n<h3>8. Pop Culture Trivia</h3> \n<p>What song did Britney Spears perform at the <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PBlBaCigDAs\">2001 VMAs</a>? What fictional town does sitcom <a href=\"https://www.nbc.com/parks-and-recreation\">Parks and Recreation</a> take place in? Unwind with your coworkers in a friendly game of pop culture trivia — 2000's style.</p> \n<p>You can come up with questions with your team, or look up fun prompts <a href=\"https://www.washingtontimes.com/quiz/2019/may/16/do-you-remember-2000s/\">online</a>. Assign a moderator, split your team up into groups, and let the games begin!</p> \n<h3>9. Farm Field Trip</h3> \n<p>Do you remember taking field trips with your classmates when you were younger? They were fun outings to learn and explore with peers. Nowadays, field trip experiences are moving to an online platform so those young and old are able to enjoy these gatherings virtually.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>As an example, you might chat with a local farm to see if they'd be willing to set up a <a href=\"https://www.americandairy.com/news-and-events/dairy-diary/dairy-farming/virtual-farm-tours-while-youre-stuck-at-home.stml\">remote farm tour</a> for your team. We've done this at HubSpot, and it's a great way to bond with colleagues as you virtually fuss over the adorable pigs or goats you see on-screen.</p> \n<h3>10. Scavenger Hunt</h3> \n<p>When was the last time you went on a deep dive of your company website? If your answer is, <em>\"Never,\"</em> here's your chance to challenge your colleagues. Choose pages or tabs from your company's website for yourself and team members, and come up with a group scavenger hunt.</p> \n<p>Break off into teams, or make it a solo venture. After 20 minutes, whoever gets the most points, wins! An idea to get the scavenger hunt ball rolling: <em>\"Find the testimonial from X customer.\"</em></p> \n<h3>11. Lunch and Learn</h3> \n<p>Send an RSVP to your team to join a webinar and learn a new skill. Alternatively, have your colleagues take turns to host mini lunch and learn sessions for tips about how to perform job functions in a simpler way. For instance, if I were to host a session, it might be \"How to Create Awesome Meta Descriptions in Less Than 15 Minutes.\"</p> \n<p>If your team members have very specific roles that differ, this could be a cool opportunity to learn a little more about what your colleagues do. For instance, your social media manager might host one session about his role regarding social accounts, while your web designer hosts another about her experience designing for UX.</p> \n<p>These sessions would give the other insight into how to perform a job function and build a new appreciation for the day-to-day of colleagues.</p> \n<h3>12. Never Have I Ever</h3> \n<p>\"Never Have I Ever: Remote Work Edition\" is another quick stress reliever that helps you learn more about your colleagues. Here are the rules: a team member says something they've never done before, but if those playing have done it, they lower one of their fingers. The person with the most fingers left wins the game.</p> \n<p>If I were to host a version of the game, my first entry might be, <em>\"Never have I ever bought noise-cancelling headphones.\"</em></p> \n<h3>13. Virtual Dance Party</h3> \n<p>If you're like me, you're known for your pretty amazing work playlists. What better way to wind down after a long workday than with a no-judgement dance party with your colleagues? You can even pull up a song from the <a href=\"https://justdancenow.com/\">Just Dance</a> video game series and learn together (you just need a smartphone!):</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 1500px; max-height: 1500px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 100.00%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/xQ79cheWg5g\" width=\"1500\" height=\"1500\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>There's no pressure to explode into a fully-choreographed sequence a la <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamma_Mia!_(film)\">Mamma Mia!</a> — all dance styles are encouraged. Blow off steam and enjoy a friendly competition with your team.</p> \n<p>\"Not every idea is going to be a winner, but what’s important is that you’re willing to be vulnerable with each other and give new ideas a try,\" Williams says.</p> \n<p>Additionally, she adds, \"If you’re just embarking on this journey for the first time, be honest with your team about this and ask them to provide feedback on what’s working and what isn’t. Even better, ask them to contribute their own ideas and lead the way on initiatives that they’re excited about.\"</p> \n<p>Team building is all about strengthening the bond of your team through different and fun activities. You can host a Pictionary session through a video call or encourage different areas of discussion during meetings. For more ideas on team building games, Williams suggests giving these options a whirl:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.patchworkadventures.com/\">Patchwork Adventures</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://jackboxgames.com/\">Jack Box Games</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.pinturillo2.com/\">Pinturillo</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Most importantly, remember to just have fun with your team and enjoy the time you have together!</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May,2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fonline-team-building-games&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 29 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/online-team-games.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"57ff994e6fdb0bf4e9a3f9664cce1c2a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn97@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118303768_d8bb3783b360c3a7.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/online-team-games.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/17%20Online%20Team%20Building%20Games%20to%20Try%20with%20Colleagues.png?width=1500&name=17%20Online%20Team%20Building%20Games%20to%20Try%20with%20Colleagues.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn93@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118308964_aaf9d9f7d6816201.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fonline-team-building-games&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn65@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118306089_c5e70bfe6d1d9fee.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"Your Blueprint to Create the Perfect Content Marketing Strategy","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-blueprint-ht","description":"<p>Creating content can feel discouraging.</p>  \n<p>For instance, you might spend hours producing something that's amazing, only to get little engagement, traffic, or leads. What's more, later, you'll have to explain that ROI to your boss — talk about a dreadful workday.</p> \n<p>If you're feeling frustrated or burnt out with your content creation process, you're in luck. Here, we've created a complete blueprint to a successful <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-plan?_ga=2.169641957.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">content marketing strategy</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Content%20Marketing-Jul-28-2020-01-42-46-34-PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Content%20Marketing-Jul-28-2020-01-42-46-34-PM.png\" alt=\"Content Marketing\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=More%20on%20@HubSpot’s%20blog%20post%20here:%20https://bit.ly/contentmbp%20pic.twitter.com/05GXNJcg7U\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><em>Share this image on Twitter!</em></span></a></p> \n<p>In this post, I'll walk you through the different aspects of the content blueprint and why each facet is so important for marketers to include in an overall strategy. For more information on content marketing strategies, we've <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/content-marketing-training-workbook?_ga=2.169641957.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">created a content marketing workbook</a> that's free to download.</p> \n<p>Otherwise, let's dive into creating a content marketing strategy that will bring you that ROI you're looking to earn.</p> \n<h2>How to Develop and Implement a Successful Content Marketing Strategy</h2> \n<p>We're going to look at three different stages that make up the blueprint. These stages will outline the main steps you can take to create your strategy. Then, we'll go into depth with details about making that happen.</p> \n<p>Let's start with step one — getting decision-makers on-board with your strategy.</p> \n<h3>Stage 1: Getting buy-in from your stakeholders in order to green light your strategy.</h3> \n<p>All great content marketing plans start with getting people within the company to buy into your vision — basically, the people who can give you the resources, budget, or information that's required to make your plans a successful reality.</p> \n<p>For example, internal customer-facing teams, such as customer support, can share their expertise and help fuel your content creation efforts. Because they have regular contact with customers, they'll know some of your audience's biggest challenges or what they care most about — which comes in handy when you need to create content those customers care about.</p> \n<p>Additionally, your marketing team likely has a limited budget. To implement certain strategies and forgo others, it's vital you're able to get leadership on board with your vision.</p> \n<p>To make this happen, you'll need a pretty awesome pitch. Generally, this pitch should do three things:</p> \n<h4>1. Talk about key challenges you will solve with your strategy.</h4> \n<p>You'll want to give an overview of the key challenges your content marketing plan will solve. Instead of complicating this step with an overload of data points, keep it simple and concise. Summarize your key challenges in just a couple of charts so it's more comprehensive.</p> \n<p>For example, in this chart below, the marketer's key challenge is that their overall <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/beginner-inbound-lead-generation-guide-ht?_ga=2.169641957.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">CPL</a> (cost per lead) is being inflated by the amount of money they are spending to acquire leads through paid programs.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/example%20of%20CPL.png?width=624&amp;name=example%20of%20CPL.png\" alt=\"example of CPL\" width=\"624\" style=\"width: 624px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">By implementing a solid content strategy, CPL can be reduced. Notice how this chart states the need for a strategy, presents key supporting data, and makes that information easy to comprehend.</p> \n<h4>2. Talk about how your strategy will relate to business metrics.</h4> \n<p>Try to always keep your audience in mind. Senior management will be focused on cost and revenue. How can your marketing strategy help with those metrics?</p> \n<p>In the example above, the answer is clear: Reducing the CPL reduces the cost it takes to acquire a customer, which can increase profit down the road.</p> \n<p>When you present your pitch to decision makers, make sure to outline how reaching your goal will also help reach the greater goals of your business.</p> \n<h4>3. Give high-level details on your strategy to achieve these goals.</h4> \n<p>Finally, you might consider talking through how your content strategy is going to help solve these key challenges and influence those business metrics. You can use this <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-plan-template-generator?utm_campaign=Offer%20-%20Marketing%20Plan%20Generator&amp;utm_source=HS-blog&amp;_ga=2.105532359.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">template generator</a> to help you organize your ideas. The goal of this step is to prove to senior-level management that you've thought through your plan and what resources you need to make it a reality.</p> \n<p>Now, you've created your pitch and you're ready to present to upper-level management. Remember, this pitch will help you convince the right people that your content marketing strategy will be successful.</p> \n<p>You should have a pitch before you begin planning your content strategy because you'll stakeholders will be aware of what campaign you plan to run to achieve your business goals. However, while you don't need to fully develop your strategy until you get support from leadership, it's still critical you spend time reviewing metrics and making a tentative game-plan for when you do develop the strategy.</p> \n<p>Next, we're going to talk about how to develop that aforementioned winning strategy.</p> \n<h3>Stage 2: Develop your content strategy.</h3> \n<p>In a <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/driving-content-success-in-2014?_ga=2.105532359.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">HubSpot report</a>, it was found that 56% of survey respondents said they were doing content marketing without a plan. Content creation can definitely be difficult, but having a content plan helps. It takes into account key challenges, business goals, and metrics, which will make you more successful in the long term.</p> \n<p>Let's talk about what a winning content strategy should include.</p> \n<h4>1. Include the buyer personas you are targeting.</h4> \n<p>At HubSpot, we <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/when-to-add-remove-persona-from-marketing-strategy-ht?_ga=2.105532359.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">align content around different buyer personas</a>. This allows us to stay really focused on for whom we're creating content. We keep our buyer personas' goals and challenges in mind so we can address these at each stage of the buying process.</p> \n<p>As an example, here is a persona I've built for a company software company that provides tools that streamline day-to-day business processes, offers inbound marketing courses, and makes reporting easier.</p> \n<p>Meet \"Marketing Macy\":</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Marketing%20Macy.png?width=784&amp;name=Marketing%20Macy.png\" alt=\"Marketing Macy persona\" width=\"784\" style=\"width: 784px;\"></p> \n<p>To make this persona, I used a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona?_ga=2.266618570.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">free persona builder</a> that made the process incredibly fun. In addition, I was able to point out exactly how to connect with a target audience by identifying why they would love a company and what challenges they were looking to solve.</p> \n<p>To create content that's going to be relevant to Macy at each stage of the buying cycle, we've included key information about her goals, challenges, and why she would love a company that offers CRM and CMS software. Knowing an ideal target customer like Macy makes it easier to connect with them.</p> \n<h4>2. Understand where the content gaps are in your buying cycle.</h4> \n<p>Make sure you understand where the content gaps are in the buying cycle for your buyer personas. To achieve this, you should conduct a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/company-content-audit?_ga=2.266618570.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">content audit</a>. Additionally, ask yourself if your buyer persona has the information they need at each point of the buying cycle.</p> \n<p>For example, at HubSpot, content is created that attracts Mary to our site and helps her evaluate our software based upon what we know about her goals and challenges. We then ask ourselves if she has everything necessary to feel confident in purchasing our product based on those goals and challenges.</p> \n<p>If you identify those gaps, you can focus on making sure that content is in your strategy. For instance, let's say that you have a gap in content for the evaluation stage. Identifying that is the first step in creating helpful content for that stage.</p> \n<p>Next, we'll talk about how to create and push the content that will bridge those gaps.</p> \n<h4>3. Create relevant content ideas and stick to an editorial calendar.</h4> \n<p>Once you have identified your personas and understand what content you need to move them through the buyer process, it's time to brainstorm content ideas to fill in those holes.</p> \n<p>When you understand to whom you're marketing, it can be easier to come up with relevant content. To ease the process further, check out our post about how to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-mapping-template-personalize-marketing?_ga=2.266618570.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">map out content</a>. Ultimately, though, make sure every piece of content you create is engaging, delightful, and created with intent.</p> \n<p>Ask yourself during the creation process if your content achieves those three things. Let's look at this social media post as an example:</p> \n<iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/post.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fhubspot%2Fposts%2F10158214020774394&amp;width=500\" width=\"500\" height=\"595\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe> \n<p>This post is engaging because it includes a graphic that attracts the attention of audiences. It's delightful, because the graphic and supporting copy are easy to comprehend and uses emojis to illustrate a point. Additionally, it's created with the intent to provide value to customers who may be looking for remote working tips.</p> \n<p>Creating content is half the battle, though. Another thing to figure out is when to schedule the publishing of that content so it gets seen by the right people and is delivered consistently.</p> \n<p>That is why all great content plans have an editorial calendar so that people within the company can see what content is being published and what dates that content is going live. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/business-blog-editorial-calendar-templates?_ga=2.266618570.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">Editorial calendars</a> keep teams in sync and organized — as far as visual workflows go, it's a necessity.</p> \n<p>When you've identified your persona, created content for them, and have finalized a calendar-based schedule, this stage is complete. The next stage is to figure out the publishing details.</p> \n<h3>Stage 3: Determine a publishing plan for your content strategy.</h3> \n<p>One of the biggest shifts in marketing today is transforming our mindset from that of a traditional marketer to that of a publisher. Sometimes, as marketers, we think in terms of immediate wins, which is why we tend to prioritize our ad budget for paid media. We invest a certain amount of spend in return for an approximate number of leads and customers.</p> \n<p>Moving to a publisher model means investing more upfront to <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-hubspot-does-inbound-creating-a-content-machine?_ga=2.266618570.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">start creating content assets that will have a far greater impact</a> over a longer period of time. For example, the HubSpot blog generates most of its traffic from blog posts not published in that month. This is because the content we've created in the past has long-term value for the company in both the leads and customers they generate each month.</p> \n<p>A lot of companies talk themselves out of publishing before they even get started due to a lack of immediate resources. However, a content team of one can be successful if they know how to source content effectively.</p> \n<p>Here are two tips to keep in mind to become a publishing rockstar:</p> \n<h4>1. Think about scaling your content by repackaging in several formats.</h4> \n<p>Consumers today connect with brands across different channels, whether that be on social media, through email marketing, or on your website. When developing a new piece of content, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/examples-repurposing-content?_ga=2.266618570.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">think about how you can repurpose that content</a> into various formats.</p> \n<p>For example, if you've developed a series of blog posts, such as a series about customer retention, you could turn them into a comprehensive customer service ebook.</p> \n<h4>2. Make sure the quality of your content always remains high.</h4> \n<p>Whether you're creating a single piece of content a week or several pieces a day, the quality of your content should always remain extremely high if you want it to pay off in the long run.</p> \n<p>Creating an editorial checklist will help you manage this process. With a checklist, you can quickly check each piece of content for quality issues and educate your team on what it takes to publish content for your company.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/content-marketing-blueprint?_ga=2.266618570.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">In HubSpot's content blueprint</a>, you'll find a range of templates that make scaling content really easy and provides an intuitive, ready-made editorial checklist.</p> \n<h3>Stage 4: Promote your content early and regularly.</h3> \n<p>So, you know about your target audience and you've created content specifically tailored to them. The task now is <i>how</i> to distribute that content to your audience effectively.</p> \n<p>The key to effective distribution is to increase the number of distribution channels, such as blogs, email, and social properties. Additionally, you have to expand the reach of that content to a broader audience.</p> \n<p>Promotion is a critical part of a content blueprint and something marketers should think about at great length during their planning phase.</p> \n<p>To become an expert at promotion, you should:</p> \n<h4>1. Make promotion an essential part of the planning process.</h4> \n<p>When my team is planning out a content campaign, we put as much thought into the distribution of that content as we do into the campaign development. We want to know who that content is for and how can we make sure they get it.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you are distributing content on social media platforms, discuss in great length how to prioritize budget, posting schedule, and using the tools offered by social channels to expand the reach of your content.</p> \n<h4>2. Make sure your team is equipped with promotional skills.</h4> \n<p>Being able to promote content to the right audience isn't an easy job. Over time, the skills to distribute content effectively will be critical to long-term success.</p> \n<p>If you want to learn more about how you can be effective at promoting your content, we have lots of information on outreach, seeding your content, and even the best way to repackage it for different networks to increase its exposure right inside — you've guessed it —<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/content-marketing-blueprint?_ga=2.103031364.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">our content blueprint</a>.</p> \n<p>Sometimes, learning the proper promotional skills comes with trial and error. You have to figure out what your audience responds to the most. For instance, you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing?_ga=2.103031364.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">create an A/B test</a> with the content you want to push on social channels to see what types of messaging your audience prefers.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can experiment with multiple content types to get a gauge of what targeted content really resonates with your audience. To get an idea, check out what your competition is doing, and what works for them. You can also do some <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/social-listening?_ga=2.103031364.590945011.1590369168-940436819.1565181751\">social listening</a> to observe the patterns in web behavior of your target customers.</p> \n<p>How are you doing with your content strategy so far in 2020? Where do you hope to improve your content marketing the most this year? With this guide, you'll be fully prepared to take on the world of content marketing, and do it successfully.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcontent-marketing-blueprint-ht&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Jul 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/content-strategy-1.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"d574363ec7bcd48c06c2154c0aac4bb5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn97@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118303657_203e8f79b8926b19.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/content-strategy-1.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"kflanagan@hubspot.com (Kieran Flanagan)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Content%20Marketing-Jul-28-2020-01-42-46-34-PM.png?width=1500&name=Content%20Marketing-Jul-28-2020-01-42-46-34-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn61@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118306218_8dae128d0d082722.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/example%20of%20CPL.png?width=624&name=example%20of%20CPL.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn1@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118311530_66fd4ffd36ea2ff3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Marketing%20Macy.png?width=784&name=Marketing%20Macy.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn54@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118310135_eb182b80db1a414c.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcontent-marketing-blueprint-ht&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn61@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118312815_a7ff32619890bf57.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:41","title":"The Ultimate Guide to On-Page SEO in 2020","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33655/a-step-by-step-guide-to-flawless-on-page-seo-free-template.aspx","description":"<p>So, you've read dozens — if not hundreds — of SEO articles online. You've digested countless tips and tricks for improving your website's SEO. You've even (over)paid that self-proclaimed \"expert\" to help you develop an SEO strategy that aligns with your business goals.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>But after all of the reading and learning and strategizing, it dawns on you: You haven't actually<em> done</em> anything yet. Perhaps you're intimidated. Maybe you're crunched for time.</p> \n<p>Regardless, when it comes to on-page SEO, there's no excuse for dragging your feet. On-page SEO has the power to bring countless new visitors — and customers — right to your website.</p> \n<p>On-page SEO is also completely up to you: <em>You </em>get to establish what the topic and/or goal of each page will be. <em>You</em> get to decide on the target audience for that page. And <em>you</em> get to choose the target keywords and phrases you want to focus on.</p> \n<p>All you have to do is get started, and we built this guide to help you.</p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Google's algorithm ranks your website on three main factors: on-page SEO, off-page SEO, and technical SEO:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>We'll cover <a href=\"#on-page-seo-elements\">on-page SEO elements below</a>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/6487/The-ABCs-of-Off-Page-SEO-Tactics.aspx\">Off-page SEO </a>refers to social sharing, external linking, and more.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/technical-seo\">Technical SEO</a> refers to all the SEO elements not included in on-page and off-page practices, such as structured data, site speed, and mobile readiness — the more <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/the-beginners-guide-to-technical-seo-7-resources-you-should-use\">technical parts of SEO</a>.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Note</strong>: This SEO \"trilogy\" isn't always divided into three clean sections; some of these SEO elements will overlap. You'll see how and why throughout this piece.</p> \n<h3>Why is on-page SEO important?</h3> \n<p>On-page SEO is important because it tells Google all about your website and how you provide value to visitors and customers. <strong>It helps your site be optimized for both human eyes and search engine bots.</strong></p> \n<p>Merely creating and publishing your website isn't enough — you must optimize it for Google and other search engines in order to rank and attract new traffic.</p> \n<p>On-page SEO is called \"on-page\" because the tweaks and changes you make to optimize your website can be seen by visitors <em>on your page</em> (whereas off-page and technical SEO elements aren't always visible).</p> \n<p>Every part of on-page SEO is completely up to you; that's why it's critical that you do it correctly. Now, let's discuss the elements of on-page SEO.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>All on-page SEO elements fall into three main categories:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"#content-elements\">Content elements</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"#html-elements\">HTML elements</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"#site-architecture-elements\">Site architecture elements</a></li> \n</ul> You'll see these elements divided into sections below. \n<a></a> \n<h3>Content Elements</h3> \n<p>Content elements refer to the elements within your site copy and content. In this section, we'll focus mostly on crafting high-quality page content that benefits your visitors and tells Google that your website provides value.</p> \n<h4>High-Quality Page Content</h4> \n<p>Page content is the heart of on-page SEO. It tells both search engines and readers what your website and business are all about.</p> \n<p>The first step to creating high-quality content is choosing relevant keywords and topics. Conduct keyword research by searching Google for terms and seeing what surfaces for competitors and other websites. You can also use tools like <a href=\"http://ahrefs.com\">Ahrefs</a>, <a href=\"http://answerthepublic.com\">AnswerthePublic</a>, and <a href=\"https://neilpatel.com/ubersuggest/\">UberSuggest</a>.</p> \n<p>Also, read our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-keyword-research-ht\">Beginner's Guide on How to Do Keyword Research for SEO</a>.</p> \n<p>Next, consider how your page content falls into the buyer's journey and visitors' search intent. These will impact how you will use your keywords and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage?_ga=2.76145557.1605302133.1560446833-1493293515.1553017609\">what types of content you will create</a>:</p> \n<table style=\"width: 100%;\"> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\"><strong>Stage in the Buyer's Journey</strong></td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\"><strong>Suggested Content/Website Pages</strong></td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Awareness</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\"> <p>Blog posts, videos<br>homepage</p> </td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Consideration</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\"> <p>Buyer's guides, case studies<br>about page</p> </td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Decision</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\"> <p>Product demos, comparison tools<br>product or pricing pages, contact page</p> </td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<p>Now, it's time to write your page content or clean it up if you're currently auditing your on-page SEO.</p> \n<p>Here are a few best practices for writing high-quality page content (we'll touch on some of these in more detail below, in our <a href=\"#on-page-seo-checklist\">Checklist</a>):</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Incorporate <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-site-keyword-optimize-ht\">short and long-tail keywords</a> <em>naturally.</em></li> \n <li>Add engaging and relevant visual content.</li> \n <li>Write for your specific <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research?_ga=2.112348804.1605302133.1560446833-1493293515.1553017609\">buyer persona(s).</a></li> \n <li>Actively solve your audience's problem.</li> \n <li>Develop content people will share and want to link to.</li> \n <li>Optimize for conversions with CTAs to offers and product pages.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Page content is your opportunity to communicate value to Google and your site visitors; it's the heart of the on-page SEO process. All other on-page SEO elements stem from high-quality page content, so invest ample resources to develop and optimize it.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>HTML Elements</h3> \n<p>HTML elements refer to the elements in your source code.</p> \n<p>Note: To see the source code for any page in your browser, click View &gt; Developer &gt; View Source in the top menu.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h4>Page Titles</h4> \n<p>Your website page titles (also known as <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/website-title\">title tags</a>) are one of the most important SEO elements.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%202.06.48%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%202.06.48%20PM.png\" alt=\"on page seo page title tag\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Titles tell both visitors and search engines what they can find on the corresponding pages.</p> \n<p>To ensure your site pages rank for the proper intent, be sure to include the focus keyword for each page in the title. Incorporate your keyword as naturally as possible.</p> \n<p>Here are some best practices for when developing a page title:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Keep it under 70 characters (per <a href=\"https://seopressor.com/blog/google-title-meta-descriptions-length/\">Google's update</a>) ... any longer and your title will be cut off in search results. Mobile search results show up to 78 characters.</li> \n <li>Don't stuff the title with keywords. Not only does keyword-stuffing present a spammy and tacky reading experience, but modern search engines are smarter than ever — they've been designed to specifically monitor for (and penalize!) content that's unnaturally stuffed with keywords.</li> \n <li>Make it relevant to the page.</li> \n <li>Don't use all caps.</li> \n <li>Include your brand in the title, i.e. \"<em>The Ultimate Guide to On-Page SEO in 2019 — HubSpot Blog</em>\".</li> \n</ul> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/datadriven-strategies-titles-headlines?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Check out our free data-driven guide to writing effective page titles.</em></a></p> \n<h4>Headers</h4> \n<p>Headers, also known as body tags, refer to the HTML element &lt;h1&gt;, &lt;h2&gt;, &lt;h3&gt;, and so on.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%202-07-12%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%202-07-12%20PM.png\" alt=\"on page seo headers\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>These tags help organize your content for readers and help search engines distinguish what part of your content is most important and relevant, depending on search intent.</p> Incorporate important keywords in your \n<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/a-simple-formula-for-writing-kick-ass-titles-ht\">headers</a>, but choose different ones than what's in your page title. Put your most important keywords in your &lt;h1&gt; and &lt;h2&gt; headers.\n<br>\n<a></a> \n<h4>Meta Descriptions</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/meta-descriptions\">Meta descriptions</a> are the short page descriptions that appear under the title in search results. Although it's not an official ranking factor for search engines, it can influence whether or not your page is clicked on — therefore, it's just as important when doing on-page SEO.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%201.43.05%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%201.43.05%20PM.png\" alt=\"on page seo meta descriptions\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Meta descriptions can also be copied over to social media when your content is shared (by using <a href=\"#structured-markup\" style=\"font-size: 1em;\">structured markup, which we talk about below</a>), so it can encourage click-throughs from there, too.</p> \n<p>Here's what makes for a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-meta-description-ht\">good meta description</a>:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Keep it under 160 characters, although <a href=\"https://seopressor.com/blog/google-title-meta-descriptions-length/\">Google has been known to allow longer meta descriptions</a> — up to 220 characters. (<span style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\">Note</span>: Mobile devices cut off meta descriptions at 120 characters.)</li> \n <li>Include your entire keyword or keyword phrase.</li> \n <li>Use a complete, compelling sentence (or two).</li> \n <li>Avoid alphanumeric characters like —, &amp;, or +.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h4>Image Alt-text</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/image-alt-text\">Image alt-text</a> is like SEO for your images. It tells Google and other search engines what your images are about ... which is important because Google now delivers almost as many image-based results as they do text-based results.</p> \n<p>That means consumers may be discovering your site through your images. In order for them to do this, though, you have to add alt-text to your images.</p> \n<p>Here's what to keep in mind when adding image alt-text:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Make it descriptive and specific.</li> \n <li>Make it contextually relevant to the broader page content.</li> \n <li>Keep it shorter than 125 characters.</li> \n <li>Use keywords sparingly, and don't keyword stuff.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h4>Structured Markup</h4> \n<p>Structured markup, or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/structured-data\">structured data</a>, is the process of \"marking up\" your website source code to make it easier for Google to find and understand different elements of your content.</p> \n<p>Structured markup is the key behind those featured snippets, knowledge panels, and other content features you see when you search for something on Google. It's also <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/structured-data#social-cards\">how your specific page information shows up so neatly</a> when someone shares your content on social media.</p> \n<p><strong>Note</strong>: Structured data is considered technical SEO, but I'm including it here because optimizing it creates a better on-page experience for visitors.</p> \n<h3><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%202.04.25%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%202.04.25%20PM.png\" alt=\"on page seo structured markup\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></h3> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Site Architecture Elements</h3> \n<p>Site architecture elements refer to the elements that make up your website and site pages. How you structure your website can help Google and other search engines easily crawl the pages and page content.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h4>Page URLs</h4> \n<p>Your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-optimize-urls-for-search\">page URLs</a> should be simple to digest for both readers and search engines. They are also important when keeping your site hierarchy consistent as you create subpages, blog posts, and other types of internal pages.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%202.16.04%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%202.16.04%20PM.png\" alt=\"on page seo page url\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>For example, in the above URL, \"blog\" is the sub-domain, \"hubspot.com\" is the domain, \"sales\" is the directory for the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales\">HubSpot Sales Blog</a>, and \"startups\" indicates the specific path to that blog post.</p> \n<p>Here are a few tips on how to write <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/url-structure-search-friendly\">SEO-friendly URLs</a>:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Remove the extra, unnecessary words.</li> \n <li>Use only one or two keywords.</li> \n <li>Use <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-ssl\">HTTPS</a> if possible, as Google now uses that as a positive ranking factor.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h4>Internal Linking</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/31388/How-to-Use-Internal-Linking-to-Improve-Your-Website-s-SEO.aspx\">Internal linking</a> is the process of hyperlinking to other helpful pages on your website. (See how the words \"internal linking\" are linked to another HubSpot blog post in the sentence above? That's an example.)</p> \n<p>Internal linking is important for on-page SEO because internal links send readers to other pages on your website, keeping them around longer and thus telling Google your site is valuable and helpful.</p> \n<p>Also, the longer visitors are on your website, the more time Google has to crawl and index your site pages. This ultimately helps Google absorb more information about your website and potentially rank it higher on the search engine results pages.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/deep-dive-into-internal-linking-for-seo?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Download our free guide to Internal Linking for SEO.</em></a></p> \n<h4>Mobile Responsiveness</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://webmasters.googleblog.com/2018/03/rolling-out-mobile-first-indexing.html\">Google started favoring sites that are optimized for faster mobile speeds</a> — even for desktop searches.</p> \n<p>Mobile responsiveness matters.</p> \n<p>It's critical to choose a website hosting service, site design and theme, and content layout that's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/responsive-design-list?_ga=2.109659013.1605302133.1560446833-1493293515.1553017609\">readable and navigable on mobile devices</a>. If you're not sure about your own site's mobile readiness, use <a href=\"https://search.google.com/test/mobile-friendly\">Google's Mobile-Friendly Test tool</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%204.19.25%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%204.19.25%20PM.png\" alt=\"on page seo mobile responsiveness\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h4>Site Speed</h4> \n<p>Whether being viewed on a mobile device or desktop, your site must be able to load quickly. When it comes to on-page SEO, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-page-speed\">page speed</a> counts big-time.</p> \n<p>Google cares about user experience first and foremost. If your site loads slowly or haphazardly, it's likely your visitors aren't going to stick around — and Google knows that. Moreover, site speed can <a href=\"https://designers.hubspot.com/blog/site-speed-test-improve-conversion-roi\">impact conversions and ROI</a>.</p> \n<p>Check your website's speed anytime using <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/speed/pagespeed/insights/\">Google's PageSpeed Insights tool</a>. If your website is movin' slow, check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-reduce-your-websites-page-speed\">5 Easy Ways to Help Reduce Your Website’s Page Loading Speed.</a></p> \n<p><strong>Note</strong>: Mobile responsiveness and site speed are considered technical SEO, but I'm including them here because optimizing them creates a better on-page experience for visitors.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%204.18.30%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-06-12%20at%204.18.30%20PM.png\" alt=\"on page seo site speed\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Now that you understand the different on-page SEO elements, let's talk through the steps of auditing and improving your on-page SEO.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>If you've been in search of a solution for organizing and tracking the various on-page SEO elements, you're in luck. The HubSpot marketing team released an updated version of our <strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/seo-template-guide?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\">On-Page SEO Template</a>, </strong>an Excel document that allows you to coordinate pages and keywords — and track changes — all in one place.</p> \n<p>In this section, we'll be using this template as a guide as we walk you through a checklist for your on-page SEO management, step by step. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/seo-template-guide?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\">Download the template now</a> and follow along.</p> \n<p><strong>Note:</strong> The fictional website \"http://www.quantify.ly\" will be used as an example throughout this post. It's simply meant to help you imagine how your own website will fit into the template.<em><br></em></p> \n<h3>1. Crawl your website.</h3> \n<p>Get an overview of all of your website pages that search engines have indexed. For HubSpot customers, our <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/cos-general/analyze-your-page-or-blog-post-performance-and-seo-optimization\">Page Performance</a> tool (under Reports) will allow you to do this. If you're not using HubSpot, you can try using a <a title=\"free tool like Xenu's link crawler\" href=\"http://xenus-link-sleuth.en.softonic.com\">free tool like Xenu's link crawler</a>.</p> \n<p>After crawling your site and exporting the results into an Excel (or .csv) file, there will be three key columns of data that you should focus on:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>The web address (a.k.a. URL)</li> \n <li>The page title</li> \n <li>The page meta description</li> \n</ol> Copy and paste these three columns into your template.\n<br> \n<p>The URL should be pasted into column B, the page title into column C, and the description into column E.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-1-2.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-1-2.png\" alt=\"on-page seo checklist crawl your website\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>2. Conduct an SEO audit and define your site architecture.</h3> \n<p>Now that you have a basic index of your site in the template, you'll want to organize and prioritize your web pages. Start by defining where within your site architecture your existing pages currently sit.</p> \n<p>Do this in column A. Note whether a page is your homepage (ideally you'll only have one of those), a page in your primary (or secondary) navigation menu, an internal page, and so on.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-2-2.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-2-2.png\" alt=\"on-page seo checklist conduct an seo audit\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>3. Update URLs, page titles, and meta descriptions.</h3> \n<p>Review your current URLs, page titles, and meta descriptions to see if they need updating.</p> \n<p>(This is the beauty of using a template to organize your SEO: You get a broad overview of the type of content you have on your website.)</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-3-2.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-3-2.png\" alt=\"on page seo checklist meta descriptions\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Notice how column D and column F automatically calculate the length of each element. The recommended length for page titles is anything under 60 characters. (And, actually, a quick and easy optimization project is to update all page titles that are longer than 60 characters.)</p> \n<p>The recommended length for page meta descriptions is 155-160 characters. This is the perfect length to ensure none of the description is cut off by the ellipses. Make sure you're not too repetitive with keywords in this space. Writing a good meta description isn't tough, but it deserves just as much consideration as the page content itself.</p> \n<p>(<strong>Note:</strong> For some sites, you may also have to update the URLs, but that's not always the case and thus was not included as part of this optimization template.)</p> \n<h3>4. Make sure your keyword is in your URL.<em><br></em></h3> \n<p>As <a href=\"#on-page-seo-URL-keyowrd\">we mentioned above</a>, add your keyword to your URL. For example, image you own a hot yoga studio called ADYoga. You have a web page that includes videos of your classes. The keyword for this page is \"hot yoga online classes\" — so, you'd want to include that keyword in your URL. The URL for this web page may look like this: www.ADyoga.com/hot-yoga-online-classes.</p> \n<h3>5. Include your keyword throughout your web page.</h3> \n<p>In addition to your URL, you'll want to add your keyword throughout your web page(s). This includes your title and headers. Sprinkle your keyword throughout your content as well where it fits naturally.</p> \n<h3>6. Track keywords and topics for each page.</h3> \n<p>Think of your target keyword as the designated topic for a particular page. If you're using the HubSpot template, In column O, define just one topic per page.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-8.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-8.png\" alt=\"on-page seo checklist track keywords and topics for your web pages\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>By doing this, you'll be able to go more in-depth and provide more detailed information about that topic. This also means that you are only optimizing for one keyword per page, meaning you have a greater chance to rank for that keyword.</p> \n<p>There are, of course, a few exceptions to this rule. Your homepage is a classic example. The goal of your homepage is to explain what your <em>entire</em> website is about, and thus you'll need a few keywords to do that. Another exception is overview pages like services and product pages, which outline what all of your products and services may be.</p> \n<h3>7. Don’t keyword stuff.</h3> \n<p>We just covered many examples in which keywords are both helpful and necessary for SEO purposes. However, one mistake many first-timers make when improving their on-page SEO is \"keyword stuff\".</p> \n<p>Keyword stuffing can be detrimental to your website and web page's SEO and it can feel spammy to readers/ visitors.</p> \n<h3>8. Establish value propositions for each page.</h3> \n<p>A very important next step, which is often overlooked, is establishing a value proposition for each page of your website. Each page should have a goal aside from just ranking for a particular term.</p> \n<p>If you're using the template, you'll do this in column G.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-4-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-4-1.png\" alt=\"on-page seo checklist establish value propositions\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>9. Define your target audience.</h3> \n<p>Define your target audience — do you have a single buyer persona or multiple personas? Keep this persona in mind as you optimize your site's pages. (Remember, you are optimizing for humans, too — not just search engine robots.)</p> \n<p>In column H of our template, you'll have the opportunity to define your page's target audience.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-5-2.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-5-2.png\" alt=\"on-page seo checklist define your target audience\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>10. Plan new page titles.</h3> \n<p>Now that you've documented your existing page titles and have established value propositions and target audiences for each of your pages, write new page titles (if necessary) to reflect your findings.</p> \n<p>You can do this in column K of the template — and double check each title length in column L.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-6.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-6.png\" alt=\"on-page seo checklist plan new page titles\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>People usually follow the formula of \"Keyword Phrase | Context.\" The goal of the page title is to lay out the purpose of the page without being redundant. You should also keep the additional recommendations we <a href=\"#how-to-optimize-your-website-title\">made above</a> related to titles.</p> \n<h3>11. Add new meta descriptions.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"#meta-descriptions-for-seo\">As we covered above</a>, meta descriptions should be a short, declarative sentence that incorporates the same keyword as your page's title.</p> \n<p>It should <em>not</em> reflect the content verbatim as it appears on the page. Get as close as you can to the 150-character limit to maximize space and tell visitors as much as possible about your page.</p> \n<p>If you need to create new meta descriptions, do so in column M of the template.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-7.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-7.png\" alt=\"on-page seo checklist add meta descriptions\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>12. Review and edit page content as needed.</h3> \n<p>Good copy needs to be thorough, clear, and provide solutions ... so, be compelling! Write for your target audience and about how you can help them. Compelling content is also error-free, so double check your spelling and grammar.</p> \n<p>Aim to have at least 500 words per page, and format content to make it easier to read and digest with the use of headers and subheaders.</p> \n<p>Columns P through R can be used to keep track of changes that you've made to your content or to note where changes need to be implemented.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-9.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-9.png\" alt=\"on-page seo checklist review and edit content on your web page\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>13. Incorporate visual content.<strong><br></strong></h3> \n<p>Content can be more than just text, so consider what kind of visual content you can incorporate into each page (if it adds value and serves a purpose, of course). Columns S and T allow you to note which visual elements need to be added. When adding an image to a page, be sure to include a descriptive file name and image alt-text.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-10.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-10.png\" alt=\"on-page seo checklist incorporate visual content\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>14. Optimize your visual content.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"#image-alt-text\">We talked earlier</a> about <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/image-alt-text\">image alt text</a>. You'll want to optimize your visual content this way — and be sure to include your keyword in your image alt text. It'll help with the page's SEO as well as offer the potential to rank in image search (e.g. on a search engine image results page or image carousel).</p> \n<h3>15. Add internal links.<strong><br></strong></h3> \n<p><a href=\"#internally-link-on-your-website\">As stated earlier</a>, incorporating links throughout your pages is a must, but it's often something that's easily overlooked.</p> \n<p>Make sure that your anchor text includes more than just your keywords. The goal isn't to stuff in as many keywords as possible, but to make it easy for people to navigate your site.</p> \n<p>Use columns U through W to plan for these elements if you don't already have them, or to document how you'll improve them.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/on-page-seo-checklist-11-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=on-page-seo-checklist-11-1.png\" alt=\"on-page seo checklist add internal links\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>16. Include external links.</h3> \n<p>It may seem counterintuitive to include external links throughout your page considering we just covered multiple reasons why <em>internal</em> linking is so important for on-page SEO. However, external links are also important.</p> \n<p>By externally linking, to credible and trustworthy sites, Google will know your page is also credible and trustworthy. Not only does Google want to know your site is well-referenced, but your visitors do, too.</p> \n<h3>17. Optimize for conversions.<strong><br></strong></h3> \n<p>If you're also not <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/conversion-rate-optimization\">optimizing your site</a> to increase the number of leads, subscribers, and/or customers you're attracting ... you're doing it wrong.</p> \n<p>Remember that each page of your website presents a conversion opportunity. That means every page of your website should include at least one call-to-action (CTA), though many pages may have multiple CTAs.</p> \n<p>Columns X through AF allow you to plan for conversions.</p> \n<p>Be sure that your site has a mix of CTAs for different <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/flywheel?_ga=2.122242699.1605302133.1560446833-1493293515.1553017609\">stages of the flywheel</a>.</p> \n<p>(<strong>Note</strong>: The On-Page SEO Template refers to the stages of the buying funnel — top of the funnel, middle of the funnel, and bottom of the funnel.
