Stec)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/marketing-product-budget-template-1.png?width=602&name=marketing-product-budget-template-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn25@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118312496_da9e8f21862686f6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-post-schedule-template.jpg?width=690&name=social-media-post-schedule-template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn65@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118312050_cb468b96dcd868bf.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blog-editorial-calendar-templates-1.png?width=524&name=blog-editorial-calendar-templates-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn85@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118309695_d1aa534957a0a9b1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/SMART_Goals_Excel_Templates.png?width=699&name=SMART_Goals_Excel_Templates.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn13@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118310790_7a8b761e6d45b17e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/SEO_Templates_Excel.png?width=669&name=SEO_Templates_Excel.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn13@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118308236_b76177378e57cff5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-ads-campaign-template.jpg?width=690&name=google-ads-campaign-template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn49@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118313477_fb550fceab44d7b4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/Social_Media_Publishing_Calendar.png?width=669&name=Social_Media_Publishing_Calendar.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn89@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118304808_8f45cde89a4f7ee3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/service-level-agreement-sla-template.png?width=690&name=service-level-agreement-sla-template.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn61@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118308735_c3b9e43742953232.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Traffic_and_Leads_Calculator_Excel.png?width=669&name=Traffic_and_Leads_Calculator_Excel.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn5@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118306367_c9ad3ac6c133ad81.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/Monthly_Marketing_Metrics_Excel.png?width=669&name=Monthly_Marketing_Metrics_Excel.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn37@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118313386_762df38872db8087.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/essential-kpi-tracking-template.jpg?width=690&name=essential-kpi-tracking-template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn5@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118311529_c33a59d4a4a14cb7.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-with-excel-templates-list&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn89@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118308823_c3969bd1b752a273.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"14 Signs Your Remote Team is Communicating Ineffectively","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-miscommunication","description":"<p>Every weekend, my friends and I have online video calls to catch-up with each other.</p> \n<p>Sometimes it feels like certain people dominate the conversation and others don't feel comfortable speaking up.</p> \n<p>These types of communication issues via remote conversations are actually normal.</p>  \n<p>In fact, for remote teams <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/hubfs/53/Remote-Work-Report-2019.pdf\">communication with co-workers is a challenge that remote workers face daily</a>.</p> \n<p>Additionally, according to HubSpot's findings, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/hubfs/53/Remote-Work-Report-2019.pdf\">non-HubSpot remote workers noted a lack of social connection (29%) and communicating with co-workers (29%) </a>as the two biggest challenges they face being remote.</p> \n<p>When your team can't be in the same space, communication needs to become more intentional. So, how do you do that? And how do you know when your communication needs some work?</p> \n<p>Below, let's review some signs that your remote team isn't communicating as effectively as possible.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Your team has too many meetings.</h3> \n<p>As a remote worker, I know I've had days where I jump from meeting to meeting with no time for a break. Sometimes, this can actually be a symptom of poor communication.</p> \n<p>Typically, your team shouldn't have to meet several times a week. In fact, plenty of meetings can be sent in an email.</p> \n<p>Before scheduling a meeting, think about whether that meeting will waste time. If you aren't sure, then reevaluate whether the content can be sent in an email.</p> \n<p>Additionally, keep in mind when you schedule a meeting that every person you invited needs to be there. If not, let them know it's optional. Plus, think about the length of your meetings. If it can be shorter, make it shorter.</p> \n<p>Regardless, it's important to be intentional when you're planning remote meetings.</p> \n<h3>2. You've never thought about digital body language.</h3> \n<p>When you're communicating via video conferencing, it can be easy to forget about digital body language.</p> \n<p>However, it's important to keep in mind that nothing on camera is subtle and it can feel like you have a spotlight on you.</p> \n<p>That means you have to pay even more attention to body language.</p> \n<p>For instance, you should still maintain eye contact, speak clearly, and have your video on during remote calls.</p> \n<h3>3. Team members don't contribute during online team meetings.</h3> \n<p>Have you ever been to a meeting where the same people speak up and other team members don't?</p> \n<p>This can be a symptom of poor communication on your team because it might mean that some team members don't feel comfortable talking during meetings.</p> \n<p>On the other hand, it's important to keep in mind that some people are more introverted than others.</p> \n<p>To ensure that all team members are contributing, consider asking everyone a question and going round-robin so everyone has a chance to speak.</p> \n<h3>4. Your team isn't collaborating.</h3> \n<p>Do you collaborate with your team when the opportunity arises? As a manager, do you notice that your team isn't collaborating?</p> \n<p>If collaboration isn't happening, this could be a sign that team members don't feel comfortable reaching out to each other.</p> \n<p>Additionally, this could mean that your team doesn't have the tools they need to collaborate effectively.</p> \n<p>For example, on the HubSpot blog team, we use Trello to keep track of our editorial assignments. With this tool, writers can easily collaborate with other team members when they want to lean on them for expertise.</p> \n<h3>5. There's no communication throughout the day.</h3> \n<p>In previous remote roles, I was able to go days without talking to another coworker. While the introverted part of my personality loved that, it was a sign that our team wasn't communicating well.</p> \n<p>The more you talk to people on your team, the more trust you'll have. This makes it easier to reach out when you need help. That's why it's important to make sure your team feels comfortable communicating throughout the day -- even if it's just to send a GIF to the group chat.</p> \n<p>While you don't want to inundate your team with messages, checking in every so often is important for camaraderie and team communication.</p> \n<h3>6. Emails are overly complicated.</h3> \n<p>Emails should always be simple, clear, and specific. If you're writing an email and it's overly complicated, you might want to schedule a quick Zoom meeting with that person.</p> \n<p>To communicate effectively, it's important to know what channel to use to deliver your message. Sometimes it works in an email, but sometimes it requires a meeting.</p> \n<h3>7. There's no agenda or meeting structure.</h3> \n<p>If you don't have an agenda or meeting structure, you might not be communicating effectively during your meetings.</p> \n<p>Meetings should be organized and structured so they're productive. Having an agenda will keep you on track.</p> \n<p>You might even want to schedule in the five minutes of informal chat before a meeting gets started. This will help team members self-regulate.</p> \n<p>If it's possible, you should always send the agenda prior to the meeting.</p> \n<p>However, this isn't necessary with regularly scheduled meetings. For those, just make sure you've set expectations.</p> \n<h3>8. Your team doesn't use \"Working With Me\" documents.</h3> \n<p>Every member on your team should have a \"Working With Me\" document that details work habits, expectations, and even interests.</p> \n<p>These documents are helpful for managers to learn about their team so they can properly manage communication among various team members.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can also share these with everyone on the team so coworkers can get to know their teammates better.</p> \n<p>Knowing each other's work habits will help build trust and psychological safety on your team.</p> \n<p>Instead of spending time trying to figure people out, your team can just talk about it.</p> \n<h3>9. Norms for communication haven't been established.</h3> \n<p>If you've ever been stressed about communicating with your remote team, that's probably because norms for communication haven't been established.</p> \n<p>For example, everyone's work hours and breaks should be clear. This could mean that everyone is on the same Google calendar or they've added a status on their Slack so people know that they aren't available.</p> \n<p>Whatever your team's method is, make sure that's communicated among everyone.</p> \n<p>Additionally, it might be wise to set expectations in your emails. When you send an email that doesn't need a response, you might want to call that out.</p> \n<p>Setting expectations and norms will help improve communication immensely.</p> \n<h3>10. Your team hasn't built psychological safety.</h3> \n<p>If there's no psychological safety on your team, then you aren't communicating effectively.</p> \n<p>On remote teams, sometimes it can be hard to feel included. However, the option to be included is so important.</p> \n<p>When people don't feel included, they won't feel comfortable speaking up.</p> \n<p>To build psychological safety in a remote meeting, make sure you go round-robin so everyone has a chance to speak.</p> \n<p>Additionally, try to focus on bigger picture conversations and ask people specific questions.</p> \n<p>Plus, you can do a \"This or That\" activity. Doing a quick icebreaker where everyone has to go around and answer a question can help people feel confident about communicating with the team.</p> \n<h3>11. Your team doesn't express appreciation for one another.</h3> \n<p>Forming connections is paramount for communication.</p> \n<p>One of the best ways to do this is to express gratitude for each other. For example, people should feel free to congratulate each other in a group chat.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can send birthday cards or just create an email thread of appreciation.</p> \n<p>Expressing gratitude is a great way to renew your energy and create a safe space on your team.</p> \n<h3>12. Managers redo work from team members.</h3> \n<p>If you're a manager and you've found yourself redoing work from your team, that means you aren't communicating effectively.</p> \n<p>When assignments are sent back with errors, typically this means that the assignment wasn't clear and expectations weren't communicated.</p> \n<p>If you ever redo someone's work, that shows that you might not feel comfortable sending edits.</p> \n<p>Again, the problem here is all about communication. The only way to improve this process is to … you guessed it, communicate with each other.</p> \n<h3>13. Assignments fall through the cracks.</h3> \n<p>Have you ever had an assignment just fall through the cracks? Or perhaps you're unsure where you left off on a project.</p> \n<p>When this happens, it's clear that you aren't using a great project management tool that enables communication.</p> \n<p>With project management tools, you should be able to see what stage a project is on and collaborate with others right in the tool. By improving communication, assignments won't fall through the cracks.</p> \n<h3>14. Your team has a high turnover rate.</h3> \n<p>If your team has a high turnover rate, that could mean that your communication isn't effective. When this happens, it's important to talk to your team so you can figure out what's working and what isn't.</p> \n<p>While working remotely can make communication feel harder, it doesn't have to be that way. If your team is communicating ineffectively, you can use these <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-productivity\">productivity tips</a> to help.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May, 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fremote-miscommunication&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Jul 2020 12:15:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/remote-miscommunication-1.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"e9841b55a3ffb0dd0d24b6e4a6f82098","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn13@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118303820_cfb7b852ea6de01f.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/remote-miscommunication-1.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fremote-miscommunication&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn41@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118312709_635a255abbf11144.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"How to Create an Ebook From Start to Finish [Free Ebook Templates]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-create-an-ebook-free-templates","description":"<p>At age 11, I dreamed of being an editor at a major magazine. I even put together my first publication, <em style=\"letter-spacing: 0px; background-color: transparent;\">Teen Scene Magazine, using colored construction paper, yarn, and in-depth feature interviews with ... my dad.</em></p> \n<p>Flash forward to today. I've swapped my colored construction paper and yarn for PowerPoint and InDesign. I've replaced my dad with marketing experts and influencers (in the office, that is). And week after week, I have the satisfaction of being an ebook creator.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>What Is an Ebook?</h2> \n<p>Ebook is short for \"electronic book,\" and uses either a computer, mobile device, or ebook reader to display long-form texts in book form. Ebooks have multiple digital \"pages\" that people can navigate through, and are often packaged as a PDF document so they can easily be sent from one user to another.</p> \n<h3>What Are the Benefits of an Ebook?</h3> \n<p>Let's say you have an amazing blog full of long-form content. Why in the world would you want to offer your readers an ebook? Is it even worth your time?</p> \n<p>Here's some advantages ebooks offer content creators:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Unlike long-form printed media, an ebook is immediately accessible.</li> \n <li>You can put it behind an opt-in of some kind, incentivizing your website visitor to become a lead if they want the information.</li> \n <li>In some ways, ebooks have design capabilities you may not be able to achieve on your blog.</li> \n <li>After the initial creation of the ebook, you can distribute the file a multitude of times with no additional production cost. They also have no associated shipping fees.</li> \n <li>You can embed links to other media in the ebook file, encouraging the reader to further engage with your content.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Perhaps more importantly, ebooks offer a number of advantages for your audience:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Ebooks are extremely portable, able to be stored on a number of devices with no physical storage space associated.</li> \n <li>The reader gets the choice to print the ebook out if they want to consume the information in a traditional physical format. Otherwise, the digital format is environmentally friendly.</li> \n <li>Ebooks are accessible with the ability to increase font sizes and/or read aloud with text-to-speech.</li> \n <li>They're also easily searchable if the reader is looking for something specific.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>How Is an Ebook Structured?</h3> \n<p>There's no set rule for organizing your content into an ebook. It generally mimics the structure of a novel or textbook (depending on what it is you're writing about). But, there are some aspects of an ebook you should be sure to adhere to.</p> \n<p>Ebooks have some system of chapters and supporting images. Similar to a blog post, they also do well when further segmenting their text with subheaders that break down the discussion into specific sections. If you're writing about professional sports, for example, and one of your chapters is about Major League Baseball (MLB) in the U.S., you might want to establish subchapters about the various teams belonging to the MLB.</p> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>What Can an Ebook Be About?</h3> \n<p>Anything. Well, within reason. Ebooks are simply a marketer's way of delivering lots of critical information in a form their potential customers are most willing to read it. An environmental company might write an ebook all about water conservation. They also might focus an ebook entirely on how their water-saving product is used, or how it helped a customer solve a problem. Discover more ebook ideas at the end of this article.</p> \n<p>No matter what subject your ebook takes on, research is a significant part of ebook creation. Unlike short-form content like articles and videos, the content of an ebook is predicated on trust and evidence. A user who obtains (or requests access to) your ebook wants the full story, not just the bullet points. That includes all the content and testing you went through to produce the ebook.</p> \n<h3>Can You Edit an Ebook?</h3> \n<p>Nope. An ebook can't be edited once it's been saved in one of the file formats described above, so it's best to ensure you have an editable version saved in a program like Microsoft Word.</p> \n<p>But why would you want your ebook to be uneditable? Making ebooks uneditable ensures the content remains unchanged -- both the format and the information -- as it's shared between multiple uses.</p> \n<p>You&nbsp;<em>can</em> edit ebooks if they're saved using an editable PDF, a feature that is specific to Adobe Acrobat -- the founding program of the PDF file type. Learn how to edit PDFs in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-edit-pdf\">this blog post</a>.</p> \n<h3>How Do You Read an Ebook?</h3> \n<p>You can read an ebook on many different devices: iPhone, Android smartphones, a Macbook, PC, and e-readers such as the Nook and Kindle. The latter two devices are typically used to read novels in digital form. Nook and Kindle owners can store thousands of books (literally) on a single Nook or Kindle.</p> \n<p><strong>But making an ebook can be overwhelming.</strong> Not only do you have to write the content, but you also need to design and format it into a professional-looking document that people will want to download and read. With <a href=\"http://www.emarketer.com/Article/Leads-Take-Hold-Primary-Goal-of-Content-Marketing/1010107\">lead generation being the top goal for content marketing</a>, however, ebooks are an essential part of an successful inbound marketing program.</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll walk you through the ins and outs of creating an ebook by, well, creating an ebook. And if you're worried about your lacking design skills, fret not ...</p> \n<p>Got your free ebook templates? Ready to make an ebook? Great -- let's get to it.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">In What File Formats Can You Save an Ebook?</h2> \n<p>Ebooks can be saved in one of several formats. Depending on your end user, though, you might find a use for any of the following file types:</p> \n<h3>PDF</h3> \n<p>PDFs are likely the most well-known file type. The \"PDF\" extension stands for \"Portable Document Format,\" and is best for ebooks that are meant to be read on a computer (digital marketers, you'll want to remember this one). We'll talk more about how to save your ebook as a PDF later in this article.</p> \n<h3>EPUB</h3> \n<p>This file type stands for \"Electronic Publication,\" and is the more flexible ebook formats. By that, I mean EPUB ebooks can \"reflow\" their text to adapt to various mobile devices and tablets, allowing the ebook's text to move on and off different pages based on the size of the device on which a user is reading the ebook. They're particularly helpful for viewing on <a href=\"https://support.ebooks.com/hc/en-gb/articles/213875366-Guide-to-ebook-formats\">smaller screens</a>, such as smartphones as well as the <a href=\"https://www.barnesandnoble.com/b/nook/_/N-1pbl\">Nook</a> from Barnes and Noble.</p> \n<h3>MOBI</h3> \n<p>The MOBI format originated from the Mobipocket Reader software, which was purchased by Amazon in 2005 but was later shut down in 2016. However, the MOBI file extension remains a popular ebook format with compatibility across the major e-readers (except the Nook).</p> \n<p>While the format comes with some limitations, such as not supporting audio or video, it does support DRM, which protects copyrighted material from being copied for distribution or viewed illegally.</p> \n<p>Newer Kindle formats are based on the original MOBI file types.</p> \n<h3>AZW</h3> \n<p>This is an ebook file type designed for the <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Kindle-eBooks/b?ie=UTF8&amp;node=154606011\">Kindle</a>, an e-reader device by Amazon. However, users can also open this file format on smartphones, tablets, and computers.</p> \n<h3>ODF&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>ODF stands for OpenDocument Format, a file type meant primarily for OpenOffice, a series of open-source content creation programs similar to Microsoft Office.</p> \n<h3>IBA</h3> \n<p>IBA is the proprietary ebook format for the Apple iBooks Author app. This format does support video, sound, images, and interactive elements, but it is only used for books written in iBooks author. It is not compatible with other e-readers.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How to Write an Ebook</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Choose a topic that matches your audience's needs.</li> \n  <li>Outline each chapter of your ebook.</li> \n  <li>Break down each chapter as you write.</li> \n  <li>Design your ebook.</li> \n  <li>Use the right colors.</li> \n  <li>Incorporate visuals.</li> \n  <li>Highlight quotes or stats.</li> \n  <li>Place appropriate calls-to-action within your ebook.</li> \n  <li>Convert it into a PDF.</li> \n  <li>Create a dedicated landing page for your ebook.</li> \n  <li>Promote your ebook and track its success.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>1. Choose a topic that matches your audience's needs</h3> \n<p>Remember: The goal of your ebook is to <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/lead-generation-introduction\">generate leads for your sales team</a>, so pick a topic that will <strong>make it easy for a prospect to go from downloading your ebook to having a conversation with your sales team</strong>.</p> \n<p>This means your ebook shouldn't deviate much from the topics you cover in your other content marketing channels. Rather, it's your opportunity to do a deep dive into a subject you've only lightly covered until now, but something your audience knows they need to learn more about.</p> \n<p>For example, in listening to sales and customer calls here at HubSpot, I've learned ebooks for use in content marketing is a huge obstacle for our audience, who are marketers themselves. So if I can provide not only this blog post, but resources to make ebook creation easier, I'm focusing on the right topic for opening up a sales conversation.</p> \n<p>To get your creative juices flowing, here are some example ebook titles to consider. (Note: Replace \"x\" with an appropriate number.) You can also use our free <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/blog-topic-generator\">Blog Topic Generator tool</a> to come up with more ideas. Most blog topics can be made comprehensive enough to serve as longer form ebook topics.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>X Best Practices for [Insert Industry/Topic]</strong></li> \n <li><strong>An Introduction to [Insert Industry/Topic]</strong></li> \n <li><strong>X Common Questions About [Insert Industry/Topic] Answered</strong></li> \n <li><strong>X [Insert Industry/Topic] Statistics For Better Decision Making</strong></li> \n <li><strong>Learn From The Best: X [Insert Industry/Topic] Experts Share Insights</strong></li> \n</ul> \n<p>For this blog post, I'm going to use the PowerPoint version of template two from our <strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates\">collection of five free ebook templates</a></strong>. Through each section of this post, I'll provide a side-by-side of the template slide and how I customized it.</p> \n<p>Below, you'll see my customized cover with my sales-relevant ebook topic. For help with writing compelling titles for your ebooks, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/a-simple-formula-for-writing-kick-ass-titles-ht\">check out the tips in this blog post</a>.</p> \n<p><img style=\"width: 618px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-363177797-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-1.png?width=618&amp;height=444&amp;name=how-to-create-an-ebook-1.png\" width=\"618\" height=\"444\" alt=\"an ebook template side-by-side with the customized version of that template\"></p> \n<h3>2. Outline each chapter of your ebook.</h3> \n<p>The introduction to your ebook should both set the stage for the contents of your ebook and draw the reader in. What will you cover in your ebook? How will the reader benefit from reading it? <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-introduction-quick-tip-ht\">For tips on how to write an effective introduction, check out this post</a>.</p> \n<p>Some ebook creators say that an ebook is simply a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/repurpose-blog-content-ebook-ht\">series of blog posts stitched together</a>. While I agree you should treat each chapter like an individual blog post, the chapters of your ebook should also flow fluidly from one to the other.</p> \n<p>The best way to outline your ebook is by thinking of it as a crash course on the sales-relevant topic you selected. In my example of creating an ebook, I know I need to cover how to:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>write effective copy</li> \n <li>design an ebook</li> \n <li>optimize ebooks for lead generation and promotion</li> \n</ol> \n<p>While my example has a few chapters, keep in mind that your ebook does <strong>not</strong> need to be lengthy. I have one golden rule for ebook length: <strong>Write what is needed to effectively educate your audience about your selected topic</strong>. If that requires five pages, great! If that requires 30 pages, so be it. Just don't waste words thinking you need to write a long ebook.</p> \n<p>With that, let's move on to the actual copy you're writing.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 618px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-362689316-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-2.png?width=616&amp;height=447&amp;name=how-to-create-an-ebook-2.png\" alt=\"an example of ebook copy within an ebook template\" width=\"616\" height=\"447\"></p> \n<h3>3. Break down each chapter as you write.</h3> \n<p>Get writing! Here, you <em>can</em> approach each chapter the way you might write a long blog post -- by compartmentalizing each chapter into smaller sections or bullet points, as shown in the picture below. This helps you write simply and clearly, rather than trying to use sophisticated language to convey each point. It's the most effective way to educate readers and help them understand the new material you’re providing.</p> \n<p>Be sure to maintain a consistent structure across each chapter, as well. This helps you establish natural transitions between each chapter so there's a clear progression from one chapter to the next (simply stiching blog posts together can rob you of this quality).</p> \n<p>These practices should hold true for all your other marketing efforts, such as email marketing, call-to-action creation, and landing page development. “Clarity trumps persuasion,” as Dr. Flint McGlaughlin of MECLABS often likes to say.</p> \n<p>Want to make sure you're keeping your ebook exciting for readers? Here are some key tips to keep in mind:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Use <strong>keywords</strong> in the title that emphasize the value of your offer. Examples include adjectives like “amazing,” “awesome,” or “ultimate.”</li> \n <li>Keep your format <strong>consistent</strong> so you create a mental model for readers and enhance their understanding of the material.</li> \n <li>When appropriate, make use of <strong>formatting</strong> -- like bulleted lists, bold text, italics, and font size changes -- to draw people’s eyes to your most important content or emphasize certain points you want readers to remember.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img style=\"width: 618px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-361187118-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-4.png?width=618&amp;height=444&amp;name=how-to-create-an-ebook-4.png\" alt=\"an example of ebook formatting\" width=\"618\" height=\"444\"></p> \n<h3>4. Design your ebook.</h3> \n<p>Our <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates\"><strong>downloadable ebook templates</strong></a> are offered in both PowerPoint and InDesign. For this example, we'll show you how to do it in PowerPoint, since more people have access to that software.</p> \n<p>You'll notice we only have one \"chapter page\" in the template (slide three). To create additional chapter pages, or any pages really, simply right click the slide and choose <strong>Duplicate Slide</strong>. This will make a copy of your slide and allow you to drag it to its proper place in your ebook via the sidebar or Slide Sorter section of PowerPoint. You can then customize it for any subsequent chapters.</p> \n<p><img style=\"width: 618px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-361181293-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-5.png?width=618&amp;height=444&amp;name=how-to-create-an-ebook-5.png\" alt=\"an example of duplicating ebook pages in a template\" width=\"618\" height=\"444\"></p> \n<h3>5. Use the right colors.</h3> \n<p>Ideally, our <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates\"><strong>free ebook templates</strong></a> would magically match your brand colors. But, they probably don't; this is where you get to truly personalize your work. However, because ebooks offer more real estate for color than your logo or website, it's a good idea to consider secondary colors within your brand's color palate. Ebooks are where this color scheme can truly shine.</p> \n<p>To learn how to add your brand's colors to PowerPoint, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-brand-colors-in-powerpoint-ht\">check out this blog post</a>. That way, you can customize the color scheme in our ebook templates to match your brand!</p> \n<h3>6. Incorporate visuals.</h3> \n<p>Images and graphics in ebooks are hard to get right. The key to making them fit well is to think of them as complementary to your writing. Whether you add them during or after you’ve finished writing your ebook’s copy, your visuals should serve to highlight an important point you’re making or deconstruct the meaning of a concept in an easy-to-understand, visual way.</p> \n<p>Images shouldn’t just be there to make the ebook easy on the eyes. Rather, they should be used to enhance the reader’s understanding of the material you’re covering. If you need help gathering visuals, we have three sets of free stock photos that might help you along the way:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-stock-photos\">75 Standard Stock Photos</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-stock-photos-business\">160 Business-Themed Stock Photos</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-holiday-stock-photos\">250 Holiday Stock Photos</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>And if you're compiling a data-heavy ebook, you might want to download our <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/data-visualization-guide\">free data visualization ebook</a> for tips about designing compelling charts and graphs for your content.</p> \n<p><img style=\"width: 618px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-360025649-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-6.png?width=618&amp;name=how-to-create-an-ebook-6.png\" alt=\"an example of using visuals in ebook template\" width=\"618\"></p> \n<h3>7. Highlight quotes or stats.</h3> \n<p>Another way to enhance your ebook is by highlighting quotes or stats within your design. Just be sure the quote or stat you're using genuinely adds value to the content.</p> \n<p>Whether you're emphasizing a quote or adding a visual, keep all your content within the same margins. If your copy is consistently 1-inch indented on your page from both the left and right side, keep your designed elements aligned using that same spacing.</p> \n<p><img style=\"width: 618px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" title=\"how-to-create-an-ebook-6-1\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-363858177-png/how-to-create-an-ebook-7.png?width=618&amp;height=444&amp;name=how-to-create-an-ebook-7.png\" alt=\"an example of a highlighted quote on an ebook template\" width=\"618\" height=\"444\"></p> \n<h3>8. Place appropriate calls-to-action within your ebook.</h3> \n<p>Now that your content is written and designed, it's time to optimize it for lead generation, reconversion, and promotion.</p> \n<p>Think about how you got here -- you clicked on a call-to-action (CTA) in an email, on a social media post, or somewhere else. A CTA is a link or visual object that entices the visitor to click and arrive on a landing page that will get them further engaged with your company. Since your ebook readers have probably converted into leads in order to get their hands on your ebook to begin with (more on this in Step 2 below), use the CTAs within your ebook to reconvert your readers and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/31406/How-to-Map-Lead-Nurturing-Content-to-Each-Stage-in-the-Sales-Cycle.aspx\">propel them further down your marketing funnel</a>.</p> \n<p>For instance, a CTA can lead to another offer, your annual conference's registration page, or even a product page. Depending on what this next action is, CTAs can be an in-line rectangle or a full page teasing the next offer (see both images below).</p> \n<p>To hyperlink the CTA in your ebook (or any image or text in your ebook) to your destination URL, simply go to <strong>Insert &gt;&gt; Hyperlink</strong> in PowerPoint.</p> \n<p><img style=\"width: 618px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-362721066-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-8-1.png?width=618&amp;height=444&amp;name=how-to-create-an-ebook-8-1.png\" alt=\"examples of using hyperlinks in ebook template\" width=\"618\" height=\"444\"></p> \n<em style=\"letter-spacing: 0px; background-color: transparent;\"><em style=\"letter-spacing: 0px; background-color: transparent;\"><img style=\"width: 618px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" title=\"how-to-create-an-ebook-10\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-360054779-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-10-1.png?width=618&amp;height=444&amp;name=how-to-create-an-ebook-10-1.png\" alt=\"example of including a call to action within an ebook template\" width=\"618\" height=\"444\"></em></em> \n<p>We've even designed 50 customizable calls-to-action in PowerPoint you can download and use in your ebooks. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/call-to-action-templates\"><strong>You can grab them here</strong></a>.</p> \n<p>Now, we don't have a dedicated CTA template slide in the PowerPoint ebook templates for you to customize ... but it's still simple! All you have to do is duplicate slide four (the Header/Subheader slide) and customize copy or add images as needed. You can also go to <strong>Insert &gt;&gt; New Slide</strong> and work from there.</p> \n<h3>9. Convert it into a PDF.</h3> \n<p>Once you've finished writing your ebook -- CTAs and all -- it's time to convert it to the right file type so it's transferrable from you to your recipient.</p> \n<p>To convert your ebook to a PDF, click <strong>File &gt;&gt; Save As</strong> in the ebook template you have open. Under <strong>File Format</strong>, select <strong>PDF</strong> and select a destination on your computer for this new file.</p> \n<p>Why can't you just attach what you have to a landing page and be done with it? Word documents, PowerPoints, and similar templates are perfect for creating your ebook, but not for delivering it. Because these templates are editable, the contents of your ebook are too easily corrupted, distorted, or even lost when moving from your computer to the hands of your future leads. That's where PDFs come in.</p> \n<p>You've seen these letters at the end of files before. Short for Portable Document Format, the .PDF file type essentially freezes your ebook so it can be displayed clearly on any device. A popular alternative to PDFs is the .EPUB file type. See a <a href=\"https://www.thoughtco.com/epub-vs-pdf-3467286\">comparison of EPUB to PDF here</a>.</p> \n<h3>10. Create a dedicated landing page for your ebook.</h3> \n<p>Your ebook should be available for download through a landing page on your site. A <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/an-introductory-guide-how-to-use-landing-pages-for-your-business\">landing page</a> is a web page that promotes/describes your offer and provides a form that visitors need to fill out with their contact information in order to access your ebook. This is how you are able to convert your visitors into business leads that your sales team can ultimately follow up with.</p> \n<p>For instance, you went through <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates\">this landing page</a> in order to access this ebook template. To learn more about how to optimize your landing pages for conversion, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/optimize-landing-pages-more-leads\">download this free ebook</a>.</p> \n<p><img style=\"width: 618px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-363216512-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-9-1.png?width=618&amp;height=444&amp;name=how-to-create-an-ebook-9-1.png\" alt=\"how-to-create-an-ebook-9-1\" width=\"618\" height=\"444\"></p> \n<h3>11. Promote your ebook and track its success.</h3> \n<p>Once your landing page is all set, you can use that destination URL to promote your ebook across your marketing channels. Here are five ways you can do this:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Advertise your new ebook on your website. For example, feature a CTA or link to your offer’s landing page on your resources page or even your homepage.</li> \n <li>Promote your ebook through your blog. For instance, consider publishing an excerpt of your ebook as a blog post. Or write a separate blog article on the same topic as your ebook, and link to it at the end of your post using a call-to-action to encourage readers to keep learning. <em>(Note: This very blog post is the perfect example of how to promote an offer you created with a blog post.)</em></li> \n <li>Send a segmented email to contacts who have indicated an interest in receiving offers from your company.</li> \n <li>Leverage paid advertising and co-marketing partnerships that will help you promote your ebook to a new audience.</li> \n <li>Publish posts to social media with a link to your ebook. You can also increase social shares by creating social media share buttons within your ebook, such as the ones at the bottom right of this ebook. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33402/A-Simple-Guide-to-Creating-Social-Media-Sharing-Links-for-Your-Ebooks.aspx\">Here’s a blog post that shows how to hyperlink them</a>.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>After your content is launched and promoted across your marketing channels, you’ll also want <strong>marketing analytics</strong> in place to measure the success of your live product.</p> \n<p>For instance, you should have landing page analytics that give you insight into how many people downloaded your ebook and converted into leads, and closed-loop analytics that show how many of those people ultimately converted into opportunities and customers for your business. Learn more through <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/landing-pages\">HubSpot's Landing Pages App</a>.</p> \n<p>And with that, we've built an ebook, folks! You can check out the packaged version of the example I built through this post here:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 420px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-364748345-gif/Blog-Related_Images/5-free-ebook-Templates.gif?width=418&amp;height=552&amp;name=5-free-ebook-Templates.gif\" alt=\"an animation that scrolls through several pages of an ebook template\" width=\"418\" height=\"552\"></p> \n<div style=\"position: absolute; top: 2156px; left: 0; background: red; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;\"> \n <div>\n  After your content is launched and promoted across your marketing channels, you’ll need to have marketing analytics in place that measure the success of your ebooks. For instance, having landing page analytics that give you insight into how many people downloaded your ebook, or show how many of those downloaders converted into opportunities and customers for your business.\n </div> \n</div> \n<h2>Ebook Ideas</h2> \n<p>So, what should you write about in your ebook? I'll answer that question with another question: What do you want your readers to get out of this ebook? To identify an ebook idea that suits your audience, consider the&nbsp;<em>type</em> of ebook you're trying to create. Here are a few ideas.</p> \n<h3>New Research</h3> \n<p>Conducting an experiment or business survey? This is a great way to develop proprietary knowledge and become a thought leader in your industry. But how will you share your findings with the people who care about it? Create an ebook that describes the experiment, what you intended to find out, what the results of the experiment were, and what these findings mean for your readers and the market at large.</p> \n<h3>Case Study</h3> \n<p>People love success stories, especially if these people are on the fence about purchasing something from you. If you have a client whose business you're particularly proud to have, why not tell their story in an ebook?</p> \n<p>Ebook case studies show your buyers that other people trust you and have benefited from your product or service. In your ebook, describe what your client's challenge was, how you connected with them, and how you were able to help your client solve their challenge and become successful.</p> \n<h3>Product Demo</h3> \n<p>The more complex your product is, the more information your customers will need to use it correctly. If your product or service can be used in multiple ways, or it's hard to set up alone, dedicate a brief ebook to showing people how it's done. In the first section of your ebook, for example, explain how to launch your product or service. In the second section, break down the individual features and purposes your product is best used for.</p> \n<h3>Interview</h3> \n<p>Interested in interviewing a well-known person in your market? Perhaps you've already sat down with an influencer to pick their brain about the future of the industry. Package this interview into an ebook, making it easy for your customers to read and share your inside scoop.</p> \n<h3>Playbook</h3> \n<p>A \"playbook\" is a document people can use when taking on a new project or concept that is foreign to them. Think of it like a cheat sheet, full of tips and tricks that help your customers get better at what they do.</p> \n<p>When done right, a playbook equips your customers with information they would need to excel when using your product. For example, a software vendor for IT professionals might create a \"virus protection playbook\" that makes support teams better at preventing viruses at their respective companies.</p> \n<h3>Blog Post Series</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, the best ebook for your business is already strewn across a series of blog posts. If you've spent the last month writing articles all on the same subject for your business, imagine how these posts would look stitched together?</p> \n<p>Each article can begin a new chapter. Then, once this ebook is created, you can promote it on a landing page, link to this landing page from each individual blog post, and generate leads from readers who want to download the entire blog series in one convenient ebook.</p> \n<h2>Ebook Creation Resources</h2> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates\">5 Free Ebook Templates in PowerPoint and InDesign</a> [Free Download]</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/13-free-customisable-ebook-templates\">13 More Customizable Ebook Templates in PowerPoint</a> [Free Download]</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/data-visualization-guide\">Data Visualization 101: How to Design Charts and Graphs</a> [Free Download]</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/repurpose-blog-content-ebook-ht\">How to Easily Turn Blog Posts Into an Ebook</a> [Blog Post]</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33402/A-Simple-Guide-to-Creating-Social-Media-Sharing-Links-for-Your-Ebooks.aspx\">A Simple Guide to Creating Social Sharing Links for Your Ebooks</a> [Blog Post]</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Do you have any other tips or resources for making ebook creation easier? Apply them to your content marketing strategy. I'd be remiss not to admit every company's ebook will come to fruition differently. It all depends on the needs of your brand.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in November 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\">&nbsp;</a>\n</div>  \n<img Hussain)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-363177797-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-1.png?width=618&height=444&name=how-to-create-an-ebook-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn69@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118301671_19a8281bbcec752a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-362689316-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-2.png?width=616&height=447&name=how-to-create-an-ebook-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn77@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118309925_28f3b0f2904c211c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-361187118-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-4.png?width=618&height=444&name=how-to-create-an-ebook-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn81@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118306339_30994d3cd3893c78.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-361181293-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-5.png?width=618&height=444&name=how-to-create-an-ebook-5.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn9@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118308389_f306918ee86271da.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-360025649-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-6.png?width=618&name=how-to-create-an-ebook-6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn9@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118311563_9747c5518956bccc.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-363858177-png/how-to-create-an-ebook-7.png?width=618&height=444&name=how-to-create-an-ebook-7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn21@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118311541_7943cdaa8e8b7e16.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-362721066-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-8-1.png?width=618&height=444&name=how-to-create-an-ebook-8-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn53@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118308743_72677ea4342ae007.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-360054779-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-10-1.png?width=618&height=444&name=how-to-create-an-ebook-10-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn85@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118305442_6b0d97b670c35c8b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-363216512-png/Blog-Related_Images/how-to-create-an-ebook-9-1.png?width=618&height=444&name=how-to-create-an-ebook-9-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn85@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118313380_bfef5ec3e3b6566d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-364748345-gif/Blog-Related_Images/5-free-ebook-Templates.gif?width=418&height=552&name=5-free-ebook-Templates.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn77@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118308890_62637a4b03f7b3d6.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-create-an-ebook-free-templates&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn93@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118309758_82b6f028dc568c2c.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"The 5 Key Components of a Killer Customer Marketing Strategy","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/customer-marketing","description":"<p>It's easy to see marketing as a process specific to attracting and converting prospects — the practice of generating and capitalizing on <em>potential</em> customers' interest.</p> \n<p>But once that <em>potential </em>has successfully been removed from the equation, and the prospect of winning a prospect's business is no longer prospective, are you supposed to stop marketing to them altogether?</p>  \n<p>Absolutely not.</p> \n<p>Your current customer base is a perfectly lucrative wellspring of new and sustained business opportunities that you should constantly be tapping into. That's where the concept of <em>customer marketing</em> comes in — a school of marketing that allows you to get much more out of your customers than their initial business.</p> \n<p>Let's take a more thorough look at what customer marketing is and a picture of the five key elements of a successful customer-driven marketing strategy.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Customer marketing is, in large part, the art of building customer loyalty and enthusiasm in the hope that those elements will ultimately translate to new business. And in the context of the practice, the term \"new\" takes on multiple meanings.</p> \n<p>\"New\" business could mean existing customers buying new products or services as you develop them. It could mean current customers <em>upgrading</em> the products of yours they currently leverage or upping the tier of your service they subscribe to.</p> \n<p>Or, and perhaps most importantly, it could mean customers being enthusiastic enough about your business to evangelize to their friends and family about how awesome your company is to attract new customers <em>for you</em>.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, a solid customer-driven marketing strategy is a way to leverage your current customers as marketing assets. The process is incredibly useful — but often tricky to navigate. Here are some of the key components of an effective customer-driven marketing strategy.</p> \n<h3>1. Leverage buyer personas to segment and understand your customers.</h3> \n<p>This point applies to virtually every kind of marketing, and a customer-driven marketing strategy is no exception. The success of these kinds of efforts inevitably leans on your ability to understand and approach the people you're trying to appeal to. That's why it's in your best interest to use detailed buyer personas to guide your customer marketing efforts.</p> \n<p>As per HubSpot's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research\">own definition</a>, a buyer persona is \"<em>a semi-fictional representation of your ideal customers based on data and research.</em>\" Who are your customers? Can you identify multiple segments with different interests and sensitivities? What kind of customer marketing will best suit those various bases?</p> \n<p>For instance, say you're in the B2B SaaS space, and various iterations of your software are consistently bought by both freelance developers and decision-makers at midsize businesses.</p> \n<p>Those two groups would warrant the creation of two separate personas — ones that will probably be fundamentally different in how they approach your product and can be best appealed to.</p> \n<p>Say you've recently released a new paid add-on to your program tailored to appeal to companies with over 100 employees and want to sell to established customers.</p> \n<p>If you wanted to create an email campaign to support your customer-driven marketing efforts, you would refer to your midsize business decision-maker persona for cues on appropriate messaging and specific contacts.</p> \n<p>That way, your customer marketing effort would be adeptly targeted. You would reach the most interested customers with appropriate content — all without bothering or alienating your other base.</p> \n<p>One way or another, you have to know your customers before you can market to them effectively. Creating, maintaining, and referring to detailed buyer personas is central to that process. You can learn more about the nature and process of creating buyer personas <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research\">here</a>.</p> \n<h3>2. Provide exemplary customer service.</h3> \n<p>Two of the primary endgames of a customer-driven marketing strategy are garnering customer loyalty and facilitating customer evangelism. Those factors tend to hinge upon your customers' experiences — their experiences with your product or service and their experiences with your company as a whole.</p> \n<p>The latter tends to be easier to control than the former, so investing in customer service is always a must. Make sure your customer support infrastructure is sound.</p> \n<p>Be thorough and responsive when addressing individual customers' problems and concerns with your product — whether that be through email, over <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm/live-chat\">live chat</a>, on the phone, or in person.</p> \n<p>Have that structure in place and those resources on-hand to ensure that any potential problems your customers might have are immediately, patiently, and thoughtfully addressed.</p> \n<p>They'll help you delight your customers and provide specific insight into what you could be doing better — two actions that will inform your customer marketing strategy and allow you to maintain a happier customer base that will be more receptive to it.</p> \n<h3>3. Listen to and engage with your customers.</h3> \n<p>Customer feedback is central to the efficacy of any customer marketing strategy. How can you know what your customers want and expect out of your company if you don't listen to them? If you ignore their thoughts and input, you're undermining your ability to appeal to them as meaningfully as possible.</p> \n<p>Pay careful attention to how customers are interacting with your brand on social media. Hear what they say over those platforms and be willing to adjust your product development, messaging, outreach, and customer-driven marketing strategies accordingly.</p> \n<p>In many cases, just looking and listening won't be enough. <em>Engage</em> with your customers online. Actively interact with them on social media. Ask for their feedback and insight yourself. Address issues and concerns that they might be raising personally.</p> \n<p>Your customer-driven marketing strategy, at its core, is a means of cultivating and capitalizing on customer satisfaction. One of the best ways to do both is to let customers know that you care, are willing to listen, and will act on the feedback they offer.</p> \n<p>Consistently demonstrating that you're willing to do all that can be huge in the context of a successful customer-driven marketing strategy.</p> \n<h3>4. Incentivize loyalty.</h3> \n<p>Sustaining — if not consistently improving — impressive customer retention needs to be at the heart of your customer-driven marketing efforts. Your customers need to be loyal if you want to sell them on any new products or keep them on board as long as possible. But how can you help develop and foster that kind of loyalty?</p> \n<p>The two prior points — providing exceptional customer service and engaging with your customers — are significant parts of that process. But there are certain programs and strategies you can implement to give your pushes for customer loyalty a little extra <em>oomph</em>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-loyalty\">Customer loyalty</a> programs — incentivizing long term business with current customers through avenues like offering free merchandise, rewards, coupons, or even advance released products — are always worth considering when it comes to customer marketing.</p> \n<p>Give your customers tangible, immediate reasons to remain loyal. Again, this point ties into the overarching theme this article keeps touching on — letting customers know you care.</p> \n<p>The customers who have remained with your business want to know they're not being taken for granted. And newer customers could always use a few extra reasons to plan on staying with you in the long run.</p> \n<p>Customer loyalty programs are one of the better, more straightforward ways to supplement an effective customer-driven marketing strategy. So no matter the nature of your business, give some serious thought to incorporating one into your customer marketing efforts.</p> \n<h3>5. Have systems and strategies in place to generate referrals.</h3> \n<p>This point is where customer marketing and traditional marketing intersect. It's one of the most clear-cut ways to translate general loyalty into new business — all while keeping current customers enthusiastic about your company.</p> \n<p>There's tremendous utility, versatility, and value in a well-constructed <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-referral-program\">customer referral program</a>. It's essentially an official channel through which you can turn customers into evangelists — a program that incentivizes the projection of positive, customer-generated publicity.</p> \n<p>If you can put together a referral program with simple instructions and attractive rewards, you can give your customers a personal stake in promoting your business.</p> \n<p>It keeps them engaged, makes them articulate the value of your product or service to their friends, and ultimately wins you new customers while making the current ones that much happier with your business.</p> \n<p>One of the main — or perhaps <em>the</em> main — endgames to implementing a customer-driven marketing strategy is to turn your customers into spokespeople. A customer referral program expedites that process.</p> \n<p>Regardless of the size or nature of your business, you stand to gain a lot from carrying out effective customer marketing. Once you have customers on board, the last thing you should do is cast them by the wayside. There's tremendous potential in meaningfully engaging with and appealing to them, so it's worth your time to research and construct a solid customer-driven marketing strategy.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcustomer-marketing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 27 Jul 2020 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/CUSTOMERMARKETING%20%281%29.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"2ceb878aaab0abf82594ce351d40a9ef","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn13@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118303968_0821fd1005f7371d.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/CUSTOMERMARKETING%20%281%29.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"jfuchs@hubspot.com (Jay Fuchs)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcustomer-marketing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn17@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118308271_0b3a3015d3464a09.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"How to Conduct Successful Remote Interviews, According to HubSpot's Recruitment Coordinator","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-interviewing-best-practices","description":"<p>For your business to thrive, it's critical you set up a process for conducting effective interviews — and, in 2020, it's equally vital you create a comprehensive <em>virtual </em>interview strategy, as well.</p>  \n<p>As a Program Coordinator on HubSpot's Recruiting Operations Team, I'm familiar with the struggles of creating a cohesive remote interview experience. But, as HubSpot continues to grow globally, I also know how important it is to create a scalable remote candidate interviewing process.</p> \n<p>Plus, at HubSpot, we have a strong commitment to global-first and remote inclusion — so further developing our remote interview practices only makes sense.</p> \n<p>While there's no \"secret sauce\" to remote interviewing, we've iterated on a process that helps both candidates and interviewers have strong, purposeful conversations virtually.</p> \n<p>Here, I'm going to tell you about the best practices we've learned as a result of listening to both candidate and interviewer feedback so you can learn how to create your own powerful virtual recruitment process in 2020.</p> \n<h2>How to Conduct Successful Remote Interviews</h2> \n<h3>1. Be human and keep the personal touch.</h3> \n<p>While it’s a bit harder to make a personal connection when interviewing remotely, putting in the extra effort can be the difference between an average and remarkable candidate experience.</p> \n<p>There are many ways to do this, but some efforts our candidates are loving are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Providing 15-minute prep calls with recruiters if candidates are nervous about interviewing remotely. We want to set up candidates for success, so having quick sessions to familiarize themselves with Zoom (our video conferencing tool of choice) and have a test run can make all the difference.</li> \n <li>Hold a virtual meet-and-greet before the interview starts, so you can have a pulse check with your candidate, workout any pre-interview jitters, and make sure they are comfortable before handing them off to their first interviewer.</li> \n <li>Over-communicate the interview logistics to the candidate so they know exactly when the interview starts and how the exchange between interviewers will work to ensure a smooth process.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Knowledge and resources are power.</h3> \n<p>Interviewing remotely presents its own set of unique challenges for candidates: how to prepare, what to wear, and how to get an idea of the office, team, or culture they could be joining.</p> \n<p>The good news is that there are many ways you can share information and resources with candidates to fill these gaps, such as:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>A one-pager for how to prepare your work space, download your video conferencing software of choice, and practice with it</li> \n <li>This blog post: <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/careers-blog/video-interviews-how-to-prepare\">How to Prepare for Your Video Interview Debut</a></li> \n <li>Virtual office tours</li> \n <li>Content that gives candidates a glimpse into your culture and lets it shine, like your YouTube channel, your brand's Instagram page, or your business's Glassdoor page</li> \n <li>Team lunches or weekly stand-ups, to give candidates a look at their future team’s culture</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. Remote interviewing can feel very different from in-person, so make it as comfortable as possible.</h3> \n<p>Without the natural flow and physical reminders of an in-person interview, it’s easy to forget the small things that would make a remote interview just as comfortable as coming into the office.</p> \n<p>Here are some small things that you can do to make your candidates feel as comfortable as possible:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Before starting your interview, offer the candidate a water and restroom break.</li> \n <li>Ideally, take notes on paper so that you’re not typing while the person is talking. If you’ll be taking notes on the computer, call out the fact that you’ll be typing during the interview. In this scenario, it’s also best to mute yourself so that you’re not typing in their ears as they’re speaking, but keep in mind that for them it will feel like they’re talking to a silent crowd.</li> \n <li>Don’t lose the small talk you would normally have with candidates in-person.</li> \n <li>Be overly expressive — interviews are extra stressful when it’s hard to read body language. Nod, smile, and laugh, to help make the situation more comfortable.</li> \n <li>Include a \"breather\" whenever possible by building in 10 to 15-minute breaks in the interview schedule.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Channel your inner technology support specialist.</h3> \n<p>While most of our interviewers aren’t in tech support roles, it’s easy to forget that we use remote collaboration tools regularly, so we may be (and usually are) more experienced using and troubleshooting issues that can come up during a remote interview.</p> \n<p>Technology issues can happen, so don’t panic and stay strong in the face of adversity. Here are some of our tips for working through tech issues:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>When in doubt, leave and rejoin the meeting. If that doesn’t work, we recommend giving the candidate a call (which we list in all of our interview calendar invites).</li> \n <li>If the issue is Wi-Fi connectivity, the first troubleshooting step we recommend is suggesting that the candidate move closer to the wifi router (if able). Second step would be to turn off video and attempt to communicate just over audio. Third and final step would be to switch the call to take place over the phone.</li> \n <li>If you’re spending more than five minutes troubleshooting tech issues, it may be best to reschedule for a later time. Work with your internal stakeholders to make it happen.</li> \n <li>At HubSpot, we use Zoom, so keeping <a href=\"https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/sections/200305593-Troubleshooting\">Zoom’s troubleshooting guide</a> open makes it easier to search and troubleshoot on-the-fly. Make sure, whichever video tool you choose, that you have the tool's troubleshooting or FAQ page open just in case.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The way we have approached the adoption, measurement, and evaluation of the remote interviewing process is very HubSpot by nature.</p> \n<p>HubSpot <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34234/the-hubspot-culture-code-creating-a-company-we-love.aspx\">pushes its employees to have HEART</a> — be humble and listen, be empathetic towards others, adapt to changing situations, generate remarkable experience for everyone, and be transparent and share what you learn.</p> \n<p>I would encourage you to take this a step further and let the culture of your company shine throughout your interview process, whether in-person or virtually.</p> \n<p>Additionally, remember your candidates and interviewers can offer critical feedback to help you strengthen your process over time. Continue to collect feedback from both sides, and use it to improve your virtual experience.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally written in April 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fremote-interviewing-best-practices&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Jul 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/remote-interview.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"728992abc987f6619b8cb7e1bce86f94","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn85@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118303769_2a5241f082f61fbd.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/remote-interview.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Jake Richards","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fremote-interviewing-best-practices&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn81@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118307037_935a01609916ca88.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:41","title":"Social Media Definitions: The Ultimate Glossary of Terms You Should Know","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-terms","description":"<p><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0px; background-color: transparent;\">For many people, posting a tweet, hashtagging an Instagram caption, and sending out an invite for a Facebook event on Facebook has become common practice.&nbsp;</span></p>  \n<p><span style=\"background-color: transparent;\">(In fact, if you're highly experienced, you probably do&nbsp;all three at once.)</span></p> \n<p><span style=\"background-color: transparent;\">But with new social media networks and innovative software cropping up almost daily, even&nbsp;seasoned&nbsp;social media users are bound to run into a term or acronym that leaves them thinking, \"WTF?\"</span></p> \n<p><span style=\"background-color: transparent;\">For those head-scratching&nbsp;moments, we've created the ultimate glossary of <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/social-media\">social media marketing</a> terms.</span></p> \n<p><span style=\"background-color: transparent;\">Whether&nbsp;you're still hung up on the difference between a mention and a reply on Twitter or you just want to brush up on your social knowledge, check out the following roundup of social media terms to keep yourself in the know.&nbsp;</span></p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Social Media Terms to Know, Listed Alphabetically</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li><a href=\"#A\">Social Media Terms - A</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#B\">Social Media Terms - B</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#C\">Social Media Terms - C</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#D\">Social Media Terms - D</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#E\">Social Media Terms - E</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#F\">Social Media Terms - F</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#G\">Social Media Terms - G</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#H\">Social Media Terms - H</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#I>Social%20Media%20Terms%20-%20I</a></li>%20<li><a%20href=\">Social Media Terms - J</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#K\">Social Media Terms - K</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#L\">Social Media Terms - L</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#M\">Social Media Terms - M</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#N\">Social Media Terms - N</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#O\">Social Media Terms - O</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#P\">Social Media Terms - P</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#Q\">Social Media Terms - Q</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#R\">Social Media Terms - R</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#S\">Social Media Terms - S</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#T\">Social Media Terms - T</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#U\">Social Media Terms - V</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#W\">Social Media Terms - W</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#X\">Social Media Terms - X</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#Y\">Social Media Terms - Y</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"#Z\">Social Media Terms - Z</a></li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<a></a> \n<h3>A</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a title=\"Add This\" href=\"http://www.addthis.com/\">AddThis</a> - AddThis is a<span>&nbsp;web-tracking technology company that offers a wide range of social media and content tools -- from&nbsp;<span>responsive sharing buttons to custom follow buttons to recommended content plugins --&nbsp;designed to help you increase engagement on your website and earn more followers on social media.&nbsp;</span></span></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reddit#IAmA_and_AMA\">AMA</a> - AMA is an acronym for \"ask me anything,\" which originated in a&nbsp;popular subreddit where users will use the term to prompt questions from other users. Since its inception, the term has gone on to be used in other online social settings, such as <a href=\"http://inbound.org/discussion/view/i-am-alexis-ohanian-startup-guy-reddit-breadpig-hipmunk-bestselling-author-partner-at-y-combinator-ama\">this discussion on Inbound.org</a>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-analytics\">Analytics</a> - Analytics is data that helps you track the performance of your social media content. Analytical data could include page views, time on page, clickthrough rate, and engagement rate.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a title=\"Algorithm\" href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithm\">Algorithm</a> - An algorithm is a set of formulas developed for a computer to perform a certain function. This is important in the social sphere as the algorithms sites like Facebook and Google use are critical for developing content promotion&nbsp;strategies.</li> \n <li><a title=\"Application Programing Interface (API)\" href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Api\">Application Programming&nbsp;Interface (API)</a> - An API is a documented interface that allows one software application to interact with another application. An example of this is the <a href=\"http://apiwiki.twitter.com/\">Twitter API</a>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avatar_%28computing%29\">Avatar</a> - An avatar is an image or username that represents a person online, most often within forums and social networks.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>B</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://bit.ly/\">Bitly</a> - Bitly is a free URL shortening service that provides statistics for the links users share online. Bitly is popularly used to condense long URLs to make them easier to share on social networks such as Twitter.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/creative-snapchat-ideas\">Bitmoji</a> - A Bitmoji is an avatar or emoji that users can create to look like them. Bitmojis can then be added to your personal or Snapchat keyboards so you can send them to fiends or use them in place of profile pictures.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.likeable.com/blog/2014/08/how-to-write-the-perfect-social-media-bio\">Bio</a> - A bio on social media refers to a short bit of explainer text that explains who the user is. To&nbsp;see some examples, check out this roundup&nbsp;of some of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/twitter-bio\">most amusing bios on Twitter</a>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blog\">Blog</a> - Blog is a word that was created from two words: “web log.” Blogs are usually maintained by an individual or a business with regular entries of content on a specific topic, descriptions of events, or other resources&nbsp;such as graphics or video. \"Blog\" can also be used as a verb, meaning <em>to maintain or add content to a blog</em>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.blogger.com/\">Blogger</a> - Blogger is a free blogging platform owned by Google that allows individuals and companies to host and publish a blog typically on a subdomain. Example: yourblogname.blogspot.com</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.blogtalkradio.com/\">Blog Talk Radio</a> - Blog Talk Radio is a free web application that allows users to host live online radio shows.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://boardreader.com/\">BoardReader</a> - BoardReader is a free search engine that allows users to search for keywords only in posts and titles of online forums, a popular form of social networking.</li> \n <li><a title=\"Bookmarking\" href=\"http://www.ebizmba.com/articles/social-bookmarking-websites\">Bookmarking</a> - Bookmarking online follows the same idea of placing a bookmark in a physical publication -- you're simply marking something you found important, enjoyed, or want&nbsp;to continue reading later. The only difference online is that it's happening through websites using one of the various bookmarking services available, such as <a href=\"http://getpocket.com/\">Pocket</a>, or right within your browser.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>C</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.likeable.com/blog/2014/08/how-to-write-the-perfect-social-media-bio\">Canva</a> - Canva is an easy-to-use design tool for non-designers and designers alike. The tool offers several templates that adhere to the required dimensions for sharable social images on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, etc.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_chat\">Chat </a>- Chat can refer to any kind of communication over the internet but traditionally refers to one-to-one communication through a text-based chat application, commonly referred to as instant messaging (IM) applications.</li> \n <li><a title=\"Circles  \" href=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BeMZP-oyOII\">Circles </a>- Circles are clusters of a user's friends, colleagues, family, or connections on the now-discontinued Google+. On the platform, you got to choose who went in what Circle, and what you shared with those individuals.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clickbait\">Clickbait</a> - Clickbait is a term to describe marketing or advertising material that employs a sensationalized headline to attract clicks.
