They rely heavily on the \"<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/common-headline-myths\">curiosity&nbsp;gap</a>\" by creating&nbsp;just enough interest to provoke engagement.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.marketingterms.com/dictionary/clickthrough_rate/\">Clickthrough Rate</a> - Clickthrough rate is a common social media metric used to represent the number of times a visitor clickthrough&nbsp;divided by the total number of impressions a piece of content receives.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_intelligence\">Collective Intelligence</a> - Collective intelligence is a shared intelligence that emerges from the collaboration and competition of many individuals and appears in consensus decision-making in social networks.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comment\">Comment</a> - A comment is a response that is often provided as an answer or reaction to a blog post or message on a social network.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://compete.com/\">Compete</a> - Compete is a web-based application that offers users and businesses web analytics. It also enables people to compare and contrast the statistics for different websites over time.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-social-media-manager-job-description\">Community Manager</a> - The community manager is responsible for building and managing&nbsp;the online communications for a business in an effort to grow an online community.</li> \n <li><a title=\"Connections\" href=\"http://www.linkedin.com/connections\">Connections</a> - The LinkedIn equivalent of a Facebook 'friend' is a 'connection.' Because LinkedIn is a social networking site, the people you are <em>connecting</em> with are not necessarily people you are friends with, but rather professional contacts that you've met, heard speak, done business with, or know through another connection. Connections are&nbsp;categorized&nbsp;by: 1st degree, 2nd degree, and 3rd degree.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.nngroup.com/articles/conversion-rates/\">Conversion Rate</a> - Conversion rate refers to a common metric tracked in social media that is the percentage of&nbsp;people who completed an intended action (i.e. filling out a form, following a social account, etc.).</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.craigslist.org/\">Craigslist</a> - Craigslist is a popular online commerce site in which users sell a variety of goods and services to other users. The service has been credited for causing the reduction of classified advertising in newspapers across the United States.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://creativecommons.org/\">Creative Commons</a> - Creative Commons is a nonprofit corporation dedicated to making it easier for people to share and build upon the work of others, consistent with the rules of copyright. It provides free licenses and other legal tools to mark creative work with the freedom the creator wants it to carry, so others can share, remix, use commercially, or any combination thereof.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crowdsourcing\">Crowdsourcing</a> - Crowdsourcing, similar to&nbsp;outsourcing, refers to the act of soliciting ideas or content from a group of people, typically in an online setting.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>D</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://delicious.com/\">Delicious</a> - Delicious is a free online bookmarking service that lets users save website addresses publicly and privately online so they can be accessed from any device connected to the internet and shared with friends.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://digg.com/\">Digg</a> - Digg is a social news website that allows members to submit and vote for articles. Articles with the most votes appear on the homepage of the site and subsequently are seen by the largest portion of the site’s membership, as well as other visitors.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://support.twitter.com/articles/14606\">Direct Message (or DM)</a>&nbsp;- Direct messages -- also referred&nbsp;to as \"DMs\" --&nbsp;are private conversations that occur on Twitter. Both parties must be following one another to send a message.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/snapchat-discover-examples\">Discover (or Snapchat Discover)</a> - Discover is a section of Snapchat's app dedicated to large brands, influencers, and longer form story content.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://disqus.com/\">Disqus</a> - Disqus is a comment system and moderation tool for your site. This service lets you add community management and social web integration to any site on any platform.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>E</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a title=\"Ebook\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/internet-marketing-whitepapers/\">Ebook</a> - An ebook is an electronic version of a book. However, most ebooks are not actually available in print (unless you print them). These are typically published in PDF form. For marketers, ebooks commonly serve as lead generating content -- people&nbsp;must fill out a form to receive their ebook copy.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"http://linkhumans.com/blog/employee-advocacy-guide\">Employee Advocacy</a> - Employee advocacy refers to the act of employees using their own social presence&nbsp;to increase the reach of the company and its&nbsp;content.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/emojis\">Emoji</a> - Emojis are small cartoonish images that can be sent along with text in social media and private messages.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://www.google.com/search?q=endorsement+on+LinkedIn&amp;oq=endorsement+on+LinkedIn&amp;aqs=chrome..69i57j0l5.3736j0j4&amp;sourceid=chrome&amp;es_sm=91&amp;ie=UTF-8\">Endorsement</a> - An endorsement on LinkedIn refers to an instance in which another LinkedIn user&nbsp;recognizes you for one of the skills you have listed on your profile.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"http://trackmaven.com/marketing-dictionary/engagement-rate/\">Engagement Rate</a> - Engagement rate is a popular social media metric used to describe the&nbsp;amount&nbsp;of interaction -- likes, shares, comments -- a piece of content receives.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.eventbrite.com/\">Eventbrite</a> - Eventbrite is a provider of online event management and ticketing services. Eventbrite is free if your event is free. If you sell tickets to your event, Eventbrite collects a fee per ticket.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>F</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.facebook.com/\">Facebook</a> - Facebook is a social media platform founded by Mark Zuckerberg in 2004. The site&nbsp;connects people with friends, family, acquaintances, and businesses from all over the world and enables them to post, share, and engage with a variety of content such as photos and status updates. The platform currently boasts around 1.49 billion active users.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/Facebook-fan\">Fans</a> - Fans is the term used to describe people who like your Facebook Page.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&amp;ion=1&amp;espv=2&amp;ie=UTF-8#q=favorite%20a%20tweet\">Favorite</a> - Represented by the small star icon on Twitter, favoriting a tweet signals to the creator that you liked their content or post.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/finsta\">Finsta</a> - Short for \"fake insta\" this term describes one's secret or fake Instagram page that's hidden from their employers.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flash_mob\">Flash Mob</a> - A flash mob is a large group of people who assemble suddenly in a public place, perform an unusual and pointless act for a brief time, then quickly disperse. The term flash mob is generally applied only to gatherings organized via telecommunications, social media, or viral emails.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.flickr.com/\">Flickr</a> - Flickr is a social network for&nbsp;online picture sharing. The service allows users to store photos online and then share them with others through profiles, groups, sets, and other methods.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_forum\">Forums</a> - Also known as a message board, a forum is an online discussion site. It originated as the modern equivalent of a traditional bulletin board, and a technological evolution of the&nbsp;dial-up&nbsp;bulletin board system.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.webopedia.com/TERM/F/follower.html\">Follower </a>- In a social media setting, a follower refers to a person who subscribes to your account in order to receive your updates.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a title=\"Follow Friday (#ff)\" href=\"http://twitter.com/#%21/search?q=%23ff\">Follow Friday (#ff)</a> - Follow Friday&nbsp;is a trend via the hashtag #ff every Friday on Twitter. Users select other usernames and tweet them with #ff in their post, meaning they recommend following those Twitter users.&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/outdated-internet-trends-list\">There is debate</a> whether this trend is&nbsp;past its prime.</li> \n <li><a title=\"Friends\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/find-friends\">Friends</a> - Friends is the term used on Facebook to represent the connections you make and the people you follow. These are individuals you consider to be friendly enough with you to see your Facebook profile and engage with you.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/fyp?lang=en\">#FYP (For Your Page)</a> - #FYP is a hashtag that TikTok users place in their videos to prioritize their content on other users' \"Your Page\" feed. This feed algorithmically sends users content from people you follow or related to hashtags you might be interested in.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>G</h3> \n<ul> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://gaggleamp.com/\">GaggleAMP</a> - GaggleAMP is a social media marketing platform that provides businesses with the ability to leverage its&nbsp;employee's online presence to increase brand awareness&nbsp;and expand its&nbsp;reach.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geotagging\">Geotag</a>&nbsp;- A geotag is the directional coordinates that can be attached to a piece of content online. For example, Instagram users often use geotagging to highlight the location&nbsp;in which their photo was taken.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GIF\">GIF</a> - GIF is an acronym for Graphics Interchange Format. In social media, GIFs serve as small-scale animations and film clips. (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-gifs\">Check out this round up of reaction GIFs</a> used to illustrate our excitement when Facebook announced that they were supporting their functionality.)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.google.com/chrome\">Google Chrome</a> - Google Chrome is a free web browser produced by Google that fully integrates with&nbsp;its online search system as well as its other&nbsp;applications.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://docs.google.com/\">Google Documents</a> - Google Documents is a group of web-based office applications that includes tools for word processing, presentations, spreadsheet analysis, etc. All documents are stored and edited online and allow multiple people to collaborate on a document in real-time.</li> \n <li><a title=\"Google+\" href=\"https://plus.google.com/up/?continue=https://plus.google.com/&amp;type=st\">Google+</a> - Google+ is Google's discontinued social network. It served as a platform for users to connect with friends, family, and professionals while enabling them to share photos, send messages, and engage with content. Google uses the \"+1\" to serve as the equivalent to a Like on Facebook or Instagram.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-facebook-groups-examples\">Groups</a> - Facebook and LinkedIn offer a Groups feature where people in similar industries or with similar passions can join a group and discuss topics related to it.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>H</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://twitter.com/hubspot\">Handle</a> - Handle is the term used to describe someone's @username on Twitter. For example, HubSpot's Twitter handle is @HubSpot.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://support.twitter.com/articles/127871\">Header image</a> - A header image refers to the large photo displayed at the top of your profile on Twitter. The header image is also commonly referred&nbsp;to as the banner image on LinkedIn or the cover image on Facebook.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a title=\"Hangout  \" href=\"http://www.google.com/tools/dlpage/res/talkvideo/hangouts/\">Hangout </a>- A Hangout is a video service on Google+ that allows you to video chat with up to 10 Google+ users are a time. You can name these chats, watch YouTube videos during them, open a Google Doc with colleagues, and much more.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter\">Hashtag</a> - A hashtag is a tag used on a variety of social networks as a way to annotate a message. A hashtag is a word or phrase preceded by a “#\" (i.e. #InboundMarketing).&nbsp;Social networks use hashtags to categorize information and make it easily searchable for users.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/new-social-media\">Houseparty</a> - Houseparty is an app that Gen Z has notably used to connect with friends over video calls.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog/tabid/6307/bid/5847/A-Marketer-s-Guide-to-HTML5.aspx\">HTML</a> - HyperText Markup Language (HTML) is a programming&nbsp;language for web pages. Think of HTML as the brick-and-mortar of pages on the web. It provides content and structure while<a href=\"http://www.w3.org/Style/CSS/\"> CSS</a> supplies style. HTML has changed over the years, and it is on the cusp of its next version: HTML5.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>I</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/igtv\">IGTV</a> - IGTV is where verified businesses and accounts can host long-form videos or place longer live streams after they've aired.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impression_(online_media)\">Impressions</a> - An impression refers to a way in which marketers and advertisers keep track of every time ad is \"fetched\" and counted.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/inbound-marketing\">Inbound Marketing</a> - Inbound marketing is a style of marketing that uses&nbsp;permission-based marketing techniques to get found by potential customers, convert them&nbsp;into leads, customers, and advocates, and analyze the process along the way. Inbound marketing leverages tactics and tools&nbsp;such as&nbsp;SEO, blogging, social media, lead generation, email marketing, lead nurturing, marketing automation, surveys, personalization, and CRM.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/31965/how-to-analyze-facebook-insights-to-improve-your-content-strategy-with-video.aspx\">Insights</a> - Many social media networks, like Facebook or Instagram, offer insights pages to their business account holders. These pages often allow the user's to see valuable analytics about their page and how they're performing compared to similar pages.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a title=\"Instagram  \" href=\"http://instagr.am/\">Instagram</a> - Instagram is a photo sharing application that lets users take photos, apply filters to their images, and share the photos instantly on the Instagram network and other social networks like Facebook, Flickr, Twitter, and Foursquare. The app is targeted toward mobile social sharing, and has gained more than 300 million users.&nbsp;<strong><br></strong></li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instant_messaging\">Instant Messaging</a> - Instant messaging (IM) is a form of real-time, direct text-based communication between two or more people. More advanced instant messaging software clients also allow enhanced modes of communication, such as live voice or video calling.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-live-video-ephemeral-messages\">Instagram Live </a>- Instagram Live is the platform where individuals and businesses on Instagram can share a live feed of what's going on in their lives.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>K</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/advertisers-guide-mobile-messaging-apps\">Kik</a> - Kik is a social media network where people can send short video messages to each other via the Kik mobile app.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a title=\"Klout\" href=\"http://klout.com/home\">Klout</a> - Klout is a measure of social influence. The service allows users to connect various social accounts such as Facebook, Flickr, YouTube, etc., and then provides every user with his or her Klout score. The score is out of 100 -- the higher the score, the more influence it estimates you have in the social world.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>L</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://developers.facebook.com/docs/reference/plugins/like\">Like</a> - A Like is an action that can be made by a Facebook or Instagram user. Instead of writing a comment or sharing a post, a user can click the Like button as a quick way to show approval.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_engine_optimization\">Link Building</a> - Link building is an aspect of search engine optimization in which website owners develop strategies to earn&nbsp;links to their site from other websites with the hopes of improving their search engine ranking. Blogging has emerged as a popular method of link building.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.linkedin.com/\">LinkedIn</a> - LinkedIn is a business-oriented social networking site with over 380 million members in over 200 countries and territories. Founded in December 2002 and launched in May 2003, it is mainly used for professional networking.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://help.linkedin.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/47445/~/long-form-posts-on-linkedin---overview\">LinkedIn Publishing</a> - LinkedIn's publishing platform functions as a place where members can publish long-form posts that related to their professional interests and expertise. While this capability used to be limited to <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/discover\">LinnkedIn Influencers</a> only, the platform was opened up to everyone in 2014.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"http://www.slideshare.net/?ss\">LinkedIn SlideShare</a> - LinkedIn&nbsp;<span>SlideShare is an online social network for sharing presentations and documents. Users can favorite and embed presentations as well as share them on other social networks such as LinkedIn, Twitter, and Facebook.</span></li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://www.google.com/search?q=what+is+a+twitter+list&amp;oq=what+is+a+twitter+list&amp;aqs=chrome..69i57j0l5.3004j0j9&amp;sourceid=chrome&amp;es_sm=91&amp;ie=UTF-8\">Listed</a> - The act of being \"listed\" on Twitter refers to when a user curates a custom list of Twitter users to more easily keep tabs on their tweets.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streaming_media\">Live streaming</a> - Live streaming is the act of delivering content over the internet in real-time. This term was popularized in social media by apps such as Meerkat and Periscope.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lurkers\">Lurker</a> - A lurker online is a person who reads discussions on a message board, newsgroup, social network, or other interactive system, but rarely or never participates in the discussion.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>M</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mashup_%28digital%29\">Mashup</a> - A content mashup contains multiple types of media drawn from pre-existing sources to create a new work. Digital mashups allow individuals or businesses to create new pieces of content by combining multiple online content sources.</li> \n <li><a title=\"Meme\" href=\"http://memegenerator.net/\">Meme</a> - A meme on the internet is used to describe a thought, idea, joke, or concept that's widely&nbsp;shared online. It is typically an image with text above and below it, but can also come in video and link form. A popular example is the <a title=\"&quot;I Can Has Cheezburger\" href=\"http://icanhascheezburger.com/\">\"I Can Has Cheezburger</a>?\" cat meme that turned into an entire site of memes.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://support.twitter.com/articles/14023\">Mention</a> - A mention is a Twitter term used to describe an instance in which a user includes someone else's @username in their tweet to attribute a piece of content or start a discussion.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>N</h3> \n<ul> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Native_advertising\">Native Advertising</a>&nbsp;- Native content refers to a type of online advertising in which the ad copy and format adheres to the format of a regular post on the network it's being published on. The purpose is to make ads feel less like ads, and more like part of the conversation.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a title=\"News Feed\" href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_feed\">News Feed</a> - A news feed is literally a feed full of news. On Facebook, the News Feed is the homepage of users' accounts where they can see all the latest updates from their friends. The news feed on Twitter is called Timeline.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32983/The-Inbound-Marketer-s-Complete-Guide-to-Newsjacking.aspx\">Newsjacking</a> - Newsjacking refers to the practice of capitalizing on the popularity of a news story to amplify your sales and marketing success.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>P</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.pandora.com/\">Pandora </a>- Pandora is a social online radio station that allows users to create stations based on their favorite artists and types of music.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://www.periscope.tv/\">Periscope</a> - Periscope is a social video app that allows users to broadcast live video from wherever they are. App users also have the ability to engage&nbsp;with others videos, browse live or recent broadcasts, and follow users to receive notifications.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permalink\">Permalink</a> - A permalink is an address or URL of a particular post within a blog or website that remains indefinitely unchanged.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.pinterest.com/\">Pinterest </a>- Pinterest is a photo sharing&nbsp;social network that provides users with a platform for uploading, saving, and categorizing \"pins\" through collections called \"boards.\" Boards are typically organized by theme, such as: Food &amp; Drink, Women's Fashion, Gardening, etc. Users have the ability to \"pin\" and \"repin\" content that they like to their respective boards.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Podcast\">Podcast</a><span> - A podcast is a series of digital media files, usually&nbsp;audio, that are released episodically and often downloaded through an RSS feed.</span></li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://getpocket.com/\">Pocket</a>&nbsp;- Pocket is an app that enables users to manage a reading list of articles they've saved from the internet to read later. Pocket has an open API that allows it to integrate with over 500 applications including social networks like Twitter.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pay_per_click\">PPC</a> - PPC is an acronym for pay per click. Pay per click is an online advertising model in which advertisers display ads on various websites or search engines and pay when a visitor clicks through. Bid-based PPC involves an auction in which advertisers compete&nbsp;with other advertisers by setting the max bid -- or highest amount they're willing to pay -- for each click. Each time a visitor triggers the ad spot, the auction process pans out to select which ad will be displayed.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Q</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.quantcast.com/\">Quantcast</a> - Quantcast provides website traffic and demographics for websites. The tool is primarily used by online advertisers looking to target specific demographics.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>R</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_web\">Real-Time Search</a> - Real-time search is the method of indexing content being published online into search engine results with virtually no delay.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_marketing\">Real-Time Marketing</a> - Real-time marketing is a strategy that requires marketers to publish timely content as news breaks. For example, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/oreo/status/298246571718483968\">Oreo tweeted this quick-witted response</a> to the 2013 Super Bowl blackout as it was unfolding.&nbsp;<br><br><a href=\"http://help.linkedin.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/90/~/recommendations-overview\">Recommendation</a> - A&nbsp;recommendation&nbsp;on LinkedIn is a term used to describe a written note from another LinkedIn member that aims to reinforce the user's professional credibility or expertise.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.reddit.com/\">Reddit</a> - Reddit is a social news site that&nbsp;contains specific, topic-oriented&nbsp;communities of users who share and comment on stories.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://support.twitter.com/articles/14023\">Reply</a> - A reply is a Twitter action that allows a user to respond to a tweet through a separate&nbsp;tweet that begins with the other user's @username. This differs from a mention, because tweets that start with an @username only appears in the timelines&nbsp;of users who follow both parties.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_retargeting\">Retargeting</a> - Retargeting is an online marketing and advertising technique&nbsp;that allows marketers to display ads to people who have visited their website or are part of their contacts database.&nbsp;For more on how a retargeting campaign works, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/retargeting-campaigns-beginner-guide\">check out this beginner's guide.</a></li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a title=\"Retweet\" href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/27675/How-to-Retweet-the-Right-Way-in-4-Easy-Steps.aspx\">Retweet</a> - A retweet is when someone on Twitter sees your message and decides to re-share it with his or her followers. A retweet button allows them to quickly resend the message with attribution to the original sharer's name.</li> \n <li><a title=\"RSS\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSS\">RSS Feed</a> - RSS is a family of web feed formats used to publish frequently updated content such as blogs and videos in a standardized format. Content publishers can syndicate a feed, which allows users to subscribe to the content and read it when they please from a location other than the website (such as Feedly or other RSS readers).</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aggregator\">RSS Reader</a> - An RSS reader allows users to aggregate articles from multiple websites into one place using RSS feeds. The purpose of these aggregators is to allow for a faster and more efficient information consumption.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>S</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_engine_optimization\">Search Engine Optimization</a> - Search engine optimization is the process of improving the volume or quality of unpaid traffic to a website from search engines.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selfie\">Selfie</a> - A selfie is a self-portrait that is typically taken using the reverse camera screen on a smartphone or by using a selfie stick (a pole that attaches to your camera). Selfies are commonly shared on social media networks like Instagram, Twitter, and Facebook using the hashtag #selfie.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.skype.com/intl/en-us/home\">Skype</a> - Skype is a free program that allows for text, audio, and video chats between users. Additionally, users can purchase plans to place&nbsp;phone calls through their Skype account.</li> \n <li><span><a href=\"https://www.snapchat.com/\">Snapchat</a> - Snapchat is a social app that allows users to send and receive time-sensitive&nbsp;photos and videos known as \"snaps,\" which are hidden from the recipients once the time limit expires (images and videos still remain on the Snapchat server). Users can add text and drawings to their snaps and control the list of recipients in which they send them to.&nbsp;</span></li> \n <li><span><a href=\"https://map.snapchat.com/\">Snap Map</a> - The Snap Map is a feature of Snapchat that allows you to see where your friends are as well as hot spots where people are publicly posting stories.</span></li> \n</ul> \n<p><span><img src=\"https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/snap-map1.jpg?w=730&amp;crop=1\" alt=\"Someone holds a smartphone displaying a Snap Map\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></span></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2017/06/21/snap-map/#:~:text=To%20access%20the%20Snap%20Map,directly%20to%20make%20meetup%20plans.\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<ul> \n <li><span><a href=\"https://support.snapchat.com/ca/stories\">Story</a> - A Snapchat, Facebook, or Instagram story is a string of videos or images that lasts for 24 hours. Users can create stories to be shared publicly or just a customized group of recipients.&nbsp;</span></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/social-inbox\">Social Inbox</a> - Social Inbox is an app in&nbsp;the HubSpot software that plugs into your contacts database and allows users&nbsp;to optimize their social monitoring, publishing, and analysis.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://wiki.kenburbary.com/\">Social Media Monitoring</a> - Social media monitoring is a process of monitoring and responding to mentions related to a business that occur in social media.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_proof\">Social Proof</a> - Social proof refers to a psychological phenomenon in which people seek direction from those around them to determine how they are supposed to act or think in a given situation. In social media, social proof can be identified by the number of interactions&nbsp;a piece of content receives or the number of followers you have. The thought is that if others are sharing something or following someone, it must be good.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-selling-definition-under-100-words\">Social Selling</a> - Social selling is a sales concept in which representatives leverage the power of social communication to engage&nbsp;with prospects by answering their questions, providing helpful content, clarifying information, etc.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://www.spotify.com/us/\">Spotify</a> - Like Pandora, Spotify is a music streaming service with a social media twist. Not only can you share what you're listening to with other social networks, but you can also see what your friends are listening to or listen to their playlists directly from the platform.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.stumbleupon.com/\">StumbleUpon</a> - StumbleUpon is a free web-browser extension that acts as an intelligent browsing tool for discovering and sharing web sites.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/reddit-marketing\">Subreddit</a> - Discussion board dedicated to a specific topic on reddit.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>T</h3> \n<ul> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/help/124970597582337\">Tag</a> - Tagging is a social media functionality commonly used on Facebook and Instagram that allows users to create a link back to the profile of the person shown in the picture or targeted by the update.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/how-to-use-threaded-comments-on-your-blog\">Thread</a> - A series of comments or discussion posts on a post or in a subreddit.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-tiktok\">TikTok</a> - TikTok is one of the fastest-growing social media platforms of all time, The app, beloved by Gen Z, is similar to Vine in that it highlights bitesized looping videos that can also have musical overlays.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://support.twitter.com/articles/101125\">Trending Topic</a> - Trending topics refer to the most talked about topics and hashtags on a social media network. These commonly appear on networks like Twitter and Facebook and serve as clickable links in which users can either click through to join the conversation or simply browse the related content.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_troll\">Troll </a>- A troll or internet troll refers to a person who is known for creating controversy&nbsp;in an online setting. They typically hang out in forums, comment sections, and chat rooms with the intent of disrupting the conversation on&nbsp;a piece of content by providing commentary that aims to evoke a reaction.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://www.tumblr.com/\">Tumblr </a>- Tumblr is a microblogging platform that allows users to post text, images, video, audio, links, and quotes to their blog. Users can also follow other blogs and repost other users' content to their own blog.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/twitch\">Twitch</a> - Twitch is a live streaming social platform which gained notoriety when gamers used it to stream their video game skills. Recently, brands have also begun to experiment with the platform.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com\">Twitter</a>&nbsp;- Twitter is a real-time social network that allows users to share 140-character updates with their following. Users can favorite and retweet the posts of other users, as well as engage in conversations using @ mentions, replies, and hashtags for categorizing their content.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/twitter-topics\">Twitter Topics</a> - A recently launched Twitter feature that allows users to follow specific topic categories from marketing, to politics, to birdwatching. Once users follow topics, they'll see more content related to these categories on their feeds.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"http://tweepi.com/\">Tweepi</a> - Tweepi is a social media management tool that provides users with a platform for simplifying the way they manage their social following. It's typically used for mass following or unfollowing a group of people based on certain criteria.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://tweetdeck.twitter.com/\">Tweetdeck</a> - Tweetdeck is a Twitter&nbsp;tool that provides users with a way to manage their Twitter presence&nbsp;through custom columns. The platform integrates with the Twitter API to allow users to both send and receive tweets.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"http://www.techopedia.com/definition/29186/twitterverse\">Twitterverse</a> - Also referred to as the Twittersphere, Twitterverse&nbsp;is a nickname for the community of users who are active on Twitter.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3 class=\"p1\">U</h3> \n<ul> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User-generated_content\">User-Generated Content</a> (or UGC) - User-generated content is content -- blogs, videos, photos, quotes, etc. -- that is created by consumers. Marketers typically tap into their audience in an online setting to collect this type of content to support a campaign or initiative.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3 class=\"p1\">V</h3> \n<ul> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://vine.co/\">Vine</a> - Founded in 2012 and discontinued in 2017, Vine was a social video sharing service where users could create and engage with short-form, six-second video clips. Videos published through the service were easily shared across other social platforms such a Twitter and Facebook.</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><span><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viral\">Viral</a> - Viral is a term used to describe an instance in which a piece of content -- YouTube video, blog article, photo, etc. -- achieves noteworthy awareness. Viral distribution relies heavily on word of mouth and the frequent sharing of one particular piece of content all over the internet.</span></li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_blog\">Vlogging</a> - Vlogging or a vlog is a piece of content that employs video to tell a story or report on information. Vlogs are common on video sharing networks like YouTube.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3 class=\"p1\">W</h3> \n<ul> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"http://www.webopedia.com/TERM/W/Webinar.html\">Webinar</a> - A webinar is an online seminar or presentation that is hosted by an individual or a company. Most often, the host requires attendees to fill out a form before granting them access to stream the audio and&nbsp;slides. In marketing, webinars are held&nbsp;to educate audiences about a particular topic while opening up the floor for a discussion to occur on social media using the webinar's unique hashtag.&nbsp;</li> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/whatsapp-marketing\">WhatsApp</a> - WhatsApp is a messaging, phone, and social media app that allows people to connect internationally over a Wi-Fi network.</li> \n</ul> \n<a> <h3 class=\"p1\">Y</h3> </a> \n<ul> \n <li class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/yelp-business\">Yelp</a> - Technically Yelp isn't a social media platform. But, it is a great way to spread awareness if you're a business owner. The platform one of the leading sites for online recommendations.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Z</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&amp;rct=j&amp;q=&amp;esrc=s&amp;source=web&amp;cd=1&amp;ved=0CB8QFjAAahUKEwj2prPlpbrHAhVGgJIKHTMRDyc&amp;url=https%3A%2F%2Fzapier.com%2F&amp;ei=einXVfaBLMaAygSzory4Ag&amp;usg=AFQjCNExHqHMTW7Ix273nP5XzbmM7oyUZw&amp;sig2=MitEd1DUyKoe9ZOH5Oeumg\">Zapier</a> - Zapier is a software that leverages \"zaps\" to connect apps and provides users with a way to automate tasks. Zaps are&nbsp;automations that contain both Triggers and Actions. For example, you can connect your Twitter with your Evernote to save your favorited tweets to a folder, or connect Facebook and Twitter to tweet posts from a Facebook Page.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published in July 2018, but was updated for comprehensiveness and freshness in July 2020.&nbsp;</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fsocial-media-terms&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 27 Jul 2020 00:45:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/00-Blog_Thinkstock_Images/Social_Media_Dictionary_Terms.png#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"0b4b0766802b3fe01854282e3cc734de","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn33@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118303799_a8fec91914e85778.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/00-Blog_Thinkstock_Images/Social_Media_Dictionary_Terms.png#keepProtocol","author":"cstec@hubspot.com (Carly Stec)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/snap-map1.jpg?w=730&crop=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn33@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118307528_b1a483b278cb7af6.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fsocial-media-terms&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn5@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118310691_507ec6fc715db39f.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:41","title":"How to Host an Inclusive Virtual Meeting, According to HubSpot's Remote Work Manager","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-meetings-tips","description":"<p>As HubSpot's remote population has grown from a handful of folks to over 300 in the past few years, we've learned a number of lessons on how to pivot in-person communications into a virtual environment.</p>  \n<p>When it comes to a team meeting, we've learned that while the content often remains the same, the way in which that content is presented and discussed often needs to be modified to ensure that the information resonates and all attendees are actively engaged.</p> \n<p>We've all been on a conference call that <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DYu_bGbZiiQ&amp;t=4s\">goes something like this:</a></p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/DYu_bGbZiiQ\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>But, with remote working on the rise, conference calls are no longer the only option.</p> \n<p>Today, there are loads of options available to host meetings over a virtual meeting platform such as Google Hangouts, Zoom, WebEx, or Join.me.</p> \n<p>While every business will have different needs to consider, if you're just starting to think about virtual meetings, we recommend starting with a platform that allows video, audio, and screen sharing as these tools allow for better engagement and collaboration during the meeting as opposed to the standard conference call.</p> \n<p>Here, I'll dive into some of the best practices I've picked up along the way as HubSpot's Remote Work and Inclusion Program Manager.</p> \n<h2><strong>How to Host an Inclusive Virtual Meeting</strong></h2> \n<h3>1. Have ground rules in place for your first meeting.</h3> \n<p>Whether it's your <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/remote-leadership?utm_source=marketing_blog&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=remote_leadership\">first time managing a remote team</a> or your team is suddenly working from home, virtual meetings are often a new environment for everyone. So it's important to lay some ground rules for how meetings will work and what you expect from your attendees.</p> \n<p>Here are a few things to consider:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Video:</strong> Encourage attendees to use their video for meetings as this allows us to better engage with each other through non-verbal communication.</li> \n <li><strong>Audio:</strong> Generally speaking, it's best practice to stay muted in a virtual meeting unless you're presenting or answering a question. This prevents background noise from becoming a distraction and creates a signal (unmuting) when someone has something to say.</li> \n <li><strong>Engagement:</strong> Be clear about how you expect participants to engage in meetings (see Tip #3 for more details).</li> \n <li><strong>Etiquette:</strong> Be intentional in calling out meeting etiquette expectations. Some common ones that come up are use of phones, having to step away from your desk, checking notifications, or eating during meetings. If you have specific expectations around meeting etiquette, be explicit about this up front with your attendees.</li> \n <li><strong>Set the Stage:</strong> If you're meeting with a larger group, it can be helpful to set expectations on a starting slide that attendees will see upon entering the meeting.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>For instance, at HubSpot, I often present with this slide at the beginning, so my attendees know ground rules for the meeting:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-04-30%20at%2010.34.27%20AM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-04-30%20at%2010.34.27%20AM.png\" alt=\"how to work from home\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">Additionally, you might consider including a slide that says, \"Record the meeting\", as a reminder for yourself, in case anyone misses the meeting or wants to refer back to it later.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>2. Take some time to break the ice.</h3> \n<p>Virtual environments can be intimidating, especially if you aren't accustomed to them or if you're meeting with folks you're unfamiliar with. To warm things up, we recommend <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ice-breaker-games\">starting your meetings with an icebreaker</a>. It's a great way to test that everyone's audio works properly and it's an even better way to learn more about each other and get everyone feeling comfortable before jumping into the agenda.</p> \n<p>To make this easier, we suggest:</p> \n<p><strong>Keep it simple: </strong><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Depending on the meeting, it might make sense to start with a standard question such as \"How are you feeling today?\"</span></p> \n<p><strong>Mix it up:</strong><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"> If you have the time, try mixing in some unique ice breakers to get to know each other better (take a look at some of </span><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ice-breaker-games\">our suggestions here</a><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">).</span></p> \n<p><strong>Pass the microphone:</strong><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"> We're all likely familiar with that awkward silence that occurs when everyone is expecting someone else to jump in. To solve for this, encourage teams to “Pass the Microphone” to each other after their own answer. </span></p> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">If everyone is expected to provide an answer, have the host start and then pass the proverbial microphone to any participant. Once that participant answers, they'll end their statement with, \"Next, I'll pass the microphone to [name].” This keeps the conversation moving and prevents the awkward silence of waiting for someone else to jump in.</span></p> \n<h3>3. Determine a structure for how you expect participants to engage during the meeting.</h3> \n<p>It's not always obvious how folks should provide feedback or answers during a virtual meeting. To keep the conversation flowing, determine a structure for how you expect participants to engage during meetings, and be upfront about these expectations at the start of the meeting.</p> \n<p>A few of our favorite strategies are:</p> \n<p><strong>Raise your virtual hand.</strong>&nbsp;Many virtual meeting platforms have non-verbal feedback tools that allow a participant to indicate they have a question — for example, Zoom's “<a href=\"https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/115001286183-Nonverbal-Feedback-During-Meetings\">raise hand</a>” feature. For large meetings, ask folks to use these tools to indicate when they have a question or input and the host can then call on them directly. This can also be a great way to have a quick yes/no question answered by the group and expanded upon.</p> \n<p><em>Example: “Raise your hand if you have had a positive interaction with an external Support team.” Based on who raises their hand, you can then call on one person to expand on that answer if needed.</em></p> \n<p><strong>Use the chat feature:</strong> For quick questions, you may ask folks to enter their answers into the chat (for instance, <a href=\"https://support.google.com/a/users/answer/9300511?hl=en\">Google Hangouts' Chat feature</a>). This allows you to quickly hear answers from a large group and allows everyone to learn from each other's answer. In addition, as our APAC Customer Success Trainer, Mariel Argonza, points out, this is also a great way to be inclusive of attendees who use English as a Second Language.</p> \n<p><em><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Example: “How is everyone feeling today? Describe it in one word in the chat pane.”</span></em></p> \n<p><strong>Jump in:</strong><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"> Depending on the size of your meeting and psychological safety of your attendees, you may opt to have folks simply jump in with their feedback and questions. As the facilitator, it's important to be cognizant of participation in order to ensure that one individual isn't dominating the conversation.</span></p> \n<p><em><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Example: “Can anyone tell me the definition of Inbound Marketing? Feel free to jump right in.”</span></em></p> \n<h3>4. Ensure every attendee is on the same page.</h3> \n<p>Depending on the nature of your meeting, you may need some additional tools to get on the same page with your idea, such as a virtual whiteboard or collaboration tool. Some of our favorites include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Virtual Whiteboard: </strong>Many of the virtual meeting tools have a native whiteboard tool built in that will allow attendees to whiteboard their ideas as well as save their whiteboard images for future use.</li> \n <li><strong>Share Your Screen:</strong> Looking at an email you need help with or struggling to explain a glitch you're seeing? Use a screen sharing tool such as <a href=\"https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362153-Sharing-your-screen\">Zoom's Screen Share</a> so that your attendees can see what you're seeing from your point of view.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://jamboard.google.com/\"><strong>JamBoard</strong><strong>:</strong></a> Part of GSuite, JamBoard allows you to use a virtual whiteboard, insert pictures and text, and save/share your whiteboard for future use.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.lucidchart.com/\"><strong>LucidChart</strong><strong>:</strong></a> Lucidchart is a visual productivity platform that helps individuals understand and share ideas, information, and processes with clarity.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://miro.com/\"><strong>Miro</strong></a>: Miro is an online whiteboard tool that allows distributed teams to collaborate virtually from wherever they may be seated.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. <span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Stay on track with a clear agenda or slides.</span></h3> \n<p>Even with a clear agenda, it can be challenging to keep a conversation on track — and on time — in a virtual setting. To help your meeting stay on course, try:</p> \n<p><strong>Circulate the agenda:</strong><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"> In the meeting invitation, make it clear what topics you'll be discussing, what's expected of attendees in terms of preparation, and what the outcomes of the meeting will be.</span></p> \n<p><strong>Pause:</strong><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"> When everyone is on mute and staring at you on camera, it can be instinctual to race through your notes without coming up for air. However, in a virtual atmosphere, it's more important than ever to slow down and pause often to ensure that folks have an opportunity to jump in, slower WiFi connections can catch up with a delayed sound response, and participants have the opportunity to digest your words.</span></p> \n<p><strong>Ask for questions:</strong><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"> In a virtual setting, you may not always catch a confused look and folks might not feel as comfortable interrupting you for clarification. So, intentionally ask your participants - what questions do you have for me? Pause longer than you normally would to wait for questions.</span></p> \n<p><strong>Use slides to stay on-track:</strong><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"> Having a visual to keep you on track will allow everyone to be more organized and focused during the meeting. You can choose to send slides out in advance of or following the meeting, but it's a helpful way to have a record of what was discussed. In addition, sending out slides means that folks won't have to take as many notes (and therefore won't spend the meeting typing).</span></p> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-04-30%20at%2011.16.07%20AM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-04-30%20at%2011.16.07%20AM.png\" alt=\"how to use slides to stick to your agenda\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></span></p> \n<p>Even with preparation, you're likely to encounter some awkward pauses, technical glitches, and uncomfortable moments. But, we encourage you to embrace these moments, learn from them, and move past them. We're all in this together after all!</p> \n<p>If you're just starting out with virtual meetings, we encourage you to be honest with your team that this is a skill you're working on. Practice different techniques to find what works best for you. Ask for feedback from your team on what's working in the context of your meetings and what isn't.</p> \n<p>Plus, when you find something that works for you, share it with others so that we can all learn together.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fremote-meetings-tips&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Jul 2020 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/virtual-meeting-tips.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"ed29eaa13d76ef551dc1ee22d2123d08","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn5@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118303666_cae9d0dbe0d581b2.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/virtual-meeting-tips.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Meaghan Williams","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-04-30%20at%2010.34.27%20AM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-04-30%20at%2010.34.27%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn49@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118307362_915ed3a91f5e4d26.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-04-30%20at%2011.16.07%20AM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-04-30%20at%2011.16.07%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn73@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118310311_43949c4291c2b9f8.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fremote-meetings-tips&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn5@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118312410_21748a85ba45ae02.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"Email Sign Up Forms: How to Increase Email Sign Ups With Better Forms","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-sign-up-form","description":"<p>In 2019, there were <a href=\"https://www.campaignmonitor.com/resources/knowledge-base/how-many-people-in-the-world-use-email/\" style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">3.8 billion</a> estimated email users across the globe.&nbsp;With half of the world’s population on email, and the ability to reach people at any time of day, email marketing remains a crucial technique to build a customer base.</p> \n<p>So how do you attract people to your email list? There are a few important steps, but it all starts with an email sign up <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/web-forms\">web form</a>.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What Is An Email Sign Up Form?</h2> \n <p>An email sign up form is used to collect email addresses from leads and potential customers. These forms are are embedded on a web page where a visitor can enter their email address in a form field to be added to your email newsletter.&nbsp;</p> \n</div> \n<p>The best thing about email opt-ins is that you can build a pipeline of leads to nurture and communicate with. Over time, your email list can turn into a valuable source of revenue as cold prospects get to know and trust you while you stay top of mind (or top of inbox).</p> \n<p>But what do you do if you're not getting enough subscribers into that pipeline? After all, email marketing is only as good as its list. Here are our tips for how to get more mailing list signups.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How to Get More Subscribers for Your Email List</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Monitor your metrics.</li> \n  <li>Place calls to action on high-traffic pages.</li> \n  <li>Be mindful that your conversion rate may not be the problem.</li> \n  <li>Use contrasting colors.</li> \n  <li>Consider placement.</li> \n  <li>Offer something of value.</li> \n  <li>Reduce the friction.</li> \n  <li>Try out different offers.</li> \n  <li>Consider user intent.</li> \n  <li>Reduce the number of forms and calls to action on a page.</li> \n  <li>Use a form builder with smart field capability.</li> \n  <li>Use pop-ups.</li> \n  <li>Test everything.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>1. Monitor your metrics.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-conversion-rate-optimization-faqs\">Conversion rate</a> refers to the percentage of website visitors who converted on your opt-in. In order to calculate conversion rate, you divide the number of conversions from that form or offer by the amount of traffic to the page or post it's on.</p> \n<p>If you have a form or offer that coverts 3% of the website visitors that see it, that form or offer is more valuable than one converting at a rate of .75%. With 1000 website visitors, the first form would generate around 22 more leads than the second (all other things being equal). That's why <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.de/marketing/conversion-rate-optimization\">conversion rate optimization</a> is so important.</p> \n<h3>2. Place calls to action on high-traffic pages.</h3> \n<p>Conversions to your email signup form only happen if the form is seen. For this reason, you should be putting the opportunity in front of your website visitors. Identify your highly visited pages and put your form or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-call-to-action-faqs-ht\">calls to action</a> (CTAs) on them to maximize visibility.</p> \n<h3>3. Be mindful that your conversion rate may not be the problem.</h3> \n<p>If you don't have a large amount of traffic, finding ways to increase traffic may be a more worthwhile activity. As previously mentioned, conversions only happen when there's an opportunity to convert. With no traffic, there's no opportunity. You won't have the means to increase conversion rate if the starting number is zero, and if traffic is low, your conversion rates may not be statistically significant.</p> \n<h3>4. Use contrasting colors.</h3> \n<p>The last thing you want is for a potential subscriber to miss the opportunity to convert simply because they didn't notice it was there. You want to draw attention to your conversion elements, making them attention-grabbing and bold. One way to do this is by using contrasting colors that stand out on the page.</p> \n<h3>5. Consider placement.</h3> \n<p>Prominent page placement is a game-changer when it comes to increasing conversion rates on email signup forms. A form or call-to-action can go in a number of places, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>The top of the page</li> \n <li>Within the text of the page</li> \n <li>In the sidebar</li> \n <li>At the bottom of the page</li> \n <li>As a popup generated from a user action</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You'll want to test which placements work for your conversion rates. For example, if people aren't making it to the bottom of a page or post, they may not see your call-to-action. Through testing, you'll be able to determine the placements that work best for your audience.</p> \n<h3>6. Offer something of value.</h3> \n<p>The majority of today's internet users know that giving up their email address may result in email solicitation or, in some cases, spam. That may not be your intention, but that doesn't erase their caution. To overcome their caution, you must incentivize them to give it up.</p> \n<p>Promising high-value content that they want, providing social proof that your newsletter is valuable, holding giveaways or contests, and being transparent about what they can expect signing up are all ways to provide the incentive.</p> \n<h3>7. Reduce the friction.</h3> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"Dollars flow where friction is low.\"&nbsp;</p> \n <p style=\"font-size: 18px;\">— Brian Halligan, INBOUND 2019</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>The more friction that a visitor encounters, the less likely they'll sign up. Ultimately, you want to keep the momentum going to completion.</p> \n<p>One way that you can reduce friction is by removing form fields and making the process of signing up faster. The amount of required form fields should be proportional to the amount of value you're providing. Too many will cause the user to bounce. Instead, ask for less up front and have your team gather what they need after the individual has become a lead.</p> \n<h3>8. Try out different offers.</h3> \n<p>Don't be afraid to scrap an offer if it seems to be under-performing. Maybe the word \"newsletter\" fails to appeal to your specific audience. Switch it out with something different and monitor your metrics to see what happens.</p> \n<h3>9. Consider user intent.</h3> \n<p>Your website visitors landed on a particular page for a reason. If your offer doesn't help them meet that need in some way, they may not be incentivized to convert.</p> \n<p>Here's an example to illustrate this point:</p> \n<p>Let's say you have a blog post that compares your product/service to a competitors. The visitor arrived here because they want to see how well you match up with others in the industry.</p> \n<p>But if your offer is something like \"Reasons Why You Should Buy [Product/Service],\" you may fall flat. If the user is already comparing providers, they already know they the value of the product or service; they're just figuring out which provider to go with.</p> \n<p>In this scenario, an offer suited to this intent, such as a free sample or product demo, may work much better.</p> \n<p>Consider the intent on your pages and craft offers that match up with that intent.</p> \n<h3>10. Reduce the number of forms and calls to action on a page.</h3> \n<p>As the old saying goes, \"A confused mind says no.\" If you present a website visitors with too many choices, you run the risk of driving them away completely. Consider presenting one offer or conversion element per page. If that's not possible, find other ways to reduce the confusion and make it clear exactly what you want the website visitor to do.</p> \n<h3>11. Use a form builder with <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/forms/use-progressive-fields-in-forms\">progressive field</a> capability.</h3> \n<p>Some <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/forms\">form builders</a> (like HubSpot's) have the ability to remove form fields if the CRM already knows the information. For users who may be converting a second time, HubSpot may already already know some of the information, and it will remove those unnecessary forms, removing the friction for the user to type that information again. After all, dollars flow where friction is low.</p> \n<h3>12. Use pop-ups.</h3> \n<p>Pop-ups may seem intrusive, especially if used incorrectly, but the fact of the matter is that they convert! By using a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/pop-up-form\">pop-ups tool</a>, offering something of value, and using specific triggers (such as exit intent), you can create a pop-up experience that isn't annoying and generates leads.</p> \n<h3>13. Test everything.</h3> \n<p>Testing has been mentioned already in a few of the tips above, but it stands to get its own section. Improvement doesn't happen in a vacuum, and leads don't increase because of intuition. By testing hypothesis and continuing to iterate improvements, you'll learn about your audience, be mindful about your metrics, and increase email signups as a result.</p> \n<p>A lead might provide their email address for any number of reasons — to receive details about sales, blog post notifications, a discount code or information about your business. Either way, that makes your email sign up form one of the most important things on your site. And while they're&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.formisimo.com/blog/top-15-online-form-building-tools-on-the-market/\">simple to create</a>&nbsp;with the help of a&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/forms?_ga=2.125593866.1682462320.1538429223-1384912595.1528309621\">form builder</a>, you’ll still need to put some time and thought into how you build, format and embed your form.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Let’s go over some ways to create a sign up form that will get more leads on your email list.</p> \n<h2>Email Sign Up Form Best Practices</h2> \n<p>Whether you’re looking to reach ten people or ten million, you’ll need to create a sign up form that gets people excited to sign up.. Here are some best practices that will help you create a high-converting email sign up form</p> \n<h3>1. Make the Value Exchange Clear</h3> \n<p>Your leads should be able to answer the question, “What’s in it for me?” when they complete your form. An email address is a valuable commodity and it should be worth their while to sign up. Add a short description to the top of your email sign up form that describes what your lead will get in return for signing up and make it good. For example, instead of saying, ”Sign up for our weekly newsletter” you should say, “sign up for our newsletter and receive exclusive deals and offers.” A strong incentive means your website visitors are <a href=\"https://smartblogger.com/email-list-incentives/\">more likely to convert</a>.</p> \n<h3>2. Use a Double Opt-In</h3> \n<p>You don’t necessarily need more sign-ups as you need <em>quality</em> sign-ups. You need people who actually want to receive your emails — more is not always better. Ensuring quality sign-ups means less fake leads wasting your time and less chances that you’ll end up in the SPAM folder or <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/email/what-is-an-email-blacklist?_ga=2.168198561.1682462320.1538429223-1384912595.1528309621\">blacklisted</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>To ensure quality sign-ups on your form, consider using a <a href=\"https://sendpulse.com/support/glossary/double-opt-in\">double opt-in</a>. This is the type of email subscription that confirms your lead wants to be added to your email list <em>twice</em>. The first time is when the lead enters and submits their information using your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/web-forms\">web form</a>, and the second time requires the lead to click an additional CTA (usually in their inbox) that confirms their submission. A double confirmation means a high-quality relationship with your leads.</p> \n<h3>3. Keep It Simple</h3> \n<p>A lead should be able to look at the form, enter their information, hit “submit” and carry on with their lives within a matter of seconds. Successful email sign up forms are straightforward and clear. If your form is too complex, you risk losing the interest of your website visitors.</p> \n<p>Don’t get greedy and ask for too much information right away — if you do, there is a large chance you will turn people off and drive them away from your website. Keep your email sign up form as a way for visitors to sign up for emails.</p> \n<h3>4. Consider Place and Time</h3> \n<p>The placement of your email sign up form on your website matters. You should think about how you want your website visitors to find your form. For example, do you want your form to pop-up on the page the second someone lands on your website? Do you want them to scroll down to the bottom of your homepage to find your form? Or do they need to land on a specific page on your site?</p> \n<p>Form placement isn’t one-size-fits-all. Think about where most visitors land on your site, how your buyer personas want to interact with your brand and the overall user experience.</p> \n<p>Consider questions like, “Will my target audience get frustrated with a pop-up the second they enter our site, or will they find it helpful?”</p> \n<h3>5. Send a Kickback Email After Submission</h3> \n<p>Once someone completes your form, thank and welcome them.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>A<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33725/why-thank-you-emails-are-the-untapped-gold-mine-of-email-marketing.aspx?_ga=2.168198561.1682462320.1538429223-1384912595.1528309621\"> kickback email</a> is an email that gives your new lead something in return for their information. In the case of an email sign up form kickback email, you’ll want to welcome your new lead and perhaps offer them links to useful content. Thank them for their interest and get them excited about their decision to give you their personal information. This is also where you can provide your new leads with their discount codes, details on future sales, why you value their interest in your business, and how you will support them in the future.</p> \n<h2>Great Email Newsletter Signup Form Examples</h2> \n<p>Now that we’ve reviewed email sign up form best practices, let’s dive into some examples to provide you with some inspiration while creating your own form.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/subscribe?_ga=2.168198561.1682462320.1538429223-1384912595.1528309621\">HubSpot’s Marketing Blog</a></h3> \n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms-2.png?width=1500&amp;name=Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms-2.png\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"hubspot's marketing blog with subscribe form in the sidebar\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em>Source</em>:&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/subscribe?_ga=2.172974627.1682462320.1538429223-1384912595.1528309621\">HubSpot</a></p> \n<p>HubSpot’s marketing blog has an email sign up <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/forms?_ga=2.172974627.1682462320.1538429223-1384912595.1528309621\" style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">form</a> with clear benefit statement. Any website visitor could look at this subscription landing page and understand what they will get from signing up in a matter of seconds.</p> \n<p>By using a separate landing page for this form, HubSpot is able to eliminate any confusion about what leads are signing up for.</p> \n<p>There is also a feature on the form that requires leads to determine whether or not they want to sign up for a daily or weekly subscription. This provides clarity for the lead signing up and ensures a quality subscription for HubSpot.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.theskimm.com/\">theSkimm</a>&nbsp;</h3> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms-3.png?width=1500&amp;name=Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms-3.png\" alt=\"theSkimm's page with subscription form at the top of the page\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em>Source</em>: <a href=\"https://www.theskimm.com/\">theSkimm</a></p> \n<p>When you head to theSkimm’s website, the first thing you see is their email sign up form. That’s because their entire business revolves around a subscription. theSkimm is a daily email about the top news stories around the globe, so it would only make sense for their homepage to contain their sign up form.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Above their email sign up, there is a short, straightforward description about how theSkimm works. They provide leads with social proof by mentioning the “millions” of other people who have subscribed to their emails. And lastly, they show a bit of personality and humor with a line beneath the form that says “Still on the fence?” and allows potential leads to read their latest newsletter as well as check out a few celebrity Tweets about how great theSkimm is.&nbsp;</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms-5.png?width=1500&amp;name=Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms-5.png\" alt=\"theSkimm's next step that says &quot;still on the fence? checkout the latest newsletter. oh, and you're in good company...&quot; along with a retweet from sarah jessica parker confirming that she reads theskimm\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em>Source</em>: <a href=\"https://www.theskimm.com/\">theSkimm</a></p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.anthropologie.com/?mrkgcl=694&amp;mrkgadid=586468124&amp;cm_mmc=Google-_-*US+-+Brand+-+Top+Traffic-_-Brand-_-anthropologie&amp;utm_medium=paid_search&amp;utm_source=Google&amp;utm_content=anthropologie&amp;utm_term=Brand&amp;utm_campaign=*US+-+Brand+-+Top+Traffic&amp;adpos=1t1&amp;creative=268434397179&amp;device=c&amp;matchtype=e&amp;network=g&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMInZvz5fWF3QIVT18NCh3q-QF0EAAYASAAEgK1yfD_BwE\">Anthropologie</a></h3> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms-4.png?width=1500&amp;name=Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms-4.png\" alt=\"anthropologie homepage with signup form at the bottom of the page above the footer\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em>Source</em>: <a href=\"https://www.anthropologie.com/?mrkgcl=694&amp;mrkgadid=586468124&amp;cm_mmc=Google-_-*US+-+Brand+-+Top+Traffic-_-Brand-_-anthropologie&amp;utm_medium=paid_search&amp;utm_source=Google&amp;utm_content=anthropologie&amp;utm_term=Brand&amp;utm_campaign=*US+-+Brand+-+Top+Traffic&amp;adpos=1t1&amp;creative=268434397179&amp;device=c&amp;matchtype=e&amp;network=g&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMInZvz5fWF3QIVT18NCh3q-QF0EAAYASAAEgK1yfD_BwE\">Anthropologie</a></p> \n<p>Anthropologie places their email sign up form towards the bottom of their homepage after users have had a chance to look around and become familiar with the site. Their signup form has a short description about what leads can expect once they sign up . Anthropologie also respects their visitors’ time by simply asking for an email address to sign up.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.lulus.com/\">Lulus</a></h3> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms.png?width=1500&amp;name=Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms.png\" alt=\"lulus sign up form at the bottom of the homepage above the footer\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em>Source</em>: <a href=\"https://www.lulus.com/\">Lulus</a></p> \n<p>Lulus form is located towards the bottom of their homepage. Their email sign up form gets website visitors excited about converting with an offer: a 10% discount code upon sign up. The form is simple and only requires an email address. After form submission, new leads receive a kickback email that welcomes them and also provides them with the code, as promised.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://www.questnutrition.com/\">Quest Nutrition</a>&nbsp;</h3> \n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=Email%20Sign%20Up%20Forms%20How%20to%20Increase%20Email%20Sign%20Ups%20With%20Better%20Forms-1.png\" alt=\"quest nutrition pop-up window that says 'sign up now!' along with a subscription form\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em>Source</em>:&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.questnutrition.com/\">Quest Nutrition</a></p> \n<p>Quest Nutrition’s form is in a pop-up window that dims the background, eliminating any distractions. The form offers incentives like recipes, discounts and surprises for visitors to sign up. Only an email address is required to sign up. Website visitors have the option to bypass the pop-up and look around the site instead.</p> \n<p>Email sign up forms are a simple, efficient and effective way to obtain leads, create more conversions, and increase your overall sales. You’ll reach your audience with email sign up forms that are straightforward and embedded on a convenient location on your website.</p> \n<p>So, take a few minutes to create your own email sign up form and get started broadening your customer base, developing relationships with your potential customers and increasing your number of leads today. From there, you can close the gap between lead and customer by doing email marketing.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in October 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\">&nbsp;</a>\n</div>  \n<img
