border-top: 8px solid #F4F4F4; border-right: 8px solid transparent; transform: translateY(16px);\">\n       &nbsp;\n      </div> \n      <div style=\"background-color: #f4f4f4; flex-grow: 0; height: 12px; width: 16px; transform: translateY(-4px);\">\n       &nbsp;\n      </div> \n      <div style=\"width: 0; height: 0; border-top: 8px solid #F4F4F4; border-left: 8px solid transparent; transform: translateY(-4px) translateX(8px);\">\n       &nbsp;\n      </div> \n     </div> \n    </div> </a> \n   <p style=\"margin: 8px 0 0 0; padding: 0 4px;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/CAYSe7WjNUl/?utm_source=ig_embed&amp;utm_campaign=loading\" style=\"color: #000; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: 17px; text-decoration: none; word-wrap: break-word;\">Viral Nation has put together an influencer marketing campaign for @goldfishcanada to help drive brand awareness. It’s all about using Goldfish Crackers as entertainment and fun while you’re stuck at home! 📷 @priscillaventurablog #GoldfishMoments</a></p> \n   <p style=\"color: #c9c8cd; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: 17px; margin-bottom: 0; margin-top: 8px; overflow: hidden; padding: 8px 0 7px; text-align: center; text-overflow: ellipsis; white-space: nowrap;\">A post shared by <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/viralnation/?utm_source=ig_embed&amp;utm_campaign=loading\" style=\"color: #c9c8cd; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: 17px;\"> Viral Nation</a> (@viralnation) on May 19, 2020 at 11:28am PDT</p> \n  </div> \n </blockquote> \n</div>  \n<p>The post shows how one of their clients worked with Goldfish for a sponsorship. Ideally, this post will demonstrate the types of clients Viral Nation works with, so similar influencers will consider reaching out. This type of content is helpful for prospective agencies and influencers that are looking for campaign help and representation.</p> \n<p>Additionally, fans from the influencer, Priscilla Ventura, and agencies that follow Goldfish, could come across this post and decide to inquire about services.</p> \n<h3>With other agencies</h3> \n<p>Maybe you run an agency that focuses solely on social media. Your team conceptualizes, creates, and implements campaigns solely for social media. It works, and it's great.</p> \n<p>But you know your agency would benefit from offering a little more to clients. For that, consider partnering with an agency that offers services that complement social media — perhaps this is a website branding company.</p> \n<p>A partnership deal could include a bundled services offer: Clients can receive both services from each agency for a special price. This is a great way to obtain new leads and generate new business. Complementary agencies wouldn't be direct competition, and there's an advantage of tapping into their clientele.</p> \n<p>Sometimes, creative agencies are the unsung heroes behind your favorite campaign. It's always fun to look at which agencies produced a viral campaign. But in order to obtain the resources to create an effective campaign, you need revenue.</p> \n<p>For extra inspiration, check out what your favorite agencies are doing. How are they managing pricing models, and how are they using their social channels? Do you come across ads for that agency?</p> \n<p>Creative agencies can use a lot of the resources around them to pull in extra money. If you're part of an agency that is struggling to make ends meet, consider some of the out-of-the-box ideas, above, to either restructure your pricing model or increase revenue through partnerships or additional services.</p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-creative-agencies-make-money&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 24 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/how%20creative%20agencies%20make%20money.png","linkMd5":"6400251335e5c2ce389bec9d76ff49eb","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn61@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118301648_a7dc117bf1ac020a.webp","author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/how%20creative%20agencies%20make%20money.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn61@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118301648_a7dc117bf1ac020a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-creative-agencies-make-money&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn53@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118311008_660321b479f04939.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Google Analytics in 2020","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-analytics","description":"<p>Are you confused — even intimidated — by Google Analytics? Good news: you’re not alone. GA is notoriously complicated.</p>  \n<p>In fact, when I first started to delve into GA’s waters, I wondered if I’d ever truly <i>get </i>it. There were so many concepts to learn and reports to run. How did people ever conquer this thing?!?!</p> \n<p>Lots and <em>lots</em> of reading plus some trial and error, it turns out.</p> \n<p>I’m not saying I’ve reached total mastery — there’s always something new to pick up — but I’m vastly more comfortable.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>And I want you to be, too. So, here’s the cheat sheet to everything I’ve learned over the years. This guide might be long, but it’ll take you from zero to hero in ~6,000 words. And if you still have questions, let me know! I’m <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ajavuu?s=20\">@ajavuu</a> on Twitter.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>What is Google Analytics?</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://analytics.google.com/analytics/web/\">Google Analytics</a>, or GA, is an analytics tool that gives you an extremely in-depth look at your website and/or app performance. It integrates with <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/products/\">Google's marketing and advertising platforms and products</a> (including Google Ads, Search Console, and Data Studio) making it a popular choice for anyone using multiple Google tools.</p> \n<p>What other types of people is GA popular among?</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/analytics\">Other marketing analytics options, such as HubSpot</a>, can give you all the data you need with much less work. Oh, and here's another aspect of GA you'll want to take into consideration:</p> \n<h3>Is Google Analytics free?</h3> \n<p>There's a <a href=\"https://marketingplatform.google.com/about/analytics/compare/\">free and a paid version of GA</a> (the latter is called Analytics 360). Small and medium-sized businesses will likely get all the features you need from the free version. <a href=\"https://marketingplatform.google.com/about/contact-us/\">Enterprise businesses need to upgrade</a> if you want:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Advanced funnel reporting and attribution modeling</li> \n <li>Roll-up reporting</li> \n <li>More views, dimensions, and metrics per property</li> \n <li>Unlimited and unsampled data</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Paying for 360 also gives you access to dedicated support, including your own account manager. This alone can make the subscription fee worth it.</p> \n<p>And about that subscription fee? It’s not cheap. Analytics 360 <i>begins </i>at $150,000 per year (invoiced monthly) and increases after your site receives more than one billion monthly hits.</p> \n<p>360’s cost will price out many businesses. However, if you have the budget for both the service and an agency or in-house analyst to manage your analytics operations, consider investing.</p> \n<p>Now, what steps will you need to follow when setting up GA? Good question.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Set Up Google Analytics</h2> \n<p>Before you start using Google Analytics, <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1102152?hl=en#:~:text=To%20use%20Analytics%2C%20you%20must,create%20your%20Google%20Account%20now.&amp;text=You%20can%20only%20access%20Analytics,valid%20Google%20Accounts%20email%20address.\">you'll have to set up a Google account</a>. This means you must have a registered Google Account email address and password.</p> \n<p>Once you've <a href=\"https://accounts.google.com/signup/v2/webcreateaccount?continue=https%3A%2F%2Faccounts.google.com%2FManageAccount%3Fnc%3D1&amp;flowName=GlifWebSignIn&amp;flowEntry=SignUp\">created a Google account</a>, that doesn't mean you automatically have access to GA — rather, you have to register for Analytics (which we'll review how to do in the <a href=\"#how-to-use-google-analytics\">next section</a>). But the important thing to note as you go to set up GA is that you can only access the tool by using a valid Google account.</p> \n<p>Additionally, to set up GA properly, you'll want to understand the various layers of the tool — specifically, the hierarchy.</p> \n<h4>Google Analytics Hierarchy</h4> \n<p>Here's a look at the GA hierarchy:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image12-6.png?width=1500&amp;name=image12-6.png\" alt=\"google analytics hierarchy\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Let's dive into each of the sections within the hierarchy.</p> \n<h5>1. Organization</h5> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/7645246?hl=en\">organization</a> is the highest level. It represents a company. For example, our organization is HubSpot, Inc. One organization can encompass multiple GA accounts.</p> \n<p>Organizations are recommended for larger businesses, but not mandatory.</p> \n<h5>2.Account(s)</h5> \n<p><a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1102152?hl=en\">Accounts</a> are not optional. Using Google Analytics requires at least one (sometimes several) accounts.</p> \n<p>An account doesn’t mean a <i>user</i> account. I can log into the HubSpot Google Analytics accounts using my Google email ID. HubSpot’s head of technical SEO can also log into the same account using his Google email ID. Our historical optimization specialist can <i>also </i>log into the same account using <i>his </i>Google email ID.</p> \n<p>Important details:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>You can assign one property to each account or multiple properties to one account. Every account can hold up to <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1102152?hl=en\">50 properties</a>.</li> \n <li>You can give user permissions for an entire Analytics account, a property in an account, or a view in a property.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You might be wondering, “What’s better: creating a new account for every property or adding every account to the same property?”</p> \n<p>It depends on your use case and goals.</p> \n<p>For example, suppose you have one website — the Stark Industries corporate site — and five subdirectories, including the Stark Industries blog, careers section, media resources, case studies, and investor relations information.</p> \n<p>You want to create separate properties for each subdirectory so the people on each team can look at how their portion of the site is performing, as well as the larger site.</p> \n<p>But maybe you have another site that discusses Tony Stark’s work with S.H.I.E.L.D. You want the S.H.I.E.L.D. team to see data for this subdirectory, but you don’t want them to see data for the rest of the website. You create a new account and property for the S.H.I.E.L.D. site.</p> \n<h5>Property</h5> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://support.google.com/adsense/answer/6090824?hl=en\">property</a> is a website or app. Each property can support up to 25 views.</p> \n<h5>View</h5> \n<p>At the minimum, you need two views per property:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>One with zero configuration — essentially the “raw” version of the view</li> \n <li>One with filters set up to exclude any traffic from within your company (i.e. a filter for your IP address) as well as bots and spam traffic</li> \n</ul> \n<p>A view only captures the information <strong>after </strong>your filters and configured settings have been applied. And once you delete a view, that data is gone forever. For those reasons, it’s critical to keep an unfiltered view of your data.</p> \n<p>Now that you have completed the basis for how how to set up GA, here are the steps involved in using the tool.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Here are the <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1008015?hl=en\">steps involved in using your GA account</a>.</p> \n<h3>1. Create a Google Analytics account.</h3> \n<p>First, you'll have to <a href=\"https://marketingplatform.google.com/about/analytics/\">create a Google Analytics account</a>. Or, sign in to your current account.</p> \n<h3>2. Add the name, URL, and industry of the website you want to track.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1042508\">Choose which account</a> you want to add the <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1042508\">property</a> to. You should create and name your Property at this point and enter the website's URL as well as industry and reporting time zone. Then you'll be able to Create and Finish this step of the process.</p> \n<h3>3. Add a view to your property.</h3> \n<p>Go to the account and property you want to <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1009714\">add a view</a> to — use the menu to Create a View, name your view, select the type of view (web or app), and answer a few other questions. Remember, you can add up to <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/6099198\">25 views to a property in GA</a>.</p> \n<h3>4. Add your tracking code directly after the &lt;head&gt; tag of your site.</h3> \n<p>When you <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1042508\">create a property</a>, you'll have access to a unique <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/7372977\">ID for tracking</a> and a global site tag (code you need to add to each site page you want to measure). This is how you'll be able to collect data in your property.</p> \n<p>Then, paste your global site tag right after the opening &lt;head&gt; tag on each site page you plan on measuring.</p> \n<p>You'll be asked to choose your type of site (static, dynamic, web hosting, Google Tag Manager) so that you can set up the data collection accurately.</p> \n<p>(For more, read our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-install-google-analytics-tracking-code-website-ht?_ga=2.264748431.1638437897.1554681579-1350116256.1554681579\">guide to installing the Google Analytics tracking code on your site</a>.)</p> \n<h3>5. Visit your GA portal and verify the code is working.</h3> \n<p>Lastly, <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1008080\">verify your code is working</a>. You can do this by looking at the <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1638635\">Real-Time reports</a> section while clicking around on your site in a different tab or on your phone. The report should show at least one visitor to the site (that’s you!)</p> \n<p>And that's pretty much it! After that review, you may be wondering the following:</p> \n<h4>Do you need to add the GA code to every page of your site?</h4> \n<p>That’s a lot of manual work — especially if your website has more than 50 pages. Plus, what happens when you create new pages? Do you need to add the tag every time?!</p> \n<p>Relax, because the short answer is: <em>no</em>.</p> \n<p>The longer answer: you only need to add the tag to every page template. So, if you have one page type on your site (meaning every individual page uses the same header module), you only need to add it to that module — and it’ll be applied to every page.</p> \n<p>If you have two page types, you’d need to paste the code into the two separate header modules. Three page types? Three header modules.</p> \n<p>And if you use a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms\">CMS like HubSpot</a>, this task is even easier. These tools come with a separate field where you paste your tracking code just once. <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/cos-general/how-do-i-put-my-google-analytics-code-onto-my-new-landing-pages?_ga=2.100588702.1638437897.1554681579-1350116256.1554681579\">HubSpot users can follow these simple instructions for adding GA</a>.</p> \n<p>Additionally, to use GA successfully, you need to understand <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1033861?hl=en\">dimensions versus metrics</a>.</p> \n<h4>Google Analytics Dimensions and Metrics</h4> \n<p>I’ve found the easiest way to think about it is:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Dimensions = categorical variables. Simple examples include names, colors, and places.</li> \n <li>Metrics = quantitative variables. Basic examples include age, temperature, and population.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Or as my Data Analytics professor put it, \"Metrics are what you can do math on.” Not the most eloquent phrasing, but it works.</p> \n<h5>Dimension Examples</h5> \n<ol> \n <li>Browser</li> \n <li>Location</li> \n <li>Landing page</li> \n <li>Device</li> \n <li>Customer type</li> \n</ol> \n<h5>Metric Examples</h5> \n<ol> \n <li>Sessions</li> \n <li>Pageviews</li> \n <li>Conversions</li> \n <li>Bounce rate</li> \n <li>Session duration</li> \n</ol> \n<p>In any GA report, your dimensions are your rows and your metrics are your columns.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image6-10.png?width=1500&amp;name=image6-10.png\" alt=\"google analytics metrics\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h4>Custom Dimensions and Metrics</h4> \n<p>GA lets you create <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/2709828?hl=en&amp;ref_topic=2709827\">custom dimensions and metrics </a>from Analytics data plus non-Analytics data. To give you an idea, suppose you track the membership type of customers who have created an account in your CRM. You could combine this information with page views to see page views by member type.</p> \n<p>Or maybe you run a blog. If you want to understand how audience engagement impacts other metrics (like conversions, pages per session, etc.), you could create three custom dimensions for each type of reader:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Advocate</strong>: user who shared one-plus posts on social media</li> \n <li><strong>Subscriber</strong>: user who signed up for your email list</li> \n <li><strong>Customer</strong>: user who purchased premium access</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Using these dimensions will give you invaluable information.</p> \n<h4>What’s a Google Analytics audience?</h4> \n<p>An <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/2611404?hl=en\">audience</a> is a group of users that have something in common. That commonality could be anything: maybe you’re targeting consumers in Australia, so you have an \"Australian audience,” or you want to sell to millennials, so you have a \"25-34 audience.”</p> \n<p>GA comes with several built-in audiences (including the two I just mentioned, location and age). You don’t need to do a thing to set these up — once you have the tracking code installed, GA will automatically break down your visitor data into these audience reports.</p> \n<p>However, you can also create custom audiences. Perhaps you’re only interested in \"Australian millennials\"; you’d need to make a custom audience that only includes visitors who are A) in Australia and B) between the ages of 25 and 34.</p> \n<p>Creating an audience is fairly easy. Honestly, the hardest part is figuring out what you’re trying to accomplish and then identifying the user characteristics that’ll help you do that.</p> \n<p>Once you’ve done that, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-create-custom-audience-segments-in-google-analytics-quick-tip?_ga=2.264748431.1638437897.1554681579-1350116256.1554681579\">follow these instructions to create a new audience segment</a>. From there you can <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/2611404?hl=en\">import a segment to use as the basis for your Audience Report</a>.</p> \n<p>That brings us to the next question:</p> \n<h4>What’s a Google Analytics segment?</h4> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/3123951?hl=en\">segment</a> is a subset of your data. I like to picture an entire pizza made up of all different slices — one slice has pesto and mozzarella, another has sausages and spicy peppers, another has ham and pineapple, and so on. Metaphorically speaking, each slice is a segment.</p> \n<p>You can create segments based on:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Users</strong> (e.g. users who have bought something on your site before, users who have signed up for a consultation, etc.)</li> \n <li><strong>Sessions</strong> (e.g. all sessions that were generated from a specific marketing campaign, all sessions where a pricing page was viewed)</li> \n <li><strong>Hits</strong> (e.g. all hits where the purchase exceeded $85, all hits where a specific product was added to the cart)</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Like audiences, GA provides you with several segments. I wouldn’t stop there: you can get incredibly granular with your segments.</p> \n<p>To give you some inspiration, here are a few of HubSpot’s segments:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Users who viewed a specific product page and watched the demo video</li> \n <li>Users who viewed the same product page and <i>didn’t </i>watch the demo video</li> \n <li>Users who view a specific Academy course page</li> \n <li>Users who view a specific Academy lesson page</li> \n <li>Users who view a blog post <i>and </i>a product page</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The sky is your limit — well, that, and <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/3123951?hl=en&amp;ref_topic=3123779\">GA’s segment cap</a>.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Alright, now let's look at GA Reports. Remember, you can apply up to four segments at a time to any report.</p> \n<h2>Google Analytics Reports</h2> \n<p>GA’s left-hand sidebar can be a bit overwhelming. You’ve got six reporting options (all with confusing, vague names), and clicking on any of those only gives you <i>more </i>options.</p> \n<p>Let’s walk through each report together.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image16-1.png?width=400&amp;name=image16-1.png\" alt=\"google analytics reports\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Google Analytics Real-Time Report</h3> \n<p>As the name suggests, the <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1638635?hl=en\">Real-Time report</a> gives you insight into what’s happening on your site at this very moment. You can see how many visitors are on your site, which pages they’re visiting, which social platforms they’re coming from, where they’re located, and more.</p> \n<p>While this report is fun to look at occasionally, it’s probably the least valuable. Here are some ways to use Real-Time:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>See how much traffic you’re getting from a new social or blog post</li> \n <li>Know immediately if a one-day sale or event is driving views and/or conversions</li> \n <li>Make sure tracking URLs and custom events that you’ve just set up are working as they should</li> \n</ul> \n<p>These are useful, but as you’ll see, the other reports pack a far greater punch.</p> \n<h3>Google Analytics Audience Report</h3> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/7162572?hl=en\">GA Audience report</a> gives you a high-level overview for the property you’re currently looking at. Check this report once a day to get a sense of how you’re trending overall.</p> \n<p>Underneath \"Overview,\" you’ll see \"Audiences,” as well as expandable menus for \"Demographics,” \"Interests,” \"Geo,” \"Behavior,” \"Technology,” \"Mobile,” \"Cross-Device,” \"Custom,” and \"Benchmarking.”</p> \n<h4><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image15.png?width=400&amp;name=image15.png\" alt=\"google analytics audience report\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></h4> \n<p>Explore each of these sections to get a sense of what they can tell you about your visitors.</p> \n<p>Every section describes an audience.</p> \n<h4>Active Users</h4> \n<p>Whoever named this report belongs in the same group as the person who named guinea pigs: \"active users” doesn’t refer to users currently on your site — that’s the Real-Time report — and <a href=\"https://www.rd.com/culture/misnomers/\">guinea pigs are neither pigs nor from Guinea</a>.</p> \n<p>The Active Users report shows you the number of users who visited in the last day (1-day active users), week (7-day active users), two weeks (14-day active users), and four weeks (28-day active users.)</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image14-2.png?width=1500&amp;name=image14-2.png\" alt=\"google analytics active users report\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>What’s the value of this report, you ask?</p> \n<p>If you have more one-day users than longer-term ones, you’re struggling with retention. People aren’t coming back to your site or app — you need to figure out why.</p> \n<p>I’d also recommend looking at this report with various segments; for instance, perhaps you see that users in a certain age bracket have much better retention than the average.</p> \n<h4>Lifetime Value</h4> \n<p>First things first: do you need a refresher on Customer Lifetime Value (CLV) and how to calculate it? <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/how-to-calculate-customer-lifetime-value?_ga=2.264748431.1638437897.1554681579-1350116256.1554681579\">We’ve got you.</a></p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/6182550?hl=en\">Lifetime Value report</a> gives you a sense of how valuable users are to your company. You can see lifetime value for, say, the users you generated from email marketing versus the ones you acquired from organic search. Armed with this information, you can decide which channel to invest more in.</p> \n<p>A few notes: Lifetime Value is capped at 90 days. The Acquisition date range, however — which you can adjust — reflects all the users you acquired in that time frame.</p> \n<p>Imagine you’re interested in looking at transactions per user for users you acquired in the week before Black Friday. You’d adjust the date range to that week specifically. Then you’d see the average transactions per user for that cohort over the following 90 days.</p> \n<p>Because HubSpot is a SaaS company, not an ecommerce business, I look at goal completions per user, page views per user, and sessions per user by Acquisition Channel.</p> \n<p>If my team has recently wrapped up a marketing campaign, I’ll look at the same metrics by Acquisition <i>Campaign</i>.</p> \n<p>But if you are in ecommerce and want to see transaction and revenue data, you’ll need to have <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1037249?hl=en&amp;ref_topic=1037061\">ecommerce tracking set up</a>.</p> \n<p>(By the way, here’s <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/reports/how-do-i-report-on-revenue-in-hubspot?_ga=2.34013089.1638437897.1554681579-1350116256.1554681579\">how to track revenue in HubSpot</a>.)</p> \n<h4>Cohort Analysis</h4> \n<p>Some people have gone so far as to call <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/6074676?hl=en\">Cohort Analysis</a> <a href=\"https://medium.com/the-data-dynasty/the-single-most-overlooked-report-in-google-analytics-yet-most-powerful-6ec90eba243a\">\"the single most powerful report in GA.”</a></p> \n<p>So, how does it work? This report groups users by one characteristic — so far, \"Acquisition Date” is the only “Cohort Type” you can use. By the way, Acquisition Date is the day a user first visited your website.</p> \n<p>You have several options from there.</p> \n<ol> \n <li>First, pick your <strong>cohort size</strong>: day, week, or month.</li> \n <li>Next, pick your <strong>metric</strong>, or what you want to explore for this cohort. It can be further broken down into Per user, Retention, and Total.</li> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Per user </strong>means the total count of that metric divided by the cohort size. So if you choose Transactions per user, for example, you’ll see the average number of transactions per user for that cohort.</li> \n  <li><strong>Retention</strong> is simple: user retention, or the number of users who returned that day, week or month (determined by the cohort size you selected) divided by the total number of users in that cohort.</li> \n  <li><strong>Total</strong>: the total number of sessions, transactions, etc. that occurred for that cohort size.</li> \n </ul> \n <li>Choose your <strong>date range</strong>. GA lets you see up to three months of data.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Now let’s dive into <i>reading </i>the report, because it’s not obvious.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image13.png?width=1500&amp;name=image13.png\" alt=\"google analytics cohort report\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>The left-hand column shows you the Cohort Type you picked — Acquisition date, by default — broken down by Cohort Size (day, week, or month).</p> \n<p>The first row shows you the totals for all the users in that cohort. Each row underneath that represents the activity in that day, week, or month (in this example, we’re looking at month.)</p> \n<p>The row outlined in light blue reflects the Cohort Size you’ve chosen. Remember that data only goes back three months at the max.</p> \n<p>The row outlined in yellow shows you the values for the metric you chose (in this case, Goal Completions per User). In the eternal words of Calvin Harris: baby, this what you came for.</p> \n<p>Look at the first row. This tells you the average goal completions for the entire cohort in the first month after they were acquired was 1.09. Average goal completions for the entire cohort in the second month after they acquired dropped to 0.09. By the last month, it’s 0.02.</p> \n<p>Now look at the next three rows. It looks like average goal completions per user in the first month after they were acquired increased slightly from December to January and again from January to February.</p> \n<p>This is pretty usual behavior. Let’s imagine that instead, this report tells us average goal completions per user for February 1-28, 2019 (the last row) was 4.07. Woah! That’s nearly four times as high as December and January.</p> \n<p>We’d definitely want to investigate further. And to do so, all we have to do is right-click on the cohort we’re interested in.</p> \n<p>Make sure you click on the column if you want the entire day, week, or month analyzed. Click on a cell if you want to analyze only the users who, for example, completed a goal three days after they were acquired on February 27, 2019.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image3-15.png?width=1500&amp;name=image3-15.png\" alt=\"google analytics cohort report\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>When you right-click, this box will pop up:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image10-8.png?width=1500&amp;name=image10-8.png\" alt=\"google analytics cohort segment\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Give this cohort a descriptive name. Change the views to \"Any View” if you want to use this segment across your entire property (which I usually recommend), then click \"Create.”</p> \n<p>Voila — now you can compare this cohort to any other segment in any report you choose.</p> \n<h3>Google Analytics Acquisition Reports</h3> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/3157419?hl=en\">Acquisition report</a> breaks down your traffic by source: organic, direct, referral, email, social, paid search, display, affiliate, and (Other). (<a href=\"https://www.wholewhale.com/tips/other-traffic-google-analytics/\">GA uses the (Other) category</a> when it doesn’t know how to categorize a subset of traffic.)</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image8-10.png?width=400&amp;name=image8-10.png\" alt=\"google analytics acquisition report\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>From All Traffic, you can click into Channels.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image17.png?width=1500&amp;name=image17.png\" alt=\"google analytics acquisition by channel\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Click on any category to explore each source in detail.</p> \n<p>Depending on the category, you’ll see <strong>landing pages</strong> (which URLs your visitors entered the site on), <strong>source</strong> (which website brought them to yours), or <strong>keyword</strong> (which query took them to your site.)</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image1-29.png?width=400&amp;name=image1-29.png\" alt=\"google analytics acquisition report\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>To see this information presented visually, click on All Traffic &gt; <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Treemaps</span>. This post walks you through <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/6180144?hl=en\">how to read and adjust the Treemaps report</a>.</p> \n<p>The next report, <strong>Source/Medium</strong>, breaks down the general category of traffic (which you saw in “Channels”) into the search engine or domain.</p> \n<p>It’s useful if you want to get more granular insight into the ways people are coming to your site. For example, you might notice that a whopping 70% of your referral traffic is coming from LinkedIn, while just 5% is coming from Pinterest. Depending on your marketing team’s priorities it may be time to shift focus.</p> \n<p>The last report, <strong>Referrals</strong>, reveals the specific URLs that sent people to your site, e.g. your referral traffic.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image24.png?width=1500&amp;name=image24.png\" alt=\"google analytics acquisition by landing page\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>I like to add \"Landing page” as a secondary dimension so you can see which pages on your site are receiving the referral traffic.</p> \n<h3>Google Analytics Behavior Reports</h3> \n<p>Out of all the reports in GA, I use the <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/7126596?hl=en\">Behavior</a> ones the most.</p> \n<h4>Site Content</h4> \n<p>This report gives you a review all of the blog posts, landing pages, web pages on your site.</p> \n<h5>All Pages</h5> \n<p>Let’s start with Site Content &gt; All Pages. This shows the top-trafficked pages for your current view and/or segment. It’s useful in and of itself — you should always keep a careful eye on your most viewed URLs — but I especially like it when I’m analyzing traffic growth or declines.</p> \n<p>To give you an idea, maybe total traffic to my website has dropped 10% month over month. I’d navigate to Site Content &gt; All Pages and change the date range to this month compared to the last month (making sure the days of the week match up).</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image5-15.png?width=1500&amp;name=image5-15.png\" alt=\"google analytics site content\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Then I can see the differences in page views by URL:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image20-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=image20-1.png\" alt=\"google analytics page views\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>This helps me identify which pages received less traffic and contributed to that decline.</p> \n<p><strong>Helpful tip: </strong>I like to change the \"Sort Type” from \"Default” to \"Absolute Change” so I see the results sorted by the greatest differences in percentage rather than total views.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image7-6.png?width=1500&amp;name=image7-6.png\" alt=\"google analytics\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>I also add Page Title as a secondary dimension so I can see the name of each page alongside its URL.</p> \n<h5>Content Drilldown</h5> \n<p>This report breaks down the structure of your site by subdomain and then subfolder. To give you an idea, for HubSpot we can see data for each of our subdomains, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>blog.hubspot.com</li> \n <li>developers.hubspot.com</li> \n <li>community.hubspot.com</li> \n</ul> \n<p>And so on. If I clicked into blog.hubspot.com, I could then see aggregated data for:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>blog.hubspot.com/sales</li> \n <li>blog.hubspot.com/marketing</li> \n <li>blog.hubspot.com/service</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You get the drift. This report is probably most valuable for those managing highly complex properties.</p> \n<h5>Landing Pages</h5> \n<p>Landing pages is another one of my favorite reports. GA defines a landing page as the first page in a session — in other words, the visitor’s first interaction with your website.</p> \n<p>There are a few ways to slice and dice this report.</p> \n<p>First, if you’re interested in the sources (organic, paid social, direct, etc.) driving users to the landing page, you can add Source/Medium as a secondary dimension.</p> \n<p>This is basically the opposite version of the report we added earlier.</p> \n<p>Second, if you only want to see which landing pages users visited from a specific source, on a specific platform, or within a specific category, you can add the appropriate system segment:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image9-5.png?width=1500&amp;name=image9-5.png\" alt=\"google analytics landing pages\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Maybe you’re most interested in the landing pages that mobile and tablet users see — so you choose the Mobile and Tablet Traffic.</p> \n<p>Or perhaps you’re curious about users who ended up buying something, so you choose the \"Made a Purchase” segment. There are lots of possibilities here.</p> \n<h5>Exit Pages</h5> \n<p>This report shows the last pages users visited in their sessions before they left your site.</p> \n<p>That’s a little confusing, so let’s use an example.</p> \n<p>I want to find a place to grab dinner with my friends so I search, \"Mediterranean restaurants near me.” A place that looks good pops up, so I click on it. First, I check out the menu. They have a hummus sampler — yum. Then I click on their press page. It links to a recent article on Eater, so I leave the site to read it. The reviewer loved the food. I’m sold.</p> \n<p>The Press page would be my exit page.</p> \n<p>You may hear that you should analyze your exit pages to understand why users are leaving your site — I think this example reveals why that strategy doesn’t always make sense. Just because someone has left doesn’t mean anything is wrong with the content.</p> \n<p>Check this report out but take the data with a grain of salt.</p> \n<h4>Site Speed</h4> \n<p>This report is pretty self-explanatory: it tells you how quickly your site is loading for users. Obviously, the faster the better — not only do <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/page-load-time-conversion-rates?_ga=2.34013089.1638437897.1554681579-1350116256.1554681579\">faster pages correlate with higher revenue</a>, but <a href=\"https://webmasters.googleblog.com/2018/01/using-page-speed-in-mobile-search.html\">Google’s algorithm takes page load time into account</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image21.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=image21.jpg\" alt=\"google analytics site speed\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h5>Site Speed Page Timings</h5> \n<p>This report delves into the average page load times for each URL. I use it to identify the slowest-loading pages on HubSpot’s site with the ultimate goal of figuring out why they’re taking their sweet, sweet time and how to speed them up.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image20-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=image20-1.png\" alt=\"google analytics site speed\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>The default metrics are page views and average page load time, but I also recommend looking at:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Avg. page load time and bounce rate</li> \n <ul> \n  <li>Change the Sort Type to “Weighted” so you see the blog posts with the highest page views first</li> \n </ul> \n <li>Avg. page load time and page value</li> \n <ul> \n  <li>The latter gives you a sense of <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/2695658?hl=en\">how much a specific page contributes to your total revenue</a></li> \n  <li>Looking at these two together helps you find slow-loading pages that are valuable to your bottom line (even if they don’t get a ton of traffic), making them a high priority to fix</li> \n </ul> \n</ul> \n<h4>Site Search</h4> \n<p>First things first: if users can search your website, make sure you’ve set up Site Search in GA. You must enable it for every view separately (here are <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1012264?hl=en\">the step-by-step instructions</a>).</p> \n<h5>Usage</h5> \n<p>I typically start with the \"Usage” report, which tells me how many sessions occurred with and without one-plus searches. In other words, I learn how frequently people used site search for the view and time period I specified.</p> \n<h5>Search Terms</h5> \n<p>Here’s where you learn what people are searching for. Look for themes: if you see the same search terms coming up multiple times, there are a few conclusions you could draw.</p> \n<p>Either you need to create new content that gives users the information they’re looking for, and/or you need to better surface existing content so it’s easier to find.</p> \n<p>Pay attention to the \"% Search Exits” column, as this tells you how many users clicked away from the search results page rather than choosing a result. You can usually infer there wasn’t a good answer for their question (or it wasn’t appropriately titled.)</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image22.png?width=1500&amp;name=image22.png\" alt=\"google analytics search terms\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h5>Search Pages</h5> \n<p>This report displays which pages users are starting searches from. It’s important to think about this contextually. Maybe people are commonly beginning searches from your 404 page — that makes sense and isn’t anything to be alarmed about.</p> \n<p>If, on the other hand, they’re starting searches from a product landing page, something’s wrong. The content clearly isn’t living up to the expectations they had when they clicked the ad link.</p> \n<p>Loves Data provides a <a href=\"https://www.lovesdata.com/blog/site-search-reports\">solid overview of GA’s Site Search reports</a> if you want to explore them even further.</p> \n<h4>Events</h4> \n<p>A user clicks a button. Then they download a file. Next they watch a video.</p> \n<p>No, this isn’t the world’s most boring bedtime story — it’s an example of a GA event. Three events, to be specific.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1033068?hl=en\">GA defines events as,</a> \"user interactions with content that can be measured independently from a web page or a screen load.”</p> \n<p>Those user interactions are up to you; you’ll need to add special code to your site or app that tracks the specific actions you’re interested in. Here are <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1136960\">the instructions</a>.</p> \n<p>If you’re not excited about events tracking already, I want you to get excited. There are infinite possibilities here: if you have an event set up for watching a product demo, and another for clicking a link to an external review of your tool, you can measure how many times each event happened.</p> \n<p>Maybe you discover your video isn’t getting many plays. It’s probably time to optimize the current video, make it easier to find on your site, or create a new one. Or perhaps you see that way more users than you expected are checking out the third-party review of your product.</p> \n<p>That tells you users want more social proof and testimonials. Since the review is favorable, you might want to put it front and center on your site.</p> \n<h5>Top Events</h5> \n<p>This report tracks the events taking place most frequently — pretty straightforward. You’ll see total events (e.g. how many times that event happened) and unique events (how many sessions included one or more occurrences of that event).</p> \n<p>If you’ve set values for your events, this report also shows you how the total value of each event and its average value (or the total value divided by the frequency.)</p> \n<h5>Pages</h5> \n<p>In this report, you can see which pages generate the most actions. I typically add \"Event Category” as the secondary dimension, then filter for the event I’m most interested in.</p> \n<p>To give you an idea, my team tracks \"Blog CTA.” This event fires whenever a user clicks a CTA embedded in a blog post. To get to the report below, I added \"Event Category” as the second dimension, then filtered for \"Page begins with blog.hubspot.com” (so I’d only see URLs on the blog) and \"Event Category equals Blog CTA.”</p> \n<p>Now I can see which posts generate the most CTA clicks. Hopefully you’re starting to see the power of event tracking!</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image18.png?width=1500&amp;name=image18.png\" alt=\"google analytics page\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h5>Events Flow</h5> \n<p>The Events Flow report tracks the order in which events take place on your site. It can tell you:</p> \n<p>A) Whether particular events tend to happen first — and if they trigger other events</p> \n<p>To give you an idea, maybe users frequently watch your demo video, then click the CTA to schedule a call with a salesperson.</p> \n<p>B) Whether certain event categories are more common than others</p> \n<p>Imagine you see that videos are played far more often than PDFs are downloaded.</p> \n<p>C) Whether users act differently based on segment</p> \n<p>For example, perhaps people coming in via organic scroll to the bottom of your pricing page far more than people coming in via social media.</p> \n<p>Note: This report is very subject to sampling. (Read more about <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/2637192?hl=en&amp;utm_id=ad&amp;visit_id=636892309605632354-846865128&amp;rd=1\">GA’s data sampling practices here</a>.) Sampled data is usually pretty accurate, but it means the more important the conclusion you’re drawing, the less uncertainty you’ll be able to tolerate.</p> \n<p>To reduce the level of sampling, make the date range smaller.</p> \n<h4>Publisher</h4> \n<p>If you monetize your website with Google AdSense or Ad Exchange, you can use the Ad Manager and Google Analytics integration to bring information on how your ad units are performing into GA.</p> \n<p>I won’t go into any more detail here, but I recommend reading the following resources if you want to know more:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/6183286?hl=en&amp;ref_topic=6183302\">About the Google Ad Manager integration</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/6183304?hl=en&amp;ref_topic=6183302\">Set up the Google Ad Manager integration</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Google Analytics Conversion Reports</h3> \n<p>If you have a website, you have an objective — probably several — for the people who visit your site.</p> \n<p>Ecommerce store owners want their visitors to subscribe to their mailing list, make a user account, add something to their cart, and/or complete the order confirmation process.</p> \n<p>Media companies want their visitors to stay on their site for as long as possible and/or view a certain number of pages (all the better to maximize their ad revenue.)</p> \n<p>B2B businesses want their visitors to download an ebook, sign up for a webinar, or book a call with a sales rep.</p> \n<p>Google Analytics makes it possible to measure all of these things — plus many more.</p> \n<p>A goal is essentially a conversion that you’ve defined (which is why this info shows up under the Conversion section.)</p> \n<p>There are four main types of goals:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Destination: </strong>This goal is completed when a user reaches a specific page, like a product page, order confirmation page, or thank you page</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Event: </strong>This goal is completed when a predefined event fires (like the Events you can set up as, well, Events — think watching a video or sharing something to social media)</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Duration: </strong>This goal is completed when a user’s session lasts longer than a pre-set time</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Pages/screens per session: </strong>This goal is completed when a user views a specific number of pages (or screens for an app) per session</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The first two are insanely useful. The last two are pretty useless. (If you have an interesting use case for Duration or Pages/screens per session, let me know on Twitter @ajavuu. I’d love to be proven wrong.)</p> \n<p>Once you’ve identified your goals, take a look at these instructions for <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1032415?hl=en&amp;ref_topic=6150889\">creating, editing, and sharing</a> them. This guide on <a href=\"https://www.jeffalytics.com/google-analytics-goal-value/\">choosing goal values</a> is also quite helpful.</p> \n<h4>Overview</h4> \n<p>Head here to learn how you’re doing goal-wise across the board. I get the most from this report when I compare date ranges and/or look at goal completions by segment.</p> \n<p>For example, quickly looking at goal completions by device reveals mobile visitors sign up for the blog newsletter much less frequently than desktop and tablet visitors. That could be because it’s hard to sign up for the newsletter on a phone — or it could be mobile users are looking for one thing and ending their session as soon as they’ve found it. I should dig in more to decide which case it is.</p> \n<h4>Goal URLs</h4> \n<p>Knowing a goal was completed isn’t helpful in and of itself; you also need to know <i>where </i>it happened. Suppose you’ve embedded the same form in three separate pages on your site.</p> \n<p>It’s great that Daenerys Stark from Dragonstone, Blackwater Bay just filled out your form to get in touch with a consultant, but which page did she fill it out on?</p> \n<p>The Goal URLs report shows you. It breaks down conversions by \"Goal Completion URL” (read: where it went down.)</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image2-40.png?width=1500&amp;name=image2-40.png\" alt=\"google analytics goals\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h4>Reverse Goal Path</h4> \n<p>Reverse Goal Path is the unsung hero of the Conversion section. Well, I’m singing its praises now. This report allows you to see the last three pages a user visited before completing the goal.</p> \n<p>It’s useful for goals that aren’t sequential. Maybe you have a contact form that appears in multiple places on your site, or there are two different paths that lead users into buying your ebook. Thanks to this report, you can understand the various ways people arrive at the end destination — and there’s no need to set up a funnel.</p> \n<p>I usually filter down to a specific goal completion location or goal previous step 1, 2, or 3.</p> \n<p>For example, since I’m interested in seeing which blog posts generated leads from content downloads, I added \"Goal Previous Step - 1 containing blog.hubspot.com” to the filter.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image11-8.png?width=1500&amp;name=image11-8.png\" alt=\"google analytics reverse goal path\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Here’s what I got:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image4-12.png?width=1500&amp;name=image4-12.png\" alt=\"google analytics reverse goal path\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>\"(Entrance)” means the user came to the site on that step; \"(not set)” means the user didn’t complete any steps prior to that one — because they weren’t on the website yet.</p> \n<p>For a comprehensive exploration of Reverse Goal Path, take a look at <a href=\"https://online-metrics.com/reverse-goal-path-report/\">OnlineMetrics’s guide</a>.</p> \n<h4>Funnel Visualization</h4> \n<p>For sequential goals, Funnel Visualization is your go-to report.</p> \n<p>Going back to the ecommerce example, the last goal would be \"Arrived at the order confirmation page.” The goal before that, or goal #3, would be \"Clicked checkout.” The goal before that, goal #2, would be \"Added something to cart.” And the goal before <i>that</i>, goal #1, would be \"Looked at product listing page.”</p> \n<p>At each stage, you can see user drop-off. That lets you identify areas where you can improve conversion rates; for example, maybe you lose a lot of users during the checkout process. You change the flow so they can check out as a guest (versus needing to create an account), which dramatically reduces checkout abandonment.</p> \n<p>To see this level of detail, you’ll need to map out your goals as a series. If all of your goals are simply the end objective, like \"Arrived at the order confirmation page,” you won’t be able to reverse-engineer how users progress.</p> \n<p>The Funnel Visualization report also requires you to mark the first step in the goal path as required or not. If you tell GA that yes, the first goal <i>needs </i>to be completed, Funnel Visualization will only show you the sessions where the user first finished goal #1. If a user skips goal #1 and goes straight to goal #2, their session won’t be represented here.</p> \n<h4>Goal Flow</h4> \n<p>If Funnel Visualization is the uptight relative who always made you take your elbows off the table and wash your hands before you ate, Goal Flow is the laid-back, fun relative who’d randomly take you out of school to go to the zoo.</p> \n<p>All that to say: Goal Flow gives you a lot more freedom than Funnel Visualization. Unlike the latter, Goal Flow shows you all sessions that led to the completed end goal — regardless of whether the user completed the required goal #1 or not.</p> \n<p>Another difference from Funnel Visualization: Goal Flow also shows you loopbacks — i.e. when a user goes back to a previous page or refreshes their current one.</p> \n<p>If the user skips a step, Funnel Visualization \"backfils” it. Goal Flow doesn’t.</p> \n<p>If you edit an existing funnel or create a new one, Funnel Visualization will show you all your data from that moment onward. Goal Flow, on the other hand, can show you data from the past.</p> \n<p>You can also toggle the Dimension and Level of detail of the report, as well as the segment, to get even more granular.</p> \n<p>I recommend looking at various segments to see which convert at the highest and lowest rates — plus where they commonly drop out.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image19.png?width=1500&amp;name=image19.png\" alt=\"google analytics goal flow\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Note: This report is subject to sampling. (Read more about <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/2637192?hl=en&amp;utm_id=ad&amp;visit_id=636892309605632354-846865128&amp;rd=1\">GA’s data sampling practices here</a>.) Sampled data is usually pretty accurate, but it means the more important the conclusion you’re drawing, the less uncertainty you’ll be able to tolerate.</p> \n<p>To reduce the level of sampling, make the date range smaller.</p> \n<h4>Smart Goals</h4> \n<p>This report is helpful if you’re A) using Google Ads and B) <i>not </i>measuring conversions. Basically, Google uses machine learning to identify your \"best” sessions — or those likeliest to generate conversions — and then translates those themes into Smart Goals.</p> \n<p>Once you have Smart Goals, you can use them in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-adwords-ppc\">Google Ads</a> to optimize your ads performance.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.bounteous.com/insights/2017/05/23/google-analytics-adwords-smart-goals/\">Smart Goals are controversial</a> within the marketing community because the data is minimal and businesses will be far better served by setting up their own conversion tracking. Keep that in mind if you decide to use them.</p> \n<h2>Now You’re Ready to Track</h2> \n<p>Google Analytics is a highly valuable tool for any business as it gives you tangible data that you can apply to grow your business. Bookmark this guide and come back to it as your data tracking becomes more sophisticated.</p> \n<p>Good luck on your Google Analytics journey.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August, 2017 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 24 Jul 2020 16:30:00 Frost)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image12-6.png?width=1500&name=image12-6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn61@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118309649_d64b341f6622e43e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image6-10.png?width=1500&name=image6-10.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn53@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118304792_05238bcca2a7d1ba.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image16-1.png?width=400&name=image16-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn13@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118311814_a9efcd0b322e79ef.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image15.png?width=400&name=image15.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn65@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118308936_175cd83eba335f3e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image14-2.png?width=1500&name=image14-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn45@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118312168_28fd7f49305d1e09.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image13.png?width=1500&name=image13.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn29@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118307458_cc9659bd775aec79.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image3-15.png?width=1500&name=image3-15.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn37@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118313069_bf7d5420ccb52f33.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image10-8.png?width=1500&name=image10-8.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn25@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118304834_30ae46fb0f00afbc.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image8-10.png?width=400&name=image8-10.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn57@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118306876_4b5ec37e1a3787c7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image17.png?width=1500&name=image17.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn37@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118305857_e8143ef352ccc25f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image1-29.png?width=400&name=image1-29.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn93@2020_5/2020-07- 5/2020-07-30/1596118305566_42e1efd80f3f5f81.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image19.png?width=1500&name=image19.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn97@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118309026_45f56d4f4068d4d6.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgoogle-analytics&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn73@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118304958_39a281c62b46a9c9.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"How to Optimize Your URLs for Search [Quick Tip]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-optimize-urls-for-search","description":"<p>Organic search is the most consistent, long-term way to drive traffic to your website — if you can perform well on the SERPs (Search Engine Results Pages). While many SEO factors are out of your control, such as who you're competing with and what they're doing, you can still benefit from <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33655/a-step-by-step-guide-to-flawless-on-page-seo-free-template.aspx\">on-page optimization</a>, which is very much in your control.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>One on-page best practice is optimizing your URL slug for each page and post you create. It's one of those <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-algorithm-visual-history-infographic\">SEO best practices that's actually stood the test of time</a>, left relatively unscathed by violent little penguins and fuzzy-yet-aggressive pandas.</p>  \n<p></p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What Is a URL Slug?</h2> \n <p>A slug refers to the part of the URL that identifies the address of the individual page. The slug is located at the end of the URL after the domain and any subdirectories.</p> \n</div> \n<p>Let's use a physical address as an analogy. If your website was a complex filled with offices, your domain is the address where the \"complex\" can be found. The slug, then, would be a box number or suite number that corresponds to a specific place in that complex.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Just as that box or suite number directs people to the correct office in the complex, a URL slug directs your browser to the correct page on your site, differentiating it from all the others on your domain.</p> \n<h3>URL Slug Example</h3> \n<p>Let's take our URL for this post:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-optimize-urls-for-search</em></p> \n<p>Here are the elements of this URL:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Protocol:</strong> https</li> \n <li><strong>Subdomain:</strong> blog.</li> \n <li><strong>Domain:</strong> hubspot.com</li> \n <li><strong>Subdirectory:</strong> marketing</li> \n <li><strong>URL Slug:</strong> how-to-optimize-urls-for-search</li> \n</ul> \n<p>At minimum, a URL is composed of the protocol and the domain. Other elements are added depending on the page and where it is within your site's structure.</p> \n<p>In this example, it's really clear from the subdomain and subdirectory where you are — you're on HubSpot's blog in the Marketing section. From there, you can tell what you're going to read about on the Marketing section of HubSpot's blog — how to optimize URLs for search. Search engines get it. Readers get it. It doesn't look like spam. All good.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>URL Slug Best Practices</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Keep it as simple as possible.</li> \n  <li>Take out the extra words in the page part of the URL slug.</li> \n  <li>Include relevant keywords.</li> \n  <li>Don't keyword stuff.</li> \n  <li>Make it reader-friendly.</li> \n  <li>Separate words with hyphens.</li> \n  <li>Don't use slugs that already belong to other pages.</li> \n  <li>Avoid using dynamically generated URLs.</li> \n  <li>Standardize your URL naming conventions.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>1. Keep it as simple as possible.</h3> \n<p>In SEO, where much is left to experimentation and theory, it doesn't get much better than the search engine telling you exactly what it prefers.&nbsp;According to <a href=\"https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/76329?hl=en\">Google</a>, \"A site's URL structure should be as simple as possible.\"</p> \n<p>A shorter URL also has the added benefit of being easier to remember should your website visitor want to return to the content without bookmarking it.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>2. Take out the extra words in the page part of the URL slug.</h3> \n<p>In the spirit of keeping things simple, words that add little or no meaning to the URL — like \"and\" or \"that\" — can be removed for the sake of brevity and/or readability. Here's a before &amp; after of this post's URL, for instance:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 650px;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-689109071-png/Blog_Thinkstock_Images/url-slugs.png?width=650&amp;name=url-slugs.png\" alt=\"url slug that reads &quot;how-to-optimize-your-urls-for-search-quick-tip&quot; vs. a better example that reads &quot;how-to-optimize-urls-for-search&quot;\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<p>I removed \"your\" for brevity and the fact that it didn't add any value for readers or search engines. I removed \"quick tip\" for the same reasons since most website visitors will know it's a quick tip from the title or description.</p> \n<p>I could go either way in keeping \"for\" in, but I decided to keep it in because it helps make the URL more readable for humans. If anyone stumbles on this URL elsewhere, I'd like it to be readable so they understand the contents of the page and feel they can trust the site.</p> \n<p>In theory, I could've also chosen \"url-slug\" as the slug. This would've been more desirable in terms of simplicity, but ultimately, I wanted to URL to convey value to readers by explaining what they're getting from the post.</p> \n<h3>3. Include relevant keywords.</h3> \n<p>One way search engines and humans learn about your page contents is through the keywords in the URL. Include keywords in your URL slug, but be sure they align with the actual page contents. Luckily, this URL is already pretty well-optimized as it is, because it's a long-tail search term on its own.</p> \n<h3>4. Don't keyword stuff.</h3> \n<p>Even though this article may be useful for a number of different keywords, that doesn't mean I should have them all in the URL. Otherwise, you're left with a mess like this:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-url-slug-optimize-urls-best-practices</em></p> \n<p>Wow, that looks ugly.</p> \n<p>Keyword stuffing in content, titles, and URLs is an outdated tactic and only hurts your SEO and the experience on your site. Instead of cramming keywords into the slug, choose a single keyword for the URL and let the content on the page drive the rest of the conversation.</p> \n<h3>5. Make it reader-friendly.</h3> \n<p>We talked about this a little already, but it's worth reiterating. Both search engines and readers should be able to look at your URL and understand what they might find should they click to the other side. That means when you add a bunch of keywords and delete those little extraneous words, you should end up with a URL that still makes sense.</p> \n<h3>6. Separate words with hyphens.</h3> \n<p>Don't use underscores to separate words or try to squish a bunch of words together. The hyphens are meant to help with readability. Use them.</p> \n<h3>7. Don't use slugs that already belong to other pages.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Your office/home only has one address, and only one office/home exists at that address. This goes for your website.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Using similar or duplicate slugs can result errors or Google seeing pages as <a href=\"https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/139066?hl=en\">duplicate content</a>. Either scenario will hurt your SEO performance.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>You can also consider updating the settings in your CMS to prevent this from happening accidentally.</p> \n<h3>8. Avoid using dynamically generated URLs.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>A dynamic URL contains parameters that are automatically generated when the page is loaded. This is in contrast to a static URL that is consistent every time it's accessed.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Dynamic URLs can cause crawling issues, which will result in poor performance.</p> \n<h3>9. Standardize your URL naming conventions.</h3> \n<p>Create a standard process for naming URLs, a system that can be applied to any of the pages and posts you create. This will help you develop a more consistent experience across your site and make navigation simpler and easier for your website visitors.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Your URLs are an important element of on-page SEO, and just one element to consider as you build your site's foundation. By implementing the above best practices for URL slugs and optimizing pages according to additional SEO guidelines, you're one step further to increasing your visibility on search engines such as Google.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in April 2014 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-optimize-urls-for-search&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 23 Jul 2020 17:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/optimize-url-slugs.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"b52466068ebde5c5945cc63f90cb88af","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn41@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118303894_8568b136558930b2.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/optimize-url-slugs.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Amanda Sellers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-689109071-png/Blog_Thinkstock_Images/url-slugs.png?width=650&name=url-slugs.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn73@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118306506_8a9622a710025896.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-optimize-urls-for-search&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn49@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118305922_b6292fcd69ad6ffb.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"38 Free Online Marketing Classes to Take This Year","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/free-online-marketing-classes","description":"<p>I don't know about you, but I miss taking classes. I miss taking notes, studying, and most of all, learning a ton of new skills.</p> \n<p>That's not to say I don't learn a lot on the job here at HubSpot -- because I absolutely do. But sometimes, there's nothing quite like listening to a lecture, taking notes, and doing homework.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Given the frequency at which new technologies and software are developed, it can be overwhelming to try to keep up your knowledge by only reading blog posts and ebooks. That's where self-paced online learning comes in.</p> \n<p>I've taken a few awesome courses and certifications through <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/\">HubSpot Academy</a>, including an <a href=\"https://certification.hubspot.com/inbound-certification?_ga=1.201491799.798140974.1486135114\">inbound marketing certification</a> and a <a href=\"https://certification.hubspot.com/content-marketing-certification-course?_ga=1.201491799.798140974.1486135114\">content marketing certification</a>. These offerings vary in time commitment, but many are self-paced so you can work on your own schedule. HubSpot Academy</li> \n  <li>Email Marketing - QuickSprout</li> \n  <li>Make a Website - Codeacademy</li> \n  <li>Learn Javascript - Codeacademy</li> \n  <li>Learn Ruby - Codeacademy</li> \n  <li>Learn Python - Codeacademy</li> \n  <li>Learn HTML &amp; CSS - Codeacademy</li> \n  <li>Learn to Code Awesome Websites - General Assembly</li> \n  <li>What Digital Advertising Is &amp; How to Do It - HubSpot Academy</li> \n  <li>How to Build a Paid Media Strategy - HubSpot Academy</li> \n  <li>Paid Advertising - QuickSprout</li> \n  <li>Wordstream PPC University</li> \n  <li>Advertising Your Business Online - Alison</li> \n  <li>Copywriting 101: Crafting Your First Ad Campaign - Skillshare</li> \n  <li>Advertising Foundations - Lynda</li> \n  <li>Basic Graphic Design Course - Canva</li> \n  <li>Photoshop 2020: One-on-One Fundamentals - LinkedIn Learning</li> \n  <li>InDesign 2020: Essential Training - LinkedIn Learning</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<a></a> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Content Marketing Courses</h3> \n<h4>1. <a href=\"https://certification.hubspot.com/inbound-certification?_ga=1.37518950.798140974.1486135114\">HubSpot Inbound Marketing Certification - HubSpot Academy</a></h4> \n<h4>2. <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/content-marketing-training\">HubSpot Content Marketing Certification - HubSpot Academy</a></h4> \n<h4>3. <a href=\"http://www.copyblogger.com/online-marketing-course/\">Internet Marketing for Smart People - Copyblogger</a></h4> \n<h4>4. <a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/learn/wharton-contagious-viral-marketing\">Viral Marketing and How to Craft Contagious Content - Coursera</a></h4> \n<h4>5. <a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/learn/content-marketing\">The Strategy of Content Marketing - Coursera</a></h4> \n<h4>6. <a href=\"https://www.udemy.com/copywriting-blunders-do-you-make-these-10-common-mistakes/\">Copywriting Blunders - Udemy</a></h4> \n<h4>7. <a href=\"https://www.udemy.com/b2b-content-marketing-training/\">Content Marketing for B2B Enterprises - Udemy</a></h4> \n<h4>8. <a href=\"https://www.quicksprout.com/university/category/content-marketing-videos/\">Content Marketing - Udemy</a></h4> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Social Media Marketing Courses</h3> \n<h4>9. <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/social-media\">Free Social Media Certification - HubSpot Academy</a></h4> \n<h4>10. <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/instagram-marketing\">Developing an End-to-End Instagram Marketing Strategy For Your Business - HubSpot Academy</a></h4> \n<h4>11. <a href=\"https://www.edx.org/course/social-media-marketing-bux-qd504x\">Strategic Social Media Marketing - edX</a></h4> \n<h4>12. <a href=\"https://alison.com/courses/Diploma-in-Internet-Marketing\">Diploma in Social Media Marketing - Alison</a></h4> \n<h4>13. <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/blueprint\">Facebook Blueprint - Buffer</a></h4> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">SEO Marketing Courses</h3> \n<h4>16. <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/seo-training\">SEO Training Course - HubSpot Academy</a></h4> \n<h4><strong>17. </strong><a href=\"https://www.google.com/onlinechallenge/dmc/\">Google Digital Marketing Course -
