HubSpot Academy</a></h4> \n<h4>22. <a href=\"https://www.quicksprout.com/university/category/email-marketing-videos/\">Email Marketing - QuickSprout</a></h4> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Web Development and Site Design Courses</h3> \n<h4>23. <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/make-a-website\">Make a Website - CodeAcademy</a></h4> \n<h4>24. <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-javascript\">Learn Javascript - CodeAcademy</a></h4> \n<h4>25. <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/ruby\">Learn Ruby - CodeAcademy</a></h4> \n<h4>26. <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/python\">Learn Python - CodeAcademy</a></h4> \n<h4>27. <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-html-css\">Learn HTML &amp; CSS - CodeAcademy</a></h4> \n<h4>28. <a href=\"https://dash.generalassemb.ly/\">Learn to Code Awesome Websites - General Assembly</a></h4> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Online Advertising Courses</h3> \n<h4>29. <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/digital-advertising-training?library=true\">What Digital Advertising Is and How to Do It - HubSpot Academy</a></h4> \n<h4>30. <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/paid-media\">How to Build a Paid Media Strategy - HubSpot Academy</a></h4> \n<h4>31. <a href=\"https://www.quicksprout.com/university/category/paid-advertising-videos/\">Paid Advertising - QuickSprout</a></h4> \n<h4>32. <a href=\"http://www.wordstream.com/learn\">Wordstream PPC University</a></h4> \n<h4>33. <a href=\"https://alison.com/course/advertising-your-business-online\">Advertising Your Business Online - Alison</a></h4> \n<h4>34. <a href=\"https://www.skillshare.com/classes/Copywriting-101-Crafting-Your-First-Ad-Campaign/92436378\">Copywriting 101: Crafting Your First Ad Campaign - Skillshare</a></h4> \n<h4>35. <a href=\"https://www.lynda.com/Business-Skills-tutorials/Advertising-Fundamentals/382569-2.html\">Advertising Foundations - Lynda</a></h4> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Other Digital Marketing Courses</h3> \n<h4>36. <a href=\"https://designschool.canva.com/courses/graphic-design-basics/?lesson=design-to-communicate\">Basic Graphic Design - Canva</a></h4> \n<h4>37. <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/learning/photoshop-2020-one-on-one-fundamentals\">Photoshop 2020: One-on-One Fundamentals - LinkedIn Learning</a></h4> \n<h4>38. <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/learning/indesign-2020-essential-training/indesign-learn-the-fundamentals\">InDesign 2020: Essential Training - LinkedIn Learning</a></h4> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Where to Find Free or Affordable Courses</h2> \n<h3>HubSpot Academy</h3> \n<p>HubSpot Academy offers certification and training courses to teach people how inbound marketing and HubSpot software work. Classes are often taught by marketers at HubSpot and are made up of video lessons, quizzes, and tests. Most HubSpot Academy classes are available free of charge, and if you pass the certifications, such as the two below, you get a nifty certificate and badge to share on your social media profiles. Check out mine on LinkedIn:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot%20certifications.png?width=640&amp;name=hubspot%20certifications.png\" alt=\"HubSpot Content Marketing Certification badge\" width=\"640\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 640px;\"></p> \n<h3>Copyblogger</h3> \n<p>Copyblogger is a content marketing company that creates content about content (so meta). Its blog provides a ton of great resources about digital marketing, and this class, \"Internet Marketing for Smart People,\" is made up of ebooks and emailed lessons and other course materials. Copyblogger espouses four pillars of content marketing success, which it delves into over the course of this class.</p> \n<h3>Coursera</h3> \n<p>Coursera offers MOOCs (massive online open courses) created and taught online by universities such as Northwestern University, the University of Pennsylvania, and the University of California system. These courses start at various times throughout the year, so browse the catalog to see when one lines up with your schedule. Below are a couple courses that are perfect for content marketers -- here's what a module for #4 looks like:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/coursera%20course%20module.png?width=640&amp;name=coursera%20course%20module.png\" alt=\"Coursera content marketing course list\" width=\"640\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 640px;\"></p> \n<h3>QuickSprout</h3> \n<p>QuickSprout is Neil Patel's content and business marketing blog, and QuickSprout University features a ton of helpful videos breaking down and explaining a myriad of concepts and best practices. Each video also includes a transcript in case reading is more your learning style than watching a video. Here's what one course video looks like:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/quicksprout-1.png?width=640&amp;name=quicksprout-1.png\" alt=\"Quicksprout content marketing course\" width=\"640\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 640px;\"></p> \n<h3>Udemy</h3> \n<p>Udemy is another online learning platform that focuses specifically on courses related to skill building for working professionals. One thing to note about Udemy: The classes we've highlighted are free, but it offers a myriad of other paid options for as little as $10, in some cases. If you have a good experience with a free course, it could be worth a small investment to deepen your skills, too.</p> \n<h3>Wordstream</h3> \n<p>Wordstream is a search engine and social media marketing software company that helps marketers drive the greatest ROI from their paid search and social media campaigns. These free guides and ebooks distill learnings and best practices for users with varying levels of expertise running pay-per-click (PPC) campaigns. Here are some of its topics and offerings:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/PPCuniversity.png?width=640&amp;name=PPCuniversity.png\" alt=\"Wordstream social media marketing course on how to run PPC campaigns\" width=\"640\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 640px;\"></p> \n<h3>edX</h3> \n<p>edX is another MOOC provider that features courses offered by top-tier universities, including Harvard University, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Boston University. Like Coursera, classes are taught online and start at specific times throughout the year. Here's a class we think you'll find valuable:</p> \n<h3>Alison</h3> \n<p>Alison offers free online classes in various professional skills users can take at their own pace. In the Diploma in Social Media Marketing course below, students can get into the nitty-gritty and big picture views of different skills of different topics -- just check out one of the many modules:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/alisontopiclist.png?width=600&amp;name=alisontopiclist.png\" alt=\"ALISON digital marketing course module\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Facebook</h3> \n<p>At this point, you probably already know what Facebook is and what it does. What you might not know? It has a training and certification program. Facebook Blueprint offers self-paced and live e-learning courses for marketers seeking to grow their organizations using Facebook. Blueprint offers classes in different languages on how to use Facebook and Instagram -- here's a peek at the course catalog.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/facebookblueprint.png?width=640&amp;name=facebookblueprint.png\" alt=\"Facebook Blueprint social media marketing course catalog\" width=\"640\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 640px;\"></p> \n<h3>quintly</h3> \n<p>quintly is a social media analytics tool that offers courses through quintly Academy. The self-paced course provides an overview of social media analytics, benchmarking, and goaling using downloadable written materials and video lessons.</p> \n<h3>Buffer</h3> \n<p>Buffer's Social Media Week of Webinars isn't exactly a course -- it's a series of live webinar recordings on YouTube -- but the videos are chock-full of current and valuable information for social media marketers from the experts. Topics include Instagram and Facebook marketing and how to do public relations on social media.</p> \n<h3>Google</h3> \n<p>Google is another company you've probably heard of before, and its digital marketing course offers a ton of valuable information if you plan to advertise and rank on the search engine. You can even take a Google AdWords certification at the end of the process that helps you beef up your resume (and your Google+ profile).</p> \n<h3>CodeAcademy</h3> \n<p>CodeAcademy offers free, interactive coding classes that take you from lesson one to building a fully-functioning website. The courses we've highlighted below are just a few of the courses; CodeAcademy offers many more, depending on your organization's needs. CodeAcademy classes feature lectures and a workspace in the same browser window so you can see the effect of your work live, as it's created.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/codecademy-learning-environment-3.png?width=600&amp;name=codecademy-learning-environment-3.png\" alt=\"Codeacademy digital marketing course workspace\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://thenextweb.com/dd/2014/04/23/codecademy-unveils-stunning-redesign-learn-code-site/#.tnw_LzBgKtnJ\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 14px;\">Image Source</span></em></a></p> \n<h3>General Assembly</h3> \n<p>General Assembly offers live and online paid and free courses for a variety of technical skills and disciplines. General Assembly's Dash offers a free online coding class that teaches the fundamentals of HTML5, CSS3, and Javascript -- watch the course overview below:</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.07%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/w2tcMPCcnt8\" width=\"560\" height=\"314\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<h3>Canva</h3> \n<p>Canva helps people easily make beautiful images for web design, and <a href=\"https://designschool.canva.com/design-courses/\">Canva Learn</a> offers design courses that are valuable for any kind of storyteller. The Creativity course explores the challenges of constant creation and innovation and how to do it well -- with visuals, of course.</p>  \n<p></p>  \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published in May 2018, but was updated in July 2020 for comprehensiveness and freshness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffree-online-marketing-classes&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Jul 2020 10:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/online-marketing-courses.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"2437f160f983a77a3113ca3871ed73df","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn1@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118303768_3e0eb7447f79be0d.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/online-marketing-courses.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"sbernazzani@hubspot.com (Sophia Bernazzani)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot%20certifications.png?width=640&name=hubspot%20certifications.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn93@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596118312377_c572edcaf469ec5f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/coursera%20course%20module.png?width=640&name=coursera%20course%20module.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn73@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118313990_01d4ba67206edb30.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/quicksprout-1.png?width=640&name=quicksprout-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn77@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118305029_23d1808ad4824868.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/PPCuniversity.png?width=640&name=PPCuniversity.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn85@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118312259_ed5b63bf63edcbb1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/alisontopiclist.png?width=600&name=alisontopiclist.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn93@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118305330_e0dcc78afa2415c7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/facebookblueprint.png?width=640&name=facebookblueprint.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn33@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118309192_105ea78902373c1a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/codecademy-learning-environment-3.png?width=600&name=codecademy-learning-environment-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn57@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596118308056_852d5a45f51a4ca7.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffree-online-marketing-classes&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn1@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118304807_ab6d0c5b3d942f60.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"10 Lead Generation Mistakes Marketers Need to Avoid in 2020","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/lead-generation-mistakes","description":"<p>For many businesses, the key to making sales is to first generate leads.</p> \n<p>Leads are valuable because they're the people who have indicated organic interest in your content and your business by giving you their information in some way, whether it's by filling out a form to download an ebook, completing an online survey, or something else.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>But leads don't grow on trees. Some marketers have trouble generating enough leads to feed their sales team. Others generate plenty of leads, but <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/signs-your-lead-is-a-terrible-fit\">they're not good leads</a>, and your sales team is having trouble closing them into customers. Others just have no idea where their leads are coming from.</p> \n<p>These are all common <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/beginner-inbound-lead-generation-guide-ht?utm_campaign=Leadin%20Blog%20Post%20-%20Lead%20Generation%20Mistakes%20Oct%202016&amp;utm_source=HS-blog\">problems marketers have with lead generation</a>. In this post, we'll go over many of these problems and talk about how to fix them. We'll also highlight a few tips directly from HubSpot acquisition experts.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>10 Lead Generation Mistakes Marketers Should Avoid</h2> \n<h3>1. You're buying leads, not generating them organically.</h3> \n<p>If you're having trouble generating leads, it can be tempting to buy email lists so you can feed your sales organization with something -- <em>anything. </em>But buying or renting contacts out of desperation will cause you more long-term (and short-term) harm than good.</p> \n<p>There are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32892/Why-Purchasing-Email-Lists-Is-Always-a-Bad-Idea.aspx\">a lot of reasons buying email lists is never a good idea</a>. Not only will sending emails to purchased lists <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/30594/a-marketer-s-guide-to-getting-past-email-spam-filters.aspx\">harm your email deliverability</a> and IP reputation, but there's a good chance the people on your purchased list have never heard of your company -- making them far more likely to mark you as spam. They'll also think you're super annoying. And you're not annoying, are you?</p> \n<p><strong>Bottom line here is that quality email addresses simply aren't for sale.</strong> The whole point of generating leads is to eventually nurture those leads into customers. In order for your leads to become customers, the leads you generate need to actually want to hear from you.</p> \n<h4>How to Fix It</h4> \n<p>Your leads need to opt in, plain and simple. This means your contacts chose to give you their information in exchange for something valuable, like a content offer, webinar, event, and so on. Focus on creating offers that are valuable in some way for your target audience, and then package that value and put it behind a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/forms\">lead capture form</a>.</p> \n<p>Growing a healthy, opt-in email list takes time, but it's worth its weight in gold down the line. And once you have people to email, be sure you're <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-guide-to-optimizing-email-marketing-for-conversions\">creating remarkable email content</a> that makes people want to actually open your emails and stay subscribed.</p> \n<h3>2. You don't offer lead-gen content for people in different stages of the buyer's journey.</h3> \n<p>Not everyone who visits your website is going to be in the same stage of <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/broadcasts/the-buyers-journey\">their buyer's journey</a>. Think about the folks who are landing on your website for the very first time. Do you think they're ready to see a demo of your product? Or do you think they'd be more likely to want to download a helpful piece of content, like a step-by-step guide?</p> \n<p>Some of your site visitors might be ready to buy, but most won't -- and you need to give them the opportunities to learn more about your business and what you're selling before asking them take any sort of purchase action.</p> \n<p>Creating valuable content to teach and nurture your leads down the funnel is time-consuming, which is why so often you'll browse a business' website and see nothing but \"Buy Now!\" and \"Click Here for a Free Demo!\" all over the place.</p> \n<h4>How to Fix It</h4> \n<p>There is no one-size-fits-all CTA for everyone who visits your website. To maximize clickthrough rates, you'll want to cater to visitors who are at all different stages of the buyer's journey using CTAs.</p> \n<p>So, yes -- you'll need to spend time creating a variety of offers you can put behind landing page forms that cater to people at different stages. Folks who are just starting to get to know you might be interested in offers like checklists, contests, and templates. Visitors who are a little further down the funnel might be interested in email courses, kits, and whitepapers. Folks even further down might be ready for a demo.</p> \n<p>Make sure you're creating content that cover the whole funnel, and that you're offering this content on your website so there's something for everyone. (Need ideas for lead gen content? <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/lead-gen-content-ideas\">Here are 23 ideas</a> for you.)</p> \n<p>If you want to take personalization a step further, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/smart-ctas-personalization\">use smart CTAs</a>. Smart CTAs are CTAs that change depending on the person viewing the page -- his or her interests, location, pages viewed already, items or services bought before, and so on. Unsurprisingly, <strong>personalized CTAS actually convert <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/personalized-calls-to-action-convert-better-data\">42% more visitors</a> than basic calls-to-action. </strong>They make for a better user experience for your user, and higher conversion rates for you: a win-win! You can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/smart-ctas-personalization\">learn more about smart CTAs here</a>.</p> \n<h3>3. You aren't using your blog to generate leads.</h3> \n<p>HubSpot's blog is responsible for a significant percentage of our marketing team's incoming leads.</p> \n<p>In fact, at one point, we found that <strong><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/76%%20of%20our%20monthly%20blog%20views%20came%20from%20&quot;old&quot;%20posts%20(in%20other%20words,%20posts%20published%20prior%20to%20that%20month).\">76% of our monthly blog views </a></strong>come from \"old\" posts (in other words, posts published prior to that month). We always joke that if the entire blogging team went on vacation for a month, we'd still hit a good portion of our leads goal.</p> \n<p>“At HubSpot, we have an entire team dedicated to continuously optimizing our blog conversion strategy,\" says Carly Stec, HubSpot's Team Manager of content acquisition. \"This group works in lockstep with our SEO team and writers to provide insight into the topics that are converting well to ensure a well-rounded editorial mix.\"</p> \n<p>\"This level of alignment allows us to provide blog readers with helpful next steps based on their intent,” Stec adds.</p> \n<p>Despite <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/business-blogging-in-2015\">blogging's many lead generation benefits</a>, we find that marketers aren't fully taking advantage of this tactic as a lead generation powerhouse. Either folks aren't blogging at all, or they're not putting lead capture forms or CTAs on their blog -- sometimes because they don't have any valuable content offers to put behind a form.</p> \n<p>But, still one of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/the-benefits-of-business-blogging-ht\">the biggest benefits of business blogging</a> is converting the traffic it brings you into leads. Just like every blog post you write is another indexed page, each post is a new opportunity to generate new leads. Here's what that looks like in numbers: If each one of your blog posts gets about 100 views per month, and your visitor-to-lead conversion rate on the blog is about 2%, then you'd get two leads from a single blog post each month. If you write 30 blog posts per month, you'd get 60 leads in a month -- two from each blog post.</p> \n<p>Keep blogging consistently like that for a year, and thanks to each blog post's<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hubspot-blog-compounding-posts\"> compounding value over time</a>, each post you write will drive value for you in the form of traffic and leads. By the end of 12 months, you'll end up getting 4,680 opt-in contacts per month, not just 720 opt-in contacts (60 leads*12 months).</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blogging_compounding_returns-5.jpg?width=640&amp;name=blogging_compounding_returns-5.jpg\" alt=\"blogging_compounding_returns-5.jpg\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<h4>How to Fix It</h4> \n<p>Generating leads from your blog posts is simple: Just add a <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/call-to-action-templates\">lead-generating call-to-action</a> to every blog post. Most of the time, these CTAs will lead to landing pages offering free content like ebooks, whitepapers, checklists, webinars, free trials, and so on. Promote your content offers by blogging about subject matters related to them, and then put CTAs that lead to the asset's landing page on every one of those blog posts.</p> \n<p>What that CTA looks like on your blog posts is up to you. On HubSpot's blog, we use three main types of CTAs on our blog: end-of-post banner CTAs on every single post, and slide-in CTAs and anchor text CTAs on select posts. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-anchor-text-call-to-action-study\">Read this post</a> to learn when it's appropriate to use end-of-post banner CTAs, anchor text CTAs, or both.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/end-of-post-cta-banner-1-1.png?width=640&amp;name=end-of-post-cta-banner-1-1.png\" alt=\"end-of-post-cta-banner-1-1.png\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/anchor-text-cta%20(1).png?width=640&amp;name=anchor-text-cta%20(1).png\" alt=\"anchor-text-cta (1).png\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p>As for <a href=\"http://leadin.hubspot.com/free?utm_campaign=marketing-blog-CTA&amp;utm_source=Blog&amp;utm_medium=HS-Marketing&amp;utm_content=Lead%20Generation%20Mistakes%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Stop%20Making&amp;utm_id=\">slide-in CTAs</a>, we've found these to perform better than end-of-post CTAs -- which makes sense because visitors see them sooner since they slide in at about 25%-50% of the way down the post. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-add-a-slide-in-call-to-action-to-your-blog-posts\">Learn how to add slide-in CTAs to your blog posts here</a>.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slide-in-cta-example-1.png?width=640&amp;name=slide-in-cta-example-1.png\" alt=\"slide-in-cta-example-1.png\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<h3>4. You aren't using the best lead generation tools.</h3> \n<p>You know that people are coming to your website, but do you know who they are? How about what they're doing once they get there, or what they're doing before and after taking certain actions? If you're unable to answer these questions, then you're going to have a hard time connecting with the people who are visiting your site or learning what's resonating with them and what's not.</p> \n<p>But these are questions you can and should answer -- but you need the right tools to do it. There are some great tools out there that can help you learn about your website visitors and convert them into leads.</p> \n<h4>How to Fix It</h4> \n<p>The trick is finding the best combination of tools that'll give you the most insight and the best bang for your buck. There are a few different tools and templates out there that'll help you create different lead gen assets you can put on your site.</p> \n<p>At the simplest level, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/call-to-action-templates\">these 50+ free, customizable CTA Templates</a> will help you create clickable buttons you can put on your blog, your landing pages, and elsewhere on your site. Use them to create CTAs that lead to a landing page form.</p> \n<p>Speaking of forms, a form embedding tool will come in handy when it comes to actually collecting information from your site visitors and converting them into leads. If you're a HubSpot customer, you can <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/forms/where-can-i-find-the-embed-code-for-my-forms\">create and embed forms using HubSpot</a>. Non-HubSpot customers can use a tool like Contact Form 7, JetPack, or Google Forms, and then <a href=\"http://leadin.hubspot.com/knowledge/collected-forms?utm_campaign=marketing-blog-CTA&amp;utm_source=Blog&amp;utm_medium=HS-Marketing&amp;utm_content=How%20to%20Generate%20Leads%20from%20the%20Most%20Popular%20Pages%20on%20Your%20Website&amp;utm_id=\">use Leadin's free Collected Forms tool</a> to automatically capture these form submissions on your website.</p> \n<p>Finally, a lead capture and contact insights tool like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/lead-flows\">Lead Flows by HubSpot</a><a href=\"http://leadin.hubspot.com/free?utm_campaign=marketing-blog-CTA&amp;utm_source=Blog&amp;utm_medium=HS-Marketing&amp;utm_content=Lead%20Generation%20Mistakes%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Stop%20Making&amp;utm_id=\">&nbsp;</a>(which is free) will help you capture leads using pop-ups, dropdown banners, or slide-ins. It'll also scrape any pre-existing forms you have on your website and add those contacts to your existing contact database.</p> \n<p>Here's an example of a slide-in CTA created with <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/lead-flows\">Lead Flows</a>, HubSpot's free conversion tool:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slide-in-lead-flow.gif?width=640&amp;name=slide-in-lead-flow.gif\" alt=\"slide-in-lead-flow.gif\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<h3>5. You have a \"right vs. wrong\" testing mindset.</h3> \n<p>Knowing that you should test your website and constantly work on improving it is one thing. What most marketers have trouble with is seeing testing and experimenting not as a way to prove your ideas, but as a way to find something better.</p> \n<p>I like the way Andrew Anderson put it <a href=\"http://conversionxl.com/the-psychology-of-a-successful-testing-program/\">in his post on ConversionXL</a>: \"The real challenge is in getting yourself and your organization ready to accept one really simple truth: Being wrong is far more valuable than being right.\"</p> \n<p>Often, this will manifest itself in someone having an idea for how to improve a part of their website. Perhaps they think removing distractions from a landing page will increase conversion rates on that page, for instance. What happens here is that most marketers will limit what they test in a way that skews the data to help them reach that conclusion, often without meaning it. After all, it feels bad -- and might look bad -- to have an idea or make an assumption and have it proven totally wrong.</p> \n<h4>How to Fix It</h4> \n<p>\"The first and most vital step to dealing with this is to focus all discussions on the comparing of actions and not on validating opinions,\" writes Anderson. \"It isn’t about if Tactic A or B works, it is how well does Tactic A or B or C or D and so on compare to each other.\"</p> \n<p>In other words, treat every idea that's brought to the table the same, whether or not you think it'll \"win.\" This makes the testing program less personal and encourages a more holistic approach. Remember: by nature, a program that tests your website is meant to prove yourself and others wrong, and that's a good thing.</p> \n<p>You and your teammates need to check your egos and adopt this mindset to avoid finger-pointing. Instead of rewarding people for being right, which reinforces that toxic mindset, focus on the system and the outcomes more holistically.</p> \n<h3>6. You aren't optimizing your top pages for lead generation.</h3> \n<p>Not all webpages should be treated the same. In fact, if you look at traffic numbers to specific pages on your website, you'll probably find that the vast majority of your traffic is coming in to a few, very specific pages -- maybe your homepage; your \"Contact Us\" page; maybe one or two popular blog posts. With so many people landing on those pages, why would you treat them like any other ol' page on your website?</p> \n<p>Because so many people are landing on those pages, it's very important that you create opportunities for people to convert on those pages, lest you leave potentially massive lead numbers on the table.</p> \n<h4>How to Fix It</h4> \n<p>First, figure out which of your webpages are the four or five most popular for traffic. (HubSpot customers: You can do this in HubSpot by going to Reports &gt; Page Performance, then filter the report by Views.)</p> \n<p>Then, optimize those pages for leads. This means making sure you create calls-to-action (CTAs) that stand out from the page, and then place them where people naturally look on your website. Our natural eye path starts in the upper left-hand corner of a website and moves on from there, <a href=\"http://blog.eyequant.com/blog/2014/01/15/the-3-most-surprising-insights-from-a-200-website-eye-tracking-study\">according to an eyetracking study</a>.</p> \n<p>Another way to increase the conversion rate on a page that already gets a lot of traffic? Create special offers specifically for your most popular pages, and gate them behind landing page forms. I know, I know, creating a brand new offer can time-consuming -- but it could be <em>much</em> more <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/beginner-inbound-lead-generation-guide-ht?utm_campaign=Leadin%20Blog%20Post%20-%20Lead%20Generation%20Mistakes%20Oct%202016&amp;utm_source=HS-blog\">effective for lead generation</a> than optimizing button color, language, images, and so on. For example, the folks at Eastern International College <a href=\"http://www.eicollege.edu/quiz.aspx\">created a quiz</a> for students on which college major they should choose, which they linked to on their popular Careers page.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/eastern-international-college-quiz.png?width=640&amp;name=eastern-international-college-quiz.png\" alt=\"eastern-international-college-quiz.png\" width=\"640\" title=\"eastern-international-college-quiz.png\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p>At the end of the quiz, they promised to send the quiz results in exchange for people's name, phone number, and email address <a href=\"https://www.tryinteract.com/blog/how-to-generate-leads-on-social-media-using-quizzes-this-example-got-125-in-20-days/\">as a lead capture tactic</a>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/lead-generation-tips-for-popular-webpages\">Read this blog post for more tips</a> on how to generate leads from your most popular webpages.</p> \n<h3>7. You're ONLY optimizing your top pages for lead-generation.</h3> \n<p>Yes. When you have a page that earns high traffic, it might also win over a lot more leads. However, AJ Beltis, a HubSpot marketing manager who specializes in content creation and lead acquisition, says you might be missing solid opportunities by only optimizing high-traffic-getters.</p> \n<p>\"It’s tempting for content marketers to immediately go to the most-viewed blog posts and try to convert their viewers into leads. High traffic means high potential, so it makes sense to look at these posts first,\" Beltis says.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>\"However, those most-viewed posts are often on topics that cast a wide net and might not tie directly back to your product or service,\" Beltis explains. \"Instead, try focusing on blog posts or topic clusters that may not have the most views, but have a clear path for conversion.</p> \n<p>\"After all, what’s better – a 5% conversion rate for a blog post with 50,000 views, or a 1% conversion rate on a blog post with 100,000 views,\" Beltis concludes.</p> \n<h4>How to Fix It</h4> \n<p>Finding posts with conversion opportunities that don't pull in major traffic can take a bit of research.</p> \n<p>Using HubSpot, or other data-tracking tools, consider creating and analyzing a conversion rate optimization report that highlights each post's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/conversion-rate-optimization-guide\">conversion rate, number of new contacts, and lead goal.</a> This will allow you to see how each post is performing and help you zone on posts that are pulling in a solid number of contacts. It will also allow you to see how traffic impacts a conversion rate.</p> \n<p>For example, if you see a low conversion rate on a post but a high number of contacts, this could mean the post has many leads due in part to its traffic. On the other hand, if you see a post with a lower contact number but a higher conversion rate, this could be a lower traffic post with a higher chance of pulling in leads.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Aside from using the reporting tools you have at hand to learn from your own data, you could also ask yourself a few topic-related questions like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>What are our audience's interested in learning more about?:</strong> Sometimes, trends that impact people in your industry might be highly discussed on social media, but haven't yet gained enough search volume to pull in high traffic. Are there trend-related blog posts and content offers you can create or update that can tie well together, provide value to your audience, and get them to convert?</li> \n <li><strong>Do we have any tactical posts that relate strongly to our product or current offers?:</strong> For example, if you sell a task-management software, a post on how to multitask, how to organize your office, or how to create a project schedule might not be shareable on social media or pull in huge traffic, but it still could align well with an offer related to your product -- such as a free trial.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>8. You're not using social media strategically for lead generation.</h3> \n<p>Although social media is most effective for top-of-the-funnel marketing metrics like traffic and brand awareness, it can still be helpful as a source for lead generation -- and a low-cost one, at that.</p> \n<p>If you're finding that social media isn't generating very many leads for you, there's a chance you're not doing it strategically enough. At least that's what Jeremy White, a serial entrepreneur and conversion consultant, <a href=\"https://blog.crazyegg.com/2014/04/14/b2b-lead-gen/\">wrote in a post on CrazyEgg's blog</a>.</p> \n<p>\"It’s not that you <i>can’t</i> get leads on social media; it’s that we’re not taking what’s there,\" he wrote. In other words, you might be doing it wrong. If your social strategy is to post your new ebooks to all your social media channels and that's about it, then don't expect to bring in a whole lot of leads from those posts. The spray-and-pray technique isn't enough.</p> \n<h4>How to Fix It</h4> \n<p>One way to generate more leads from social media is to sprinkle blog posts and offers that have historically generated higher-than-average leads numbers for you in with the new posts and offers your team is creating.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, we've found that one of the best ways to generate leads is simply to link directly to landing pages for blog posts and offers that have historically performed well for lead generation. (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-lead-generation-analysis\">Learn how to do your own blog lead generation analysis here</a>.)</p> \n<p>We've also found that linking directly to an offer's landing page can be more effective -- as long as your post copy sets the expectation that you are, in fact, sending people to a landing page. In the Facebook post below, we set that expectation by putting \"Free Template\" in brackets in front of the offer title.</p> \n<iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/post.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fhubspot%2Fposts%2F10154680768144394&amp;width=500\" width=\"500\" height=\"501\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe> \n<p>You'll also want to make sure you're using some of the features on each social network that are specifically designed to help you generate leads.</p> \n<p><strong>On Twitter,</strong> your lead gen tweets should contain a value proposition, a short URL linking to the landing page with a form, and an image to ensure the post stands out. (<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/templates-shareable-graphics-social-media\">Here are some social media image templates</a> you can use to create those images.)</p>  \n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"> \n <p>Your design skills nonexistent? You're gonna want these templates: <a href=\"https://t.co/7fxTWZw3BC\">https://t.co/7fxTWZw3BC</a> <a href=\"https://t.co/CKvgfyuZpY\">pic.twitter.com/CKvgfyuZpY</a></p> — HubSpot (@HubSpot) \n <a href=\"https://twitter.com/HubSpot/status/790437932813484032\">October 24, 2016</a>\n</blockquote>   \n<p>Twitter also offers lead generation cards that can help you generate qualified leads at a lower cost than most of the other major ad platforms. Twitter cards let you embed rich media that don't count toward your tweet character limit that allow your fans and followers to do things like download an app, visit a landing page, give over their email, or use a coupon -- all without leaving Twitter. (HubSpot customers: You can connect your Twitter lead gen cards to HubSpot by <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/forms/can-i-connect-twitter-lead-generation-cards-to-hubspot-forms\">following these instructions</a>.)</p> \n<p><strong>On Facebook:</strong> There are a number of great ways to generate leads from Facebook, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-lead-generation-tips-ht\">the best of which I've rounded up in this blog post</a>. For example, one way to easily generate leads is by simply using the call-to-action feature available for Pages. The feature lets you put a simple call-to-action button at the top of your Facebook Page, and it can help drive more traffic from your Facebook Page to lead generation forms like landing pages and contact sheets.</p> \n<p>Here's an example from Tough Mudder's Page, and you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-cta-button\">learn how to insert your own Facebook CTA button here</a>.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tough-mudder-facebook-for-lead-gen.png?width=640&amp;name=tough-mudder-facebook-for-lead-gen.png\" alt=\"tough-mudder-facebook-for-lead-gen.png\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p><strong>On LinkedIn,</strong> B2B businesses can take advantage of the perception that LinkedIn is the most sophisticated of social platforms, and a place where B2B relationships are most likely to be built. Like on Facebook, you can publish your lead-generating content directly to your business' Facebook Page alongside actionable copy and a compelling image.</p> \n<h3>9. Your forms are too long or too short.</h3> \n<p>How long should your lead capture forms be? Striking a balance between asking too much and too little on your forms is a common problem marketers gripe with.</p> \n<p>If your form's too short, more people might be willing to fill it out, which is great for leads numbers -- but the <em>quality</em> of those leads might not be very high. If your form's too long, though, fewer people might be willing to fill it out, meaning you'll get fewer leads out of it. On the bright side, the people who <em>do </em>submit their information could end up being higher quality leads.</p> \n<p>So what gives? What's the \"magic number\" of questions to ask on your forms?</p> \n<h4>How to Fix It</h4> \n<p>There's no hard-and-fast rule for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32079/How-Long-Should-Your-Landing-Page-Forms-Be.aspx\">how many fields to put on your forms</a>. Your \"sweet spot\" will depend entirely on your goals: Do you need <em>more </em>leads, or do you need <em>better </em>leads? Essentially, the length of your form will lead to a tradeoff between quantity and quality of the leads you generate. In general, s<span class=\"s1\">horter forms usually result in more overall leads, while longer forms will result in fewer, but <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/30889/How-to-Expose-the-Best-Leads-to-Your-Sales-Team.aspx?_ga=1.175987234.1456347280.1474306255\">higher quality leads</a>.</span></p> \n<p><span class=\"s1\">“Think of every field in your checkout as a hurdle your prospect has to leap over,\" <a href=\"http://www.copyblogger.com/high-converting-checkouts/\">writes Copyhackers' Joanna Wiebe</a>. \"Then ask yourself if it’s worth the possibility of losing a sale — or thousands of sales — because you want to fill a database.\"</span></p> \n<p><span class=\"s1\">You can’t possibly know how many form fields you can pull off without conducting conversion research and running your own tests. Even then, you have to compare the ROI of additional information with the ROI of increased conversions. How much does having a phone number <em>really</em> help the sales team? Is it enough to warrant a potential decrease in conversions?</span></p> \n<p>It's important that you don't make this decision without involving your sales team. They have a better idea of what information will actually help them close deals. How much does asking for a phone number actually help your sales team -- and is it enough to potentially lose leads over? Speaking of talking with your sales team ...</p> \n<h3>10. Your definition of a qualified lead isn't well communicated with your sales department.</h3> \n<p>You know the definition of a lead in the general sense of the term: It's a person who has indicated interest in your company's product or service by giving you their information in some way, like by filling out a form to download an ebook or completing an online survey.</p> \n<p>A marketing qualified lead, or MQL, is a lead that's been deemed more likely to become a customer compared to other leads, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/lead-scoring-instructions\">based on lead intelligence</a>. MQLs have metaphorically raised their hands and identified themselves as more deeply engaged, sales-ready contacts than your usual leads, but who have not yet become full-fledged opportunities. In other words, from a marketing perspective, your sales team should be talking with them.</p> \n<p>But sales teams tend to have their own system for qualifying leads. Sales qualified leads are leads your sales team has accepted as worthy of a direct sales follow-up. Agreeing on that quality threshold is where things tend to get muddy. Both the quantity and quality of leads needed and the sales process are mutually agreed upon by both Marketing and Sales.</p> \n<h4>How to Fix It</h4> \n<p>That's exactly where the conversation begins. To align Marketing and Sales on what constitutes a qualified lead from both sides, you'll have to learn to speak each other's language. Similar to your marketing qualified leads, Sales has its own definition of \"qualified\": sales qualified leads are leads they've accepted as worthy of a direct sales follow-up.</p> \n<p>Both teams need to align on their definitions of a marketing qualified and sales qualified lead. And there's no one-size-fits-all definition for one, either -- an MQL at one company may be completely different than an MQL at another company. You should do your own internal <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/closed-loop-marketing/\" title=\"analysis of your leads and customers\">analysis of your leads and customers</a> to create your business’ definition of an MQL. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/30889/How-to-Expose-the-Best-Leads-to-Your-Sales-Team.aspx\">Read this post to learn</a> how to get started defining an MQL for your business and communicating that definition with Sales.</p> \n<h2>Avoid Losing Great Leads</h2> \n<p>There are plenty more lead generation mistakes we could add to this list, but these are some of the most important ones we see marketers make every day. For our readers out there who want to get more and better quality leads, we hope this post will help you prioritize where to focus your time and resources.</p> \n<p>Now that you've had time to read up and reflect on some of the most common lead-generation mistakes, we'd love to hear from you. Vote in this completely anonymous poll to tell us which mistake you or your company have commonly made, or check the results to see how others voted.</p> \n<p>  </p> \n<div class=\"playbuzz\">\n &nbsp;\n</div> \n<p>If you want to learn more about creating an effective conversion rate optimization strategy, check out these beginner's guides on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/conversion-rate-optimization-guide\">conversion rate optimization</a> and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/beginner-inbound-lead-generation-guide-ht\">lead generation</a>.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published in October 2016, but was updated in July 2020 for comprehensiveness and freshness.</em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em></em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flead-generation-mistakes&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Jul 2020 16:04:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/lead-generation-mistakes-1.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"0f0615bba5304d9c93b23c7f267f1721","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn1@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118303769_83e4fa41eab97e9c.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/lead-generation-mistakes-1.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"lkolowich@hubspot.com (Lindsay Kolowich)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blogging_compounding_returns-5.jpg?width=640&name=blogging_compounding_returns-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn81@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596118309675_26b7349191bcb1aa.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/end-of-post-cta-banner-1-1.png?width=640&name=end-of-post-cta-banner-1-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn65@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118313204_89fd9f2ad4e7102a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/anchor-text-cta%20(1).png?width=640&name=anchor-text-cta%20(1).png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn29@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118309162_bdc008c0de37c738.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slide-in-cta-example-1.png?width=640&name=slide-in-cta-example-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn9@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118306811_c1b0f064d589951e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slide-in-lead-flow.gif?width=640&name=slide-in-lead-flow.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn37@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596118307065_e686e998a660be12.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/eastern-international-college-quiz.png?width=640&name=eastern-international-college-quiz.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn25@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118311931_be7a48725fdef100.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tough-mudder-facebook-for-lead-gen.png?width=640&name=tough-mudder-facebook-for-lead-gen.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn33@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596118312141_f4d812be15ee1834.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flead-generation-mistakes&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn21@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596118313396_6327a52954795205.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 22:11:40","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 14:11:40","title":"The Ins and Outs of Facebook Landing Pages","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/create-landing-page-on-facebook","description":"<p>How many times have you interacted with an ad on Facebook and gotten lost down a rabbit hole? If you're like me, your answer is probably up in the dozens. I could click on an ad about ice cream, and five minutes later, find myself looking at YouTube videos of homemade sundaes.</p>  \n<p>Sometimes, though, I come across an ad that's seamless — They're quick to grab my attention, and it tells me everything I need to know when I reach the landing page.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>This morning, for example, I checked my timeline. I came across this ad while scrolling, and because I saw my favorite colors in the ad, I had to click on the image.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ins%20and%20Outs%20of%20Facebook%20Landing%20Pages.gif\" alt=\"Example of a Facebook landing page.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>The landing page wasn't busy. In fact, the simplicity caught my attention. All the page had was text, an image, and a CTA. I noticed how the ad and landing page were centered around the same product.</p> \n<p>It was effective because its only purpose was to get me to fill out the free trial offer, and that's exactly what I did. After all, I wanted to track my personal Instagram posts.</p> \n<p>As far as Facebook landing pages go, this one was great.</p> \n<p>Have you ever made a landing page specifically for Facebook ads? If the thought of creating another landing page just for social media sounds like a burden you'd rather avoid, don't worry. In most cases, you won't need to make more than a few small adjustments to one you already have.</p> \n<p>If you're ready to dive into what makes Facebook landing pages a must for ads, read on, and let's get started.</p> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/landing-page-best-practices?_ga=2.169832808.831801315.1596056938-940436819.1565181751\">landing page</a> is a web page visitors \"land\" on when they engage with an ad or offer. The purpose of a landing page is to drive action by offering something of value in exchange for lead information. Usually, they'll have a form to download a free ebook, receive a demo, get a template, or something similar.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ins%20and%20Outs%20of%20Facebook%20Landing%20Pages-Jul-29-2020-08-49-32-45-PM.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Example of a good landing page.\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/crm/e010a\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>Good landing pages, like the one above, reflect the company and include at least one CTA. Facebook landing pages have the same goal.</p> \n<p>Facebook landing pages refer to the ones attached to Facebook ads. They're still meant to entice audience members to take action, but are optimized for use on Facebook.</p> \n<p>Just like there's best practices for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/landing-page-examples-list?_ga=2.233206871.831801315.1596056938-940436819.1565181751\">creating landing pages</a> for your website, there's some for those linked to Facebook ads. They have to do with your ad goals and optimizing the content for audiences.</p> \n<p>They shouldn't differ largely from landing pages on your website, in fact, they should mirror your brand. You'll just have different things to look for — So instead of traffic being the number one priority, now it might be the number of shares or comments. If you're someone who benefits from visual examples like I do, don't worry, we'll go over best practices, as well.</p> \n<p>So let's dive into how to create a landing page that'll be an amazing experience for your Facebook audience.</p> \n<p>There's no landing page creation tool for Facebook, but you can insert them into ads via Ad Manager to boost leads and conversions. Even without this function, the website has general pointers for making your pages stand out to audiences.</p> \n<p>Facebook suggests making the page easy to navigate. The content should be straightforward and relevant to its supporting ad to prevent confusion. And finally, match the page with the overall branding of your website.</p> \n<p>Those are pretty straightforward, right? Upload a page that's comprehensive and branded. But there's a little more to it than that — let's take a deeper look at creating Facebook landing pages.</p> \n<p>For this example, let's pretend I'm creating a Facebook landing page for an ebook offer. The ebook is directly related to the services my fictional PR company, Off The Press Release, provides. This offer and ad are intended to increase conversions.</p> \n<h3>1. Choose a template.</h3> \n<p>I am not a website designer, so I decided to use a landing page builder to make mine, and it turned out looking awesome. For this design, I decided to use <a href=\"https://www.wix.com/\">Wix</a>, but you can use any software with webpage tools, like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/landing-pages?_ga=2.123705410.831801315.1596056938-940436819.1565181751\">HubSpot</a> or <a href=\"https://mailchimp.com/\">Mailchimp</a>.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ins%20and%20Outs%20of%20Facebook%20Landing%20Pages-4.png\" alt=\"Wix template choices.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://www.wix.com/website/templates/html/landing-pages/promotional-page\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>When picking my template, I wanted to go with one that would best serve my offer. I decided that one with a simple form and text — that way, I wouldn't have much to edit, and the static design wouldn't distract Facebook viewers.</p> \n<p>A simple template for a conversion ad is ideal. Landing pages should be a simple design so they don't distract audiences from engaging with the right content. In this case, an ebook offer.</p> \n<h3>2. Brand the content.</h3> \n<p>With a template picked out, I changed the design to fit with my brand. First, I added new colors: Pink, and midnight blue, to match my company. Then, I changed the text to appear more conversational and relevant to my offer.</p> \n<p>I wanted my copy to connect with my Facebook audience. Additionally, I chose colors that were appealing — They weren't too bright or dim.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ins%20and%20Outs%20of%20Facebook%20Landing%20Pages-1.png\" alt=\"Wix's landing page editor. \" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Think about which logo, images, and copy will make your message come across the best to your Facebook audiences. If you've noticed your audience responds really well to cool tones, use the darker versions of your company colors for assets like landing pages.</p> \n<p>If you're stuck with coming up with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/search-ad-copy?_ga=2.123705410.831801315.1596056938-940436819.1565181751\">copy that'll speak to your customers</a>, or want <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ad-design?_ga=2.199718119.831801315.1596056938-940436819.1565181751\">branding advice from experts</a>, we've got you covered.</p> \n<h3>3. Make the CTA the star of the page.</h3> \n<p>This ad's goal was to earn as many downloads as possible. To make that happen, I used the design to make the CTA the star by placing it in a visible position on the page. Doing this makes it only easier for audiences to complete the action.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ins%20and%20Outs%20of%20Facebook%20Landing%20Pages-2.png\" alt=\"How to edit the CTA on Wix.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>The action you want Facebook users to take on your landing page should be clear. All copy should point to a clear CTA. It's helpful to make the button a different color. I chose gray, for instance, because it was a color I hadn't previously used.</p> \n<p>Or let's say you work for a retail company. If the ad intent is to boost sales, the landing page could be an offer for a percentage off in exchange for signing up for emails. Whatever you're giving the consumer should be front and center, along with the button to get there.</p> \n<h3>4. Preview and test your page.</h3> \n<p>When you're satisfied with your page, view it in preview mode. Seeing it from the viewer's perspective catches mistakes. Additionally, you can make last minute changes to best fit multiple screen types.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ins%20and%20Outs%20of%20Facebook%20Landing%20Pages.png\" alt=\"Viewing a landing page in Preview mode on Wix. \" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>If you have the time, test your page. One of Facebook's Paid Ads managers, Nicole Ondracek, cites testing landing pages as a <em>must</em>. \"Testing is very useful because we have the most concrete data about how to make our pages more effective for Facebook,\" she says.</p> \n<p>Check to see if your software has testing features. Mine did not, but <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm?_ga=2.199718119.831801315.1596056938-940436819.1565181751\">HubSpot's CRM</a> and Facebook both have testing tools that could give useful data, like conversions and click-through rates. I could run a landing page A/B test using HubSpot's software, then test the ad using the winning A/B test page.</p> \n<h3>5. Upload it into the Ad Manager.</h3> \n<p>When you're satisfied with your landing page ad, save it and switch gears over to Ad Manager. From here, the process is pretty intuitive — especially if you've created an ad before. After picking your ad type, it's pretty much just filling in numerous fields.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ins%20and%20Outs%20of%20Facebook%20Landing%20Pages-Jul-29-2020-08-49-32-71-PM.png\" alt=\"Example of uploading your landing page on Facebook\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>The fields \"Primary Text,\" \"Headline,\" and \"Description\" are going to be visible to audiences, so fill them in accordingly. For example, the primary text of my ad introduces my company, the offer, and what's inside.</p> \n<p>Headlines emphasize the offer's subject, while the description gives more detail. Every field but primary text is optional, so you don't have to make the ad as wordy as I have. Add enough text to convey what you're advertising and the tone of your company.</p> \n<p>As soon as you've got these fields settled, you've chosen your target audience, your ad is ready to run. Click \"Publish!\" to finish configuring details like budget and duration. And, if you need a full guide on setting up a Facebook ad, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/facebook-marketing/facebook-lead-ads?_ga=2.225555539.831801315.1596056938-940436819.1565181751\">this post is an amazing help</a>.</p> \n<p>So now, you know how to make a landing page for Facebook ads. Now, it's time to go over how, and why, to optimize those landing pages for audiences.</p> \n<h2>Facebook Landing Page Best Practices</h2> \n<p>Think about the intent of your audience. What kind of landing page will make them interested in your offer? These design and optimization tips are a handy bookmark to make sure the content lines up with customer preference.</p> \n<h3>1. Give the page its own URL.</h3> \n<p>If you're using a landing page that already exists, and you want to track leads from Paid ads, give the page its own URL. Direct response ads, ads that are meant to incite immediate action, are generally used for lead generation.</p> \n<p>When you give your Facebook ad landing page its own URL, you'll be able to see the leads earned specifically from that ad. Additionally, if you want to make small tweaks for Facebook performance, you can do so without modifying the original page.</p> \n<h3>2. Keep the design free of distractions.</h3> \n<p>As marketers, we know that landing pages should be simple. For Facebook ad landing pages, this is especially true. Your ad goals most likely center around audiences taking action, and a clean landing page supports that.</p> \n<p>If your landing pages outside of Facebook usually include clickable logos and text, remove them for this version. For instance, this landing page on HubSpot's site has a clickable logo and text. The Facebook version, however, doesn't. It distracts from the overall purpose of the ad.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ins%20and%20Outs%20of%20Facebook%20Landing%20Pages-Jul-29-2020-08-49-32-20-PM.png\" alt=\"Example of a HubSpot offer landing page.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>When you're designing your landing page, use the page space to make CTAs visible. Copy should succinctly reflect what's being advertised on Facebook. For instance, the Facebook landing page above leverages branding, large fonts and photos, and an actionable button.</p> \n<h3>3. Create according to your ad goals.</h3> \n<p>When you create a Facebook ad, you have to choose an ad type. These ad types reflect the ultimate goal of your campaign, like lead generation. Your landing page should be designed according to that campaign objective to maximize their effectiveness.</p> \n<p>A landing page should be made with a purpose in mind. For example, a brand awareness ad can be broad — it's just introducing audiences to a company. However, a page for conversions should specifically lead viewers to download the ebook or demo.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ins%20and%20Outs%20of%20Facebook%20Landing%20Pages-3.png\" alt=\"Example of a HubSpot form on a landing page.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.es/demo-hspd\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>This landing page, for instance, has the form at the top of the page to help grow conversions. There's little room for distraction — the only interaction available is filing out the form.</p> \n<h3>4. Add the Pixel feature for optimization.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/learn/facebook-ads-pixel\">Pixel</a> is a Facebook feature that was designed to boost ad performance. Adding Pixel to your ads is like adding an extra targeting feature.</p> \n<p>Let's say a 35-year-old woman in an urban area clicked on the landing page and completed an offer for a brand awareness ad. Facebook then tells Pixel to suggest the ad to profiles with similar demographics in order to reach more qualified leads.</p> \n<p>Essentially, Pixel targets audience members based on the demographic information of people who've previously interacted with the ad, and increases the amount of traffic your landing page earns.</p> \n<h3>5. Track the right metrics.</h3> \n<p>If you want to track landing page performance, make sure you're looking at the right metrics. Facebook will offer you an analytics report based on your ad type, and there's a few you can attribute to the landing page.</p> \n<p>Ondracek recommends looking at the amount of money spent, forms filled, and conversions. Staying in budget for your ad campaign is a no-brainer. The amount of forms completed lets you know if your form was effective for converting leads, and conversions shows you how many.</p> \n<p>When tracking performance outside of Facebook, add <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht?_ga=2.166164855.831801315.1596056938-940436819.1565181751\">UTM parameters</a>. This is basically a special tag on a URL that'll track page performance. UTM codes can be imported into analytics software, like Google and Looker.</p> \n<p>You don't have to track landing pages using different services. However, if you made your page using marketing automation software that offers analytics, they're worth keeping in mind. Additionally, UTM codes will give you analytics you can compare with Facebook and other software.</p> \n<p>Having multiple sources of data, Ondracek recommends, gives you a more holistic view of landing page performance.</p> \n<h3>6. Test landing pages frequently.</h3> \n<p>Test your landing page before it goes live, if possible. If you used software that offers testing features, use them to test the effectiveness of your page. Even though it won't be connected to Facebook, you can make small changes before uploading based on test results.</p> \n<p>\"We build landing pages using HubSpot, so we use the A/B testing feature before and while we use the page. We choose one thing to tweak at a time to keep results accurate. Over time, we'll build the most effective Facebook landing pages possible,\" says Ondracek.</p> \n<p>You don't have to use specific software to test your landing page. You can even use Facebook's A/B testing feature for ads. If you decide to go that route, make your ad goal conversions so landing page design will be a factor.</p> \n<p>When created for your audience, Facebook landing pages can be an awesome tool. They jumpstart buying journeys, earn leads, and expand reach. When you track their performance, you can learn more insights about how customers interact with your company on Facebook.</p> \n<p>Use landing pages to further inform and delight your audience. I, for one, love a good landing page, and will be looking forward to seeing yours on my Facebook timeline next.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcreate-landing-page-on-facebook&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
